description:
I have to give props to De Young for constantly refreshing their exhibits. They have several diverse exhibits that run which is appealing regardless of which art you favor most. A variety of ethnic, Time periods as well as contemporary exhibits. 
I also like the way they are incorporating events with an exhibit so that you can get more out of it if desired.

Thanks for being inclusive of all backgrounds!
author: Summer S.

description:
I was lured to de Young by the North American Reciprocal membership but I decided to pay for the ticket anyway because otherwise I would not have been able to see the Contemporary Muslim Fashion show that they have going on at the moment. Tickets were your standard price tag for SF/NY/LA/CHI.

This was my first time and I will definitely come back again. Two things really caught my attention. First were the breathtaking Gottardo Piazzoni's "The Sea" and "The Land" murals. The second were the Hollywood Suites by Steven Kahn. Apparently the murals caused a lot of controversy when they were moved from their original location - the San Francisco Public Library which is now the home of the Asian Art Museum. Unfortunately, I did not have time on this trip to check out the Asian Art Museum but it is on my list for the next trip. The murals are absolutely beautiful and I spent quite a chunk of time just lost looking at them. The second thing that stuck to me the most was the Hollywood Suites. I don't want to talk about them much because they are very intense and I think putting it in writing will take away from the mental experience of looking at it in person.

Aside from the current exhibit of Muslim contemporary fashion which basically ended up taking up almost all of my time there some of my favorite things to see were the art work dedicated to AIDS outbreak awareness, Latin American arts (pre-colonization), and works highlighting LA riots. They have a huge Mesoamerican collection which is a must see.
author: Zain R.

description:
This is a great museum. I come here often with friends. They often have new pieces, which is exciting except when the replace other art that I really like. 

With an admission sticker from de Young, you can also visit The Legion of Honor on the same day, and vice versa. On the first full weekend of the month, Bank of America customers can get free admission by showing their BofA debit or credit card. 

There's plenty to see even without a ticket, such as the observation deck, lily pond, sculpture garden and skyspace.
author: Julia C.

description: This is a fine arts museum and it was pretty interesting to look at the different kinds of art they had on display. My fiancé and I been wanting to come here for a while and we finally did since we had time to kill. I was really fascinated by some of the things they call art because honestly to me it's nothing but ART. Some of the painting they had was truly remarkable and fascinating to look at. I highly recommend to check out the native Indian section it offers many sculptures, painting, and artifacts from that period of time.
author: Neloffer E.

description:
Situated near all of the other museum at Golden Gate Park. Lots of great unique artifacts to see.  The view from the top is incredible. Bring your camera to capture the moment. This place is huge so you will need wear comfortable shoes to get around.  We are very fortunate, we found a great parking around the corner......but around the corner, it was still quite a distance.  You'll see what I mean when you get there.  Parking can be tough if you come too late.  My suggestion is to come here way before all the museums open.

This place can get very busy.  I've been here when the line was so long that it took us 30 minutes to stand in line.  Today, was fast.

Make sure to ask questions so you won't miss any exhibits while you are here.  Check out my pictures.
author: Grace L.

description: The fine arts museums in San Francisco are well worth their dual memberships. Over the past year plus, I've really enjoyed attending new exhibits at the De Young and the Legion of Honor as well as revisiting their permanent exhibits. The permanent collection at the De Young features a selection of western art ranging from Modigliani to Dali to Chihuly. Most recently, the Contemporary Muslim Fashions exhibit unveiled a well-curated selection of high fashion pieces and modern athleisure-wear designed with Islamic female modesty in mind while still advancing style and dramatic effect. There are beautiful pieces featuring truly impressive and precise couture detailing. The Art of Propaganda was also a great exhibit that features historic print and film media from the 1930s and 1940s that were designed to influence public opinion and wartime morale. I especially enjoyed discovering Disney's wartime posters and cartoons.
author: Christine T.

description: This is a great museum with a lovely cafe, beautiful grounds, and a fantastic lookout tower to bring visitors. The museum focuses on Bay Area artists in addition to fan-favorites.  Parking was easy and admission was fair. Will be back.
author: Moriah H.

description:
I'm not a modern art fan. Aside from a few arts and crafts (Greene and Greene, Frank Lloyd Wright) and glass pieces (Chihuly). I find modern art a big meh.  I also haven't set foot in the deYoung since their remodel. That said, this is a big spacious museum. Big enough that you don't feel like you are a sardine when it gets crowded. 

Art is arranged on the top two floors. You can spend the whole afternoon here.

There's also one of chairs for you to sit and rest. I'd stay away from the square chairs in the lobby area. I found those so uncomfortable to sit on.
author: Wendy H.

description: A lovely museum to visit whether visiting the area or just looking for something to do on a Saturday (like me). It has a wide array of exhibits so everyone can find something they are interested in. The textile room is easy to miss and the drawers aren't very prominent but they are open for you to look in and see the textiles. Plenty of restrooms and elevators throughout for your natural and ability related needs. Yes, wheel chair check out is available. I didn't notice a coat or locker room and all backpacks and large bags had to be carried below waist level so I suggest leaving your bag at home if possible. Staff are timely and friendly. If you are lucky there might be a performance or demonstration happening- often unannounced.
author: Hayly P.

description:
One of the pleasant surprises in visiting San Francisco was the amount of things to see and do at Golden Gate park. This included the de Young Museum. You simply need to  the top floor of the tower and the 360º view of the city. We have been visiting and we we able to see the various highlights of our trip in a incredible and beautiful view.

I was not crazy with the background music played, but it was fun to learn the facts.  There was a young lady who was the "guard" - talk to her, engage them in conversation - so many facts and insights.

Great spot for photo's of the city and selfies with family.
author: Larry S.

description:
Simply stunning architecture landscaping and backdrop for a unique collection of artwork donated by some of the most prominent collectors on both coasts.

All periods, all continents, all beautiful tributes to the beauty of human expression.

Cafe and gift shop and usual amenities lockers coats check to make your visit comfortable.

The Herzog De Meuron copper plated structure on massive wheels and the ancient tree ferns are worth the visit you will find unforgettable.
author: Daniella S.

description: From the person greeting us at the entrance, to the person "helping" at guest services, from the first five minutes to the last five minutes - every single person who works here that interacted with were all complete assholes. If a guest asks a question about what's available, it shouldn't receive a flippant, rude response. I also brought a service dog with all of the proper tags visible and was harassed by the man who "greeted" us as the door. The entire situation was more like we were entering the White House with a bomb. Absolutely horrible people, absolutely horrible experience.
author: Zachary N.

description:
We have been Members for years... I do not know if we will continue.
Last year there was not a single show I had any interest in.
When the Cult of the Machine came up I was thrilled, and signed up for Member Preview Day.
My dad was a well known Industrial Designer, and I was a Mechanical Designer.  I love the art of engineering.
This showing was not crowded on a Friday morning....
So tiny it took us 10 minutes!! A handful of interesting pieces... the tiny book I purchased contained almost all of them. 
I get curators are not Engineers, and the are showing art... but for me it was a complete waste of time.
Sad.
author: Katherine F.

description:
Bouquets to Arts 2018! It's here for just 6 days (March 13-18). If you love art and appreciate beautiful floral arrangements you will absolutely love seeing the two in concert. Throughout the museum, you'll see unique floral arrangements "paired" with paintings. Essentially, florists designed their arrangements, as inspired by the paintings.  Many of the florists have incorporated prominent colors from the paintings into their floral arrangements. I was truly in wonderment of how the flowers perfectly complimented the paintings.  Take a peek at all my photos, as they truly speak for themselves.

A friend and I enjoyed a lovely evening tonight during Members-Only Viewing hours, which was between 6-8pm. We easily could have spent 4 hours viewing the arrangements. Unfortunately, the 2 hour time limit doesn't really allow ample time for also proper viewing of the paintings.  If you're coming here to see the bouquets, plan on doing solely that, and return on another day to view the art.

Photographing the bouquets wasn't an easy task, given the crowds. It felt as if every time I was finger-ready to capture that Kodak moment, someone walked into my photo or a pointed figured appeared out of nowhere and ruined my chances of earning a Pulitzer for Photography. 

Note that there will be a "Photo-free Period" on March 16, from 9:30-noon, but personally, I'd want a photographic souvenir of this showing. Plus, I need to post these on Yelp!
author: Lori N.

description: This is a cute lil date spot plus it's free every 1st Tuesday of the month.  I didn't realize how big this place is but I easily spent 3 hours wandering about.
author: Jezhra S.

description:
It's not one of the greatest museums I've been to but it is one more museum I do appreciate. It's beyond convenient that the academy of sciences, the japanese tea garden, and park are all there alongside De Young, the only catch is finding parking if you've foolishly decided to drive though. You'll most likely be funneled into the underground paid parking lot if anything. 

The museum was smaller than I had anticipated so the little breathing room I did have was accentuated with other guests. I stopped in to check out the Bouquets to Arts which only lasted a week or so. The flower arrangements were delicately and thoughtfully sprinkled in where they could fit in the museum intermingling the other exhibits??? Related or non-related to the art pieces they were placed next to? I'm used to exhibits being in it and of itself, whole so to speak, standalone... haha. Call me one-dimensional, why don't ya? Anyways, it was all interesting to see that type of interaction in a museum which offered something different. I'd come back if there's another exhibit that catches my attention.
author: David N.

description: Really great collection of very diverse art. The price is practically free and the architecture is wonderful. The flow of the building was semi-confusing for an art museum but regardless, I had great time! I really enjoyed the propaganda exhibit. I would have enjoyed more benches to sit and enjoy the art because there are very few in such open rooms.
author: Andrew A.

description:
FIELD NOTES //

- Bless student discounts.
- Observation tower is free even without a museum ticket!
- The interior is a little dirty but with so much foot traffic I can't really blame them.
- We spontaneously took a guided tour. It was just me, my friend, and two older women. The two older women were very cute and empathetic towards any emotional stories the tour guide told. It got a little boring at times but the guide was genuine and informative.
- Interesting architecture...such as utilizing scientific properties of copper (it turns green over time).
- Very cool pieces both inside and outside. 
- Totally worth admission price!
- On a random note, the benches were unique haha.
author: Pim Y.

description:
This is a wonderful gallery, nestled in a cozy, wooded area of the city. There's an amazing view from the top floor as well. One current exhibit, Cult of the Machine is a fascinating collection of pieces from the precisionist period, including some surprising works from Georgia O'Keeffe; if you only know her from the flowers, check this out. 

While you're here, be sure to visit the gift shop as well. You'll find an assortment of gifts you're not likely to find anywhere else.
author: Dave S.

description:
Nice, this is an incredible museum. I enjoyed my visits to the golden gate park which is right next to the Japanese Tea Gardens.

Parking is a breeze with the new lot across the lawn. I love going here. You can view art without paying the full admission fee which is excellent for those who can't afford admission. The cafe is wonderful especially on warm afternoons when you can sit on the patio.

I love the different level of the building which house a variety of artworks. The Museum hosts interesting exhibits and the bring in quality works. I recommend visiting the Museum on your next visit to Golden Gate Park.
author: Veda F.

description:
This museum was a surprise.  Bunny and I were actually walking through the Golden gate park where this place is located, from one end to the other.  Cal us crazy we thought it be fun and relaxing.  What we didn't realize it HOW BIG the GOLDEN GATE PARK is.  So when we stopped to take a break we wandered pass this museum and wanted to check it out.  We didn't actually think we'd be in there long because neither of us is that into modern or contemporary art.

When you walk in you hit with this massive entryway.  We buy tickets and start to walk though.  There are restrooms all over and there is also a café in the back of museum with seating inside and out.

The first art we saw was this huge piece of something on the wall. It was made of old wood, and metal and parts looked like birds.  I'm not sure what it was but it looked like something my little nieces could do.  Sorry I don't get that style of art or why someone thinks it is art.  It was both cool and weird at the same time.

We wandered upstairs and into the South Pacific.  This was a HUGE exhibit and seem to take up half the floor.  Tribes and the headdresses they wear, bags the make and carry, rituals and etc.  Basically a taste of how they live.  I found that very interesting.  There was also a film showing with another group I believe Thailand and how they do funerals, the music and what they wear.  Very cool to see.

Next e wandered through the halls of more our style of art. Mostly European.  They had furniture which I LOVED as well and sculptures.  Some Deigo Rivera but sadly no Frida.  I LOVE HER! 

On to a room with huge pieces of fruit and some sort of large statue that looked like a man.  We were definitely back to the more modern art.  At least I think it was modern.  By this time we had been there a few hours.  Next was the New Zealand room were they had different people painted from photos on the wall.  The nice thing is that they also had a large table book which you could read as you walked through.  In the back was a film on the people that were painted.  Some of the people interviewed were distant family members or historians.  They gave you a inside look of what the people were like and their life.  I found that VERY INTERESTING.

There is a GI-NOR-MOUS book store or gift shop as well.  two floors jam packed with books, a large kid section, all types of housewares, scarves, etc.  You'll find something for yourself or someone else.

Over all a RELLY NICE and HUGE museum.  I don't care for all the art in there and the place was a bit confusing so it made it hard to actually know where we went at times.  You can kill a lot of time in there.  At least we did.
author: Ryan P.

description:
Beautiful space, beautiful arts, sculptures, and exhibitions, too bad we didn't get much time to tour it all.

Company event here, the catering food was bad. Who thought of outdoor sushi bar, bad idea, in an outdoor environment, when it's cold and the rice is cold, and everything was cold!

They got heated lamps outside but 2 was broken. They wouldn't let us go inside till 8 pm for sitting down dinner! My ass was cold and so every other lady tried to look pretty in cocktail dresses!

Restrooms were clean, catering service folks was nice, professional, but the foods got to go!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
One of the best museum I've ever been on the West Coast. It is well worth the price to explore all the magnificent paintings, artwork and history behind each piece. The panoramic view from the tower was well worth it, however it was cloudy when we went.

I would definitely go back if I am back in San Francisco
author: Eric E.

description:
There's so much to do and see in Golden Gate Park, maybe it's worth passing on?

Disclaimer: I'm not a huge fan of art galleries, but if you're been to other galleries in the world, de Young doesn't quite stand out. It's clean and spacious, but not as many exhibits. 

General admission for adults is $15, more if you want to see the special exhibits and get the audio tours. It can be quite pricey for the dual special exhibitions (Teotihuacan, Legion of Honor) for $35. Maybe worth seeing for the first time, but unless you're a huge fan of art galleries, I think I'll pass the next time.
author: Vincent H.

description:
I have to admit that this review is slightly tainted by the fact that I am from Los Angeles and have spent lots of time at the Getty Museums and LACMA for basically free.  For a free museum, this place is really great.   If I had paid full price, I would have been slightly less impressed.  We went on a Bank of America "free weekend." Everything free to BofA cardholders, except the special exhibit, so we opted not to do the special exhibit.  It was still a ton to see, but nothing that really was so incredible that it stuck in my head, and I can think of at least one truly remarkable thing that sticks out in my head from almost every other museum I have visited.  

The coolest thing about this museum is the observation tower, and from what I have heard, you don't actually have to pay for a ticket for that. You just turn right instead of left at the ticket counter and go up the elevator.  The observation tower is pretty much the best view in all of San Francisco.

We ate in the cafe as well, and it was very much over-priced, so we just got pre-packaged salads. They were pretty good, but small for what we paid for them.
author: Niki M.

description: Large museum with several exhibits going on at the moment including works from the African American Diaspora and a Maori exhibit. Literally spent hours reading and learning about various artists through their artwork. Entry was $15 for the standard exhibits and it cost extra to include access to the featured exhibit (Cult of the Machine) but I'm glad we didn't pay for that due to being short on time. Beautiful artwork, plenty of benches scattered throughout, restrooms on both floors and of course elevator access to both floors.
author: Mike C.

description:
After wandering around the exhibitions and the museum store, if you are hungry or want a coffee or tea, stop by here.  They have fresh salads, soups, entrees, and desserts.  They change the menu frequently, with fresh ingredients. They also have a wide selection of beer and wine in bottles.  Take a book and read by the windows, surrounded by Golden Gate Park vistas.  Enjoy!

Today, I had a Dungeness crab taco and a pecan tart, followed by a hot cup of coffee.
author: Jeff P.

description:
"The Summer of Love!" @ The de Young!

SITREP

The de Young is one of the nation's premiere art galleries set amid Golden Gate Park in San Francisco, always fresh & alive with terrific exhibits circulating through it's hallowed corridors.  On this occasion I got to experience the fantastic "Summer of Love!"
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/de-young-san-francisco?select=zumny8hITxzTolTcqYTLvw&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

THE SETUP

When enjoying your day at the de Young, some things to consider!

* PARKING

If you want to start your day off right in going to the de Young, it would be best to catch your ride there either cabbing or LYFTing:  driving/parking there is a nightmare and I would strongly suggest you not put yourself in a bad mood with having to deal with these logistics - you want to "ENJOY" the day afterall, not be in a funk.

* THE GROUNDS

Save time to wander around the grounds of this beautiful park!  Right across the fountain plaza from the museum is the Academy of Sciences, itself it's own all day destination.  And speaking of the fountain plaza, take a gander at all the art displays that local talent have up and available for viewing AND purchasing!  Support the local art community.

* THE CAFE

It's not cheap, but there is a very serviceable on-site café to get some tasty food and drinks at.  Two lines on either side with duplication of items on each side.  Large inside dining room, but also a large outside dining area amongst some beautiful art pieces.

* THE "OBSERVATORY"

An elevator journey nine (9) floors up takes you to a beautiful glassed observatory overlooking the entire museum, the park, even with better vista views of the City of San Francisco.  
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/de-young-san-francisco?select=jjB6rbYumAnLfeg1kaa_xg&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

Save time to do this, and get  some pictures!
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/de-young-san-francisco?select=zwVW12_ISc6oa-j1spT-Jw&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

GALLERIES!

The de Young has some of the most amazing physical plant set-ups in terms of art rooms, art corridors, available disabled access to elevators to get between floors, etc.

* SUMMER OF LOVE

WOW!  What a hippy psychedelic trip going down a flower power pathway of remembrances!  
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/de-young-san-francisco?select=3uxMSGe543DttlWg7qup9Q&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

From stylish vintage clothing and anthem wear of the music stars, to the colorful art tapestries and artistic playbills of music concerts, and spoken poetry showcases.
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/de-young-san-francisco?select=daix1vh1NCtADxvRvGAPfA&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

* RESIDENT ART EXHIBITIONS

The Dutch Masters, the Rococo movement, Victorian master pieces galore:  exquisite in all mediums - oils, sculpture, water color - breath-taking in their own way, with some quite ....SCINTILLATING.... 
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/de-young-san-francisco?select=y8L4XLOpkIhMKzYcLM0l0w&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

Hey!  George Washington!
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/de-young-san-francisco?select=mBBvXGIYeh1i7DcyAY_2Tg&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

REALITIES

I acknowledge the realities that this is an expensive endeavor when you deal with the admissions just to get into the gallery, and then even EXTRA admissions to get into certain exhibits on that top of that.  But I am willing to pay extra to enjoy a truly marvelous art experience.

Just watch out for the Dinosaurs wandering around outside...
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/de-young-san-francisco?select=dUB97f2BPC_PP44bIwCmRg&userid=3mNz5nQFTIBQm0oU5mBR0w

THE LOWDOWN

The de Young is a fantastic journey through the world of the visual arts.
author: Michelangelo S.

description:
The Hamon Observation Tower is a post modern glass-walled space with spectacular 360 degree panoramic views of downtown San Francisco, Golden Gate Park, the Bay, and the Marin headlands.

Couldn't see the Marin headlands & other points north because fog from the Pacific Ocean rolled in & obscured the view. But all other points were clear to show the rest of San Francisco at our feet. 

There is floor to ceiling clear glass so as to not obstruct the wide panorama. There is a large satelite photo map of San Francisco to inform visitors as to what they are observing.   

And all this is FREE. So generous of the city of San Francisco. All this is set within huge, sprawling Golden Gate Park & next to the famous Hagiwara Japanese Gardens. 
How cool is that? 

PS  The MUNI bus system is a great way to get here so leave the car behind to avoid the hassle of finding the rare San Francisco parking space. Now an endangered species.
author: Gary I.

description:
Beautiful way to spend a lovely Thursday afternoon! 
The staff was so helpful I didn't know about the view above  
The art was breathtaking from Mayan to African artifacts. 
Student discount: a plus plus plus (:
author: Valeria D.

description:
This place is great! The park it resides in is humongous and beautiful. The trees are exotic and tall. It's green and designed innovatively. The walk into the museum is especially scenic with magestic but odd looking naked trees. 

The day we went was a fundraiser, so we couldn't use our work pass, but the museum is extremely big. It would take hours, if not days to go through even at a mediocre pace.

We went specifically for the Maoris, New Zealand native portraits. They were so fascinating and we'll painted. My friends and I had a wonderful time looking at the other parts of the museum too!
author: Esther J.

description:
If there's one more reason why the Bay Area is as amazing as it is (like we all need another reason why the Bay is the BAE), it's that museums are EVERYWHERE - far as the eye can possibly see. For example, in the South Bay/Silicon Valley area, you have places like the Tech museum and the Pace Gallery. Heck, even Intel has its own little space for the public. In the East Bay, you have places such as the Oakland Museum of California. 

And in San Francisco, you have more museums than you can count on your fingers. The de Young Art Museum is definitely one that I recommend you check out. 

Recently, my girlfriend and I had this ambitious plan (well I technically dragged her along, but you know) of visiting 3 different museums around the Bay in one day. The first on our list was the de Young. The really cool thing (that makes the Bay Area EVEN BETTER) about this museum and several others around is that it's free during certain weekends (if not most) of the year for people who have Bank of America cards. Note: even if you don't it's only $15 admission and I think they really don't look at your ID to see if it matches your card. Just use a friend's or something. 

The de Young museum is located in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park, the giant playground that is the equivalent of New York's Central Park. I really recommend coming to the de Young a bit earlier in the day to avoid lines, find a parking spot + have more time during the rest of your day to enjoy the city. Unfortunately, parking can be a nuisance in Golden Gate Park, and so you may have to use the garage/park on the street.

If I have to describe the de Young in a few words, I'd say that it is "truly a magical place for various types of art." Here, you will see different exhibits ranging from African American history, glass art, as colonial art. There's at least a few floors with hundreds or different things to look at. If I have to give you an estimate of how long you can spend here, I'd say you can spend upwards to 2-3 hours here. Personally, my favorite part of the de Young was actually the tower. It's 9 stories up and you get a GORGEOUS 360 view of the SF/Bay Area. You can also peep on the long lines at the Academy of Sciences next door. 

For those of you who may not know, the de Young is actually the sibling museum to the Legion of Honor. They both operate under the same system (I think). For example, they both offer free admission to BoA customers and their admission tickets have both names on it. I've been to the Legion of Honor before (also when it was free haha), and I have to say that de Young is definitely a better experience. Though the former has different exhibits (i.e. more sculptures and architecture), I feel like you can spend so much more time on the latter for the price.

Overall, I have to say that de Young is absolutely a must-try experience in San Francisco. If it is considered a tourist trap, then let it be known that it's an amazing one. I have to give it an "omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this." You can get SO lost in this museum, and it's totally worth it - be it free or be it that you spend $15. If I come back, you bet I'm paying that extra $$ for the special exhibits!

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
The de Young Museum is one of the nation's premiere art galleries  in San Francisco located in the Golden Gate Park. I think is a must see when in San Francisco.


Few recommendations:


-Time 

Go with plenty time to spare, there is a fabulous garden almost like a mini plaza with fountain and everything. You also have the Park all around you and the Japanese garden right next to it and the Academy of sciences museum right across. I went in the morning and spent 4.5 hours. 


-What to do first?

Go up the Hamon tower to experience 360 views of the grounds and some parts of the city. 
Amazing and totally worth it.

-Collections

My favorites were the Oceanic art and the art of the Americas but they have lots more (more info here http://deyoung.famsf.org/collections)

-Food

 There is a café in the museum although not cheap, it offers great tasty food.  I had the tomato soup and it was fresh and flavorful. They have a variety of bake goods and salads that will satisfy anyone from Gluten free, vegan to carnivore.
 They have an indoor dining room and outdoor patio with greenery and some beautiful sculptures.

There are some food tents outside that offer different types of cuisines. (at least that day i visited) 

I know it can be pricey but in my opinion is worth it. Also, you can find deals when you purchase the citypass.
author: Deborah T.

description:
de Young is a small museum that focuses on quality over quantity. It was well curated even in the rest rooms by the sinks there was nice flower arrangements. 

I was greeted by a gigantic 1989 sculpture by Keith Haring of three dancers on arrival. I have long been a fan of Keith Haring so set a great tone. There were some exceptional pieces including a rare Dali & Diego Rivera along w/ murals. 

The crest jewel of the museum was the 9th Floor Observation tower that is free to enter for those who choose not to go to the museum. The 9th Floor Observation tower offers panoramic views of San Francisco where you can watch the magical fog roll in off the Pacific Ocean. You can see all the big trees, the cyclists, Golden Gate Park, Victorian homes, runners, gardens, & be above it all for awhile. Worth a visit!
author: Shane S.

description:
Summer of Love 2017: 
Hippie Culture in San Francisco

Came on a Friday evening when they open up the museum until later than normal business hours. Filled with music and libations it was a very happy place and buzzing with people. Gets crowded so I suggest coming early if you want to get a head start on the exhibits.

Came with friends for the summer of love, great exhibit that you can tell many came to relive since it was not that long ago. For us young'uns, it was more of a dip into SF cultural history and appreciation for the band posters they made back in the day. You think at first... why did I pay to see all these band posters? I thought it was supposed to be an art museum?? But then you gain appreciation for the detailed handiwork and the amount of LSD that went into producing these incredible happy 8.5"X11" billboards essentially to promote bands and agendas.

Super cool and while it was pricey ($25) it was worth it the one time to go and see. Keeping in mind the normal standing exhibits were $FREE to go check out, that might be a better way to go about it next time.

Also, drinks are delish (had myself a Bloody Mary) but the prices are not ($13 for a tiny plastic cup).

Go check out the high tower before it closes early for the night, gorgeous views and located just right of the museum ticket desk. Open for free to the public and you can see a lot of SF!
author: David T.

description: The observation tower was the main highlight of the museum, with expansive views of Golden Gate Park and the city. We barely made it, because it closes at 4:30, while the museum closes at 5:15. As for the art itself, the best find for me was Georgia O'Keeffe's vibrant purple painting- "Petunias." I also spotted "Sacramento Railroad Station" (William Hahn), which is today's Old Sac.
author: Helen H.

description: If you need to choose between the Legion of Honor and the DeYoung, choose the Legion. I came to see the Cult of the Machine exhibit which is well-themed and timed given our current fascination with robotics and artificial intelligence. However,the rest of the museum is a hodgepodge of African and Mayan sculpture with an obsession with male genetalia (eye roll...typical). There is a small Impressionism exhibit with an emphasis on John Singer Sargeant. There are also a few Tiffany lamps and sculptures. The blown modern glass is beautiful. But whoever organizes all of the permanent exhibits is partaking in the medicinal marijuana movement. It feels like my great grandmas basement of random pieces kept simply for antiquity's sake.
author: JoAnn Y.

description:
I don't know if this is a new museum rule but it you have a backpack you have to hold it below the waist.  Ok...?  What they didn't tell was that I can coat check my heavy bag on the bottom floor. Thanks for telling me security! (insert sarcasm).

Buying a ticket here also gives you entry to the Legion of Honor which is kinda far from here but more bang for your buck.

The museum didn't look that big but was I wrong!  

Pro tip: Take the elevator to the top floor to get a beautiful 360 window view of the Golden Gate Park.  It's absolutely beautiful and you can take great pictures here.
author: Jackie N.

description: Prices are very reasonable.  Good portions and delicious food.  I had the Linguini seafood and it was spectacular.  Great service to boot
author: Howard A.

description:
de Young Museum is probably the best value for attending a Museum.  General admission is only 15 dollars for general admission.  Better yet free for Bank of America card holders during the first week of each month.  Just going up to the 9th floor observation deck and getting a great views of San Francisco is worth the admission. (I believe)

Parking can be really tough to find.  The parking lot was at full and we had to circle around Golden Gate park in order to find a space.  We ended up walking about a mile to get there.  Luckily Golden Gate park is a nice place to take a walk on our way to the musuem. 

The building design is great and is the perfect setting to showcase art.  I plan on coming back as I didn't have time to check out all the exhibits.   I would say de Young museum is up there as other notable museums in different cities.
author: Garett S.

description:
I love this museum I've gone a few times & they always have very interesting exhibits. 

They do student discounts as well & one time I went they had a special offer for bank of america card holders which made the tickets even cheaper. 

I really like the current exhibit they have now about the pyramids in mexico. it's definitely one to check out before it goes away!
author: Katrina F.

description: De Young was free on Friday. Well, I didn't get to go to the exhibition for free because that started at 5:30. They have free days here and there, and that's good because who likes paying for expensive museum entry. So thanks for the free day. I'd already seen the permanent collection many times, but I really enjoyed the Maori portraits by painter Gottfried Lindauer. They were incredible! The dark green blue background of the walls made the experience rich. Maori is an indigenous tribe of New Zealand that got pushed aside by European settlers in NZ. The portraits were of Maori leaders. There were so many fine details like the facial tattoos of the Maori. These portraits can be found in collections mostly in NZ. Really rare exhibit to see, and I'm so happy I caught it.
author: Denise C.

description:
Nice museum at Golden Gate Park, next to Japanese Tea Gardens. We didn't go to the special exhibit but the art that was displayed was interesting. Disclaimer: I'm not an art enthusiast, but I do love to see beautiful pieces created by artists. Some are questionable but that my opinion. I like looking at the sculptures and the materials used to create the art.

The awesome part of the museum is the 360 observation tower it does close before the museum so if your there late afternoon I would say to go there first. We went on a beautiful day and wow the views! You can see the park, and the city.
author: Julie Ann I.

description:
This great private institution was built three times. First building was destroyed by fired and the second was damaged beyong repair by the Loma Prieta earthquake in 1989.

With private money the trustees hired the architect who they think could do the best job and built a museum with no compromises. The LA County Museum is no comparison to this museum which is in the third city of California. Goes to show private money was so much less restrained in judgement and more savvier than public money.

Great museum in a beautiful setting; gorgeous and uplifting spaces to perambulate and appreciate art.
author: Keo N.

description:
Yes an architectural gem...and a lovely cafe, when it's open. But  membership operations foolishly dismisses the importance of their "bread & butter" members. It appears that if you are a member in the lower tiers (that actually make the organization viable due to the volume we contribute)---you are only selectively noticed for the more private events. Now this is not uncommon, all non-profits reward their big donors, but none to my knowledge, choose to conceal the most intimate and meaningful events from the basic membership tiers. They are always sold out, right away, because these events are not publicized to the lower member tiers. Of course, deYoung their membership department's great excuse is "they are public events" but alas they aren't publicized to the "public" until they have "sold out". Very crafty of this group, but not surprising given Ms. Wilsey's exalted leadership.. 
There are alot of other problems including with their IT, often not up to date and one can't sign out...hmmm that's a privacy issue.
author: Peppermint P.

description: excellent and eclectic collection spanning multiple periods and styles. well laid out and roomy. the downstairs exhibition space is really large and hosts some really fine works. love this place
author: Bob U.

description:
Stepping beyond the obvious that this is an art museum, this is a great stop on your staycation or tour through San Francisco.
This review with focus on a visit with kids.

The museum has a great variety of art, beautiful outdoor space and an observation tower.

I recently visited with three kids 8, 10, 12-- each liked the observation tower with varying degrees--one deeply concerned about the glass giving way, while another just marveled at all they could see.

We walked rather quickly through the rooms with pauses to look at detailed weapons, glass work and statues.

Go without an agenda and see what draws their interest.
Start on the first floor--do the tower and then take a break after 1 hour and get some food and eat outside so they can roam a bit and use outside voices.

Bathroom break and then the second floor.

We didn't make it to every room but we did about 80%.

Now go get some ice cream!
author: Joanna M.

description:
My friends and I loved the Teotihuacan Exhibit. Beware the expensive cost of parking.

For the 3 hours and 16 minutes we were parked under the Music Concourse we paid $24. I suppose a ride in and out would exceed that so may be it is not really out of line, you judge.

As for the exhibit, we loved it. Spread out in several galleries we examined ceramics, stone, volcanic rock(s) and shell artifacts that really grabbed our attention. It was well lighted and for a fee an audio tour is available. Also, if you need a wheel chair one will be provided at no charge. I don't know if flash photography is permitted or not yet I can attest to the fact I took many non-flash cell phone photos with out any one interrupting me.

I hope your experience is as good as ours was.
author: Caesar A.

description:
ABSOLUTELY DREADFUL! I issue a strong caution to Veterans, immigrants from war torn countries, young children who don't handle surround sounds of war and people in distress well. I recently took my 19 month old granddaughter to the Observation Tower.  While the view was fabulous, the room began vibrating and explosive sounds erupted in surround sound! My equilibrium was thrown off and I had to immediately sit down on one of their pyramid benches. I  quickly explained to my granddaughter that the sounds were pretend.  She then relaxed and took in the great views of this great city.  However, for me, I remained tormented by the experience which launched me into a panic attack that evening.  
We were sitting on the floor and she was bursting with joy at each new sight!  Then e were tvery politely told that we could not sit on the floor and we couldn't park stroller and let her explore.  I urge this place to consider their audience and to keep war explosions in the theater below!
author: Kathy D.

description: one of the more fascinating museums ive been to. must see are the observation tower, the weapons of mass seduction, and art of africa. all of them made me feel uneasy tbh but only because everything was so new and eye opening. educational.
author: Soojeong H.

description: I visited last time for my assignment . It was so amazing. The view from tower is so great . I really enjoyed it . I will be visiting this museum more often.
author: Anisha K.

description:
A MUST DO! THE SUMMER OF LOVE EXHIBITION @ The De Young. It was mobbed. This is part  of The  50th Anniversary being celebrated all over California this year. People piled in from all over the world to see the exhibition. There was over a 2 1/2 hour wait just to get in for the final weekend of the exhibition. As you walked into the museum the outside glass walls were lined with giant buttons of sayings back in the day. So we had time to kill & had lunch @ their cafe which was also mobbed. I had to have the Summer of Love Melon & Cucumber Salad which was very good. Healthy & Tasty. The museum highlighted the first gathering called The Human Be-In which was held @ Golden Gate Park in San Francisco in January 1967. The gathering of The Tribes with poetry & music. This event led to the rise of Haight Ashbury, The Hippie Movement, The legendary Monterey Pop Festival & then to Woodstock. People seem to take these outdoor concerts for granted. This is where & how Pop Culture all began. They had Jerry Garcia's Hippie Diploma along with his Americana hat. Janis Joplin's pocket book was also on display. They had a room from top to bottom of an endless array of concert posters of back in the day. You were enveloped in it. They also had another room which simulated You being on a Psychedelic trip. There was also a room where lights Color & music collided - the very beginnings of Pre MTV, music videos & dance clubs. There were giant shag pillows you sat down & got totally immersed in the happening vibe. Wavy Gravy's  Rainbow Jumpsuit was also featured. Then Levi's had a fashion display of all the clothes  of the 60s & 70s on mannequins in many of the rooms. Some of the clothes were cool, others were hysterical & still others you could wear today. They also had a pair of Home Made pair of  Watergate Jeans from The Nixon Era.  A fantastic day & I hope they bring this exhibition back. More people will definitely come back to revisit or missed it the first time. It was Cool!  
It used to be, you had to have mega bucks & be really rich to have the Good Life, not anymore. The Game has changed. You've been Upgraded. Now You Can 
Live Like a King on a Limited Budget!
author: Stephen Z.

description:
Disappointing. 
Advertised as free first a Tuesdays, but did not advertise that it's $25 for Summer of Love exhibit. :( doorman was mean and yelling at everyone who had a backpack: same information could have been conveyed nicely. 

The whole experience 'gave me the sads.'
author: Sarah F.

description:
Kudos to the de Young people for designing such a great space and consistently coming up with diverse and interesting exhibits that appeal to a wide swath of people. 

Despite knowing the obstacles in front of me - navigating traffic to get out to Golden Gate park and circling for parking, I still end up at the de Young at least 3-4 times a year - which justifies the cost of a tax deductible membership. At least twice a year, there's an exhibit that draws me and oodles of other people from San Francisco. Another 1-2 times a year, I'll bring people to see the great views from the observation deck or check out the evening events or even just for the museum itself.  

The downside of all this greatness is the excess popularity of the museum. The last couple exhibits were extremely crowded, even on a Friday, and I'm not a fan of crowds. I wish they'd run the popular exhibits longer to spread out some of the demand and reduce the crowding.
author: Judy C.

description:
de Young Museum - Golden Gate Park - 5 Stars: : loved Golden Gate Park and this is one of the little jewels nestled in the vast park. The de Young Museum is a beautiful art museum with loads of room for its collection on exhibit. In some museums, you feel that the items are all out on exhibition and very close to one another...here they are perfectly satisfied to have but one large painting on an entire wall. Gives great perspective. 

We saw the Summer of Love (1967) rotating exhibition at the de Young when we visited. Neat exhibit and filled with the posters and LP covers from that era...and of course long hair and free love. This was also well worth the trip as you could peruse the artifacts, and then see the main museum permanent displays. Cheers for the de Young Museum.
author: Rick B.

description: We live on the peninsula and our daughters in the city. We bought a family membership so we could enjoy the museum and family days. Love the special exhibits and events they rotate through to keep us going back over and over.
author: Susan K.

description:
Visited on 7/21/17 for the second time. We wanted to see "The Summer of Love" exhibit and it was worth the trip. As with Golden Gate Park use mass transit or a Lyft in order to avoid the parking dilemma.  The museum is beautiful, located across from the Academy of Sciences (we really need to get there next trip). 

When there make sure you go to the top of the observation tower. Great 360 degree of the city and surrounding area. The museum itself is a top shelf establishment with terrific exhibits. The Summer of Love exhibit was a trip down memory lane (I was a junior in college at the time - but never inhaled). The clothing and concert posters were amazing as well as the history of the movement that descended upon the city almost overnight. 

Other exhibits were equally impressive and I look forward to visiting again in the future.
author: Dave W.

description:
Having just come back from Chicago, we got very spoiled by the museums in that city, particularly the Art Institute. 

This museum's architecture is best described as "modern minimalist" and reminded me of the Dongdaemon Design Center in Seoul, South Korea.
The architects must of been to the same school.  It looks like a spaceship landed in the middle of GG park.
 
Although the regular museum exhibits are extensive and worthwhile (particularly on BAC Credit Card Free Weekends) but the "Teotihuacan" exhibit was overpriced and underwhelming.

We could have skipped that attraction and would have saved $28 each, because they are ripping off the credit card holders!

My advice is save your money and don't pay extra for the basement attraction!
author: Matt C.

description:
First (as an architecture student): if you're in Golden Gate Park, come by just to take a look at the exterior of the building. Designed by Swiss architects Herzog and de Meuron, the copper skin is actually a really revolutionary idea and gives you some sense for the architecture inside. If you decide to pay a trip to the museum, the interior is really architecturally beautiful and laid out very well for the various exhibits. 

The de Young is a great place to see modern art, but especially their extensive Art of the Americas collection - super well curated and not typical in most art museums. Also, make sure to visit the observation tower before it closes at 4:30PM - it gives one of my favorite 360 views of the city. 

Make sure not to miss the sculpture garden! I'm ashamed to admit that in the three times that I've visited before, I hadn't seen the James Turrell exhibit in the back.

As with every museum, check to see what exhibitions are currently showing. I originally came to see the Frank Stella exhibit (which was great!), but was actually more wow'd by the Danny Lyon photography exhibit (Message to the Future). If you come, I think it's a really crucial exhibit in today's age - take the time to read, listen, and watch all of the stories. 

Overall, a great visit (as always), and it's always nice to be in the Golden Gate Park.
author: Cat D.

description: This is a place you want to visit on a random week day and arrive right when the museum opens. This place is best when it's empty and you can really walk around and take in all of the different exhibits, especially the observation level on the top floor. There's a really nice outdoor area and cafe where you can sit and eat while enjoying the sculpture garden. The current exhibits (DIS, Maori portraits, African American South) are really powerful. Heads up: if you bring a backpack you have to carry it and make sure it's held below your waist.
author: Sarah N.

description:
Shhhh ... Be quiet staff! 
The voice echoed. 

It was on Wednesday morning, more staff talking, yelling in groups than quiet observing patrons in galleries.  

This day, the special exhibition was Maori Portraitd: Gottfried Lindauer's New Zealand.
The facial tattoo art paintings were copied from original photographs, therefore lost its originality and charm. The documentary screening was informative. 

I enjoyed strolling around the garden, the panoramic view from the tower, a cup of decaf coffee and an apple Danish at the dine...

A good day.
author: Marial L.

description: Hmm slightly disappointed by the selection as it was mainly paintings and no so much sculptures and fun unique art pieces. I enjoyed the free admission days on the first Tuesday of the month, not sure if I would pay full price to see it.
author: Lesley Y.

description: de Young is such a beautiful museum, architecturally as well as the interior. I wish I had more time to explore the museum. Their permanent collection was amazing and some I haven't seen before. Loved their A.D. pieces and early American photography. Being near Golden Gate Park doesn't hurt either. Makes for a relaxing afternoon!
author: Patricia T.

description: Not impressed, kind of typical & boring really. The counter staff are awesome, but the ones in the lobby & throughout are incredibly rude & harsh - no tact or class at all.
author: Kara H.

description: This review is for the summer of love exhibit. I think I was expecting more. About 80% of it was poster art. I have also seen more compelling and authentic vintage clothes in the shops at haight ashbury. Not sure I would pay $20 again for this (saved $5 with a promo code) Maybe the $8 audio tour makes it better? The rest of the museum was nice too. They are on their game with security. TLDR: if you like poster art and big brother and the holding company go.
author: Emily M.

description: The permanent collection isn't always my favorite, however, the rotating exhibits are absolutely amazing. From JMW Turner, to Georgia O'Keefe, not to mention the annual Bouquets to Art weekend, this is definitely worth a visit!
author: Chloe J.

description:
I really love the diverse collection they have at de Young from Mesoamerican, Eskimo/Inuit and African artifacts to the "On the Grid" textile collection. There's so much that you can't find at other museums. With that being said there are some areas in which the museum is lacking, such as sculptures (which are scattered throughout the 2nd floor to draw attention away from this). They also use so much space for administrative offices...

The view from the watchtower is also pretty cool, and what some people don't know is that it's FREE! Watch tower closed at 4:30pm daily.

One thing that caught me off-guard (and this has nothing to do with the actual museum) is how expensive the parking is. There is very little signage coming in to the garage and NO it is not free on Sundays. The rates go up each hour, but I paid about $24 or about 3 hours, when I could have just parked outside and walked 5 minutes extra -__-
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
de Young is a must visit if you're doing an SF trip. Because you can do the whole Golden Gate park thing, maybe do the California Science Academy too, and throw in the Japanese Tea Garden. But at a minimum, you should do the de Young museum.

Just walking in makes you appreciate the design and architecture of the museum. But I came here for the art, and there's plenty of them. 

Sure they have my favorites from the impressionists period, but my favorite for this museum were the photographs exhibit from the early 1900s in San Francisco. They had pictures showing the after effects from the 1906 earthquake.

Other honorable mentionables are the random contemporary art and a few Picassos from the modern period too.
author: Mike C.

description:
I was very impressed by the various textiles and art this place has. 
It's a great place for families, kids, taking a date.  I love the way this place is built. I love the texture. The location is perfect and it has an excellent ambiance. Everything here is very informative and very helpful.
author: Luke S.

description: Came here 2 time in a year  saw the 60's and now Teotihuacán exhibit . Great  exhibitions and in an easy to follow with the audio guide a must to get
author: Lydia H.

description:
My aunt has been a member forever. The Oscar de la Renta exhibit was so spectacular, I joined. Easy to park in the  park...a block away...or on Fulton Street. The assortment of art is staggering. You could spend a day gazing at O'Keefe, Thiebaud, and glass by Chihuly.
The Oscar show was so good, I went three times. Love the cafe and sitting outside.
 The Bouquet de Arts is. do not miss event!  Breathtaking and you have never seen so many iPhones clicking pix!
author: Laurel G.

description:
Here's what you need to know about the de Young Museum:
- Admission is free to the Observation Tower, which closes at 4:30.
- Admission is free to the galleries after 4:30, while the museum itself closes at like 5:10.
- You can check out the sculptures they have around the museum for free, like the giant pin.
- If you are from the Bay Area and have a library card, you can get free admission by checking out a Discover and Go pass from your library online.

We originally came here to check out the observation tower... but since it was closed we opted to do the free admission and check out the galleries quickly. Security is a little weird here - when you enter they inspect your bags and ask that you carry your backpacks next to you, rather than on your back. No outside food or drink allowed, though they didn't make us throw away our unopened box of cookies, instead asking us to put it in our backpack.

They have a very diverse collection of art, from modernism to impressionism, glass art from Chihuly, landscape paintings, classical portraits, African masks, and some abstract. It's a different theme for sections of the museum. Whoever creates the gallery spaces does a good job of putting the right pieces together, as it made our stroll through the galleries more enjoyable. It's very open so you'll never feel too crowded and you can appreciate the art the way it is. Even if you're not into art, I think there's something for everyone at the museum, and part of fun is finding something interesting. 

It's a little amusing how much security there is here - they just stand in the corners watching people. Can't imagine mysterious art thieves swooping down to steal a glass statue. And for those of you who like taking selfies with art backgrounds, they allow no-flash photography at this museum.

If you really want to be thrifty, you could come here before 4:30 to check out the observation tower... the come downstairs around 4:30 to enjoy the gallery. 40 minutes is enough time to look at the art they have, but seriously this place is huge so I recommend coming back to really appreciate the art. I'll have to come back some day.
author: Alyanna C.

description: A bit pricy but when I went years ago, the exhibits were still too good to pass up! The spine and tooth of Santo Guerro was my favorite!
author: TheOnionedElk _.

description:
Came here today for the Summer of Love Exhibition. Great set, highly recommend it! There was so MUCH history of the 60s in San Francisco. Very colorful, full of fashion and full of great vibes. 
A must see exhibit! 

*P.S Students with a valid ID get in for $16!!
author: Ivonne L.

description:
The DeYoung Museum offers some great special and featured exhibits ranging from classic to modern.  My last visit before this time was the Dutch Paintings from the Mauritshuis, including the renowned Girl with a Pearl Earring by Johannes Vermeer while their museum was under renovations.  What a coup for us to be able to see the Dutch Mona Lisa right in our backyard.  

All featured exhibits including the current Oscar De La Renta is for an additional fee if you are not a member.  However, this time we were there to see a special exhibit that was included in the general admission price, the Royal Hawaiian Featherwork: Nā Hulu Ali'i, most of which is from the Bishop Museum in O`ahu.  Although I have seen most of the pieces on a previous visit to the Bishop, there were pieces there from private collectors and universities around the country and world like New Zealand.  Anyone who is from the islands or Hawaiian at Heart would appreciate seeing this before it closes on 4/10.  After their tour is over, they will all return back to Hawai`i, their original home.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
Such a lovely place. One of the better museums in the Bay Area and one of the cheapest too. $10 for an adult, $6 for an adult, and free on the first weekend of the month if you show them your Bank of America Card! What a steal! 

There are plenty of painting and art pieces. There is a lot of early America's type of vibe going on here, but there is still plenty with the international front as well. This place has much to look at, and time will fly bye while you're here. 

It might be a bit boring for the kids or someone who doesn't appreciate art, but otherwise you'll love this place. Also, make sure to check out the tower to get some lovely views! It's great.
author: Benny H.

description:
The architecture of the museum is stunning and I really enjoyed the some of the exhibits. Luckily I took advantage of the free day or I would have been a bit disappointed. I took my two children, both under the age of 10, and they were underwhelmed and whining the entire time. Maybe good if you have sophisticated children, but my kids kind of killed the experience for me. My favorite part of the museum was Revelations: Art from the African American South. I loved reading about the various pieces. The tower had awesome views and overall there is a wide variety of things to see. 

**The restrooms here are co-ed, multi-stall. I'm pretty open-minded but this was pretty tough for me. I think this goes beyond being inclusive and it was somewhat uncomfortable** 

The museum is free the first Tuesday of every month so I would recommended going at that time if you can.
author: Heidi T.

description:
The de Young is one of two "fine arts museums" of San Francisco, the other being the Legion of Honor. It used to include the Asian Art Museum, which was one half of the pre-1989-earthquake museum building, but that is now a separate entity.

I cannot recommend either the Legion of Honor or the Asian Art Museum enough. They are both fantastic, well-curated, worth-the-admission museums. Sadly, I cannot say the same for the deYoung.

For the record, I have been a member of the deYoung since around 1988 (again, pre-1989-earthquake). I remember there being a wine and chocolate reception in the museum itself when I first joined, and being able to wander the galleries during the reception where both the security guards and the docents were chatty, professional and informative. They don't offer such receptions any more, and the security guards and docents are best avoided, as some of them are downright nasty.

The deYoung is a victim of its own success. It's not worth the price of admission, unless you truly want to see either an exhibit or a specific piece. Unless you can get in for free, the view isn't that amazingly better than many of the other high-rise view opportunities available to tourists in the City. It's always crowded, parking is always difficult, and while public transit is available it's either a long walk or undependable. I don't find the deYoung up to the caliber of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (or LACMA, where I was also a member) and it's no Met. It's simply a brag-piece, the purported flagship museum of San Francisco, and really, if you missed it, you wouldn't be missing much. Again, the Legion of Honor, though smaller, is much, much better and the Asian Art Museum downtown is exceptionally breathtaking.

Want specifics? The architecture of the new museum, both inside and out, just fails on every level. It does look like a giant, frumpy designer handbag made from the hide of an endangered species. How appropriate for the elitist clique that inhabits the governing board of this museum. The interior is cold, not well-navigated, and kind of feels smaller and less grand than promised. And whatever curator is kissing the ass of certain persons on the governing board seems to feature a lot of special exhibits of contemporary clothing designers over all other types of art. Really? It's not a specific costume museum. For costume, you'd want to visit the Met or LACMA. Why else are there so many special exhibits geared to the tastes of emaciated socialites who are the only ones who can afford such designers in the first place?

Either the staff and volunteers are demoralized, or they've been trained to treat visitors as badly as possible. I would challenge the "unlimited museum access" with a membership - I had the person checking me in snarl that I'd already been there four times that month. I like visiting the museum, especially when I'm studying a specific piece, or I'm blue and need cheering up. Apparently, that's an issue. And then there was the security guard who snatched my sketchbook and told me that drawing in the museum was not allowed. I can't even - I had a small book, about 3 X 5, and I was using a mechanical pencil. How is that against the sketching rules the museum has laid out?

Even the special "support groups" the museum has are severely lacking. I joined the Textile Arts Council, which promises seminars, workshops, field trips, even international travel opportunities. Which amounted to a couple of things a year. Hardly worth it. I very much wanted to access the library in their "Textile Study Center" but while I indicated an interest in certain books they had, I was told I'd need to present my thesis beforehand and have several professor recommendations in order to use it. And that I should probably check for the books I needed on Amazon first. Oh, okay. Wow.

Maybe the best thing that can be said about the deYoung is that it represents the municipality where it's located - it's difficult, expensive, elitist, forbidding, plastic and doesn't deliver.
author: Ingrid J.

description:
"Will my boyfriend who is bored of all museums and art like this place?" - Yes! My SO loved it and wants to come back. 

Price - No admission on a late Thursday afternoon 45 minutes before closing. We were about the only people here and it was haunting yet peaceful to go through the exhibits by ourselves. We expected the Night at the Museum to happen any second.

Exhibit - Not just paintings and portraits but lots of cultural and historical artifacts from other countries. 

Security and Staff - Excellent, friendly, and welcoming. They lured us with the free admission before closing. 

Time - 45 minutes was definitely not enough time. We only got through a third(?) of the museum at the pace of a quick stroll and a few stops for pictures.. 

Probably my favorite museum in the Bay Area. I definitely will be back to explore the rest.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
Came for the Teotihuacan exhibit the other day.

Pros:
Great exhibit of ancient Mexico. 
The building is stunning and spacious.
Friendly staff.
Cleanest restrooms I've ever seen in a public venue!!

Cons:
I've been to larger venues. 
A bit expensive, I've been to European museums that charge less than half what the de Young charges with more awesome art.
author: Simon C.

description:
Things I really enjoy about the de Young:
-The view from that thingy on top
-Free Friday evening events
-Special exhibits
-The people who work and volunteer here

Every few years, I pop in to check out the rest of it out only to rediscover that my favorite parts about it are still my favorites. 

Do go if they have a special exhibit that flutters your interest. Bonus if it's on a Friday.
author: Loli L.

description:
One of the mornings on my recent trip to San Francisco was a surprise visit to the de Young Museum to view the Royal Hawaiian Feather display.  I've seen many of the items on view at the Bishop Museum however there were a number of capes and headdresses on loan from other Museums and private collections making this a wonderful walk thru of Hawaiian culture with some items over 400 years old.

Up close you can also view the tiny birds from which the feathers are collected and the intricate patterns used on the items.  The history of each item is posted stating the dignitary it belonged to, how they obtained it, i.e., gifted by the King or queen, and who's collection it now resides.  A beautiful presentation of Hawaiian art and culture and includes the items gifted to Captain Cook who was later killed by the same King.

We were also lucky to take a ride to the rooftop observation deck for an awesome 360 degree view of the city.  Beautiful place.  Gift shops available for both the exhibits and the main floors.  I made my purchases to support both the exhibit and the museum.
author: Kathy A.

description: De Young Museum is very beautiful. I am amazed to hear from the staff about how much the museum has changed as well as the history. There was always someone standing near an entrance of the exhibit to answer any questions. Also, make sure to hold onto your bags/backpacks by hand and not over your shoulders so you don't accidentally knock off something. The staff will also remind you to hold your bag by hand or to check your bag in. I love the fact that there were tons of floors to visit. There's a nice area up on the roof top where you get to see the view of the city. The middle and lowest floors had tons of other exhibits to check out. There's tons of art here! Lots of paintings, sculptures, and beautiful views/areas for photo ops or to rest. The bottom floor has the gift shop as well as the coat check-in. They also allow you to check-in your luggage(s) if you need to. Overall, it was a neat experience at the De Young Museum!
author: Natasha N.

description: Went to a Friday night jazz performance at the museum and went early for the new sit-down dinner option with white linen tablecloths in the museum cafe. Prix  fixe meal ~ champagne, delicious salad, steak, cheese/fig course ~ for $40. Exceptional wine list, gracious service. Just lovely. The full-service section of the cafe was set apart with screens. This was a celebration night/special occasion and just amazing. (Note: Less expensive, self-serve option was also available. That's my usual option and also quite good.) Plan to return. As a long-time member, I've never had a better experience.
author: Phoebe W.

description:
A terrific collection of artworks here in this lovely structure. The art was nicely separated and not bunched up, giving an opportunity to enjoy each piece. Free docent tours at random times, though the docent who took us around was a bit at a loss for words especially when one of the pieces she wanted to show us was out on tour. Oops.

While backpacks are permitted, they can not be work on front or back. I'm sure there's logic to this, but they do have a free coat check room. No lockers, but this will have to do.

Don't miss the elevator to the top of the 9th floor observation deck. It's not high high, but it's pretty good!

Dali, Warhol, Copley, etc. Great masters, terrific artworks including paintings, sculptures, silver and furniture.
author: Bruce K.

description:
Wow I was really impressed of the Christmas party I was invited  from my cousins friend who works here. 
Its been a long time since I've actually walked around this museum for what I could see in the dark they had some really nice pictures and paintings and artifacts little book store, the food was off the hook looking forward to going next year if I'm able to. :)
author: Lizzie G.

description:
It's hard to figure out what the de Young is about. Unlike other museums, like the Asian Art Museum or the SFMOMA, it doesn't have the main point of the museum in its name. Overall, you'd describe it as an art museum, but what kind of art museum? Even w/the Legion of Honor, you can hone it down to mainly old European art. But the de Young seems to be a random mishmash of all types of art & artifacts. I wonder how they decide to put a work of art in the de Young, Legion, or SFMOMA. What I can say for sure is that the de Young & other museums don't have Asian art because that all goes to the Asian Art Museum. 

I've always thought the interior design/architecture was the best thing about the de Young. It's very beautiful inside, & they paid a lot of attention to detail, like those tall, narrow windows on the 2nd floor that look down to the gorgeous lobby area, or that little horizontal area w/floor-length windows that look down to the pretty patio/garden area. The cool details of this museum reminds me of the East Asian library at Cal, which seems to have also been designed by very detail-oriented architects.  

In recent years, its been the thing to put a LOT of pseudo-profound, provocative thought into the design of museums & other destination buildings. And even compared to other renovated museums in SF, they put A LOT of thought into every aspect of the de Young's look. I guess they wanted this to be a defining feature in Golden Gate Park - something outlandish, the way they've liked to design important buildings since the late 90s or so. People have forgotten that the de Young is all about that ugly tower, & the view of the city from the tower, & the pretentious copper siding of the building that's supposed to turn green (verdigris) over time to blend in w/the greenery of the park. 

I've always thought the de Young's collection was pretty lame. But if you're in the mood, like if you're in the mood to read a difficult, overrated 19th century novel, then exploring the de Young's art is semi-interesting, in a reflective & introspective sort of way. You can feel proud of yourself for enjoying culture & for pretending to understand the very difficult-to-absorb wall plaques introducing the art of the region. It seems museum wall plaque writing never took a hint from Strunk & White or whatever, & museum jargon takes precedence over readability. Or maybe it's just hard to absorb stuff written on a wall as opposed to a book or something online. 

There's a deep, dark, unpopular part of the museum full of Guinea art & artifacts. I bet 90% of the people visiting that section didn't connect it to Guinea art - they don't make that obvious. All the random tribes & locations they mention in the placards are things you've never heard of. And they only have one big sign in front saying it's Guinea art, w/no map, like they have in other museums, to orient you visually to where it is. And that whole large, dark area also has Native American art, and if you go further in, it's African art, with no real delineation between the vastly different cultures on different continents. It seems the museum makers were being subconsciously stigmatizing, throwing all the non-Western stuff into one large, dark area, w/o really making it clear what is what, and putting all the European/American stuff into pretty, brightly lit rooms. 

There's a lot of interesting aspects of this museum. The cafe seems like it should be something, but the espresso drinks are mediocre. The patio is really nice, & the garden/green area is pretty romantic. I have a vague idea that the greenery area at the patio is one of the few places that stands out as having fall colors in SF. There's actually a little pond & some nondescript "nature" nooks outside the museum, but those seem like an afterthought, and they haven't put much work into the upkeep of that area. 

The top level of the museum store has a lackluster selection that seems very dated & overpriced. I'm not sure who it's supposed to appeal to. But the bottom level of the store has the more interesting art-oriented stuff, like prints & art books. It's kind of like the SFMOMA store, except less pretentious & less focused on modern art. 

The de Young has a lot of very expensive-looking, put-together, well-dressed young people, like at the SFMOMA & Legion of Honor. Like a lot of SF, the crowd at the de Young seems conservative, yet slightly edgy at the same time. It's intellectualism & academia - you think you're all that, but you're just falling into the Keeping Up With the Joneses sort of elitism that you aspire to. The de Young, like most other museums, is a very aspirational sort of place. 

Overall, I don't think the de Young is worth a visit for locals unless you come on a free day. There's plenty of free days - the usual free day of the month, as well as the free first weekends for Bank of America cardholders.
author: Valle H.

description:
I've lived within 1 mile from de Young for years and finally checked it out yesterday. Man, now I wish I've done this earlier!

The collection is very eclectic. From African artifact to modernist painting to photography to contemporary fashion design, they've got everything. 

Also, the panoramic view on top of the 9-story Hamon Tower is amazing too!
author: Joseph L.

description: The De Young is one fine museum! I visited LA's LACMA Museum this past weekend and it cannot hold a candle to the DeYoung OR the Legion of Honor. Both the DeYoung and Legion of Honor are exquisite museums! I've attended many exhibits at each location. Whomever does the presentation(s) of special touring exhibits is one marvelous individual (or team!). Give yourself a little prezzie and decide to pay a visit to either location. Their permanent collections are wonderful, presented to a 'T' and well-worth the trip! Also, I loved the restaurant at the De Young! Have fun!
author: Linda S.

description: Excellent museum, great exhibits.  Wish I had more time to take it all in.  The 'all gender' bathroom was a little awkward to deal with but doable.  The tower was really freaky especially when it swayed back and forth.  Cant help but remember you're in earthquake country
author: D D.

description:
I'm a huge fan of art and art museums. I've been to SFMOMA and LACMA and knew I needed to check out de Young as well. My least favorite thing about visiting art museums, however, is the overwhelming feeling when there's so much artwork and you just don't know where to start. De Young, being a smaller museum, did not give me that feeling. I was able to go through everything in about 2 hours. They have an amazing collection of Danny Lyon's work.

If you are a student, make sure you bring your school ID, as general admission is only $6 for students. Parking close by might be difficult to find on the weekends. When I got there the museum parking garage was full and I had to park on the street about a 13 minute walk away from de Young.
author: Christina P.

description:
This is part of the Museum on Us sponsored by Bank of America. 

We went on the first Saturday of the month and received the General Admission free of charge. There is an option though if you want to view the Frank Stella by paying $10.

This museum is great both families and art aficionados. I specifically loved the cultural and historical artifacts from Guatemala and Mexico. There are also blown glass sculpture by various artists but Chihuly is still by far my favorite.

Do not miss going to the Hamon Tower Observation Deck. Gives you a good view the Golden Gate park.

Parking is definitely a challenge so be sure to come in early. We stayed for approximately 3 hours and paid $18 of parking.
author: Rane P.

description:
I just moved to SF and have been working my butt off at a tech thing and FINALLY get some time off so i wanted to see the Teotihuacan exhibit because it looks awesome.

I checked there web page about what i need to do to enter and then ride my bike 45 minutes to go check this out.

I want to be very clear here. This cowardly overly secure country will live in now? Is way out of control. Living in fear is not the way to go.

Anyway, got to the front door and was told I would have to check my messenger bag because it was too big.

Ok, fine, I will check it.

But, a las I was wearing my mountain bike shoes and the gentleman in the flashy suit denied me access because my shoes have cleats on them. Which doesnt make sense? They are brass have rubber protecting the cleat from actually touching the floor.

Soooooooo, why?

Seriously? The idea is to HELP me spend $30 to see your exhibits NOT keep me from giving you cash.

I have to say i am still pretty pissed about this. I have NEVER had such an experience trying to get in to a museum. Heck, I was a member of the Institute of Art in Chicago and not ONCE was my shoes a reason to keep me from the art.

So, here, this is what Benjamin Franklin said:
