"They who can give up essential liberty to obtain a little temporary safety deserve neither liberty nor safety."

Let's put this in perspective....i visited the Mexican presidential palace? It was easier to get into, obviously.
author: John C.

description:
We're not super big fans of museums, but since de Young (and Legion of Honor) is part of the Bank of America Museum On Us list, we've had the chance to visit both attractions for free a few times so far. It's also free on the first Tuesday of every month. Another plus is you can visit both attractions with just one ticket normally, so it's a super cheap deal for being able to check out 2 of the most well-known museums in this area!

I really enjoy the architecture at the de Young, and it's in the Golden Gate Park, so there are many other things you can check out outside the museum as well! You literally can spend the whole weekend out here and not be bored!
author: Cathy W.

description: I went here yesterday to the Summer of Love exhibit and it was awesome! So much culture to learn about in San Francisco and the movements during the sixties!
author: Daniel C.

description: Loved the summer of love exhibit!! Took my 8 year old there and he learned about the hippie movement And how it took culture by storm. Fantastic museum! Great views of sf from the observation deck! Can't wait to go back!!!
author: Annalisa T.

description: This is a pretty nice museum right inside of Golden Gate Park.  Great space with interesting exhibits and a very cool museum store.  Make sure you head to the top of the observation tower for great views of the city.  It's worth a look.
author: Tom T.

description: What a fantastic view of SF landscape from the top floor! it was really nice. This review is long time due, I was postponing my visit to this museum and finally went when the Oscar de la Renta exhibit was running back in May. I enjoy fashion a lot, and this scenario was awesome for the purpose intended. I could observe clearly the patterns of the clothing, the displays were great, the illumination phenomenal. The bathrooms are spacious and clean (considering the amount of visitors) and the in and out of the museum are very easy and intuitive. Definitively a museum to go again and again for any exhibit, even if to only enjoy that dreamy view (in a soft rainy day is magical).
author: Carmen V.

description: We were too late to check out this museum but the architecture and outdoor sculpture garden was neat.  I can't wait to come back and check out this museum.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
So you're far from artsy but your in San Fran and you're trying to do something more than eat and drink...maybe you're even trying to impress your companion with how incredibly sophisticated you are. Why not venture over to the de Young museum and cap it off with a walk through the botanical gardens? Turns out as boring as that may sound, you'll score a good amount of points for ignoring your initial instincts and possibly even enjoy yourself. There's tons to see here, from painting and glass sculptures to artifacts dating back before Christ. I mean who doesn't want to see something Jesus might have missed? My favorite part was actually all of the ceremonial masks. Surrounding the de Young is a myriad of other point scoring experiences so you really can't go wrong here.

Try it or Pass by it Final Word

Try it men. If nothing else it will sharpen your ability to "notice" and offer positive opinions... unless of course that's already your specialty.
author: Michael R.

description: Beautiful gallery. And they had summer love and there were lots of kids activities. And the view of bay is great at the observatory.
author: Ashi C.

description:
Am a Bay Area native who's gone to exhibits at both the Legion and the De Young for 50+ years. Went to the Bouquets to Arts exhibit with a friend yesterday, and we were seriously disappointed.  Very small bouquets, sparsely spaced.  And overcrowded galleries.  We went to get a wee bit of a munchy and a coffee in the café afterward.  And instead of having the members' "free" coffee honored, I received an  astonishingly rude, and barely intelligible response from a Chinese woman behind the counter.  (Chung Hu?) And was actually charged an additional  "surcharge!"  (WTF?!)  My Asian noodle and my friend's barley salads were both painfully bland and overpriced.  And there was no soy sauce available with the EVOO and vinegar offerings to provide the flavor pick-ups that both "salads" very seriously needed.  Ugh!

I am a long-time member, and based on the poor quality of the exhibits  (This one, and the last two--the Klimt having been REALLY painfully disappointing), and yesterday's café experience, I seriously doubt I will bother to renew my membership.  And will caution friends not to become members.  BOOOOOOOO!!!!  SFFAM, you have a LOT of work to do!
author: Karen S.

description:
My first visit to de Young started off great when, through luck, I got in for free! A member left a ticket they had at the counter for someone to use! Thank you whoever you are :-)

My exploration started with a trip up the elevator to Hamon Observation Tower, 360 degrees of glass walls providing views of Cal Academy of Sciences, Golder Gate park, the top of Golden Gate bridge, and in the distance you can even see downtown SF. This was an epic view, though a bit of uneas for those with vertigo. 

In general, much of this museum (08/16) is dedicated to ancient artifacts from the Americas, Africa, and Pacific/Oceanic Islands. Clothes, tools, furniture, instruments, masks, jewelry, weapons, sculptures...the list goes on and on. I loved the variety of cultures this museum provides exhibits for. Naturally, I'm quite familiar with art from the Americas, but I was amazed by the African sculptures, New Zealand Maori carvings, and the Indonesian textiles. Never seen a Pacific Islands collection like this!

I imagine the price here is a bit steep, and I acknowledge that part of my great experience was getting in for free, hahaha. Parking across the street at the Cal Academy of Sciences is also ridiculously expensive. 

In all honesty, if you are a lover of museums then you simply must come visit de Young!
author: Stephen R.

description:
I'm a member of the FAMSF (Fine Art Museums of San Francisco) and I highly recommend you becoming one too!  The membership pays for itself if you bring a friend with you to all of their special exhibits.

If you are out of town with no intention of becoming a member, I still recommend it.

Nice amenities include a generous coat check and real orchids in the ladies' room.  It's the little things!

Also, all of the security guards are super nice.  A lot of them are fans of art, just talk to them!
author: Chloe M.

description:
I'm a sucker for the fine arts. I love the location of it, it's quite hectic around the museum but yet it still captures that peace you look for when trying to get away and just admire art. 

I love the Keith Harring piece outside, so Insta-grammable. 

Inside the museum, I loved how different exhibits of art had different lighting and the set up just made it seem like you were transporting through different eras. 

Generally the staff were very friendly, with the exception of the lady downstairs checking for tickets. Like, "really lady? I already perused the whole museum" 

Anywho, it totally made my artistic soul sing . Highly recommended! 

Though, I still have to check out the de Young Cafe. That shall be another review of its own!
author: Viktor L.

description: Great Museum. We went during the Teotihuacan exhibit and it was fascinating. It's a pretty big museum, with cohesive flow, and a wide range of exhibits. I'm a huge fan of western history and the museum has a huge variety of historical artwork, furniture, and sculptures. Plan on walking a whole lot as this museum is huge!
author: Antonio V.

description: We love this museum, and have been several times. Having seen a number of their special exhibits we were excited to check out the new "summer of love" exhibition. Very disappointing. A bunch of posters, a few outfits randomly placed on mannequins, and some very weak video installations. As my wife said, "my room looked like this in high school." Great museum, rich topic, but a weak exhibit IMHO.
author: Doron A.

description: Caught the last day of the Teotihuacan Exhibition on 2/11/18. De Young already has an impressive Mayan collection, the Teotihuacan Exhibition artifacts seem to pale in comparison; have to remind myself that the latter is almost 2000 years old. Anyway, the audio presentation revealed the extraordinary way the archeologists stumbled upon the secret tunnel under the Feathered Serpent Pyramid, where they discovered the sacrificial remains of warriors, and tiny rivers made of mercury (sounds like the tomb of the First Qin Emperor of China in China).
author: Sharon L.

description:
I have to start with saying; I never been in such a clean public place, especially the bathrooms.
We got there at 10:00 a.m. and spent 3 hours. We got to see almost everything. We really enjoy the variety of Art and periods in history.
It's great place to visit with 5-6 year old and older. Don't forget to take the elevator to the top floor for panoramic amazing view of the city.
author: Michaella B.

description: My husband and I visited the museum yesterday. A museum volunteer/employee tainted our experience almost from the start. The employee who took our ticket payment was so very kind and pleasant. He explained where we should place an adhesive decal on our shirts to indicate we'd paid. Yards away, we encountered another employee who was ensuring people who were entering an exhibit space were wearing the decal. She was loud, and incredibly rude to all the patrons climbing the stairs to the exhibit room. These were people who'd just paid for admission and were conspicuously wearing the decal. She loudly demanded to see the decal from yards away, in an otherwise quiet area. These people had all just walked past her, none of them running, or moving aggressively. It was extremely unpleasant. We'd walked within feet of her for a few minutes before climbing the stairs and she yelled at us too. She'd clearly posted herself in a poor position to view the decals. That was her choice. The interaction was terribly unpleasant and not the way I want or expect to begin a museum visit. The museum itself was alright, though I did not think the exhibit spaces were organized well for traffic flow. There are some interesting pieces, and the observation space was lovely. The museum's backpack policy was odd, too. Most museums require backpacks to be worn in front. This museum requires them to be carried below the waist, which is most uncomfortable. It doesn't accomplish anything either. There were several pieces displayed below waist height that could be damaged by someone carrying a bag this way, but not by a person carrying a bag above the waist. There are ways to preserve the art and remind people to be spatially aware (of the art and other visitors) that don't require patrons to be uncomfortable throughout their visit. Beware.
author: E A.

description: Such a great experience here. I came to de You g museum with my art class and we pretty much explored the whole museum! My favorite part is going up for the city view! All the arts are amazing, great quality of art ! Very small space, easy to go around and will still have time for more museums after this one ! I had a great time here, highly recommended for a visit.
author: N A.

description: Pretty dope museum! Located in Golden Gate Park where the Academy of Science is, so parking is tough if you don't use the parking structure. Try not to bring a big purse or backpack if necessary, like any museum, they make you wear it in the front. We went during the Summer of Love exhibition so it was a nice little addition. There is not as much as SFMOMA but it still is full of cool art. The glass view of SF I believe is free and you do not need to pay admission if you are just trying to head there, as well as the Turrell Skyspace. Both are located outside of the museum!
author: Monique L.

description:
This isn't a big garden nor are the statues packed in tight.  They are really good, and well placed.

I really like the cats on the island.  They are surrounded by plants then bu the moat with Lilly pads...

 Then right in front of the museum there is a Keith Herring statue.   I've always liked his work.

Then there are several nice older bronzes.

It's a nice little collection.  It's well worth stopping for if you are visiting the museum anyway.
author: Mark B.

description:
In the interest of keeping it short and sweet, here are just a few tips I can rattle off from my first weekend experience here:

- Try to buy tickets for special exhibits online; my husband and I came late in the day and I guess I really didn't know what I was expecting but the Oscar de la Renta exhibit was sold out.
- You'll want to come with plenty of time to explore everything, but after 4:30 admission is free, so maybe ask yourself if you are fine with missing a lot (unless you have your running shoes on) by paying nothing.
- Eat something before you start, though this is also a good rule of thumb for most activities in life.
- Plan to maybe walk around the grounds after the museum closes, because otherwise you will be stuck in parking garage traffic as everyone tries to leave at the same time as you.
- I'm more of a "stick to the map" type of person, so I highly recommend - of course - sticking to the map. It seems easy to get lost and even easier to get overwhelmed by everything around you so a plan is key.

You will definitely enjoy your visit here no matter the day or time you swing by, so you really can't miss; just learn from my mistakes and chances are you'll enjoy it much more!
author: Emily S.

description: this was a great museum! very diverse exhibits & I am glad that I paid the extra money to gain access to the summer of love exhibit! They also have a student discount, just make sure to bring your student ID. For those who bring a backpack or bag, you are required to carry it on your arm and not your back/shoulder(s), but you can check your bag on the bottom floor.
author: L. F.

description: This is my first time coming to a museum. This museum has a lot of artwork from the 18th Century. It's really beautiful and it shows a lot of feelings and thoughts Everytime when you look at them, you have this feeling of what the author is really drawing about. I will definitely be back when I have the chance to!
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
It's nicely located in golden gate park, the tower (for free! no admission) presents you a nice view over the city and parts of the bay, the architecture is interesting but nothing special... and so is the art collection. 
Too bad, I love museums but this one couldn't catch me. 
Parts of the museum are far too dark.
The staff is very nice and they have a lovely garden.
author: Corinna S.

description:
One of my favorite museums! The building itself is absolutely beautiful, as are the views outside (especially on a clear day). 

They always have great exhibitions from all over the world, and have a nice permanent collection as well.  There's a great Picasso, and even a room with futurism art. 

There's just an incredible ambiance here, bringing nature inside. I could spend hours wandering throughout the galleries. You can even go on the 9th floor to an observation deck, and on a clear day you can see all of San Francisco. 

The cafe is the perfect spot to grab a glass of wine or a cappuccino. You can sit inside or out, and both rooms have a lovely ambiance. 

I definitely recommend setting aside a few hours for a visit! With your ticket here, you can also visit the nearby Legion of Honor. I know they have lots of special dates and deals for locals, so be sure to look at those online to save some $$.
author: Angela F.

description:
Wonderful museum but what's the beef with backpacks? And we're not talking the camping kind.  My husband was using a butt pack.  No problem with that when it was on his hips, but when he had it over his shoulder because it was too warm on his butt, invariably one of the guards would freak out and ask him to get it off his back, but then as they got closer they saw it wasn't a backpack and would apologize.  None of them ever explained what the issue was (we didn't ask)

Wonderful permanent collections (make sure to see the glass sculptures) and special exhibits in a stunning building with little pockets of gardens as light wells.  

The Observation Tower is a must.  I had never been up there before so was amazed on stepping out of the elevator.  Clear panoramic views of the entire city.  Absolutely stunning.

We took BART and then MUNI (N line) to get to the museum from the east bay.  Time consuming and crowded, even on a Sunday, but worth it to avoind driving and parking in SF.
author: Jacquelin S.

description:
We just renewed our membership, moved up to a  'contributing membership' of $249 (fully tax deductible) which upgrades the dual membership to include reciprocal privileges to more than 500 museums and unlimited access to de Young & Legion of Honor. I love the de Young fashion exibits, most recently saw the Oscar de la Renta collection (closed May 30, 2016) .  It was fabulous!      

Avoid weekends if possible, we had to actually wait in line for the spaces to free up in the parking garage, we almost missed our timed entry for the special exhibit.   Also check out the de Young Friday night schedule for music, drinks and art! https://deyoung.famsf.org/programs/fridays

Parking:  Street parking is difficult so we always park in the garage which is convenient but pricey, parking for 75 minute visit was $9.50,  $5.50 per hour (which is the minimum even for a 10 minute drive thru) weekend daily max is $31.  http://goldengateparking.com/      If you live in the city public transport is a great option but from South Bay/Peninsula public transportation to the de Young would take over 2 hours and would cost $12 each, no incentive to leave the car at home.
author: Mr Kitty K.

description:
Great tip: go to the 9th floor of the De Young Museum for their observation deck--great views!

Do not miss the Ruth Asawa's artwork by the evaluators-Amazing!  She is a local SF artist. Her biography of work is impressive and her love for art and community.
author: C L.

description:
The museum and the grounds are quite attractive and I have certainly enjoyed going to that part of San Francisco on occasion, but for your own sanity *DO NOT BECOME A MEMBER*! As soon as you or anybody in your household makes the mistake of giving them your phone number you will relentlessly be hounded by robocalls requesting that you spend more money with the museum. The calls come in at all times of the day and every day of the week. The deYoung does not respect the national do-not-call list in this case.

If you search for the number that these calls originate from (231) 732 2090, you'll see that there are plenty of complaints. But if you call membership services they apparently say it is just too profitable for them to keep harassing their former (or reportedly in some cases, their current) members.
author: Markus G.

description: Huge museum in a great location with lots of things to do and see. Give yourself lots of time some of the rooms are confusing. Some of the art is in the eye of the beholder. A white canvas with a black and blue border to me is not art.
author: Phil B.

description:
Was here recently. Too amazing just walking from one era of great artisanry to another. The forms and styles, regions of the world, and architecture of each gallery is not to be missed either!

Go to an auditorium and listen to a free lecture, or follow and docent led tour and learn something new!
author: Jana C.

description:
A pretty great museum. de Young is one of those staple museums that almost everyone in SF goes to once in awhile. The best thing about this museum is that the first weekend of every month is free courtesy of Bank of America! Yay! It's quite large and the exhibits are arranged by era and geographical location. There's also a really lovely observation deck that will give some pretty spectacular views of the city that extend pretty far out. 

I'm not a huge art aficionado so it's hard for me to comment a ton on this, but the de Young is definitely a great place to spend an afternoon at. Tons of different exhibits -- paintings, portraits, sculptures, etc. 

tldr; great museum! lots of interesting things to explore
author: Jasmine X.

description:
We came to see the Jewel City and William Worden exhibits. A docent warned us that it would get very crowded on closing day of the special exhibition, so we headed downstairs to the Jewel City exhibit first.

It's too bad we couldn't take pictures at the Jewel City exhibit. I wanted a photo of the Star Maiden. If you were expecting to see pictures from the PPIE, you will be disappointed. The galleries were filled with the works of art that were actually on display at the Palace of Fine Arts in 1915. There were many forms of art, including paintings, prints, and sculptures. Included were photos showing how the art was arranged on the walls.  It was originally arranged rather densely, "salon style".

The galleries were very crowded by the time we arrived at the Jewel City gift shop. I managed to avoid temptation and not buy anything. But I was tempted by so many things. After that, we headed back upstairs to see the William Worden exhibit.

The PPIE only comprises a small portion of Worden's work on display. I really liked his nighttime PPIE photos, they were impressive. You also learn that he liked close-ups of seagulls. But my favorite photo was the one of Chinatown at night. You could see the street illuminated by Chinese lanterns.

Admission is $10 for adults, but there is an added fee for the special exhibits.
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description: These guys are running this museum like Nazis. They are quite rude telling you off what can you carry and how exactly can you carry... Be careful, they might not like the angle at which you hold your elbows. Outrageous entrance fee. No donation-based scheme. So if you don't have the money, you don't have a right to exist.
author: Albert C.

description: a great place but... don't try to get member's tickets using the museums web site. it's a total mess with conflicting and incomplete instructions. don't try and call the museum. voicemail hell leading nowhere.
author: Chuck B.

description: This review is for their membership.  I love the museum however I don't love their way to handle the member services. I wanted to upgrade my membership to include my nephew in June and I was told that the upgrade would have been pro-rated and discounted on the renewal in November for the months not used prior to the upgrade. Instead today they told me that the information was totally incorrect and that basically I was charged for months that I didn't used since there isn't such policy. What a scam! I really love de Young but in this case I feel that after years of supporting them it's time to stop.....
author: E.M. E.

description: Wonderful museum. Very unpleasant parking and driving on the weekends, except super early AM. Great exhibits and permanent collection. Given that FAMSF memberships include the legion of honor, this is a no brained for locals.
author: Anees L.

description:
Beautiful place!

My initial thought when I saw this building was that it looked like a portion of a battle ship from Star Wars lol. My friend took me here to the top floor and I thought it was beautiful. You could see an astonishing amount of San Francisco.

This would be an ideal place for a reception after a wedding if they transformed it into that! Ugh, would love to come here during night time. Really pretty.

Go. Now.
author: Aj C.

description:
How have I never visited this place before? Aware of my oversight, this was on the to-do list the last time I was in SF. I was pleasantly surprised to learn that the museum was free that day (perhaps always now?). After wandering through their "Jewel City" exhibit, I went up the observation tower (also free with admission) and was treated to probably the best view of the city I've had yet. That alone was worth going, but seeing their art collection was very cool as well. It's not such a huge museum that it feels overwhelming, either. It's worth a look!

STEPH JUDGEMENT: Great art museum in the heart of Golden Gate Park with an observation tower that is a must.
author: Steph H.

description:
This museum is so fun, and right in the heart of San Francisco at the Golden Gate Park. We arrived right when the museum opened -- was able to get parking along the street (inside the park) for free. 

They check your purse quickly to make sure you're not carrying any random weapons, etc. and off you go to either the member-only line or the non-member line to pick up your museum entrance ticket.

They place a sticker on you after you buy the ticket! My ticket was FREE because I used my BofA debit card (all BofA members get free entrance to this museum on the 1st weekend of the month). Score! We still had to pay for my husband's regular adult ticket though, at $10.

We went immediately to the top floor to check out the skyline view of the city. Wow, good thing we did because there was no one there but us! Un-obstructed views of the city! :) Then we ventured downstairs to visit all the exhibits...

Can't believe they also have some Dali paintings (which are from Spain)! We were just in Spain and visited the Dali museum, so we picked up on the paintings immediately. It was a fun day to explore this museum and you can probably finish in 1.5-2.5 hours.

Be sure to check out the outdoor sculpture garden, that was fun!
It started to get super packed as we were leaving, too!
author: Yonnie C.

description:
I've been walking by the de Young museum almost every time I come to San Francisco and have never gone in.  Time to fix that situation.

The line for tickets was surprisingly long for 2:30 PM.  First stop was the American section, heavily influenced by European art obviously, with portraits, furniture, historical settings, landscapes, statues, and silverware galore.  My favorites are still the landscapes; the detail captured in each sunset-lit mountain and forest is extraordinary.  Further on was the impressionist section and post-impressionist work, including two paintings by Salvador Dali.  Overall, it was fascinating to see the transition in art style, particularly in painting more realistic faces.  

On the same floor were statues and masks from New Guinea, Northern Africa, and Indonesia.  Quickly skimmed through this section.  Interesting contrast to the American artwork, but most of the pieces were made fairly recently (mid-1900s) so I wasn't struck by a sense of authenticity.  Still, it was fascinating to see how all these different cultures designed their gods and their rituals.

Back on the first floor, decided to check out the Mesoamerican section.  Wow.  This section is definitely worth checking out.  There are so many well preserved artifacts that are 1400+ years old, both murals and clay figures, that it's kind of mind boggling to think about.  Also it was fascinating to learn more about Mayan culture through the figurines, tools, and art displayed.  
This section leads into the modern art wing, first through sculptures and then to the paintings.  The sculptures were really fun to look at, but modern paintings only continue to puzzle me.  

All in all, it took about 2 hours to walk around the permanent collection, and I consider it time well spent.
author: Emily Y.

description:
As every child has his/her secret place, James Turrell's Three Gems is a secret space of the de Young Museum, tucked into a grassy mound in the Osher Sculpture Garden. People who live in the city at present need a secret place like Three Gems. Those people are swept away by city's indiscreet wave; the crowd and circumstances that they don't even know. Furthermore, they let the things around them go before they form their opinions about them. Within the city, we lost our chance to stop and think about the reality. There is no break. If we keep living in this way, we will eventually drown. However, Turrell's artwork is like a secret place in the city which allows people to slow down their tempos and rest themselves from their hustle and bustle lives. I firmly believe we need places like Three Gems to think about our surroundings and to reconnect with nature.

I visited Three Gems before I realized that Turrell is a renowned artist/pioneer in the Southern California light-and-space art movement. Even though I barely knew the artist, Three Gems was very impressive. I was surprised not only by its size but also by the way he arranged the experience of the artwork from the beginning until the end. The sculpture is part of a series of Turrell's work called Skyspace. This permanent artwork was commissioned for the de Young Museum in San Francisco by Mr. and Mrs. Osher in 2005, and it is free during the museum's open hours.
When I visited the place, it was the middle of the day. The weather was perfect to enjoy the artwork. First, I had to walk through a short tunnel cut into the hill which makes the work more unique and raises more expectation. Then, I faced a cylindrical space carved out of the hill. As I was walking along the chamber, I finally entered inside the dome through an open door. There was a stone bench which ran around the circumference of the chamber allowing visitors sit and view the sky through an oculus cut at the top of the dome. Viewers' perceptions of the sky color are subtly altered by LED lightings inside the dome during night visits, which is an optimal viewing time. The sculpture also provides a great experience during day time by changing based on light and weather conditions outside the chamber. The light from the roof shines a spotlight into the room. Upon first encountering Three Gems, I felt a great calm over me, and I think that wasn't just for me. While I was staying the place, a lot of visitors sat on the bench silently for several minutes, absorbing the light and the passing of the clouds above. It was a perfect moment. 

Within city nowadays, it is all about fast, fast and fast. There is no doubting the word "rapid" represents the city. There is no space or time for people to slow down and look back. Everything began to change so quickly after the tech tsunami in 2012. According to Rebecca Solnit, "the tech culture seemed in small and large ways to be a culture of disconnection and withdrawal." I am not saying accepting the emerging culture is a bad thing, but this phenomenon fabricates the world around us, and people just follow it, not looking at the negative or positive effects of it. In the interview with Michael Govan, Turrell said, "we live within this reality we create, and we're quite unaware of how we create the reality." In the city, I feel I'm in a wave. There is no point that I can stop and sort out my thoughts. Although this rush city tries to disconnect people, we need to have something that reconnects the city back to people. 

From Hito Steyerl's journal, she mentioned, "contemporary art is not only about beauty. It is also about function." Regarding function, Turrell's work is a sculpture, but at the same time, it is a great interactive art that brings people together. While I was staying at the place, I saw some visitors use the space as a cafe or any chair in the park. They talked about their daily lives such as their kids and jobs. Few other visitors utilized the place as a Buddhist meditation chamber. They just sat on the bench for a while quietly and looked up at the sky through the hole. Three Gems genuinely brings us towards nature and community.

According to Jerry Saltz, he said public spaces in the city became a simple getaway. Three Gems is not viewed as much as it is entered and experienced. Seeing the sky, which we do daily, but through the dome was an entirely new experience; sit down on the bench, close eyes, and try to experience the changing atmospheric conditions outside of the dome by hearing birds' twittering, feeling the sunshine and fresh breeze, and smelling the grass. Three Gems successfully lets viewers fully experience the artwork itself. The artwork reconnects people and nature. Lucy Lippard said, "nature includes everything, even technology, created by humans, who are part of nature."  In that sense, it is even more integral to have places like Three Gems within a city to retreat and have a moment of peace and reflection for ourselves.
author: Ji Won Y.

description:
What a wonderful place to have just a few blocks from my house. 

If you think you might come more than once a year buy a membership and support art.

Don't skip the Hudson River School! This is where you'll find me.
author: Justin S.

description: I had a fantastic afternoon at the DeYoung Museum. Although I am by no stretch of the imagination an art aficionado, it was a great afternoon looking at all of the different historic and modern art that the museum had to offer. I really liked the DeYoung because it is so conveniently located in the middle of golden gate park. If you come you need to make it up to the sky tower, probably my favorite part. Also, take note that the exhibit downstairs, right now it's Frank Stella, is not included with general admission. I have been to Moma as well, and I preferred the DeYoung Museum if you had to pick.
author: Ross S.

description: Staff at museum store were not friendly. Not helpful. Really lacked skills to work with public.
author: Tamara W.

description:
This is a beautiful museum located in Golden Gate park, across from the California Academy of Sciences. 

Admission is free every 1st Tuesday of the month. Make sure to head up to the Observation Tower for gorgeous views of Golden Gate Park and even see views of the ocean. 

The museum is massive, and the building itself is really unique.

Every Friday night, they host an after hours party until 8:45 pm. Every week is a different theme, but expect live music, hands-on art projects, a film screening, and pop-up bars. The party is actually free to attend, but won't gain you admission to the exhibits. 

Admission tickets to the de Young include same-day general admission to the Legion of Honor (special exhibition fees not included). Also, receive a $2 discount with proof of purchase from any Bay Area public transportation system, including BART, Muni, Caltrain, and more.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
I only went to the tower because our tour guide suggested that it was a must if you're at Golden Gate Park and I'm so glad we did! 

It is completely free to go up to the tower and the view is amazing! You can see how tiny the city actually is! Definitely a must if you are in golden gate park and looking to do things for FREE!
author: Mary P.

description:
I went to see the textile exhibit in particular; but was disappointed in the very small collection (don't miss opening the drawers). The pieces were quality, but the hall as a separate exhibit was a let-down. 

Save your time and pop into the exciting exhibits at the San Jose Museum of Quilts and Textiles.
author: Erin B.

description:
Probably more remarkable for its architecture than its actual art collection, the de Young is nevertheless is a must-see when visiting Golden Gate Park.  While there are some notable works here by the likes of Pablo Picasso, Diego Rivera, Georgia O'Keefe, and others, the majority of the artwork, especially those on the second floor, are anthropological in nature - objects from the Americas, Africa, and Oceania.  What really stands out here is the building's copper-plated exterior designed by architectural firm Herzog and de Meuron.  As time passes, the building's brown color will assume a greenish hue to match the surrounding environs thanks to oxidization - a process that has already begun in the years since the museum's re-opening.

Of the things you can do here, I would highly recommend the following: First, be sure to check out the observation tower, as the views of the area are spectacular.  While you won't find the stunning panoramic views of San Francisco like you would at the Marin Headlands, you will have a lovely view of the Academy of Science, Golden Gate Park, and Sutro Tower.  You should also be able to see the Golden Gate Bridge and the Transamerica Building  peaking out over the tops of not-so-distant hills.  I'm under the impression that you could get away with visiting the observation tower without a ticket, as nobody seemed to be checking stickers or tickets from the entryway to the elevator.  And, second, don't forget to visit the Osher sculpture garden.  There are many interesting sculptures that are sure to entertain children and adults alike.  The pathway leading up to James Turrell's "Three Gems" is like a secret passageway lined with bamboo.  The structure itself is striking and peaceful, and it's interesting to see how people react when they realize how their voices have echoed upon reaching the center room.  There are ceramic apples littered around the grounds that are perfect for funny photo opportunities. Like the observation tower, I'm under the impression that you don't need paid admission to enter the area.

Otherwise, take advantage of the fact that admission ($10 for adults / higher for special exhibitions) to the de Young also counts as admission to the nearby Legion of Honor - another smaller art museum with classical architecture that specializes in European artwork.  If you come early enough in the morning, especially on weekends, you can often find street parking along Hagiwara Tea Garden Drive.  If you're not willing to circle, then there are garages underneath the music concourse.  Either way, there's so much to do in the area and in Golden Gate Park that it's not a problem if you have to pay for parking.

Unless you read every caption, listen to the audio tour, or need frequent breaks, you probably won't spend the entire day at the de Young.  This isn't the Met.  But, that's okay; museums shouldn't gobble up all your time when there are so many other awesome things to do in the surrounding area!
author: Greg T.

description:
This is really rather a review of the artwork rather than the building itself. Don't get me wrong I love the top level observation deck....the views are spectacular.

However the artwork is just meh. Yeah the Georgia O'Keffe was pretty outstanding but the rest was mediocre and very disparate. Really just a mish mash of wealthy donor's pieces,

If your showing me kadinsky....kill me with a load of his works not a single piece.

The pieces on exhibition are not major pieces and not great pieces to begin with.

I much rather go to the Asian Art Museum or the Modern Art Museum in San Fran.
author: David G.

description:
When we went to this place today, a guard rudely dragged my bag out of my shoulder and told me never put it back on. How can that be? If you don't want me to carry my bag in some way, just say that to me; why directly pull it out of my shoulder without saying anything?

The way they treat visitors is really horrible, and the smell inside is terrible. Highly recommend NOT go to this place. This is the worst museum I've seem ever.
author: Conans H.

description:
Yeah, the tower is glorious but... $30 admission, which doesn't even include special exhibits?!? Way to get the 99%'s panties all in a ruffle. 

Be sure to attend on the Bank of America free days, which will get your free admission and $10 off any special exhibits when you show your B of A card. Only downside is that everyone AND their mother AND her brother attend on these days too. Can you blame them?

The regular exhibits are fine, but tower is the highlight. You can enjoy a remarkable panoramic view of SF from up there -- a cool place to propose, or even have a party (I've heard you can rent it out).
author: Nique F.

description: Nice exhibitions, building and cafe.  Quite expensive, and poorly managed.  Example: there is only one pay station for parking, we had to stand in line for 20 minutes.
author: Anon Y.

description:
Damn, de Young, you sexy!

No, but really, this is one sexy museum. First, there is the amazingly easy parking. Yeah, that is a thing that exists in San Francisco and it's at the deYoung. Also, the amazing tower which has the best view of the city.  THE BEST. 

Oh, yeah, and the art. The art of it all. I just really love this museum and can spend ages walking around it's halls and appreciating all the beauty around me.

The only complaint I have is how confusing their online ticketing system is. I bought tickets for the Georgia O'Keefe exhibit and then bought admission tickets and then when we got there they told me I only needed to buy one or the other. So confusing and I'm a fairly technologically advanced individual.
author: Tara H.

description:
The Turner exhibit is an absolute must-see for any art enthusiast. Seriously, who wants to pass up a chance to see the namesake of the prestigious Turner Award for fine art? Not me. 

The collections are varied, the museum architecture interesting, and the employees friendly and helpful. I saw a review that called the de Young the "poor man's Met." To that I say, bye Felicia. Enjoy each museum as its own experiences, and don't go around comparing apples to oranges or both fruits will go spoiled!

All in all, a wonderful experience. Come visit!
author: Connie C.

description:
I came here because it was the last weekend for free admission with my BOFA card. I tried to make this a free trip by finding street parking instead of garage parking so the closest you can park is on 10th street. It was around 1pm and I was luckily able to find one parking spot so hopefully you are lucky too. If not, there are garages with hourly rates. We originally tried parking near the Ocean and looking for the shuttle but the shuttle stops were nowhere to be found and it is a pretty far shuttle so might as well try to find parking. General admission was free but if not, it is $23 without the special exhibits. My friend forgot his card and check so the lady told him that he could download the app and sign in and got in for free. That is nice.

The rooms are pretty big and you can see most of the second and third floor but the first floor and some of the rooms are blocked off if you purchased general admission. It took us about 2 hours to go through everything. There is a mix of sculptures, paintings, and fixtures so I really enjoyed the variety. There are a few rooms that go through US history and it reminded me of AP US history haha. You must go to the Hamon Tower on the 9th floor and check out the view. It is free and you can see the rest of the park including the Academy of Science. It reminded me of the Empire State Building but obviously not to the same extent. Definitely worth a visit :) 


**TIPS**
1) I am not sure how long free admission will last but this weekend may be your last chance with your BOFA card. My friend was able to download the BOFA app and got free admission, so maybe they will let you here. If not, bring a check as proof.
2) Go to the tower and go to the 9th floor for a nice surprising view.
3) Cafe food is decent and feels so smancy fancy.
4) Enjoy!
author: Amy H.

description:
I will start by saying that I'm not an art expert. So there.

De Young is a good museum to go to at least once. It's about $11.00 admission and will take a little over an hour to get through if you walk at my pace. There were definitely some cool pieces, but others, such as the furniture layouts, just didn't do much for me.

It's in a nice area in the park though. Right outside you can see pretty fun sculptures and hang out with friends.
author: Dani P.

description:
This is a great museum to spend a couple of hours at. They have a very diverse collection and it seems like their rotating shows are great too. Overall, it's small but definitely worth the trip.

First Tues of the month there's free admission! Sold. 

I wandered around amongst the rooms. I loved the paintings. Not so much into all the tribal relics they had, but it was kinda neat to browse. Definitely some weird/interesting things in that area too! 

Really nice little cafe. Lots of vegan and gluten free snacks to choose from. You can grab a glass of wine and sit on their patio if it's a nice day too.

I haven't done the tower yet because I ran out of time, but I heard that's always free so I'll make an attempt to go back sometime when the land is free of Karl the Fog's dirty grasp.
author: Carol M.

description:
Spent a few hours here yesterday, and it's fine for just that.  There were some interesting pieces of art, and some not so interesting.  I much preferred the Legion of Honor's artwork, but again, art is subjective.  

Be forewarned:  again with the "no backpack" rule.  I carry a super small backpack purse, but it was a no go.  I felt sorry for people that had to carry giant backpacks, but the museum does offer a coat or backpack "check," for storage.  

I parked on Lincoln near UCSF and walked the 20 minutes to save the parking fee.  There was street parking for 3 or 4 hours by the museum, but it was all taken.  It's the city!
author: Marie B.

description:
The neighboring Academy of Sciences always seemed to draw larger crowds (maybe because it's more popular with families) for which I'm grateful because I like the de Young Museum more anyways. The tower is the best part of the museum, which is free. You get a 360 degree view of the city, which is amazing on clear sunny days. 

If you want to look at the exhibits, general admission is $10 for adults. They give discounts if you show proof that you took public transportation, which is kinda awesome. It costs $15 extra if you want to check out the special exhibit showing, which I was not interested in. This is definitely the kind of art museum I love touring. With its vast spaciousness and minimalistic setup, I feel so peaceful and zen when walking around.

The de Young Cafe is also a fun place to go afterwards. While their food & beverage selection is not impressive, there is plenty of seating indoors and outdoors to catch up with whoever you came to the museum with or just take a break before heading out to walking around Golden Gate Park again. The de Young Museum is a great place to take out-of-town guests. Though public transportation is always a good choice to get here, there is also a parking structure nearby... or you can always park at a meter in the Sunset District and walk. I'm already reminiscing about my time here!
author: Stefanie C.

description: I enjoyed it very much. Nice views from the observation tower. Seek out the painting of Niagara/horseshoe falls with a double rainbow. Nice art featuring yosemite, too. Sculpture garden looked promising but I was running low on time. I always enjoy furniture exhibits, too. Dunno why. Nice photo exhibit was going on when I visited last month, 1/17. I felt the price was fair. I didn't do the gift shop, except for browsing the one in the towers. Very nice remodel, I've wanted to visit since '05 or '06, hooray for achieving goals.
author: Marin C.

description:
Visiting art museums is one of my favourite things to do. Living in SF, I really, really wish I had better things to say about de Young. 

Let's start with the positives:
- the viewing gallery offers a great view of San Francisco
- it's located in a very beautiful part of Golden Gate Park
- the building itself is quite handsome 

... and that's about all I can think of. 

To be fair, I didn't spend a ton of time in the permanent collection area. The collection of American paintings seems extensive, but I found the arrangement quite hard to navigate. 

Now I will start ranting about my most recent visit, and sadly it's a pretty standard experience I've had with de Young so far. 

The exhibition:  Oscar de la Renta: The Retrospective (a blockbuster exhibition just from the title).

1. Ticket price: $38 with audio guide for a less than 1-hour exhibition, that's more expensive than most European museums. 

2. Getting into the show: On our first try, my friend and I got there at 12:30 pm. We were running a bit short on time, but the lady at ticket counter ensured us that we could finish by 1:30, so we proceeded with the purchase. However, when we got to the entrance the staff said we needed to wait till 1pm to get in. Naturally the first attempt was a failure, but luckily we were allowed to change to tickets for another day. This time, we were again told to wait in line for entrance and all the staff seemed very impatient (maybe due to how popular this exhibition was). But we got in nevertheless. 

3. The curation: This is a super interesting theme and they have some very exciting pieces of work from Oscar de la Renta, but the curation was very odd. Here's why: 
1. In the first room, the dresses and the explanatory signs were not arranged in matching order, which was very confusing. 
2. Some dresses were placed facing away from the audience with the intention of showing off the details on the back. However, in most exhibitions the mannequins would be placed in front of a mirror so people can see the front as well. Well, not de Young (at least not until the last room). 
3. All of the dresses on display were made to measure, therefore they don't always fit the mannequins. In the souvenir book of this exhibition there are photos of clients wearing the dresses and descriptions of the occasions, but these details were lacking in the actual exhibition.
4. One of the rooms was showcasing how the designer loved gardening and was inspired by gardens. There's a gigantic TV showing the views of a garden, but there was no description of where this garden is from whatsoever (we found out it was the designer's garden in the souvenir book)
5. There were some random objects on display to help creating the atmosphere of a theme. For example, in the part where they show the oriental influence on the designer, the curators put a huge Chinese style vase along the dresses. There was an explanatory sign for the vase, but it simply says "borrowed from the mayor's office" (what? why?) without giving more details on which era it's from, or country of origin. Given that this is in a fine art museum, I found it very underwhelming. It'd have been better not to put any signs at all. 

I've been to 4 or 5 exhibitions in de Young, and was disappointed by the curation every single time. Given the ticket price for these shows, I probably won't go back any time soon.
author: Rachel Z.

description: A few entrances on different sides of the building to enter. There are bag checks at every one of them. One rule is that you must carry large bags below waist level, so don't come here if you have a heavy large bag with weak arms or shoulders. General admission is $15, while students get a discount. I'm more of a modern art person, so I didn't enjoy the museum as much as my peer did. There was a textile exhibit, American gallery, African gallery...and that's all I could remember. I regret coming here, but I will say that the staff is extremely friendly. If you're just a wandering tourist like me with no real interest in history or art, I'd suggest the building in front over de Young. But if you do check de Young out, the 9th floor skyline tower closes at 4PM if I remember correctly...that, or 4:30. Definitely check that out if you come here.
author: Irene T.

description: So cool! When I was there they were celebrating some kind of garden festival and many of the works of art were represented by floral arrangements. It is hard to describe, but it was kind of fabulous. I'll post some pictures. On second thought, I have no idea how to post pictures on Yelp. My point is, it was definitely someplace worth visiting.
author: Justin S.

description:
This is a nifty art museum nestled in the beloved Golden Gate Park.

Parking in the park can be a nightmare, but luckily there's an underground parking structure nearby. Be prepared to spend some money on parking pretty much anywhere in the city. I spend 4 hours and 9 minutes here and parking was $22.50. It's a tad more on weekends.

The museum itself is pretty big! I'd suggest taking a lunch break into between the 2 floors of art because you will get tired. I like how they do have ample bench seating throughout the exhibits though. 

You can't visit this place and not go up to to the 9th floor tower (free without admission!) and see the 360 views of the city. It's absolutely beautiful up there. They've got a mini gift shop up there of course too.

Come look at some art!
author: Emily G.

description: My review is not on the museum as a whole, but specifically on the exhibition that is showing now, and through the end of August, the Summer of Love (SF in 1967). The museum is located the Golden Gate park, a treasure for all of us. Parking on the street can be challenging, but we came on a warm Sunday, with the City filled with thousands Marching for Science, and yet, we found nearby parking without much of a hassle. Admission was $25 for this exhibit, but was free for my husband and myself because our friends are members, and with a membership you can bring guests for free (I am going to buy one, looks well worth it). Be careful with backpacks, because the staff makes you take them off and carry by hand. Mine wasn't too heavy, but if it had been, it would have been uncomfortable. The exhibit itself was arranged and organized well, the photos, clothing, video clips, posters, etc were the highlights and they have a great selection. After the exhibit we drove back down through the park and through the Panhandle, where many of the videos and photos were taken, and it was like reliving that era. A great day and great experience!
author: Donna H.

description:
Beryl Sussman was the best tour guide! She really made our trip to the museum special. She is very knowledgeable and gave us so much information on the pieces. It was great to see how passionate she is about the art.

The museum itself is very interesting and has so much to see. I liked how much variety there was. The observation deck is also really cool to see.
author: Erin Z.

description: The rudest staff. Go here if you'd like to have their staff walk behind you for 2h and yell at you for not carrying your backpack correctly. They offer coffee to go, but outside patio is closed and you can't exit through cafe. You can try going out through main entrance but they will again yell at you on your way out and make you actually exit the museum to throw away the coffee in the bin in front of museum. This was the worst museum experience I've ever had. Been to Louvre, Orsay and a lot of other great museums, this one is a joke compared to them. They treat visitors very poorly. I will not recommend this museum to anyone ever again.
author: Ema P.

description:
I didn't know if we'd have time to visit De Young on our last trip to SF. It seemed like a cool place! I'm glad we had time and found a way to get to it. It's situated in the beautiful Golden Gate Park. We took the bus #5, got off, crossed the street and here we were in Golden Gate Park (huge park that hosts other museums, gardens, etc that we'd like to visit some other time).  There are signs everywhere for De Young, we got there in a minute.  The museum's building has a great, modern look to it. 

It took us around 3 hours to visit the permanent collection (didn't have time for the Hockney exhibit) which is wonderful, especially the 2nd floor dedicated to the older civilizations and arts of Africa, Oceania, New Guinea (the most extensive collection we've seen). They have also a great collection of modern art, especially North American. If you want classic art, go to Legion of Honor, if you want modern art, De Young is your destination. 
If you have time, you have to check out the Observation Deck, it's enclosed, an elevator takes you up there. There are stunning views of the city you can enjoy from every angle.

The staff is nice and helpful. Opened Tuesday through Sunday- 9:30 am to 5:15 pm. Admission is $10. $2 off if you show proof that you used public transportation. You can get in for free if you already visited Legion of Honor earlier that day or it's the 1st weekend of the month and you have a Bank of America card.

I really loved this place, I'm so glad we were able to get to it. Another great museum in SF.
author: Jo S.

description: Really enjoyed several hours here on a Saturday morning, pre- screaming kids.  Nice collection in the general admission areas.  Would recommend!
author: Tad H.

description:
A really nice, if bizarrely priced and poorly signed, art museum experience.  The building itself is a veritable work of art, and worth gazing at from various angles - including from the observation tower and from the upper gallery.  It has a really sweet view of most of the city too.  The permanent collection of American art is nicely presented and diverse, and a good value at $10 for adults.  (yes, this includes entry to the observation tower)

What was weirder, and worth preparing for, is the temporary exhibit, parking and signage situations.  The Keith Haring exhibit (Google him, he's famous) was a whopping $29, plus another $7 for an audio guide.  Apparently this institution knows something I don't, because there were massive crowds lining up to see just that, while the permanent collections were almost devoid of visitors.  Or it might be that people had to line up for tickets to ask basic questions like "where is the exhibit entrance and can I buy a ticket separately?" because there were no visible signs indicating entrance location or that you could buy regular tickets at the same counter as the (heavily advertised!) Keith Haring exhibit, for 70% less.

Also, they REALLY don't want you to drive here.  The parking is among the most expensive in the city (over $5 per hour) and they give you a $2 discount (per ticket!) if you can show a muni pass.  If you're going to drive (I'll admit it, I did) the entrance to the underground garage is at 10th Ave and Fulton St.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I am not even a museum person and I love this place.

First of all, the architecture and the design of the building alone is amazing.  Inside the museum, it is divided into various sections with different themes, such as a featured artist, photography, oil paintings, geographic/regional, ethnic, ancient as well as the most contemporary.

Honestly, I don't know art that well, but I'll post some pictures to give you an idea of the diversity and variety of exhibits there.

I was particularly impressed by the glassware exhibits; an amazing parade of glass sculptures in pastel colors, which took my breath away -- a requirement to earn 5 stars in my book.

The museum staff was all courteous, friendly and helpful.  One gentleman in particular, offered to take a picture for both of us and even showed us some "tricks" in photography. 
  
The entire layout of the exhibits was very spacious and comfortable.  Even on a crowded Saturday afternoon in summer, the place does not feel crowded.  You almost always have plenty of personal space around you to enjoy the exhibits.

I don't even like museums and I love this place.  That's awesome!
author: Rob L.

description:
I think I was more interested in the observation tower more than the museum. The elevator to go up to the 9th floor is by the entrance where you purchase admission. It is separate from the whole museum so you want to hit this up first or at the end. You get a 360 view of the whole city. The day was clear and the view was spectacular.

I spent about 1.5 hours walking around the different exhibits. There two levels and it is huge! I'm glad there were bench in some of the rooms so I could take let me feet take a break and just let my eyes wander around. It was very relaxing and quiet.

Show your muni ticket or clipper card for a $2 discount. Admission was just $8 after the discount. The ticket also includes a same-day general admission to the Legion of Honor. I was hoping this was closer (walkable) since I didn't drive here. I passed on this since it was in the opposite direction as I was going. Admission is also free the first Tuesday of every month.
author: Michael C.

description: Very cool art museum to check out! The first time I went I was actually given free admission by a random stranger; I was just sitting outside when a lady asked me if I wanted to check out the exhibit. Apparently her friend was unable to go, so she asked if I wanted to go with her. Only in San Francisco! It was a pretty cool exhibit, and I could spend hours checking things out inside. The second time I went I saw the Keith Haring exhibit which was pretty cool as well!
author: Kenny L.

description:
I'm a fan. I have been to the DeYoung many times throughout the years. Usually come for a special exhibit and then explore the main galleries if we have time. 

It is a beautiful museum, well kept and they bring in a lot of great exhibits. Watch the online calendar for whats going on before you go. The first Tuesday of the Month is Free admission and the first full weekend of the month is free to BofA card holders. Call ahead to see if the special exhibit is included. I talk to someone who said that the Tuesday's included the special exhibit but the BofA deal didn't so just call and be sure. 

The downside is really the crowd. It can get very busy during the end of an exhibit. I strongly suggest buying tickets early online and going earlier in the day.
author: Sara P.

description:
I got to see the girl with the pearl earring! 

My brother is a huge Rembrandt fan. Visited the museum with him one evening and really learned a lot about Rembrandt and his paintings from him. This museum is gorgeous and located in a huge park. It's an awesome exhibit with great paintings and sculptures. You have got to have a passion for art to really enjoy the museum or else everything will just be senseless. Be sure to take the elevators up to the ninth floor at the tower for a great view of the city. 

If you see the blown glass art called "It's Still Alive" - it's a my favorite.
author: Mei W.

description:
Dear De Young,

Next time you decide to close at 4pm on a Friday, it'd be lovely if it were posted on the website!   And not some obscure link you'd have to click on, we later found out.  

And Elisa (sp?) at the front counter who gave us our tickets, please try and not be so snarky to people who are clearly upset that they have exactly 15 minutes to see a show they've been planing for a month.  "Have fun!" in your chirpy voice surely was the wrong attitude.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
It has been almost two years since I have written an update on the deYoung! I went there today because it was first free weekend on Bank of America. However, the general admission does not cover the special exhibitions. I used to be a member, had to give it up because of lack of funds. (Temporary condition for the time being.) I also take advantage of the first free Tuesday of the month as well at the Fine Arts Museum of San Francisco aka the deYoung and the Legion of Honor. 

The last time I was here at the deYoung was for the "William S. Paley: A Taste of Modernism exhibition and the "Rudolf Nureyev: A Life in Dance." I successfully passed my online modern art history class; much of it was inspired by visiting the Modernism at the deYoung. Much of the art that I read about and was discussed on the forum boards was featured in the exhibition. Much of Picasso's works were featured here at the deYoung; was quite surprised that Mr. Paley (the head of CBS) owned much of Picasso's work, especially the cubism and the synthetic cubism. I was also surprised to see Renoir, Matisse, Cezzane, Gaughin, and Derain, to name so many.

I saw the Rudolf Nureyev exhibition last time I was here; this exhibition was the principal reason I made a return visit today.  I am taking another humanities class and one of the required assignments/elements is to do a write-up of a museum exhibition or a theatrical performance. So I figure, combine the two arts by writing about the exhibitions dedicated to one the premier male ballet dancers who devoted his whole life to the art and craft of ballet as a dancer, choreographer, director, producer, actor, and visionary. He made the role of the male ballet dancer more than just a partner, frame, and accessory to the ballerina. Other than Baryshnikov (who forged his own path), no other male ballet danseur comes to mind who has made the impact that Nureyev has in the world of ballet.

I have had the pleasure of seeing Nureyev dance while he was still alive. Before he was famous in London when I was a sprog, aged ten in one of those full-length ballets. I remember he was very, very funny.  Ballet is supposed to be a very serious craft, and here he was making the audience laugh. I saw him dance with Natalia Makarova in SF; do not recall if it was "Giselle" or "Swan Lake." (I think it was "Giselle.")  And the last time, was as a guest artist with The Royal Ballet of Canada. (Still have the program in my archives.)

I say go see "Rudolf Nureyev: A Life in Dance" before it closes; last day is February 17. 

All I know for sure is, there is nobody like Rudolf Nureyev these days who lived to dance and danced as long as he lived. Definitely one of a kind.

Yelp Update #1 for 2013.
author: Chiara A.

description:
Please note, my review is only for the free section of the museum. With that said, let's begin.

Now having lived just a few blocks down, I've been here only several of times, usually with buddies from out of town. I also have an Academy of Sciences membership so I make my photography session include sights from this museum as well. What's nice is that more than half the museum is free to enter by non members.

One particular area of interest is the tower with it's astonishing views. I remember the first time coming here and finding out about this awesome free section. It was really clean and had glass windows all around. You can see treasure island and many other awesome sights of SF from up there. It sure beats driving through twin peaks just to get to the top and freeze our bums off.

The rest of the museum was also pretty interesting if you're into the historic art pieces. They didn't have too much abstract art work but there will still be a very large array of historic items worth checking out.

Minus one star for making me hold my backpack in my hand in areas of the museum where there were absolutely no art pieces around. I understand they don't want people knocking things over but having to hold my backpack throughout the entire museum sucked...
author: Ced C.

description:
I came on a weekday afternoon and found a four hour parking spot walking distance from de Young within Golden Gate Park. There's plenty of free parking in Golden Gate Park so don't bother paying to park in the garage. I love the trees and fountains in front of this museum. This museum faces the California Academy of Sciences. 

I'm a huge fan of art and walking through this museum was relaxing and fun. Admission is $10 and includes admission to the Legion of Honor about two miles away. The museum has two floors and there is plenty to see including some well-known artists like Chihuly. 

Make sure not to miss the observatory of the ninth floor for some great views of San Francisco! This part of the museum is free so you can go up there any time.
author: Karen L.

description: Worst experience at a museum ever! The docents are suppose to be helpful and informative but the docents at this museum did nothing but humiliate and harass us. It is so awkward walking through a museum and hearing the docents openly ridicule the guests. I felt like I was being stalked and intimidated by the docents I have never felt so uncomfortable in a museum in my life. We have been to many other museums in San Francisco and they have always been enjoyable and happy experiences but after leaving the de Young museum I felt embarrassed and a bit queasy. Save your time and money and go to better museums who employ polite and knowledgeable staff. I recommend trying the moma or the asian art museum.
author: Tess M.

description: Love this museum....came when Versace had a show so it was crazy packed. Probably best not to come when they have events if you don't like crowds. The showings at this museum is always is beautiful and I love the architecture of the building. Definitely recommend this place if you're an art lover. Parking can be tough, but if you don't mind the walk you can park in sunset district and walk through the park. It's a nice walk.
author: Sally G.

description:
I went to this museum with my family today and I was disappointed. The woman at the front desk she was so rude and very unwelcoming. She didn't care to explain anything or give us a map, or ask us how our day was. She basically gave us our tickets and didn't say anything else. I have to say though the museum is a reasonable amount to get in, but the staff could use improvement. Overall, my experience here was satisfied, but most likely, I won't return. 
The outside area was very nice and the food was good! I liked it better than the museum. The museum has many different items ranging from the Arts and Crafts Movement to the Olmecs. 
But nothing worth jumping up and down for.
author: Gen D.

description:
My younger daughter and I love to spend mother daughter date at the de Young museum. We never tire of visiting our favorite exhibits. 

The most memorable exhibit for the both of us this year? Jean Paul Gautier. It was an additional fee for certain membership levels and day ticket folks, but it was worth it.  

As a native San Franciscan, we do the museum our own way - the way that works for us. We buy an annual membership. We don't worry if we visit enough to cover the really affordable cost because we are happy to support this fine institution. 

A membership helps with the one thing I am most organized with. 

Time. 

We can go for a few hours or go for a whole day and not worry about paying or getting our moneys worth. Membership has its privileges - check them out online! 

When we spend the day, we like to pack a lunch. The grounds are stunning and a great place to have a leisurely picnic. 

Parking. Ok, the Concourse can be a little overwhelming for a newbie. Just pull in on Fulton Street (if you are coming from 19th Ave like I do) and follow the signs. If there are no spaces, you will have a wait until security lets you in. No worries, just turn your car off and hang out. Once you are allowed in, drive slow and keep driving until you get to the floor of parking that is also the entrance to the museum. It really can't get any easier! You pay at the kiosk before you leave... that's it! 

I love the deYoung museum because it is a wonderful contribution to San Francisco but aside from that? 

It affords me quality one on one time with my younger daughter indulging in something we both have in common.
author: Jennifer C P.

description: At last!  A modern art museum that doesn't suck!  In fact, I really enjoyed the works here and wound up having a great time both times I visited.  Come at the right time, there are also concerts.  It's truly a great museum to visit even if you don't like modern art.  Admission is $10 but if you have the San Francisco City Pass, it's included so definitely check it out.
author: Anthony G.

description: Beautiful museum in a beautiful park with an unreal view at the observation deck. If that doesn't deserve five stars then I don't know what does.
author: Jake B.

description: Beautiful place, beautiful pieces but staff was REALLY rude! I'm 4'11 I'm not going to steal a 12X12 canvas. Geeez! Even with glasses I have a hard time seeing, I didn't pass their tape on the floor and I still got BARKED at! Then they followed me. I noticed they were very rude to people with children as well. They need a better system in place in regards to entry instead of these angry women asking to see my entry sticker every step I take. Also, I love and respect the LGBT community but I dislike the all gender bathrooms! I just left to use a street bathroom instead. LGBT i trust, i don't mind but i will not to in a stall with huge gaps with regular sometimes creepy men! Uh no! You should make 3 bathrooms, ladies, men, and all gender. Will not be going back to this place. My three stars are for the art.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Interested in fashion?
Introducing:The Fashion World of Jean Paul Gaultier: From the Sidewalk to the Catwalk...

Who's Jean Paul Gaultier? only one of the best men designers of the century.  A French  haute couture fashion expertise, who never received formal training as a designer. JPG's exhibit at de Young museum features his artistic clothing design. His visions are creative and one of a kind. Not my flavor, but found interesting for each display. Most of the mannequins have projected eyes that come to life as if they are real. Their lips move and speak in french or either sing. Creepy but its a trip! Want to take a field trip into fashion? highly recommended to visit.
author: Kathy V.

description: One of my favorite art museums. Amazing exhibits, beautiful grounds and the food in the cafe is delicious!
author: Tarah L.

description: What is it with the de Young. They have bizarrely strict rules. I was there today, walking in to the outside cafe area at the side of the museum and one of the guards told me I couldn't have my young daughter (2yrs) on my shoulders in case she fell off, they'd be liable. On a separate occasion we were in really early before almost anyone else was there and my daughter sat on the steps behind where the ticket desks are. A different guard told her I'd need to get her up as others could be coming down. Like I wouldn't have done that if there were others. Another occasion, yes another one, a member of staff barked at my two year old for being about a meter from one of the guard rails around a picture, even though I had my arms around her waist. Utterly bizarre over reactions on each occasion. Totally unwelcoming, really old fashioned. Most of the really good world class museums and galleries realized a few decades ago that democratizing access, creating a welcoming environment, not being stupid ass hats to guests who are t doing anything remotely wrong, is actually not only good for business but is good for arts in the society. Seems like the de young hasn't caught on yet.
author: Chris M.

description: What a disappointment! Same room of psychedelic music posters repeated over and over in five rooms! A few good photos, and descriptions of the time, but so much missing! No recordings of the live music of the era and video of the events. The literary content did not even include The Electric Cool-Aid Acid Test, On the Road, or Hunter Thompson's popularizations. No author readings or interviews! No mention of Rolling Stone magazine! So sorry, but not worth the fare! Go to Woodstock Festival Museum at Yasgar's Farm in Bethel Woods.
author: Ron F.

description:
Let me state up front, I am not much of a fan of modernist art.  So, being that this museum mostly has such type of art, I was not as fascinated in this museum as I was in the Legion of Honor.  However, I came for the Jewel City exhibit.  I have wanted to see this exhibit about the SF World's Fair from the Victorian era.  I have read books about the one held in Chicago and as a kid recall going to the Palace of Fine Arts where the Exploratorium use to be.  So yes, I was very excited about going to this museum.  

But sadly, I was disappointed with the exhibit.  I expected to see more.  It was just one small room with a few sculptures and paintings.  Perhaps if my boyfriend and I paid $8 for the guided tour headphones it would have been more fascinating but we did not want to pay that!  The only thing that I truly enjoyed  about this museum was going to the top floor and seeing the view of San Francisco.  It was truly amazing as you can see all of Golden Gate Park with some of the Golden Gate Bridge in a distance! 

Pros:
-great view of Golden Gate Park and more from the top floor of the de Young  
-lots to see but mostly Modernist art
-interesting temporary exhibits like the Jewel City
-fascinating architectural building -sort of built like an upside down triangle with the largest level being on the top (the viewing area)
-great way to learn about cultures and their influence in the artworld

Cons:
-gift shop is pricey
-you need to be a fan of modern/contemporary art overall to really enjoy yourself here (I prefer the Legion of Honor where the art is more focused on realism, detailed and historical)
-temporary exhibits may not be as great as expected
author: Irene S.

description: Update: Decided to go back to the museum.  As my child and I walked to the bathroom I noticed the oddly calm, pleasant and normal expressions on everyone's faces as they were leaving the restrooms.  This was a very different vibe from our last visit.  So HAPPY to say they changed the bathrooms back to traditional women's and men's restrooms.  Thank you for listening to our reasonable safety concerns and hoping the museum will put the financial resources necessary into any future all gender restroom changes to allow for appropriate safety measures.
author: I N.

description:
Lovely building, great setup, large enough to kill a few hours. The Keith Haring exhibit was amazing. One of my favorite exhibitions in any museum, ever.

Except the museum "security" caught me plugging my phone in, while in the lobby, to have a charge so I could take pictures in the museum, and was very rude to me about it. Treated me like a criminal. Rude and snarky. Totally unnecessary. Guess who WON'T be donating to de Young again?
author: Sean B.

description:
Regular exhibits are good, but not great. 3 Stars. But the special exhibits can be awesome( Add a star). The museum is definitely worth a visit, especially a first visit year round. If you can, I would avoid the weekends and bringing toddlers not in a stroller.

The De Young is in Golden Gate Park, which is worth a visit, and shares a massive underground parking garage with the California Academy of Science, which is marvelous and a delight for children. 

Hours:
Tuesdays-Sundays
9:30 am-5:15 pm

Fridays
9:30 am-8:45 pm
March 28-November 28

Adult Tickets: $10
Student / Youth: $6

I would agree with most people, especially locals, that the De Young Museum is an architectural atrocity, with fake fault line at the main entrance a joke. But the 360 degree view from the tower is spectacular.
author: David S.

description: Can't complain at all given their very kind participation in free days each month... Enjoyed it greatly and found very convenient street parking around the block. The cafe is a little odd -- everyone was asking the same question upon entrance which is "do we order up front or is it table service"? Answer: order up front.
author: Chris B.

description:
Honestly, I am kinda disappointed by the deYoung and don't enjoy this museum as much as others in the bay. For some reason, I thought this place would be bigger considering how it looks from the outside. I find the collections to be kind of lack luster and not too memorable to me overall.
