I thought the east coast had the market cornered on top-notch museums but, since that visit to the de Young, I stand corrected.
author: Courtney S.

description:
I cannot believe I have not written a review of the de Young until now. This is craziness as it is by far one of my favorite places in San Francisco. 

The building fascinates me. Yeah sure the exhibits are amazing and between the current Impressionist show to King Tut they pull in some fantastic installations. But the building is just captivating. I highly recommend checking out the museum.  

Here are a few suggestions. 

1. On a sunny day bring a bag lunch and sit outside by the water feature (free) and people watch and admire the building.

2. Check out the views at the top of the tower. Amazing and worth the sometimes long wait.

3. Check out the special exhibits and have lunch in the cafe. If nice sit out side and just enjoy it. 

This place rocks!
author: Ryan B.

description:
I'm still a die-hard fan of San Francisco museums in general.  

However, the Tut exhibit at the DeYoung was really pushing the limits of false advertising.  There was indeed a sarcophagus there, but it was not our man Tut.  NO Tut sarcophagus?  That's just ri-donk-u-lous.  (Apparently, the Tut sarcophagus is no longer allowed to leave Egypt.)

Not to say the exhibit wasn't impressive.  It was really quite amazing to see the artifacts they had there, all preserved so delicately, perfectly maintained and in most cases glistening in the professional installation lighting.  

But the advertising is pretty misleading.  You won't see a big ol' Tut.  Instead you'll see a little "Honey, I Shrunk the Boy King Tut" mini sarcophagus there.  Not nearly as impressive as what is expected after paying such a hefty price for tickets.

The cost of a ticket for members was lowered to $22.50, which seemed high for an exhibit (IMHO).  I cringed when I told my class about it because I knew my students and their families could not afford it.  (Non-members: child ticket is $16.50, adults are $32.50)

To advertise an awesome exhibit like Tut and make the price so unreachable to so many students in San Francisco seems a tad thoughtless.  I know for a fact that the majority of kids in my entire school did not get to go, which makes me frown.

Another thing that makes me frown...the impossibly large crowds of hot, sweaty people.  Being nearly 9 months pregnant at the time of our tour, I was shoved, cut in front of, denied a seat on the many benches, and basically given no slack at all as my ankles began to swell and my head became light.  By the time we left the cramped quarters of the exhibit, I was nearly passing out from the sheer effort of getting through the hoards.  They really packed the people in...and apparently, quite a few %#*@$, too.

Carrying the miracle of life in your body really gets you NO perks anymore, does it?  Geez.
author: Kristina R.

description:
Recently came here for the impressionist exhibition and I was blown away by the pieces we saw. We will be returning for the Van Gogh in Sept. I am extremely sad I missed King Tut because I made the mistake of coming on a Tuesday last time. Argh!

My two gripes are the poor presentation for the exhibition entrance and the overall permanent collection. The only indication of where to go for the Impressionist exhibition was the roped queue which didn't have a lot of people standing in). There should have been a sign and lots of people were clearly confused as to where to get in. 

I was a little disappointed in some of the pieces in the permanent collection, but it's difficult to be wowed by a gold leafed Our Lady of Guadalupe and 50 cent saint candles after seeing the 15 foot Birth of Venus  and Whistler's Mother. And the curator needs to spend some time erecting plaques for the marble sculptures. I saw a beautiful piece and didn't know who created it or what is was called. 

Oh and par for the course at any museum is the food is way overpriced.
author: El P.

description:
The Chihuly exhibit was an amazing display of vibrant colorful glass sculptures, some looking as if they were defying gravity.  I was amazed, not only by the designs and colors, but at the size of some of the pieces.  Huge!

The permanent exhibits were also very interesting.  The observation tower had an awesome view!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
The California Institute of Science had a line that was far to long, so we headed over to the De Young Museum instead. This was a great indoor attraction to explore.
I do wish they had better descriptions of the 'special exhibits' at the entrance. It was really hard to decide between getting a regular admissions or tickets to both. The ticket lady wasn't helpful. We had limited time, so we went cheap, and stuck to the regular tickets.  I got in for free thanks to Bank of America. They gave Charlotte a student discount, so it was 6 bucks for her. Not a bad price to wander around the exhibits. 
The place is pretty cool, but it is first and foremost an art museum. Considering the dearth of historical items they have displayed, this is really unfortunate. There is so much history in here, but basically no information on any of it. Indonesian and african masks, artwork of the founding fathers, furniture galore... pretty to look at, but a little more effort at educating the public about the origins would have been appreciated.

There is a really cool view from the top floor. There you will also find one of the many many gift shops that are all over this place. yay for consumerism!
author: David M.

description:
I really enjoy the friday night events at the De Young; when the Friday night music starts up; it is a must see. Relevant propulsive world music, cool vibe and easy access make this a fav.   Libations are available by the seats. Chardonnay is lively, with a clean finish.
Get the deal, purchase a membership at the Asian Art musuem and you get access to other venues like here.Oh, the restaurant has a nice organic green salad and the chardonnay is quite decent. yes quite decent.
author: Bert K.

description:
I'm so glad my friend suggested we go check out the Chihuly exhibit! How he works with glass is amazing! You probably get through the whole exhibit in about 30-40 minutes. One of the pictures I took is now the wallpaper of my monitor. So pretty!

Buy your tickets online beforehand cuz they'll sell out. Some of my friends tried to get tickets an hour before an entrance time and they were all sold out on a Sunday afternoon.
author: Char L.

description:
I'm not the biggest fan of museums, so when an art museum gets a positive review from me, I think it's pretty good.  The entrance fee is VERY reasonable, and I got discounts for:

1) being a student (bring your student ID card)
2) using public transportation to get there (show your bus ticket)

I don't remember for sure, but I'm sure there are discounts for children and senior citizens as well. 

The artwork displayed here is wide and varied.  There are some older pieces, and there are some very modern pieces too, some having been completed in the 2000's.  The information provided next to each piece is informative.  

The museum itself is also beautiful, modern and well-maintained.
author: Rona H.

description: My family and I always love going to the De Young. My kids especially love going to the observation deck, where you can see spectacular 360 degree views of the city. We also love their Friday night events.
author: Rex G.

description:
De Young is a nice museum, the building is great, and there are lots of exhibits to see. Some exhibits are not permanent so I would go back over and over.

Keep an eye out for discount tickets using you Bank of America, and American Express card. 

My recent visit was to see the Tutankhamun exhibit and I enjoyed it very much. I thought it is worth paying for the audio headset too! Lots of info from the audio tour. 

You can use this discount code and get 20% off:  TUTCLOVER , it is good till March 28, 2010.
author: Florence W.

description: The de Young is an excellent art museum located right in the center of Golden Gate Park.  The building itself is impressive, but I've also seen large Impressionist collections on loan from the Orsay, and a terrific exhibition dedicated to Jean-Paul Gaultier.  I recommend checking the list of current exhibits before you go, and keep in mind that some of the popular ones require a reservation in advance.
author: Dan W.

description:
This is for the King Tut Exhibit - 

This was my first trip to the De Young Museum and I must say it's a great location in the Golden Gate Park.  I love Golden Gate Park and you can spend the day walking, biking while visiting the museum. However, I was VERY DISAPPOINTED with the King Tut exhibit given the $35 ticket for a Sat. I agree with other reviews in that an overwhelming majority of the exhibit is about Tut's lineage, grandmother, grandfather, father, wife. Where's the stuff about King Tut? Where's the mummy wrapped in white bandages??? haahaa, just being a little sarcastic. To be serious, the items on display were nothing to awe about. I do recognize the significance of discovering these treasures and things but I feel the folks that run this held out on us or were too afraid to ship the 'good stuff' over to the US or something, I don't know. 

In any case, everything displayed was much smaller than I anticipated. It also gets pretty repetitious. I mean, the same staff, sword, coffin, headrests, etc get shown in every room it seems. 

My verdict is NO on TUT.
author: Dai T.

description:
I'm glad I took part day off from work to see the Chihuly exhibit.  

They have an awesome *free* view of The City  from their observation tower - check it out, the views make you fall in love with San Francisco, especially on a sunny day!
author: Cathy K.

description:
LAME!

I became a member because I figured, I should support the local establishments. Plus, there's the member discount on stuff..

I wanted to attend the Tut exhibit that's going on (to see what they're doing with my membership dues, I guess). Went to their site: no tickets for Sunday. WTF? Wow, it must really be popular. On a whim, I clicked on the ticketmaster link, and presto! Tickets are available.

Wait a minute: how can membership tickets to Tut not be available, but full price tickets are available? Doesn't compute. Most other places that I've been to just give you a discount for being a member. 

Turns out, there's a separate pool of tickets for members (with discount). They don't say how big this pool is (it could just be 1 ticket for all I know). But if they run out of member tickets, you have to pay full price. That is so lame!! Why treat your members like this? Why not just give them a discount, and be done with it?

Membership is also supposed to get you discounts at the gift shop. Are these discounts also limited to a few items??

This is so lame. The management seems to reek of arrogance with this attitude. Once my membership expires, I won't be renewing it.
author: A J.

description: It's a minimalist but interesting building containing both modern and traditional art works. I went in a sunny day and the view from the top floor was fantastic. The staffs there were pretty nice too. They gave me sufficient directions about how to explore the building and the exhibitions.
author: Cuting H.

description: Damn this place is cool. I practically had to drag my wife here because she hates museums, but I bragged about the tower and how cool the view would be and she obliged. The tower is FREE to access, so you don't necessarily have to visit the art exhibits if you want a stellar view. The view from up here is panoramic bliss: perfect for photos. You can see the hills, the city, the gardens below, it's just fantastic. We got some amazing shots up here and you can't beat the "price" of free. You can get student discounts here if you bring an ID, so bust out those old college IDs! Definitely want to come back if there's a cool exhibit, but they are rather pricey. I believe you pay per exhibit. Definitely come for the tower and come for the view.
author: Kerry B.

description: Only reviewing the Jean Paul Gaultier exhibit.  Amazing.  Being able to see, within inches and without glass, his amazing gowns and corsets and everything else was fantastic. What a great exhibit.  If you even like fashion a little, go see this.  I spent two hours just in this exhibit. Really well done.
author: Ginger w.

description:
You see, my baby boo has the surveilance abilities of a California Condor; whenever there is a bargain, clearance, free day or twofer in the museum-going world, she's on it. It was the twofer 'twas brought us here a week and a half ago, and it got us access to the entire museum. Just a note; for a limited time, anybody with a Bank of America card can get in here completely free, although I believe the Venetian exhibit might be over and on its way back to Austria.

Two words: Soup Urb. SUPERB. While the Venetian Masters exhibit was overpopulated, it was still a treasure to behold. However, what most grabbed my attention here was the exhibits showcasing Papua New Guinean historical and cultural artifacts, connected to the African arts area. When you step in, you almost feel like you're in a museum that was erected at the site of the "Lord of the Flies" plane crash. Old regalia and a historical narrative on that area of the world was really eye-opening, especially since most of the Western World never has any exposure to that part of the world. The next department over, a gallery devoted to American art, was also really beautiful. This is probably the part of the museum, that, if thus far you've been a little rattled out of your cage by the unconventionality of modern art, then you'd be treated to something that is conventionally easy to understand and easy on the eyes.

So much to see here. A huge plus was the Chinese ceramics area. San Francisco does it again with world class museums. A must go.
author: Davey R.

description:
TUTANKHAMUN AND THE GOLDEN AGE OF THE PHARAOHS 

http://www.tutsanfrancisco.org/ 

"Look with wonder at that which is before you." 
-- Florence Scovel Shinn 

I saw a visiting Tut exhibit at the de Young 30 years ago, and the main resident exhibit at the Cairo Museum 17 years ago. It was great to come face to face with the Boy King one more time. 

We visited on a Monday afternoon, when the de Young was closed, but the Egyptian exhibit was open. $27.50 each for admission, plus another $7 for the audio tour wand, and we were in. The entrance to the exhibit evoked a Disney ride, but once we were in the gallery we were able to examine every piece at our leisure. 

Look, they're not going to bring the Pyramids of Giza and put them in the basement. It's best to appreciate what they decided to bring over this time. 

Like life-size statues of the kings and queens of this New Kingdom dynasty. The amazing story of Akhenaten, who brought monotheism to Egypt.  The dramatic way in which Tutankhaten restored the old religion, the old temples and the old priests, renaming himself Tutankhamun, only to die suddenly and mysteriously (nobody at the exhibit mentioned the controversial reports of neck wounds), without heirs, at 19. 

Like the incredible detail in the jewelry, the ushabti, the furniture, and the other funerary artifacts. Yes, these are the grave goods from a royal tomb 3,331 years old. In perfect condition. That alone should be cause for amazement. 

Maybe the interior coffins weren't there, much to some other viewers' chagrin. But the exhibit team did bring out an outer sarcophagus, completely covered in gold, with such detailed metalwork that each hieroglyph is clearly readable, each species of bird distinguishable. 

The "meteorite glass" scarab, and the mystery of the fused desert sand that went into it, is precious. The oldest known metal hinges on a jewelry box, look like they could have been machine tooled today. 

It's enough to make you realize that the ancient civilizations were peopled by men and women who were every bit as artistic, every bit as skilled, every bit as ingenious, as you and I today. Maybe even more so. 

This exhibit will be open through March 28, 2010. I highly recommend it.
author: David D.

description: Outstanding views from the free observation/gift shopt area.  Excellent museum overall.  Cafe is nice too.
author: April M.

description:
Rude, power-tripping security guards and so-so exhibitions. 

Upon entering, a chest-puffed-out guard demanded that I open my purse for inspection. Now, I understand that this search is mandatory, but the attitude that I received was not warranted. After sticking a finger in my purse and shuffling through it, the guard pulled out my Hershey's bar and rudely demanded that I leave it at the counter (no food was allowed inside.) Trying to laugh it off, I gently snatched the chocolate back. The guard merely blinked back at me. After a 10 second pause, he mumbled a stone-faced "just kidding" and then proceeded to tell us to move out of line. WTF?

I attended the Yves Saint Laurent exhibit, which was poorly organized and contained a rather sparse collection of models. As I was walking in (and the exalted inventor of the smoking suit rolling in his grave), I saw a sign that read "No photographs except for special exhibitions." Great! I pulled out my camera and zeroed in on a fantastical YSL creation. 

Within seconds, another dipsh!t security guard appeared to tell us that "Cameras are only allowed with no flash." Fine! I turned off the flash and repositioned my camera for another shot. No sooner than the snap, the same guard reappeared to chastise me:

"WHAT DID I JUST SAY? NO CAMERAS ALLOWED!"

Well...WTF? If you're into security guards who thrive off confrontation and power trips, the De Young is perfect for you. If not: run the other way!
author: Emily O.

description:
The de Young is a world-class museum.  We have been members since it opened, and we have regularly returned to visit the established collection. The extensive collection of Polynesian art alone is well worth a visit to the museum. 

In addition they have fantastic special exhibits. We just finished viewing the exhibits for early-Impressionism and Impressionism that were on loan to the museum, and we were blown away.

If you think that you will visit the museum with any frequency, I highly encourage you to become a member. You get fantastic discounts on the special exhibits (essentially, they're free) as well as free admission to the regular exhibits. You only need to see one or two of the special exhibits to make up for the membership fee.
author: Brian M.

description:
Their security people like to make others look stupid. Period. I was with two of my friends and were on a outting to take pictures around that area. I had to use the restrooms along with them. I didn't carry a tripod but my friends did. As i walk through their security gates they check my bags with my camera gear in it. They let me go in. My friends stood outside a few feet away and i mentioned to them that they could come inside too. The security said "They can come inside." So i signal to my friends they could also get inside. They were holding their tripods in their hands as they walked towards security and they stopped then and said...you can't come in with your tripods...
SSSSOOOOOO...why did they say they could come in when they were holding their tripods and you can obviously see that? So they made me and my friends look dumb. All they had to do is look at me and say..hey..your friends can't come in because they have tripods. I think the security guards at the entrance point do that because they feel the authority.  
GET A REAL SECURITY JOB! I've worked at the San Jose Arena doing rap, rock, sports, etc. where you have to deal with fights, drunks, and everything you can name. If you want to feel authority, go start there and lets see if you can last one day.
author: Nasser D.

description: I was here again back in February, and it was *totally* boring.  And the security so tight (because we didn't look 'normal', so we were totally followed the whole time) that it was stifling.  Meh.
author: Missy W.

description:
Friday Nights at the De Young is one of my favorite things to do! It's free and fun. You get to see some art, hear music (often a local band), and sip a glass of wine. A great night with friends or out-of-town guests.

And the view from the observatory is amazing.
author: Christina B.

description:
My review is for the featured Tut exhibit right now - it's not really a Tut exhibit it's a few sculptures and items from his lifetime.

The Deyoung in general gets 5 stars except for misleading people by calling this exhibit Tut and charging so much for nothing.  Honestly I would have gone to the Academy of science on friday except I really wanted a chance to see King Tut problem is he was not there neither was his burial chamber there were like 3 items at the end in which he was buried with it was really dissappointing.  So if you go just do the regular exhibits they are much more worth being in a crowded room with not as much as expected they should have named the exhibit something closer to what it was and not mislead people.
author: Nirea S.

description:
This review only applies to the current King Tut exhibit.

Ok, so I've been 99.99% obsessed with Egypt since the time I was 10. I know all the Egyptian gods and pharoahs.I have dressed up like Cleopatra for the past 5 Halloweens. I am secretly in love with Zahi Hawass.  BUT, I had a hard time dealing with this King Tut exhibit. 

The items selected and shown were great. But, the exhibit was SO overcrowded, it was impossible to enjoy. At every turn there were children pushing past me or the gridlock of wheelchairs and lost tourists. The groups they allow into the exhibit are far too large... and the tour experience suffers. I walked past entire rooms just to get breathing room from the crowds. We have memberships at the De Young, so we at least we get a few breaks in regards to lines and waits. It did not help much.

The information in the exhibit is limited. The audio tour does not add as much as I had hoped. The written explanations and histories of artifacts are bare bones. I feel as if I learned nothing more during this visit than the smell of ripe human flesh in uncomfortably close proximity. And, the general public stinks.

I give 2.3 stars for the effort to bring egyptian artifacts to the De Young and the hope that better planning is to come. Please don't crowd us.
author: Bri B.

description:
I stopped here as part of a SF bus tour. It wasn't on my radar but it was a fascinating visit.

I only went around the free parts as it was a relatively short stop. I liked the crack in the floor from the previous big earthquake.

The guide told us about the lift to the free viewing gallery on the 9th floor. This gave a nice view of SF town.

Some of the exhibitions looked interesting but no time to visit on this occasion.
author: Yee Gan O.

description: The collection here is African/Oceanic/American art, with some contemporary art as well.  This is what I tend to skip over at a more encyclopedic museum, so it was fun to make myself take the time to learn more about those things, and the permanent exhibits had plenty of interesting pieces.  The temporary exhibits were perhaps even more impressive, and you can't forget about going to the top of the tower for 360 view of the city.  I just wish the outside of the museum wasn't so cold and uninviting.
author: Mike W.

description: Always great.  Last June my daughter and I saw the Jean-Paul Gaultier exhibit, very entertaining.
author: Julianne W.

description:
Before I entered into the King Tut exhibit, I was in San Francisco. 

By the time we entered the exhibit, the date was 1230BC-1200BC. I was sitting next to king tutankhamun and marveling at ALL THE GOLD AND THE GLITTER OMG SPARKLY.

He also told me over and over, his name is pronounced:

"TOOT-tan-kah-moon. Silly slave, fetch me my ankh staff and flail. I shall restore the faith of the people"

I left the exhibit wondering where I put my papyrus for taking down his orders and how I got home from the desert. See, I learned something.
author: Alfred Y.

description:
The Tut exhibit was OK, but not worth $32.50. The advertising and media coverage hyped it up, but in reality it left a lot to be desired. As I went through each room of the exhibit, I kept hoping for the "OMG MONEY SHOT" moment but it never happened.

Also, I wasn't too happy about being herded like cows in two long queues, but hey, they've got to control the masses somehow.
author: Rich L.

description:
Came here for the King Tut exhibit. I guess that's my fault for being dumb and not reading right, but it's so misleading, just as everyone else says. King Tut isn't there. Here's how it goes:

You start off by watching a 90-second introductory video on King Tut then once permitted, go through different rooms that all have very beautiful and interesting artifacts and ancientttt items. It's nice! Very nice. Dimly lit, some rooms have videos that talk about ancient life and times of King Tut. Everything is about King Tut basically! It's extremely crowded though. You'd think after all the waiting, it wouldn't be so packed. It'll take you a while to go to see every artifact and exhibit because of how many people there are in that cave. I was thrilled, however, to see the tomb of King Tut's grandmother or whoever she was. It was big, shiny, and really thrilling. I could NOT wait until King Tut, yeah?! So I was going to the last room and what the hell did I see? A cheap ass photo of King Tut on a plastic piece of shit. WOW GG King Tut exhibit. I mean...if you're going to have a picture and let me down, can't it at least be in COLOR?! Or a fucking hologram. Paying 27.00 for a ticket to see a black and white photo? I would have had the same damn museum experience searching photos through Google images. Room after room and the finale is a platform with a photo. Nice. I think the most exciting thing in that last room, is King Tut's dagger and the jewelry. So look for that.

It is crowdeddddd. So if you want to make the most out of your money, you might consider purchasing  an audio tour for an extra 7 or so to save you some time because it is a bit hard to make way to read the descriptions on each exhibit. But bring a wetnap or something because it's similar to a telephone device...that shit is on everyone's ears.
author: Megan C.

description:
The FREE friday night  at the de Young, is excellent. I actually went a few weeks ago at the opening, There was a great crowd in a fun atmosphere. We had thought about going early to get in line, but we ended up there around 6:30pm. Perfect time to go, less people are walking around the art, most people were around the live music and wine. 

We were able to see most of the art work, you have to have tickets for the major feature downstairs. However, it was worth, being a grad student I try to take advantage of these free admissions. 

Fun place for a date, with the family, with a group of friends or even alone. 

-JF
author: Jenna F.

description:
This is a special museum. The first time I came here, which was in 2006, I was really excited about a collection that combined contemporary art, folk art and applied art from different parts of the world, and painting from the first half of American history. It almost exoticizes painting and "the fine arts" by featuring paintings from when the medium was still developing in America while making the work from the southern hemispheres and Native American societies that is usually exoticized feel like the mainstream tradition of the world's art. 

On a recent visit, in September, I didn't enjoy myself as much. Maybe it was because the composition of the collection was less of a surprise or a novelty, or maybe it was because some of my favorite pieces had been rotated out of the permanent display. One thing that really bothered me was a temporary exhibition of the Paley collection--a private collection assembled in the mid-twentieth century that belongs to the Museum of Modern Art in New York. MoMA is a good place for it: it includes works by Matisse, Picasso, Gauguin, Cezanne, Derain... all the big names who figure in the standard history of modern painting and sculpture. Seeing it at the DeYoung felt weird, because this is a history that the museum's permanent collection ignores. The fact that these works were assembled by a private collector, the large-format photographs of the paintings hanging in the Paleys' home, and the exhibition's title, "A Taste for Modernism," made it seem like an exhibition about interior design--an appropriate theme for the De Young, given its focus on applied art, but it seems like the wrong way to handle these masterworks. In general, I don't like exhibitions of private collections because it becomes about the collectors--not the work of the painters but the money that bought all of it. Sometimes when I'm at major museums I find myself thinking about the structure of the art market and its influence on museum displays, and I like the De Young because it engages a wider variety of art's social contexts and economies. The exhibition of a private collection of modernist masterpieces makes me concerned about the direction the museum is taking, and this is a fairly young museum so it's vulnerable to missteps. 

It was hard for me to choose between three and four stars for me personally, but I wouldn't want to discourage anyone from coming for at least one visit, so I'll give it four.
author: Brian D.

description:
I took my daughter to see the Tutankhamum exhibit, and really found myself underwhelmed. I mean, taking my daughter to see this legendary exhibit was a no-brainer, and I think she was delighted with our Daddy/Daughter date, but really... the exhibit fell short.

Here are some things you should know:
- There is no coffin (sarcophagus) from Tut's tomb in this exhibit.  All 7 layers of his coffin are somewhere else.  There is an adult sized one of one of his femaie ancestors, but it wasn't in his tomb.  There is a fetus coffin and face mask from one of his two children that didn't die, but it's not very beautiful or ornate.
- His death-mask is no longer part of the exhibit.  It once was.  Hell, it's the icon of the exhibit, but alas, it's not here.
- His enbalming jars are there -- well one is -- but be careful or you'll miss it.  It doesn't look like the ones from his ancestors.
- His mummy has never traveled with the exhibit.  All mummies stay in Egypt.  If you hoped to see a mummy, you'll be disappointed.

What's left are some trinkets and a few nice pieces of furniture from his tomb.  His childhood chair...a few nice chests.  I don't mean to seem obsessed with death.  But, that's what you Egyptian tombs are all about -- how they viewed death and the afterlife.

- No photos inside.  That's standard, but I'd like to have taken some with my daughter.  We did that in the gift shop with the fake stuffed head dresses.

The audio tour with Omar Sharif was marvelous.

The Egyptians are credited with inventing many things, but alas, margaritas are not one of them, so none of those are there, either.
author: Richard B.

description:
Logistics of Buying Tickets for DeYoung vs. Tut Exhibit Only
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Non-member?  Think you can waltz in at 1pm and get tickets to 1:30pm Tut exhibit?  Wrong.  Only a limited number of tickets are available to non-members for special exhibits.  At 1pm, best you can do is buy 4:30pm tickets.  Or at least that was the case when I went.*

I know, it's cruel.  You just labored 30 sweaty minutes finding parking and tromped 2 miles to the DeYoung.  Surely, there must be a way in?  

There is!  Fork out $95 for the Family annual membership, which immediately makes tickets available for ANY special exhibit RIGHT NOW.  At a discount even.

Tut Exhibit prices:
Non-member cost :  $27.50 adult, children (6 and up) $16.50
Member cost:  $22.50 adult, children (6 and up) $12ish


Review of the Tut Exhibit by my 6 year old
------------------------------------------------------------------
Whaaat???  How come the mummy is inside the glass?  The picture on the paper doesn't show glass!  Where is the mask?  That's not the same one!

Review of the Tut Exhibit by my 3 year old
------------------------------------------------------------------
Is that a boy mummy?  I like a girl mummy better.  Is he dead?

Review of the Tut Exhibit by me
---------------------------------------------------
After you've seen your 9th or 10th gold figurine, it gets old.  When we finally saw the Ceremonial Dagger and Sheath it was like YAY, FINALLY something not a figurine or gilded chest!

Yeah, my kid came to see the mask.  It was not there.  Hence, he was bummed.  Tip to parents:  Tut is not a kid friendly exhibit.  Skip and head to Academy of Science if you got young ones under 7.  Why?

1) Exhibits are sitting about 5ft high.
2) Kids are not allowed to sit on your shoulders to get better view.
3) Backpacks are not allowed to be worn.  Can only hand carry.
4) No food or water allowed except in their Cafe and terrace.
Security guards constantly (and courteously) enforce 2, 3, 4.

Oh yeah, +++ for the hieroglyphics stencil we bought from gift store.  My 6 year old is now writing "i hate my sister" in ancient egyptian prose.  I'm sure the boy king would have loved being his pen pal.

*Clarification on Tut tickets
--------------------------------------------------
Drue C. corrected me on the ticketing system, and hey he's prolly right.  However, the day I went, all the non-member Tut tickets until 4:30pm were sold out.  And they told me buying a membership would get me in asap.  Which we gladly did.  Details, details...see below for Drue's explanation:

"There are 300 tickets per entry time - a percent go to membership and a percent to the general public. There are days that membership tickets sell out before general admission. If there are membership tickets unsold they are transferred to general admission right before the entry time.

So.... members are given a situation in which it is more likely they can get tickets for an earlier time, but it is not guaranteed."
author: Jason Y.

description: art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art art ART
author: Morris R.

description: This museum has an awesome gift shop (if extremely pricey), a swoonable collection of Arts & Crafts pottery and furniture etc.. that the Fab Fawn and I like to visit, and AND AND they have an Andy Goldsworthy that stays put! That is not ephemeral! That is cheeky and quirky and outside so you can sit on it and have your picture taken and groove on it for a while as tourists stare at you. What?
author: Stephanie M.

description:
While I still miss the old De Young Museum, I'll admit, the new one is pretty fab (even though I just don't get the whole unfinished tower thing. I'm sorry, I just don't). 

The current exhibit from the Musee d'Orsay is well done and does a great job of tying together the history of the war, the Paris Commune and The Salons. I strongly recommend buying your tickets in advance from Costco so you get a nice little discount, a free audio tour, and, can book in advance online. Works out pretty neatly, and, helps you save a few bucks. 

If you're going to go on a weekend, aim for a Sunday morning as opposed to a Saturday as Saturdays are positively bonkers busy. 

The standing collections are enjoyable, especially if you're looking for interesting pieces like Al Farrow's "Martyred Hand and Gun of Saint Guerre," glass by Chihuly, and so much more. 

And, if you're up to it, on the same day you visit the De Young, you can also stop by and visit the Legion of Honor for free (which has a sister exhibit to the Musee d'Orsay). Fantastic.
author: Melissa D.

description: Gaultier exibit was amazing well worth $10. I got a discount using my bank of america card.
author: Karen T.

description:
It was my first time at the De Young (I went for a tour of the "Van Gogh, Gauguin, Cézanne and Beyond: Post-Impressionist Masterpieces from the Musée d'Orsay" exhibit for my French class), and I'll have to say that it was not bad at all. The tour lasted about 45 minutes. I was able to absorb much about how these post-impressionist paintings were created. My favorite out of all of the pieces was Van Gogh's Starry Night.

Before the tour, we needed to park. There was also a bluegrass festival and there was ZERO parking. We found a spot about half a mile away. Then, we had to wait a about an hour outside for the tour. Man oh man, it was freezing! It was so foggy too. We went into the cafe where it was nice and warm. It was really tempting to eat in the cafe, but much was expensive. We just walked around the entire area. I was so happy to have gotten inside. After the tour, my group and I tried to go in the tower, but it was closed.

I had a fun day even though we had all these terrible experiences before and after the tour. I'd like to go back soon to see the entire facility.
author: Terri L.

description:
love the de young! they have so many exhibits for everyone's different tastes..

i've been here a handful of times but my most memorable exhibits were of course the fashion ones! i can easily spend hours going through the exhibit and then going through it again because i cant help myself and wish all of the stunning pieces were in my closet..

i believe my first fashion exhibit at de young was vivienne westwood..amazing!
http://deyoung.famsf.org/deyoung/exhibitions/vivienne-westwood-36-years-fashion

next came.. yves saint laurent.. blew my mind!
http://www.famsf.org/pressroom/pressreleases/yves-saint-laurent

recently..balenciaga and spain.. wow!
http://deyoung.famsf.org/pressroom/pressreleases/balenciaga-and-spain-opens-march-26-2011-de-young-museum-san-francisco

my friend and i visited the olmec exhibit before the balenciaga exhibit (wanted to save the best for last, imo) and my friend asked me if it was the same olmec as in the big, talking head on the legends of the hidden temple.. i had no clue.. that show was on so long ago! haha

im already planning my next visit which is to see the picasso exhibit.. cant wait! 

tips: 
-buy your tix online.. it's a couple bucks off and you don't have to wait in line when you get there..
-go on free day! which is the first tues of every month
author: Raquel T.

description:
The amish quilt exhibit was amazing...best show in the city to see high on drugs...outrageously cool.'

The musuem itself is always great to walk through...i love to spend time here hanging with my ipad...if im ever bored this is one of my spots.

I am even ok with the buildings architecture...looks like a star ship.
author: Eric H.

description: Not friendly when you go with your kids. Too strict even when you don't do anything wrong.The guards think that they are doing the security of a bank. I don't know if I will go back there!
author: F Q.

description:
I have a deep connection with this place,
I have been here every 3-4 years since I was in SF.
 I love the huge space but there could have been more use of the land and the outdoor landscaping needs lots of help. The viewing tower is the best part of the place.
author: Peter J.

description:
I love the Oceana collection.  It's huge.  I think I read that they have the largest collection of art from Papua New Guinea anywhere.  I didn't realize that there was that much art in all of Oceana's history until I visited the de Young.  The extent of the permanent collection, to me, is amazing.  I didn't have time for November/December's special exhibits.

The building is beautiful.  The interior is clean, cool, and very classy-seeming.  I felt out of place.  :D

I've only gotten to visit this place once, and the visit was too short, but I was impressed by the breadth of the collection (what I was able to see).  I arrived about an hour before closing time, but the woman I dealt with at the front desk was still very nice and accommodating and didn't try to make me feel guilty for showing up so late.  Most of the security guards are fairly unobtrusive, and when it was closing time, they announced it to me without hassling me, like a woman over at CA Academy of Sciences had done on another visit.

The observation tower is amazing-looking.  The jury's still out on whether it's cool or an eyesore, but I love the ideas behind its design and wish I could have watched the sunset from it.  Unfortunately, it closes at 4:30 PM now, making this impossible.

The admission price seems reasonable to me.  I, personally, wouldn't pay the extra to see the current special exhibits, but that's because I've seen a lot of Masters' works and don't feel the need to see any more, currently (obviously, I'm not a hardcore museum buff).  I was very content with the variety and quality of the permanent collection and really want to come back here some time when I can actually spend some time here.
author: Kimi H.

description:
My husband and I are members of the De Young and come here as often as we can. It's a beautiful museum with more than anyone could possibly see in a day, and they always have fascinating exhibits featured. The staff have always been helpful and polite, and the prices are reasonable. Excellent place to bring a date, a child, or even just get lost by yourself. 

Pro tip: there are some spots in and near the bathrooms/phones on the first floor where you can charge your phone for a few minutes.

One star off because the parking sucks big time. It always takes us AT LEAST a half hour, often times more, to find a spot.
author: Crystal C.

description: Great space. Make sure that you make your way up to the tower for the stunning, sweeping views of San Francisco. The only reason I'm not rating this a 5 star is because when we visited the William Paley collection, I just realized that I have seen these art works previously at MoMa in NY. I wish they have more content.
author: Nino B.

description:
In my humble opinion, the best museum in San Francisco, and the second best museum in California, behind the Getty. 

Some of the collections I've seen again and again include Art of the Americas, The Anderson Graphic Arts Collection, and American Sculpture & Decorative Art. One of my favorite pieces: Roy Lichtenstein's Peace through Chemistry II.

My most favorite recent exhibit was Yves St. Laurent. It covered the designer's trends through multiple decades and the dresses were decadently displayed.

The tower has a marvelous view, and I'm always pleasantly surprised wtih the cafe. It's a bit pricey- but has a nice collection of salads, sandwiches, deli treats, drinks and desserts. 

I feel that the current collection Toward Abstraction: Photographs and Photograms is MUCH better than the Tut exhibit. 

Oh oh oh- this upcoming exhibit I can hardly wait for!!!!!! Van Gogh, Gauguin, Cézanne and Beyond: Post-Impressionist Masterpieces from the Musée d'Orsay 9/25/10-1/18/11
author: Greg M.

description: Impressive collection of American art, but know that the permanent collection is relatively limited - this is the kind of museum that you go to when there is a special exhibit that you want to see and not a sprawling amalgam of art from many time periods that you can browse at your leisure.  The hubs and I drifted through the American paintings, only stopping on a couple trompe l'oeil pieces that I remember studying in college but had never seen in person.      We did catch some stunning Chihuly and Chuck Close works, along with some killer modern photography (and some Gursky's that I'd never seen before), but the trip felt abbreviated, as if the museum needed another floor or two to explore.  Still, a gorgeous building in an idyllic park means that if your interest wanes on the art, you can always drink in the scenery outside.  Would definitely visit this place again.
author: Angela G.

description:
The Post-impressionism exhibit was excellent.  It reminded me of visiting the Musee d'Orsay in Paris  -- that's where this collection of paintings originates.  The paintings are grouped in schools, with an explanation in each room that highlights the history of and connections between the painters.   The Van Gogh room had several notable paintings of his and is worth the trip in itself.   But there's a lot to learn and appreciate about Cezanne, Gaughin, Renoir, Rousseau, Seurat and many others.  I recommend it highly to anyone who loves art and  art history.  It's quite an improvement over the previous, Impressionist, exhibit.

I give the exhibit itself 5 stars, but securing tickets and going through the multiple lines is a pain.
author: Leslie G.

description:
My husband and I first went to the De Young in 1996 when I went to cover a pop art exhibit for my high school newspaper. We had fun and overall the experience was unforgettable. 

This was our first visit back since our high school days, but this time with wedding bands and a 10-month-old in tow. We specifically came to visit the King Tut exhibit, but stopped at the cafe, observatory, and upper floor exhibits. 

First, the Tut exhibit: better than expected, but crowded. There are lots of rules to control the big crowds, which was good. However, I felt a little bad hiding in the corner to feed our baby because no food or drinks were allowed. The exhibit itself was incredible. There is so much stuff and the information was nicely organized and fascinating to all ages. Lots and lots of information. 

The rest of the museum was really nice. It was relatively empty, especially the upper floor exhibits. It seemed like a nice place to really explore the many different genres of art. 

The observation floor was impressive. So good, in fact, that it made me a little nauseous when we were up there. The gift shop was a little unnecessary, though. 

I would bring snacks if you don't want to drop a bunch to eat while you're there. I liked the cafe, but I'll save that for my next review. 

We WILL be back to the De Young and I'm already looking forward to the next visit!
author: Lindsey A.

description: Great FREE access to the 9th floor observation deck. Go there.
author: dean d.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of art museums, so I won't pretend to know squat about it.

Just a tip: if you're a student, bring your ID.  Also, keep your bus pass.  With my two discounts, I paid $4.  Nice cheap way to spend half a day.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I love museums. I prefer them over bars and clubs any day of the week. They're my four of a kind to your full house, cowboys over nines. And yes, your hand sucks out loud.

What drew me to this place was the King Tutankhamun exhibit. My friends consider me well-traveled. I've seen the iconic burial mask in a different venue. I've also seen the iconic coffin. So it was time for me to see the rest, which I don't remember seeing nor appreciating it at the age I saw them. 

The lines: long but organized. They called parties into the exhibit in increments of 30 minutes.

The exhibit: Great! I love love love it. Egyptology is a favorite topic of mine. This trip was the scholastic equivalent of a very intimate physical act. It was well organized, I think, despite the droves of people that showed up. 

The staff: polite and very helpful. I'm glad they remained so, despite all the people that showed up.

All in all, this place is great. I saw some of the other exhibits while we were waiting and they're worth a look-see as well. The Tut exhibit is here till March but that shouldn't stop you from coming here even after that. Don't take my word for it.  Go go go!
author: Alex L.

description:
Loved the variety of exhibits and collections offered - you get a wide range of offerings that will keep you interested on a day long visit. African and Native American art, modern pieces, even biographical exhibits. The docents are knowledgeable and engaging. Pricing for general admission and special exhibits are reasonable, especially compared to other Bay Area art museums, but keep an eye out for special deals or offers. Clean, well-maintained, nicely laid out, and plenty of (paid) parking.

One big disappointment was that the only place to lunch was the museum cafe. An upscale fine dining restaurant is available, by reservation only, at the Academy of Sciences across the way, but otherwise nothing else was available other than a hotdog stand. That said, the de Young Cafe had a nice range of better than average offerings on it's menu.

Also, the parking garage is super easy and convenient. But you pay for it. $25 for the day.
author: B. A.

description:
The permanent collection here still hasn't floored me, but I'm enjoying the museum more after two a-plus exhibits (Warhol Live and Yves Saint Laurent).

Fun facts:
-A BofA debit card or credit card will get you (yeah, you with your name on the card, but no one else) free admission on some days, but you still have to pay $10 for the Warhol.
-The album covers book in the exhibit store is an unheard-of $30, marked down from $75. I know. Score one today. Like, now.
author: Tara R.

description:
The King Tut Exhibition was being offered for free this weekend (Feb. 20-21) so my friends and I decided to check out the marvelous treasures I've heard so much about. We arrived around noon and it was busy as weekends in the City are. The woman at the entrance told us the line was backed up for about a half hour and if we came back then, we could get in line. We all saw a line snaking around the corner and wondered if 30 minutes was an accurate estimate on her part. So we checked out some of the myriad of tribal art and came back in 30 minutes only to be told it would be a TWO hour wait in line...just to get into the exhibit!! Renee, the lovely attendant/docent, suggested we come to the 'After Hours' gathering on Friday night to see it for $20.
My suggestion for any 'free event' is 1. Get there before they open and be one of the first hundred in line 2. Become a member and avoid the clamor 3. Pay the full $32.50 and go on a weekday when everyone is back at work.
The museum is a masterpiece and I hope to return another time to see
more of the exhibits. I'm only slightly rueful that we didn't see the Amish quilts.
author: michael s.

description:
It's no Louvre, but it's worth a look at.  When we came here we were excited to see that they had a special exhibit of Post-Impressionist masterpieces from the Musée d'Orsay. However, it required an additional fee on top of the normal museum fee but the tickets for it were sold out so we missed out! :( I was truly disappointed that we missed out on the exhibit that I was not able to enjoy the rest of the museum.

I didn't care much for the American paintings but the most memorable thing about this museum was the observation tower. It has a 360 degree view of the city and what a beautiful view it is!
author: Vanessa T.

description:
Chihuly was worth examining twice.  The museum as a whole?  NOT REALLY.  I'm a die hard MoMA fan (both SF and NYC).  Visiting the de Young just solidified my resolve to become a member --- of MoMA.  

There's just something lacking about the collection over at the de Young.  None of the OOMP!!!  Nothing that makes you do that triple take.  

I still consider the new structure an eyesore from the outside.   WHAT A BUMMER.  The interior is nice.  Nothing incredibly novel, though.  Again, none of that OOMP I was hoping to keep me infatuated.  Eh.  Oh well.
author: BrasilPo P.

description: Was here for a wedding. Really nice venue and the secluded yard on the side was pretty unique. Staff there was a bit pushy, but probably they just wanted everything to go according to schedule and to prevent any damage to the museum or artwork. Can't wait to come here during regular exhibit hours! Banquet hall was nice too and they set up this dance area outside. Good thing they had heat lamps set up!
author: M. H.

description:
The "new" De Young is both an architectural highlight and a wonderful venue for displaying art and culture exhibitions.


 Let's take a look at the architecture first: 

It fulfills it's purpose beautifully: The layout creates tension-filled spaces for artwork, channels a mixture of plain and dramatic natural light to the interior, and guides streams of visitors effortlessly
 
The exterior is another thing entirely: It integrates well into Golden Gate Park, but (because of its stark lines) also contrasts magnificently with the organic shapes of the surrounding environment
 
Materials are both environmentally sensible and beautiful. As Qyper lizok mentioned, the perorated copper also literally takes on a fourth dimensions, as it will change with time.


 Second, the collecions and shows:
 
The recent Tutankhamun exhibit was a lovingly put-together show that used the location for maximum dramatic effect without dumbing the content down. THis is how one educates the public effectively.
 
Other travelling and semi-permanent shows have had the same air of lovingly detailed edutainment, bespeaking of both great knowledge and great empathy on the side of the organizers.


 The De Young is an fabulous example of how a major museum in a major city should be run: With world-class flair and respect for the locale.
author: Markus R.

description:
It's really 3.5 stars. I came here for the free King Tut Weekend sponsored by Target. We got in line at 8:30 a.m. and got to the front of the line around 10:00 a.m.. We were almost certain that we weren't going to get the tickets but we got them just in time for the 2:30 p.m. showing. 

This was the first time that I've been to the DeYoung museum in YEARS and I'd have to say that it's more for people that appreciate art or have knowledge of art. Most of the time I just took quick glances at items without reading the captions but there were a few pieces that intrigued me like the bowl of fruit made of blown glass, a sewn portrait of George Washington made completely from dollar bills, and a abstract chair that looked like it could've belong to Lady Gaga! 

As for the King Tut exhibit, I enjoyed it because I've always had a fascination with ancient egyptian things. Although it was a rather small collection, I can understand the risk that it takes to transfer these 3,000 year-old items. There are 10 galleries with 6 of those being artifacts of King Tut's relatives. The remaining 4 had items that were buried with King Tut and things found inside his tomb. To see the detail and the colors used to decorate these items was an experience in itself. They were all very beautiful. It was a bit disturbing knowing that they took this one crown-looking thing off his mummified skull.  

Overall though, I would only recommend going to DeYoung when it's free even though there's a load of people unless you were really into art. As for the King Tut exhibit, it is rather pricey to see it, so hopefully they will have another free Target weekend.
author: Crystal C.

description: Really quality fine art museum - expansive and has some great collections. I love being a member of this museum because of the diversity of the collections and the special exhibits that are often offered. The surroundings are in beautiful Golden Gate Park, and on a clear day there's a great view of San Francisco from the top. There's paid parking underneath the museum or free street parking if you're lucky.
author: Kristy C.

description: I like this museum a lot, from the location to how it looks from the outside. I'm not not crazy about the price for the King Tut's exhibition and how we couldn't take photos. Even after my student discount, it didn't help much at all with the price. It wasn't even worth the money because we never see King Tut's tomb, in fact, we see his aunt's tomb. All that waiting in line and the big fuss they make and we don't even see his tomb! It makes no sense! Then you're let out to their gift shop which is all overpriced. I love how you have to walk through the gift shop to get out so looking around is encouraged.
author: Cindy W.

description: I came here to see the King Tut museum, and was unfortunately underwhelmed.  I loved learning about Egypt when I was a kid, and when I heard that this exhibit was open.  Here's the problem: it was only a couple rooms and most of them were artifacts before King Tut's time.  When you eventually get to see his stuff, it's a couple ceremonial necklaces and some jars, but no mummy, not sarcophagus, nothing really that interesting.  Also, the facts were scarce and either we really know very little about him, or they made it seem that way.  Either way, lame!
author: Denis S.

description:
Hands down the best museum I have been to.  They have everything here!!!  From furniture, paintings to sculptures.  The best part: FREE on tuesdays!  Easy to get to as well (what isn't in San Francisco?  What a great rail/bus system).
I really enjoyed the diversity this museum has to offer, I loved all the old hand carved furniture.
author: Troy S.

description:
One Star Rating is too generous for this exhibition.... Total Rip-Off.. 
I was really mad about their deceiving, vicious, and unethical intention. 

It was totally a ripoff. Where is the mask of tutankhamun?  It is the exhibition of Tutankhanmun's great grand mother, who was not even a loyal family. How can you advertise with a poster of mask which is actually not in the exhibition? From the beginning, it started with all the curiosity of the tomb of Tutankhamun and his mask including mummies but in the end, just say"we don't have mask here and please go home ASAP after buying some craps at the gift shops"...  All the visitors went there to see the mask, which is advertised in the main poster.  Don't tell me that it is a magnification of 20cm's liver container. 

Very American business-Money oriented and great marketing...  Huge disappointment.
author: Do-Yeon C.

description:
it really depend on which exhibit is being shown. 
a warning: camera are not allow in most of the exhibit so pick wisely since some of these exhibit can cost around 80-120 per ticket.

the most recent exhibit that i been to is the Tutankhamun, and it wasn't that good. i was hoping to take a lot of picture of all those GOLD ... but it was against the rule ... something about security issue  -__-
author: Lam L.

description:
A trip to San Francisco isn't complete without a visit to the De Young Museum. Not only does the De Young house some wonderful works of art but the building itself is a work of art!


 There is a fantastic view overlooking all of Golden Gate Park from the tower observation deck and if you happen to be in town on a Friday evening there is a cocktail reception with live music. Good stuff!
author: tvham

description: Went on a first Tuesday of a month, which means it was free! :) General admission is usually $10 for adults, so not too bad either. Many great exhibits, paintings, and artworks to check out! Plan to spend around 3ish (?) hours here and be sure to check out the observation deck on L9! You get views of GGP and of SF. Afterwards, you can take a stroll at GGP and grab lunch on Irving!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Warhol and YSL.
+ 
1 full bladder and long line at Academy of Science
===================================
Fun times at  deYoung Museum! 

Embracing my inner pop fanatic, I marveled at the sight of so much WARHOL. I loved it. From the drag, the Judy Garland, the Elvis, the Album covers, Mick Jagger and his Sticky Fingers, Liza Minnelli, Debbie Harry, the Brillo boxes, this show had it all.  Did I mention a strobe light room with the sounds of the "The Velvet Underground?"

Awesome, pay the money to see this DUDE.

I am not a high priced fashionista.  I would love to be, but I have a mortgage. I have always appreciated fashion as art. I remember my first Giorgio Armani exhibit at the Guggenheim Museum in NYC: http://www.thecityreview.com/armani.html. 
I was in a perpetual daze staring at the clothes.  

Like the Armani exhibit, I was in awe at the YSL exhibit. Utter. Awe.
The bolero jacket, the wedding dresses, the cock feather jacket...yah INSANE. I kept thinking that this is as close as I am ever going to get to  Haute Couture.

Here's a fun fact from http://www.ysldeyoung.org :
In 1983, The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, under the direction of Diana Vreeland, organizes a major retrospective: Yves Saint Laurent-- 25 Years of Design. It is the first time that a retrospective is created for a living designer.

If you go check this out, you will see why. This man ROCKS! 

Although I spent most of my time at these 2 exhibits, I did enjoy the spectacular views from the tower, in addition to the  other colorful exhibits. The large fruit bowl was one of my favorites. 
The architecture, the feel, it was perfect for a rainy Sunday.

Again, Awesome, pay the money to see this DUDE.  If you do, you will also get in to the Legion of Honor.
Note the rating might have been influenced by exhibits, but nonetheless...it rocks.
author: Flor D.

description:
I came here today after going to the California Academy of Science which is located just across the street. Pretty convenient. The De Young is in a really convenient location close to Muni.

Admission was SUPER cheap for me. Im a student so I paid $6 to get in. (I didn't go into the special exhibit cause I didn't want to pay extra, but by reading the reviews, it doesn't really sound that great either.) After paying the $6, I got a $2 discount for taking Muni. So my total for the ticket was $4. Thats 4t times cheaper than the California Academy of Science! 

Was it worth the $4? Yes. But as you know the saying "You get what you pay for" I didn't really have that much fun, I found the California Academy of Science way more fun than the De Young. The exhibits were nice. I loved the artwork but thats all there is over there. The architecture of the building is amazing and the rooftop viewing is cool. Would come again since its only $4 for me.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Andy Warhol and Yves Saint Laurent, just brilliant! 

Friday night At the De Young is best time to go, but go early. Drinks, live entertainment, hat making, etc etc....be sure to visit the De Young site prior to attending.

Andy is beyond his time in terms of art and music. I love the magazine covers and the disco ball light area. Yves is just insanely creative, I'm curious, how does one fit in a size 1 dress?????? Absolutely Gorgeous! 
I would love to find out who owns these dresses, that itself would be interesting.

PS. The burning man presentation was phenomenal. Fun to watch! This year theme is Evolution.
author: Stanley K.

description: de Young is a beautiful museum. I came recently on a random sunday afternoon and decided to check out the Picasso exhibit. Well I have to say, it's a pretty solid exhibition and the museum itself is gorgeous. However, I have been too spoiled by the free museums in europe with their astonishing collection that my sense of judgement is kinda off. And yes the entrance fee into the Picasso collection is a bit more than I'd like to pay but I did it anyways to pass time and I enjoyed myself so no regrets there.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Take a second and think about all museums you've ever attended. 

For me, every one is a different animal in and of itself because they all have something unique to offer, yet they're all pretty different.

De Young is another exceptional place that houses really groundbreaking work. 

The paintings are exquisite and appealing to almost all tastes. 

The sculptures have probably been worked on for decades and kept out of the public eye before they were found. 

The craft on display really gives you a nice peak into what was going through the minds of our ancestors from thousands of years ago.

Go there. 

Experience it. 

Come back. 

Tell everybody else.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description:
I love the De Young Museum but the King Tut exhibit was over-hyped and very commercial.  The advertising is also misleading.  Their current website has the statement "Interested in Tut's visit to the Big Apple in April" although Tut will not visit the big apple as he is resting comfortably in Egypt (he is also no where near San Francisco).

But Tut is only one part of the current museum.  The stunning architecture of the De Young more than makes up for the visit.  The de Young is still a must see, but not the Tut show.
author: Eric W.

description:
View from tower is great.
Cafe outdoor garden fine.
Oceana exhibit excellent.
Permanent exhibit - look for a few hilites.
Entrance hall ' strontium ' wall not good.
Overall design - excuse me , but it still looks like an old rusted aircraft carrier washed up in GG Park - ugly.
author: Robert B.

description:
I hate to admit, first time I've been since it reopened. What a wonderful museum! The collections of work were nicely varied from ancient to abstract. The special Impressionist exhibit is fabulous. These Master Works so close up and personal are very touching. 

Can be crowded... makes tons of sense to join instead of pay the daily fee. Especially considering the upcoming exhibits as well. 

Do yourself a favor and try to get there before the 6th of Sept. Yet, the new exhibit will be right on the heels of this last one. Enjoy! Oh and go early in the day.
author: Kaethe S.

description: I would if I could give it negative rating. I have not seen such rude service against non-English speaking people for a while around the area. That guys should be fired
author: Shane D.

description:
How can you have a "King Tut" exhibit without the actual mask or the sarcophogus!!??

In San Diego when their Natural History Museum hosted the "Dead Sea Scrolls" the main attraction were the scrolls - the ACTUAL scrolls!!  So for those people that have seen the exhibit 30 years ago, this is not an equal comparison.....

We would like to see the de Young provide some truth in advertising....
author: Kellen H.

description:
The YSL exhibit was fabulous. 

It features works of "art" and fashion forward costumes worn by many regal and famous persons.  Some pieces aren't wearable but they seem to fit the fun style of the great designer himself. 
One of my favorite line was the one dedicated to the artists; the beading and intricate works were just amazing. 

Haute couture collection at its best and glad I had the chance to catch this exhibit.
author: Mika D.

description:
I remember going to the De Young when I was a little girl; it was one of the first museums I visited at 5 years old.  Wow, how times have changed!  This was my first time in the renovated space, and I have to say the architecture is completely lost on me. There was no proper entrance and the space just seemed inefficiently planned and a bit stark. Evidently the copper exterior is supposed to show it's patina over time, but I saw no evidence of this and was really turned off by it. 

The collections are another story. We had time to enjoy the African exhibit, the special Andy Warhol exhibit and John Friede's "JOLICA" collection of Indonesian Oceanic art. The story behind Friede's exhibit is almost more intriguing than the beautiful artifacts. The collection is currently caught in the crosshairs of a legal dispute involving John Friede, his brothers, and an inheritance settlement from Walter Annenberg, which was reportedly used to bankroll this exhibit. 

Aside from the drama, the De Young's collection is pretty diverse, and the current Warhol exhibition is a good intro to contemporary art, though I found it to be pretty basic. If I had my way I would have pushed the curatorial envelope a bit more. 

Overall, the De Young's collection is a nod to it's past, their special exhibits are a nod to the future and the architecture is a bust, but the winning collection trumps the facade. 

Heads up, Tut is coming back here in June.
author: C L.

description: Always something interesting going on or being exhibited here. Lovely location. Feels a bit too much like an amusement park when there are herds of patrons on weekends.
author: Elle C.

description:
This is becoming one of my most favorite museums !!!!

I just went to De Young Museum again yesterday (July 12th, 2009) to see the special exhibition, Tutankhamen. One word, the exhibition was amazing !!!! I would give 5 stars, but the wait was quite long... I waited two hours to see the exhibit. I highly recommend people to get tickets online ahead of time if you are planning to go in the weekend. 

Yesterday was really crazy. Not only the wait, but also the entire place was packed, so it was not the ideal atmosphere for my taste when I go to a museum. I like to take time and observe things quietly, but there are a lot of families and little kids who were making a lot of noise. 

I think staff at De Young are nice too. I know it's a quite stressful situation, but they managed the craziness really well. My date happen to have a ticket 30 mins after mine, but we got in at the same time as my entrance time. 

When things get little slower, I would like to go back again to see everything all over. The display was amazing and I felt like I was back in the time of the Boy King.
author: Sayaha A.

description: This place is equivalent to a candy store for me. I was running around like a child trying to soak in the amazing artwork that this museum had in store for me to see. I went here primarily to visit the Jean Paul Gaultier exhibit and boy did that knock my socks off! I was impressed by his amazing work and photography is allowed (I just didn't want to take photographs *no flash* as I was too busy soaking in the amazing designs to take any photographs).
author: Michelle H.

description: The de  Young is a beautiful, well maintained and extensive museum with a fantastic range of art, knowledgable staff and always attracts exhibits that are simply amazing! Since I have lived in SF (less than a year) I have seen a Picasso and a JPG fashion exhibit. Every time I go, I never want to leave. If you are in SF then you need to go, take a few hours to stroll the beautiful rooms, wonder the courtyard and head up to the top of the de young tower for views of the city and the bay. MUST go!
author: Shanna T.

description:
FINALLY got to see this place since the rebuild.  Skipped the Tut exhibit only because I haven't heard very good reviews on it, and I saw it in 1979.  

I'm torn.  I have to say, they did a good job with the building.  It's very unique.  BUT - as someone who grew up in San Francisco and had visited the old museum for many, many times... I have to say that this new building doesn't feel like a museum at all.  It's like a modern art gallery.  It doesn't have that "classic" feel anymore that a true museum should.  

I don't know.  Maybe I'm getting old (gasp), but I miss the old museum.  We already have a MOMA in the city - don't need another one.  

Still I give 4 stars because if you don't compare it to what is used to be, it's a very nice place.  The display areas are roomy enough for small crowds to move through.  Plenty of seating for those who tire easily.  Don't know when I'll ever go back, but I'm glad I've visited the new building once.  

Don't forget to go up to the viewing area of the tower.  Beautiful views of the city and the Golden Gate Park area.  And of course, when they say that you can see the Golden Gate Bridge from up there, they're not exactly lying.  You can see the top of the towers peeking out from behind the trees in the way.
author: Denise M.

description:
Crap, crap, crap. Waste of time.

+ves
+ free on the First Tuesday of the month, no lines unsurprisingly
+ some of the American paintings were cool
+ the view from the tower is spectacular

-ves
- the rest was pretty average - the New Guinea section was just the same things replicated over and over again
- much better fine art at the Legion of Honor
author: Joseph T.

description:
*S W O O N* 

Once I enter its doors, I have trouble leaving. The De Young makes my 'Top 5' list of places in San Francisco where eventually I WILL have to be forcibly removed. 
Just a matter of time, kiddies.
author: mnypny b.

description:
The Tower is pretty cool and the works of art are imposing for being 200 years old.  Good afternoon fun for $10.  

That being said two words to describe the King Tut exhibit, let down.  They really should call it King Tut and Family.  There were approximately five small artifacts from Tut himself; what experts "believe" to be his family was mostly represented.  Plus the exhibit was so over crowded it was frustrating and the exhibit itself is $33 to get into (which will grant you entrance to the rest of the museum).

I suppose everyone should get the Tut experience once but I'm thinking the real thing in Cairo is much more impressive.
author: Angela D.

description:
I'm a man of simple pleasures.
I'll have a bit of rainwater in my wine.
I want avocado with my Mac 'n Cheese.  

So if the sun happens to be going down, and the city is a rare kind of warm, and I find myself in the Observation Tower- despite my need to visit the lavatory, I can soak in a view that, until the De Young, could only be enjoyed by satellites.  

Then I went to the rest room.  FYI.
author: Patrick A.

description: Good if you can go for free. Clean, in Golden Park, in the avenues, and is spacious.
author: R C.

description:
Review mainly for king tut exhibit

easy to get to by muni. sits across the street from the cal academy of sciences in beautiful golden gate park. we've been many times and the museum isn't bad, though , in terms of museums, i prefer the legion of honor and the asian art museum.

the exhibit itself was underwhelming. i mean seriously overhyped. lots of little, tiny stuff in big cases, which didn't even belong to king tut.
author: Tom L.

description: The de Young museum is my favorite museum in San Francisco, b/c they offer such diversity with their exhibitions and the all-around feel of the museum is super chill. The museum is situated in the beautiful Golden Gate Park, and depending on how you enter the museum, you get to walk past the majestic Japanese Tea Gardens or you get to walk through the idyllic side garden with interesting metal sculptures. Everything about the de Young is amazing. One of my favorite things about the de Young, is the Friday night events! I have gotten to experience everything from Salsa dancing, to drag shows, to Improv shows...always something new and exciting!
author: Orey J.

description:
I came here for the first time yesterday for the King Tut exhibit. I wasn't really expecting much because I knew all the famous iconic treasures from his tomb would not be in the exhibit. The exhibit is organized into 10 galleries, the last four of which I think are the best. I know, 10 galleries? Don't worry, it only takes about 2 hours to fully go through the exhibit. I recommend purchasing tickets from Costco, which comes with the audio tour. Entrance is controlled by times and they let in small groups at a time so it doesn't get too crowded inside. 

The exhibit is well organized, with information plates at the top and bottom of the exhibit box. Most of the items come from other tombs, like those of King Tut's grandparents or his great-grandfather. The items in the last four galleries are ones that actually came from his tomb. I can't remember, but I think it was the last gallery that has a few items that were actually found on King Tut, wrapped in the linens. My favorite was the sword. It was so detailed and ornate.

I had a great time looking at all the treasures in this exhibit. I highly recommend checking it out before it's gone. Admission to the exhibit also includes admission to the museum, and if you have time you should take a look around at the galleries.
author: Lyn L.

description:
I'm still kicking myself for missing the Vivienne Westwood exhibit last year. There was no way I'd miss the Yves Saint Laurent exhibit this year, and I'm so happy I went today! 

The exhibit is mind blowing. There are nearly 130 accessorized garments and sketches on display. You can easily spend over an hour here.

Fashionistas, you WILL kick yourself if you miss this exhibit, and don't wait until the last day of the show in April 2009. This is the only U.S. venue. Take that LA and NY! SF IS haute.
author: Connie C.

description:
This is a wonderful museum inside of a beautiful building set in one of the nicest urban parks. 

There were many nice exhibits that were diverse and spanned a wide range of history and cultures. 

I came with my fiance on we spent a good 4 and half hours exploring the exhibits and even then we didn't check out the Andy Warhol exhibit because we had just seen a similar exhibit on Pop Art at the Crocker art museum in Sacramento. 

A must see is the observation tower which has spectacular 360 degree views of the city. It was a clear day so we could see the ocean to the west the golden gate bridge to the north and the bay and financial district to the east. It was like a work of art to see the city sprawling out below us. It is a very unique view and it is nice because there are no other large buildings near by to obstruct the view. 

We also had lunch at the cafe and it was very good. We both ordered salad and it was reasonably priced and were very large, fresh and refreshing. 

I look forward to coming back in the near future to check out the King Tut exhibit. Another cool feature is that on the first full weekend of the month Bank of America sponsors free admission to the museum for customers. Also we were able to find free street parking instead of parking in the garage for the museum.
author: Scott W.

description:
The de Young featured Andy Warhol & Yves St. Laurent at the same time.
It was amazing -- 

Modern Art [Andy Warhol]

Timeless Fashion [Yves St. Laurent]

Me [Vanessa W]

Threesome at the de Young. Just how I like to spend my Sundays.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
