I went to the King Tut exhibit at the De Young Museum last week and found it to be pretty cool. I hadn't ever been so it was all new to me.
(I guess it has come around in various guises throughout the years.)

You're looking at a child's chair, jewelry and statuettes from 3,500 years ago. (Many statuettes were placed in the burial vault to be 'servants to do hard labor for the King in the afterlife.' - Though they shouldn't be needed because all kings became Gods in the afterlife.

Looking at this stuff makes you wonder how dude feels about being on display. "We" ransacked his grave in the name of... history? 
This exhibit does make bank.
What if we put all the things back where they were and suddenly a curse was lifted? Yea. What if all of a sudden, canned sitcom laughter sounded less like ocean waves and more like real human snickers???.... Naw. 

Did you Mr. Tut came to power at 9 years old and died at 19?
I get the hit he was more of a dilettante king. More into statues of himself and less into Universal Health Care.  
I also think THIS king probably didn't reincarnate as Elvis because there is little to no trace of musical instruments in what I saw.

Nuf about that though.  I do recommend going. 

But you may have some sticker shock. 
It can cost as much at $32 to get in. The 'free Tuesday of the month' doesn't cover special exhibits.
(I had paid $25 as part of a networking business exchange, so I'm not exactly what the rate is for adults.)

 At the end of the exhibit they have a changing projection on a slab of concrete that shows pictures of the actual mummy with various implements found in the coffin shifting in and out of focus. A big necklace around Tutman's neck, then you see a dagger near his side etc. It's mildly creepy but interesting all the same.

What's great is that there are no tour guides. 
They give you a thing to listen to (shaped like an old telephone or tv remote). 

Certain displays have numbers posted on them. You push the numbers on the device and listen to Omar Sarif tell you about the history of the object in a (too) thick egyptian accent.

The rooms are all really dark with powerful lighting on the various displays.    Go if you can. Hey, you're in the San Francisco Bay Area!
Make use of it. My cousins in Flush Kansas will never know the wonders we take for granted daily...
author: Heather R.

description:
Having recently seen the Chiluly exhibit and seeing that I just returned from free museum day, I feel inspired to bring you...

The De Young Museum: A review in two acts

(NOTE: This'll be a long one so curl up with a cuppa and get ready to read.)

Prologue
Being unemployed and having a crap load of time on my hands, I'm making it my mission to do all the museums that offer free days. First on the list was the De Young, mostly for the recently opened Andy Warhol exhibit ($10 separate entrance fee but it was for all special exhibits. Including Yves Saint Laurent. Holla), but also just because I hadn't been in the rest of the museum in a while.

ACT ONE - ANDY
For an artist that I practically adore, I knew very little about Mr. Warhol before seeing this exhibit. I mean I knew he was a bit "out there" but not THAT out there. But I don't think I should be surprised. He was a successful artist in the 60's, and anyone doing anything worth talking about back then had to be a genius or completely off the wall, quite possibly both. At any rate this exhibit was definitely impressive and in depth. For example, I had no idea how into dance & classical music he was. It made me want to DESPERATELY purchase the diagram of the tango in the gift shop along with the print of the silk screened image of Marilyn. But then I remembered I was putting off getting my dry cleaning because it costs $30. Oh well, maybe I can get it for my birthday :)

ACT TWO - YVES
"Fashion changes, style remains"

This statement could not be said more accurately or beautifully. For someone who doesn't care what is fashionable except in the "Is this going to make me look like a house?" way, I was utterly floored by the Yves Saint Laurent exhibit. Seriously, near tears with the beauty and style I feel I have been starved of for so long. With vague interest, I wandered into this exhibit and was promptly schooled on the master of modern women's fashion. 

And in all seriousness, the styles that YSL is famous for - the women's tuxedo, the pants suit, the pea coat - are as stylish today as they were 40 years ago. At least half of the exhibits made me want to run out to my nearest consignment shop and scour the place for such timeless articles. And the other half were just as inspiring but in the way that makes you think, "I can't imagine wearing that but this man was an imaginative genius."

Exhibits like this sometimes make me sad. It makes me think our best years are behind us. Perhaps it really HAS all been done before. But then again there is hope. For all the ironic t-shirts, skinny jeans, and other fashion mistakes I pray to end each day, it is that hope for the return of fashion that HAS style that keeps me praying. After all, if it has all been done before, it most definitely will be done again.

Epilogue
The rest of the museum was as I remembered it, impressive and extensive. The best are the places to sit :) But in the end I have to tip my hat to the De Young. A fabulous main hall as well as some truly amazing special exhibits makes this museum one to watch and visit regularly.
author: Alexis B.

description: This is only for the observation tower as I have not gone into the actual museum. The observation tower is free and you just go through the front and to the right and make a left until you hit the elevators and then you go to the 9th floor. You get to see a different view of the city compared to twin peaks (http://www.yelp.com/biz/twin-peaks-san-francisco#hrid:PNUGo1HLFy0FCG7lIssbww) and grand view park (http://www.yelp.com/biz/grand-view-park-san-francisco#hrid:BOu7GWWzXda02BXEC0FRpA). Its a good place to check out for a good 10-15 minutes if you are in the golden gate park area around the academy of sciences.
author: Robert Y.

description:
This is gonna be two reviews in one, because Yelp doesn't have a separate entry for Friday Nights at the Deyoung.  I'll break it down, though, because they're very different experiences.

Aite, here we goes!
(WARNING: This is part review, part personal ramblings.  I think Yelp is quickly replacing my personal blog, so ya'll just have to put up with my irrelevant personal notes!  You can stop here if you don't want to deal with all that.)

1.  The Deyoung Museum
+ Awesome location in the park.  Although, I'm a bit biased because I only live a few blocks away.
+ Every first weekend of the month, Bank of America customers can get in for FREE.  This is an AWESOME perk.  So break out that plastic; it is well worth it!
+  If you asked me to describe what kind of art this museum holds, I'd have trouble explaining because it's got so much: Oceanic, Revolutionary-era American art, Modern Art, random sculptures, African, and the list goes on.  They always have pretty cool special exhibits, including a recent Yves Saint Laurent piece, a Maya Lin domino-like installation, and more.  Stay tuned for craziness this summer when King Tut arrives; it'll be crazy/awesome when that happens.
+ There's a Turrell skyspace outside!  I like these things because you can sit in there for a long time and zone out or fall asleep or have long talks with whoever you're with.
+ It just feels...the way a museum should.  With all the dim lighting, the darkish rooms, the galleries.  Oh!  And it doesn't have much modern art, which is always cool in my book because I hate modern art. 

2.  Friday Nights at the Deyoung
So, I've heard of Friday Nights at the Deyoung for the past year or so but never bothered to check it out.  Tonight, my friend and I finally decided to hit up this event, and WOW, what a great introduction to Friday Nights @ the museum!  We walked in, and some lady asked me if I wanted to talk to some guy dressed as Andy Warhol who was being videotaped.  At first I was like, errrrrr, but then I thought, oh what the hell, I'll just do it, it could be fun.  

So, I signed some forms, sat down, had a really stupid, inane conversation with the actor, and then just as I was walking away, I read the poster which said that all the "interviews" would be posted online, on flickr, on facebook, and the one voted most "liked" would get some sort of prize.  Oh boo.  This was right after I gave them a bunch of fake contact information on the forms.  So now even if a prize comes along (srsly doubt it), I won't be getting anything, AND there's some stupid video of myself and a stupid actor talking about soap pads floating around online.  FML. 

But anyway, that was the worst of it.  Everything else was really cool.  There were special fashion exhibits, free Fiji water, a jazz band, and lots of swing dancing.  What I thought would be a night of just looking at and making fun of art surprisingly turned into almost two hours of swing dancing.  My friend and I were at least 10 years younger than everyone around us, but whatever, it was so awesome!  I've never done any swing dancing in my life, but this was so fun, and the crowd was so fun to watch, and so even though I was messing up a lot, I didn't care at all.  I felt just so happy and alive and nothing could wipe the smile off my face.  High on life.  That's how I felt. 

I had so much fun in those two hours, and I quickly realized afterwards that I don't want it to just end.  I just feel like if you meet a new person or discover a new thing or new experience that makes you so incredibly happy and feel so alive, by all means, GO FOR IT because life's too short to just stand on the sidelines and watch.  So now, I'm going to look into taking swing dancing lessons.  Swing is really cool, fun, cute.  I can/will do all that!

So, yes, spanks to the Deyoung Museum for putting on these FREE shindigs every Friday night, for giving people the opportunity to discover something new and exciting, for promoting cultural stuff that's also extremely fun and vibrant.

Five stars for cool museum, diverse artwork, consistently good special exhibits, free/fun Friday nights, and the opportunity to discover something new that makes you feel more alive than you have in a long, long time.  

Cheers to the Deyoung!
author: Vivian C.

description:
There are many interesting exhibits that get you asking yourself a lot of questions about the origin of artifacts and their meaning. Spent most of my time in the New Guinea area, working on a project for class, and found it all very interesting. Wish the King Tut exhibit was there when I went on Saturday, but I guess Ill have to go back again in June to experience it.
Also, It closes pretty early for a Saturday.
And bring your school ID if your in college or a muni transfer fee...you'll get a discounted admission. :)
author: Rachel D.

description:
I once had an architect spend a good half hour explaining to me that this building is genius and I would love it if I were smarter.  Guess what?  It's still ugly!  Did someone leave a copper dumpster next to the Bandshell?  I know, neo-classical architecture is supposedly not for smart people (yeah, I saw "The Fountainhead"), but shouldn't the building try to fit into its surroundings a little?  If not with the Bandshell, how 'bout with nature??  Yeah, yeah, oxidation.  I heard.

And those poor sphinxes that I used to think were my ponies... someone pack them up and bring them to my house, please.  They deserve to be somewhere that doesn't so obviously hate them for their outdated style.  They told me so.  WITH THEIR EYES.  

But I do realize that the old De Young jammed stuff in dark corners and smelled like wet cat.  And the new museum is well-lit and pleasant inside.  And sure, the tower is awesome.  But can someone tell me why the aerial map of San Francisco cuts off at Alemany?  Did the Portola and the Excelsior secede??  I guess it's not that important to tourists, but if you looked at a map of your whole city and your neighborhood wasn't on it, wouldn't you be pissed?  Just 'cause a cable car doesn't run by your house, it doesn't mean you don't exist.

Membership is affordable and includes the Legion, too.
author: Rosie W.

description:
The de Young  features American art arranged by time period (colonial onwards), Mayan/Mesoamerican art (ceramics, human figures), Native American art, African art, and art from Oceania (scary masks & headdresses).  

My husband appreciates the 20th Century & Contemporary Art collection at the de Young much more than I do but despite my preference for the European art at the Legion of Honor, I do appreciate the de Young for more than its clean, public bathrooms (the BEST in Golden Gate Park!).

The building itself is a work of art with its copper, oxidizing exterior, the sculpture garden and the observation tower.  It's affordable ($10 for adults, includes same day admission to the Legion of Honor) and you can enjoy plenty of the museum for FREE - like the small but better than average gift shop, the observation tower (with panoramic views and the aerial picture of SF at the street level - you can look for your house and SF landmarks) and the de Young Café (with wine, local & sustainable products).  Right now Lotta Jansdotter ceramics are on sale and the store also has some stylish Christmas cards.

Highlights:
* Wayne Thiebaud's gumball machines painting.  I can appreciate a guy who paints cakes, including cupcakes.
* Coffin shaped like a cocoa pod.  How unique!  A coffin shaped like an éclair would also be nice. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/RJ3NiTTSl00iT-Hu0-2ktQ?select=szb1Y4r9xCuIoyp9De1BpQ
* Hanging art installation made out of the charred remains of a vandalized Southern Baptist church.  Rather inspirational.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/RJ3NiTTSl00iT-Hu0-2ktQ?select=MJR-VmN5FmZUBW0iZ8Y0cA
* Pottery from Zanesville, Ohio - it's a small town but I've been there to visit my father-in-law's cousin.  The local clay is used for pottery.
* Scary art made with human skulls: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/RJ3NiTTSl00iT-Hu0-2ktQ?select=BRmnc17vcJhDkzARe6zgRw
* Chihuly glass chandelier from the special exhibit that ended on 9/28, looks like a Xmas ornament on a grand scale: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/RJ3NiTTSl00iT-Hu0-2ktQ?select=TV0hj6B8SBXs8BQPhE1uyw
* Fashion exhibits from time to time, YSL is up next, opening Nov. 1

Areas for improvement: 
* Most of the pieces have brief or no descriptions.  I'd like to know more about the background and history of significant pieces.  
* Special exhibits sometimes cost extra.  Guess this is common practice at museums but it's not one that I like.  
* Too many boring landscape paintings
* The wooden triangle benches are visually interesting but not comfy because they're either convex or concave.
author: Lolia S.

description:
So I know I should embrace, culture and rejoice in museums, but the De Young has flaws. Yes- FLAAAWS! 

It has a bunch of art and crap that I enjoyed, but I got lost like thirty times in this place- and honestly... it's so small! How can a person get lost and still feel like there should have been more? 

Good stuffs: The featured exhibits have always been the highlight of the visits- they truly know how to showcase each piece of art in a creative, and innovative way. The food in the cafeteria taste great. The permanent collection is always sorta entertaining... and the View of the from the stop of the Museum is simply breath taking on a clear sunny day. 

Bad stuffs: Babies Babies Babies! Control your babies!!!! The food in the cafeteria was expensive! I'm actually getting kinda bored of the permanent collection- bring some new permanent stuff in. The notations on what the ancients masks consist of seem shady- one read "human skull or coconut" - how can I take the museum as a whole seriously after that?!

Nice spot, but yea...
author: Nnekay F.

description: The Picasso Exhibit was wunderbar!  The DeYoung and surroundings are a fantastic place to spend a weekend day - you can go through the mind expanding collection of art inside the DeYoung museum and also stroll through the landscaped paths of Golden Gate Park, listen to band music from the bandshell, bring a picnic, etc.  One drawback is the parking; some jackalope in the park administration decided to block half the streets to cars, eliminating a lot of free parking ... so that you get to pay $4/hr to wait for a spot in line at their garage.
author: John S.

description:
Two words: Observation Deck.

-------
If I could live with a 4-word review, I would. But I can't, so here's the rest of the USEFUL info that you can gather from their website.

Part of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, admission tickets to the de Young may be used on the same day for free entrance to the Legion of Honor and vice versa. I haven't taken advantage of that yet. Never been to the Legion of Honor - perhaps for a Sunday brunch some day?

MUNI riders with Fast Pass or transfer receive a $2 discount. I did take advantage of this one. Showed my Fast Pass, even though I had driven into the park.

Friday Nights at the de Young are its way to stay hip and keep the crowds coming. I don't mind that at all. Live music, poetry, films, dance, tours, lectures, cocktails, food, artist demonstrations, and interactive art projects - YAY!

The tower closes at 4:30 p.m. Tuesday through Sunday and 8 p.m. Fridays. Friday Nights on hiatus November 30, 2007-January 11, 2008.

-------

And this is for Guri: 

Recommend: Yes!
Will I go back:  Yes!
Romantic:  Definitely, especially that Observation Deck!
author: Tinna H.

description:
So I didn't go into the actual museum but my friend Jihan showed me their observation floor which is FREE and has amazing views.

If you go into the De Young Museum after the check, take a right and then take a left after the ticket/member booths to a stairs/elevator.  Take the elevator to the . . . 9th? floor and you'll be in an awesome view of the city from the park.  

Very romantic and a great way to see the city.  I highly recommend it.  

There was also the small sculpture garden which is ok.  The park is probably nicer to see.
author: Dr K.

description:
I like it but I wouldn't say its effing amazing or anything. 
I think this not because it has bad art or anything, its just not my kind of art. They have a textiles gallery, old american art, african art, oceanic art, and so on. The rooms are all nicely lit to accommodate each theme. For example, the african art has low lighting but the items are viewable from 360 degrees.
The tower is nice too. You get a really nice overlook of the surrounding city. It gets pretty cramped with all the tourists though.
I didn't see the King Tut exhibit. I haven't heard many good reviews for it and I'm not willing to spend $35 for a show that doesn't even include the major artifacts (they won't let those leave Egypt). So you just get to see the small items. They advertised the King Tut headdress and surcoffogus but I don't think either item is in it.
I did pay the $10 to see the photography by Richard Avedon. Loved his stuff, plus the $10 doesn't just get you to see his works, it gets you into the other special gallery which was Ansel Adams and Georgia O'Keefe.
All in all, its worth a trip to check out.
author: Mandi W.

description:
I love museums, I really do. And I love art as well. But De Young was such a BORE! I mean seriously, we went through the entire museum in about 2 hours - fastest time EVER for me in a museum! 

The reason for our trip to De Young was to see the King Tut exhibit. I already knew that King Tut would not be there, so I wasn't disappointed about that. But being a fanatic about Ancient Egypt , I was very unimpressed by the King Tut exhibit. Most of the material I already knew or was familiar with. In retrospect, I don't think I would have missed much if I didn't see the exhibit. The crowd/lines inside the exhibit were ridiculous. I mean, come on! If there are designated entry times, you would think the crowd would be more manageable.

Yes, parking is a rip off, but when is parking ever a good deal?
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Honestly, I'd rather make art than look at it...unless there's free food involved, like at the awesome Oakland Art Murmur. I am not a very cultured person and walking around in this museum makes me feel like a phony.

The de Young is huge and impressive though. I came for the Asian American Art Exhibit (which I will Yelp soon) because my professor gave us this visit as an assignment. Student tickets for general admission are $6, which is very reasonable...but I can't say the same for the Special Exhibits (ie Asian American Art).

I don't have much to say about the museum besides that it is a must-visit for people who like these things. I went through the Yves Saint Laurent exhibit, but alas...I'm not into high fashion either! My favorite piece of his was this wedding dress which was like a white furry dome...seeing an actual model strutting down the runway in that thing would make my day. Hell yeah, the igloo look.

And then his quote: "The most beautiful clothes a woman can wear are the arms of the man who loves her." That's pretty clever Mr. Saint Laurent! Maybe I'll put it in my favorite quotes on Facebook. Only, this is San Francisco...let's not assume that it's a man doing the loving.

That being said, my favorite part of my visit to de Young was walking around with my hand held by the guy who likes me (I hope).
author: K W.

description:
Came out for the Bouquets to Art exhibit. It was packed. I was stepping over old ladies and strollers left and right. Nice extensive permanent collection. The African & Guinea objects are AMAZING.

Don't pay to park. It is an unnecessary expense when there is plenty of free parking in Golden Gate Park- plus you'll be rewarded with a scenic walk, and we all know you could use the exercise.
author: Jordan P.

description:
I can always count on the De Young Museum to have exciting exhibitions.  This time they had a special exhibition for Yves Saint Laurent, and, Asian American Modern Art featuring Maya Lin.  There was another exhibition showing off prints, but I get tired of prints fast.

The two major exhibitions are great.  Keep in mind that the Saint Laurent collection is the only showing in the country.  Why?  In the words of the Laurent house, "Well because they asked us."  Although I'm not much of a fan of looking at fashion displayed on mannequins, this wasn't much of  a problem.  The haute couture designs are so meticulously made that it'll impress the truck driver in you.

In all honesty I thought there would be more on Saint Laurent's creative process and techniques; instead, they just displayed many pieces from his prolific career.  That's not to say there isn't a lot of fashion to be seen.  So much evening wear!

The highlight for me was the Asian American Modern Art exhibition.  I'm a fan of Asian American Art, so this was a treat.  Often times I think that Asian American Artists are overlooked.  I was glad to see them mention this in their exhibition statement.

Maya Lin's exhibition is awesome as well.  Until now I haven't really heard of her.  She's an artist I'll be looking out for in the future.  She does sculpture work inspired by environmental formations.  Through the use of imaging techniques Lin manipulates wood, metal, and other mediums to portray the environment in a new exciting fashion.  She has an outdoor sculpture at the Academy of Sciences near the cafe so keep an eye out.  I always wondered who made that cool sculpture.

One gripe I have of De Young is their pricing of merchandise.  I understand that museums will charge a higher percentage than retail stores in order to sustain themselves.  But there comes a point when too much is too much.  Their Saint Laurent DVDs were going for $30.  And their Karl Lagerfeld DVDs were going for $36.  That's as much as a hardcover book!  I guess that's what the Internet is for.

NOTE: If you're feeling a bit adventurous try going here without buying a ticket.  Not once did I see anyone look at my ticket or sticker.  hahaha
author: Michael H.

description:
Review on the King Tut Exhibit
It took us about an hour and half to read and look at all the artifacts

when we first arrived at the museum it was great no line but within 20 minutes it was too packed 
the exhibit itself had some amazing artifacts that were in wonderful
condition
thing is most of the artifacts did not even belong to King Tut they belonged to his relatives BOO CHEAP
author: Viri A.

description:
Phenomenal. I cant believe it took me until this last weekend to visit. I was fortunate enough to see the Post Impressionist exhibit. (van gogh, Cezanne, Matisse) We arrived at 2, as suggested, to stand in line for the 2:30 showing. This didn't take too long, however, they could have done a better job at monitoring the crowds already and still viewing. When we made that final turn before entering the exhibit- my breath was literally taken away by the sight of a stunning golden piece titled "La Carmencita"...to the art director whom arranged the lighting for this event, bravo.... I tend to notice things other than the actual subject at times, and admired the frame work, and choice of wall colors in every room. Well, onto the Van Gogh...if you ever have the chance to see what "van gogh blue" is, in person, I suggest you do so...my heart flopped, and I literally struggled to fight back tears...it was incredibly moving. 

They do offer an audio tour, which can be quite annoying to some, since a lot of folks (with the headsets) just stand around for a longer period of time (it must be very informative)- and you kinda have to nudge your way around, however, I'm sure its not like this while viewing the permanent collection. 

If youre ever near, I highly suggest even just taking a peek off the tower deck...wow! (and free) I enjoyed this more than the view from Sears Tower... I cant wait to find an excuse to go again- especially since Ive been reading about the upcoming Picasso exhibit! Great place to find cool unique gifts (especially young budding artists)
author: Rosemary W.

description:
I was always fond of the old de Young, but I adore this one!  I'd read all the complaints about it in the newspaper and the opposition to the parking garage underneath.  Last year's Bouquets to Arts exhibit was the first time I'd been here.  It was shortly after I retired.  I was entranced w/ the exhibit, but I was equally taken w/ the building itself, which has windows in unexpected places offering glimpses of the outdoors, of landscaping enclosed w/in the building, of the copper exterior walls, of galleries below.  I love the convenience of the parking lot, which allows access when the park is closed to cars on weekends.

Nina, Larry, Alan and I came this morning for the Chihuly exhibit.  Nina and I first saw Chihuly's work 15 or 20 years ago, I think, in the little art museum on the campus of Southern Oregon University in Ashland and I was hooked.  I've seen it at the Smithsonian and in a variety of galleries and a huge show last year at the Fairchild Tropical Botanical Gardens in Miami.  The latter show was both inside and outside w/ glass artfully arranged among the plants.  This exhibit is more concentrated and it is exceptional.  The first room contains an exhibit of his vase-like forms.  Another room shows his ikebana forms.  A third room showed a collection of Native American patterned woolen trading blankets, most by Pendleton, on one long wall.  On the opposite wall was a collection of Chihuly basket forms intermingled w/ Native American baskets in various sizes and patterns.  A massive wooden plank running the length of the room in the middle was arranged more of the basket forms, some alone some nested.  The room was dim and the colors were earthy and translucent and it was mesmerizing.  The next room held huge, colorful Macchia, folded and mottled bowls.  At some point in the exhibit was a series of pale purple upright forms stuck into logs, looking like so many gorgeous birthday candles.  One room held chandeliers.  Another room held cylinders w/ woven glass designs fused onto the outside and the room adjacent to that had a glass ceiling on which seaforms and Persians were arranged.  It was impossible to keep my jaw from dropping open.  Another room contained two boats, one piled high w/ various colorful shapes exploding from it, the other a more quiet collection of large and colorful balls. The last room  was another long exhibit of various fanciful plant- and animal-like forms interspersed w/ large ball forms.  Everyone seemed as excited about the glass as we were.  In each room I heard guards admonishing people not to touch and to stay behind the grey tape or to be mindful of their purses.  They must have felt like kindergarten teachers.  I was annoyed at first, but it's completely understandable.  The glass is fragile and not to be touched, although I wanted to.  It's the kind of exhibit I'm going to want to return to.  Last year I was so thrilled w/ Bouquets to Art that we joined the museums, so we're members and I can, as often as I want.

We went to the observation tower, which affords an incredible 360* view of San Francisco and environs.  You can see the Academy of Sciences building across the concourse, getting ready for its September opening.  The bandshell is being renovated.  After lunch we went outside to see the saffron tower, but it wasn't that impressive in the daylight.  Maybe at night.  The towers we saw at Fairchild were much more striking.  The Andy Goldsworthy piece in the entrance on the way out was powerful and interesting. 

We looked a little at some of the permanent collection and then decided to go home.  But as we were on our way to the garage our attention was caught by a video, "Chihuly in the Hot Shop", a 90 minute account of his reunion w/ glassblowers he'd worked w/ 20 years ago.  We came in in the middle and couldn't stay until the end, but what we saw was pure glass porn.  We bought one to take home.
author: Toni M.

description:
We have all acted for so long like Andy Warhol's art is really great because everyone else says it is so great.  We want to stand in front of his works and say stuff like, "That Andy Warhol really had vision", "Andy Warhol broke down barriers", and "Andy Warhol liked to dress up as a clown and run around scaring children."  Okay, not the last one, but what I really ended up saying is "this is crap".  The emperor has no clothes.  Maybe it's because I'm not as celebrity-crazed as some or maybe some would say I just don't have sophisticated taste, but honestly out of maybe 200 pieces, I liked about 5 (and those mostly from his early work).  Can't we just all admit that Warhol was a drugged out, partying, eccentric, flamboyant, and quirky artist who may have been amusing and interesting but mostly generated garbage?

Not to be a party pooper, but I felt a bit the same about the YSL exhibit.  Yes, I'm a dude, so I don't think I am exactly in the target audience for this one in the first place.  But, 95% of the stuff in the YSL exhibit was outrageous and gaudy and nobody would ever wear it outside.  I just don't get that about fashion.  The handful of "normal" pieces could be pretty hot, but it was hard to tell when they were draped on mannequins from 1982.  

I don't like being a downer and giving negative reviews - I really wanted to like the De Young.  But, I'm not willing to lie to feign sophistication by someone else's standard (what, you're not supposed to eat hot tamales while drinking wine?).  The building is cool, the size of the museum is manageable and not overwhelming, and there is some pretty good variety with the African, American, and Latin American collections, as well as some mod stuff.  But, overall I'd honestly say skip it.
author: Brad K.

description:
Cheap for students + Muni passport/city pass holders

I had really high hopes for this place. I really like the architecture of it, base on the pics that I saw. But in person, the color of the outside (dark brown) doesn't look good compare to the Academy of Science nearby. 

The art itself was interesting, but only barely, and the lighting was so dim that my gf and I got sleepy walking around. We had to head to the cafe for a cup of Joe 1/4 of the way through. We didn't go back since the weather was so nice outside. 

The only thing that made it 3 stars was the price. College student ID + Muni passport  = $4 per person.
author: Jack N.

description:
We went to Friday Night at the De Young last week  to join friends in seeing the Andy Warhol and the Yves Saint Laurent exhibits.

I remember the old De Young. The museum was tired. The art wasn't presented well. The building was falling down. And, that's how it was when I went the first and last time-- 25 years apart.

The new museum is a shining example of what's possible. The building is an architectural delight. The exhibits were fantastic. And, this idea of getting the public to come and spend Friday nights at an art museum is inspired. How we got parking I will never know. Thank you, Karma!

 We ended up getting a membership because you get to bring two friends in for free. We figure if we go to the Legion of Honor the pass and back to the De Young-- the membership will be paid for. Of course, I was shocked when we were told that it'd take "two to three months" for our permanent membership cards to arrive. That's just insane.

We'll definitely be going back. Next, the Legion of Honor.
author: Dave B.

description: I really enjoyed the Olmec exhibit but my favorite is their Oceanic art collection. It's impressive.
author: Sheila T.

description: I love the de Young Museum! Here's my illustrated review: http://sfbay.ca/2012/05/15/de-young-museum/
author: Mari N.

description:
Things you should know about Fridays at The DeYoung that they should tell you before you go but neglect to mention:

-It is CHILD FRIENDLY. If you do not like children or do not wish to be caught up in a swarm of them, this is not the place for you. There are exactly 5 children I care to spend quality time with. And never on a Friday night.

-The service will be short, cold, and at times downright unprofessional and rude. The "security guard" outside actually started a verbal altercation with Basi L and WOULD NOT back down, even though there was no problem to begin with. 

-If there is a special exhibit, you may have to wait in a line running the length of the entire lobby for over an hour to get anywhere near said exhibit.

-Unless you have a really good job, you probably won't be able to afford to get drunk enough here to make the visit worth your while. Even when money's not an issue, I value my time. And the time it takes to actually get to the bar, order, and wait for the "bartender" to pour a damn glass of wine is just plain outrageous.

I thought this would be like Thursdays at MOMA- civil, social, and a great way to relax at the end of the day. I couldn't have had it more twisted. I've been a member at the DeYoung since they reopened and feel more fortunate now than ever that I have the option of dropping in on weekDAYS, when everyone and their children are at work or school and I can enjoy the exhibits in peace and have a quiet glass of wine on the patio outside. 

-
author: Autumn K.

description: I love the grounds of the de Young and the observation tower.  The exhibits are a delight - far reaching with live performances (for free),  fashion, glasswork, furniture, and jewelry in addition to all sorts of cool "traditional" art.   Some of the exhibits are more successful than others, but it's always nice to have a place unafraid to push the envelope and take risks.
author: Lempi M.

description: You need a sack of gold just to get in!  I hate how museums have turned into money-making schemes.  It costs a fortune to go in, costs a fortune to shop.  How are the lower class supposed to partake in knowledge and our shared human history?  To hell with them! Come see a mockery of human history with King Tut! $100 bucks, please!  Want a King Tut coffee mug? $50 bucks, please!  King Tut t-shirts!  Step right up! Step right up!
author: Brian L.

description:
Culture.  

It's very important to ones civilized well-being.  More than that, it is important to my well-being, as I am a classy lady with classy tastes (evident from my love of Natural Ice Light, Prescription Drugs and Bon Jovi).

Sunday afternoon Sammy S. and I took our very refined aestheticism on over to the De Young for the Vivienne Westwood exhibit for a look at the collected works of one of the centuries most renowned designers.

We walked in not sure what to expect, but knowing we were in for something very...special.  

My mental notes (as I am very visual) go something like this...

The fabric is arrestingly erratic.
The dresses are fragmentary and billowing.
The shoes are scandalous at best.
The hats looked like caricatures or breasts.

And that's when it hit me like a ton of bricks.  Vivienne's work was obviously the inspiration for one of the best collections of all-time.  A collection so avant-garde, so outlandish, so bizarre that only one man could pull it off.  

DERELICTE! as worn by Derek Zoolander.

Fashion.  There really is no accounting for taste, is there?
author: Rachel G.

description:
VISITING THE DE YOUNG - 5 stars
I love the de Young museum! The regular exhibits are decent, but the special exhibits are always great. Friday nights at the de Young are a blast. It's great that they have live music in the lobby. I do wish they kept the tower open a little later though - being up in the tower at night would be quite an experience! The de Young is truly an amazing place, and the store is fun to browse. If you decide to drive to the museum, keep in mind that the nearby streets tend to be pretty chaotic. You can sometimes find free street parking near the intersection of Fulton Street and 10th Avenue. Note that Fulton has a 2 hour limit whereas the numbered streets don't.

RENTING THE DE YOUNG - 3 stars
The short version: the de Young is a wonderful place for any special event. We are so glad we had our wedding at there. 5 stars for the gorgeous venue, but 2 stars for some of the staff we had to deal with. No issues when dealing with the facility rental staff directly. However, there was clearly a serious lack of communication between the staff and security personnel. Can't believe how unreasonable and difficult they were to deal with on the day of the event.

The long version: The facility rental staff are really good with email. Securing the date, signing the contract, etc, were pretty straight forward. Keep in mind that the vendors on their recommended vendors list tend to be quite pricey, and you are limited to a small selection of approved catering companies. Everything went really smoothly with the de Young until the rehearsal and the day of the wedding...

We held our rehearsal in the sculpture garden (the actual space of our ceremony) on a weekday afternoon. We were interrupted multiple times by different security personnel telling us we were not allowed to be in the garden. Each time someone came to tell us off, I told them the facility rental manager was aware we were holding a wedding rehearsal at that time. Eventually, security told us we absolutely had to get out of the garden ASAP and should use the cafe terrace instead. Firstly, why would we come all the way out to Golden Gate Park to hold our rehearsal in the space adjacent to our actual ceremony space? For the amount of money we paid to rent the venue, I think an hour long rehearsal should be allowed. Secondly, it doesn't make any sense for us to be on the cafe terrace playing music on our little boombox while other museum visitors were sitting there eating and drinking. Security would rather us disturb other visitors on the terrace than let us rehearse in the empty garden. 

On the day of the wedding, the main entrance security personnel would not let us inside the museum because we had flowers. They told us to wait by the doors until we were granted special clearance. San Francisco in July is absurdly cold. My bridesmaids and I were freezing! Then, another member of security later came over to yell at us for standing near the doors. Awesome. Security also mistook the groom's parents for guests and refused to let them inside even though their names were on a list of approved people. Completely ridiculous that security kept trying to turn them away without even bothering to consult the list. 

Our florist and her staff showed up at the de Young around 1pm. They started decorating the garden with paper lanterns. Security made them take the lanterns down even though the lanterns had been pre-approved. Someone else showed up and said the lanterns were fine, so our florist put the lanterns back up. Then, someone else yelled at them for hanging lanterns on the trees again. Eventually, we had to sort this out with the on-site staff ourselves. Not exactly something you want to deal with a couple hours before your wedding ceremony.

de Young staff wouldn't let our florist and her team unload any flowers and insisted that everything be stored in some storage space until about an hour before the wedding. As a result, $500 of orchids wilted in some storage space. Wow, what a waste. Our florist was forced to improvise and sent her team to nearby stores to pick up pink roses at the very last minute. Apparently the de Young staff member on site threw a fit and stormed off when our florist started arranging rose petals on the tables to make up for the missing orchids. I did not see this myself, but it does not sound very professional at all. 

After our event, we felt like we were being rushed to leave. I understand they needed us to clear out so they take down everything and clean up, but it was very overwhelming as we were saying goodbye to guests and gathering our belongings. Not a pleasant end to the night. We're so glad we chose to have our wedding at the de Young, but things could have gone a lot smoother.
author: Waz W.

description:
Have you seen the third Harry Potter movie? The one where Harry gets fed up living with his asshole aunt and uncle and decides to runaway. Then that freak wizard bus comes and picks him up and this Jamaican-talking body-less head with dreadlocks starts talking to him and telling him to take his seat and shit. Well, I think I figured out that the producers of Harry Potter actually borrowed that dread-locked head from the De Young's African Art collection, because for reals yo, I saw it there yesterday.

If you think I'm a mature lady who is a connoisseur of fine wines, fine arts and fine food, then you have sadly been fooled suckas!

I like tator tots, wine under $10 from TJ's, and art that isn't too difficult to figure out, and doesn't make me giggle and point because it has boobies and thingers visible.

Even though, as Rachel G. so eloquently pointed out in her review, the Vivienne Westwood Exhibit resembled the famed couture line from Zoolander's  "Derelict," I was still charmed by the collections as I am by all clothes. The three tongued, 10 inch shoes were delicious, the Grecian-like dresses were gorgeously quirky, and the bustier were hot like a freaking trollop!! Some of the collections, like "Witches," and others that seemed burlap-bag inspired went a bit over my head, but for the most part I thoroughly enjoyed ogling the goodies, especially the videos. I'm a short busty Jewish chick with an ass, so fashion modeling has never been something I thought about pursuing, but watching those magnificent creatures strut the most ridiculous, yet brilliant get-ups on the runways is pure magic to me.

The rest of the exhibits were impressive as well, although the African and Asian art exhibits brought out the 12-year-old boy in me, and the American Art mystified me beyond belief. Rachel and I had a very detailed conversation about how fugly the rich women from the early 1900s were. They looked like men. They were decorated in fabulously decadent gowns but their faces looked like Nick Nolte. We decided that if we had been alive during that time we would have been freaking models. All the men in the powdered wigs would be all up in our business cause we so hot.

Oh, and the highlight of our trip to the De Young? Drumroll please.....

We saw Steven Spielberg!!!! Or a Spielberg look-alike, or a Jewish friend's dad who happen to keep smiling at us. Either way, it was exciting.
author: Sammy S.

description:
I have memberships to several of the museums in SF because I love to check out art and take my friends so that they can check out art without having to pay for it. Some people go to yoga to unwind, I go to galleries and museums.

This museum doesn't disappoint. There is a lot to look at, including the building itself, and they have some very cool exhibits come through. I would definitely go here if you have not been yet!!

Minus one star because....

I do wish they would make the content of their plaques and blurbs more "people friendly". Not everyone is an art lover or art critic or particularly schooled in art. Much of the verbage on the plaques is pretty assumptive that you have a basic art history knowledge. Works fine for me, but many people dont know much about art. The way they word things creates an environment which is not very thought provoking and doesn't lend well to learning more about art and how you percieve it.
author: Drue C.

description:
The new architecture is sharp, as is the view from the observation floor. It's funny how the tourists spend more time looking at a satellite map on the wall than at the actual city through the windows. Still, I left feeling like I didn't get my money's worth. I still recommend it, especially if there's a special exhibit worth seeing... like one on cat with funny cowboy hat.

I got the closest I've ever been to a Roman-inspired marble statue, and she was hot! Me to her: "Don't worry, baby... I won't take you for granite..."
author: Keane L.

description: I always love going here, just saw the Jean Paul Gaultier Exhibition, amazing!!
author: Elizabeth A.

description: The review is only for the museum cafe. 4 of us went for lunch last Fri and although the menu was not extensive,all our picks were delicious -the braised chicken dish, quiche and the nicoise salad. Also,the observation tower is a must!
author: Renuka V.

description:
Recently renovated, this museum is an eye sore.  In the evening, the building looks nice lit up.  However during the day, the entire structure is covered with a dark brown grid looking material.  The construction of the rooms are also somewhat confusing, it gets exhausting as you meander around.  You are pretty much at a lost as far which way to go. The only thing that I did like is the 360-degree view from the de Young Tower.  There is an direct elevator that goes up to the top level. The elevator does not stop anywhere on the way back down to the first floor.  It's not nearly as high up as the view from Twin Peaks but it's worth seeing.

The collection is so so.  Religious paintings, weaved baskets and blankets, carpets, tapestries, craved ivory and wood, recent artwork from unfamiliar artists, blown glass, wearable art, etc.  Gallery highlights include Art of the Americas, Native American Art, Art of Africa, Art of Oceania, and Textiles.  A changing photography exhibition, I saw a few celebrity portraits of Sophia Loren, Audrey Hepburn, Kirk Douglas, etc.  I didn't see Art in America to the 20th Century, and Contemporary American Art which other reviewer said was boring, maybe I didn't miss anything.  The artist names for the American art here that I am familiar with are Copley, Sargent, Cassatt, Lloyd Wright, O'keeffe, Rivera, and de Kooning.  The art collection does not include my favorite periods, impressionist and neo-impressionist. From the visitors guide, "Guest artists present exhbitions on the themes of shifting identities, personal narratives, and cultural assumptions."  This is a museum?  Hmmm, whatever.  There seems to be a whole lot of something going on, what that is I can't really say.

There are two "Introduction to the de Young" docent tours a day, which might be a good idea as the the traffic flow and room placement is pretty random.  The Nan Kemper - American Chic exhibit was closed for some reason.  No flash in the galleries, still photography is allowed.  Select galleries are open until 8:45pm, last tickets sold one hour prior to closing. Friday night late hours are on hold between November 30 - January 11, 2008.  $10 for adults which includes same day entry to the city's other Fine Arts Museum, The Legion of Honor.  Since the tickets for the Legion of Honor are $15, go to the De Young first to purchase the tickets, take a quick look see, go up to the de Young Tower, and then head over to the Legion of Honor.  That's really the only reason I would recommend coming here, sorry to say - two stars.
author: Nancy Y.

description:
What a cool museum! I'm so glad that they renovated the old museum. The tower is definitely a place to go - the views of San Francisco are spectacular - especially this time of the year when there is no fog.

Most recently, S and I came to the De Young to view the Chihuly exhibit. I agree with Char L. that the exhibit is amazing! The colors and shapes of the glass is truly breathtaking! Make sure that you purchase tickets on-line before arriving (especially if you plan to see the exhibit on a weekend) as lines can get very long. 

The admission to the Chihuly exhibit also gives you general admission to the rest of the museum. Great artifacts from Africa and the South Pacific. 

If you wish to take a camera with you, pictures are allowed as long as you turn off your flash.
author: Mercy B.

description: Fantastic museum! I came here with my family and really enjoyed the beautiful pieces of art. Also, they have a beautiful garden outside. I saw a wedding reception being set up for the evening while we were there. Very nice! I hope to come back soon.
author: Liz G.

description:
The current Picasso exhibit is fantastic!  If you're a fan of Picasso (and who isn't?)  you'll be blown away with the power & energy of the exhibit.
I coulda' literally spent all day there in the gallery daydreaming over the masterpieces.  I don't get the few bad reviews for this museum .  All they do is consistently bring the most sought after exhibits like King Tut, Monet-Impressionists, Van Gogh, Olmec, Cartier, Faberge, etc.  The list goes on.  Note well:  The first Tuesday of each month, you can get a discount on admission (usually around 50%).  If you object to the  pay parking garage, you can park along most of the Golden Gate Park access roads and walk in.  It's a beautiful area.  First time visitors could easily spend the whole day at the museum and surrounding park grounds.  I haven't been to the observation deck yet, but heard it's a must see too.  If you go regularly, it might make sence to join as a member in terms of cost & benefits.  The de Young is world-class.
author: Darrin K.

description: Went to the Jean Paul Gaultier exhibit today. It was exceptional. Might be my favorite I have seen yet there. To take in a comprehensive viewing of this man's life's work so far is to see the making of contemporary haute and pret-a-porter. It is impossible to adequately state the level of artistry at work here. I spent a couple of hours. Coud've stayed the whole day. The manequins have faces eerily projected as movies onto the faces of the manequins, who speak in tongues, sing songs, whistle, tell of the life story of the garments, and initially even Gaultier himself is there as a sailor introducing the whole thing in French and English. You must see this. You must.
author: Seth S.

description:
come with plenty of time because this museum is huge!!
it displays art form all around the world, i highly recommend for people to visit and enjoy culture and history form around the globe.
author: Natalie R.

description: Been here a buncha times, but most recently on mother's day when the whole place was free! We spent the whole time at the warhol live exhibit and it was great. I'd seen several warhol shows at various galleries over the years, but this was a different angle. The music and film side were emphasized, and being a big velvet underground fan, I was blown away by the memorabilia. I also liked the stones stuff.  I had trouble explaining the gestalt of his 9 hour film of the empire state building to my girl ("it just doesn't make sense", exclaimed ms. practical).
author: Henry Y.

description:
Since we were already parked and in the mood to check out exhibits, Cal and I visited De Young for the heck of it. I'm really glad we did because it gave us a chance to get to know each other. I think the only way to get to know someone is to experience different things together, and exploring art is definitely an interesting way to do that. I found out that Cal did a report on Thomas Cole and the Hudson River School. Cal found out that I get freaked out by New Guinea art. We walked through that exhibit so fast. Both of us were moved by Cornelia Parker's "Anti-Mass." We were a bit tired after checking out the Academy of Science and De Young, that we decided to eat here.

Our meal consisted of chicken potato soup, a grilled chicken sandwich, and the greek salad. It was definitely pricey. I think water was close to $3 for a bottle. But the flavors, texture of the food coupled with the outdoor setting made for a great dining experience.
author: Mary T.

description:
terrible online ticket system. always a pain in the ass to book the tickets.

And next time for special exhibition, for god's sake, don't stuff them in the basement.  I know there may be security concerns, but I am so sick and tired of the "SOLD OUT".
author: Barry W.

description:
Kind of ironic how everything in de young museum is pretty old. 

The Met in NYC blows this place out of the water but some of the collections and displays are impressive. I hate to be a Debbie Downer but this museum didn't get my juices flowin. If I had to choose, I definitely rather go to The Academy of Sciences.
author: Jen Y.

description: I got free admission because of my account with Bank of America. I wasn't too impressed with their collection of art. I wouldn't pay full price to come back.
author: Jordi P.

description:
This was my first time at the De Young, which we went to for the King Tut exhibit.

We had tickets for the 4:00 entry on a Saturday into the exhibit, but because of the popularity of the exhibit, we ended up standing in Disneyland-esque lines (yes, multiple lines) for the next 45-60 minutes. I wanted to spend time in the museum afterwards, but we didn't have time.

The exhibit was crowded because it was so popular, but once you started looking at the artifacts, everyone else disappeared. The quality of the items on display is remarkable. Beautiful jewelery, headpieces and even chairs still in great condition from the 1300's B.C., and the last four rooms was all items from King Tuts tomb.

Although, with the recent news about his family and cause of death, the exhibit was a little outdated by the time we got to see it.

Overall, I love Egyptian history and I'm so glad we went. The only thing I would change is the time we got tickets for. Now I know the earlier the better!
author: Ellen S.

description:
I walked in around 2 pm on a Sunday.. DO NOT, I REPEAT, DO NOT GO ON A SUNDAY!!!!  It was the thing to do on this particular Sunday at least.  We parked in the garage, cost $9 for 3 hours.  When we walked in, it was a mess, people everywhere, but we finally got our tickets and you get a discount with a student ID, Muni Pass or transfer about a $3 discount.  We decided to see the rest of the museum before going to Chihuly exhibit, which is what we came for.  Although in the end we did not have a choice, because of the popular demand, you are assigned a time to view the exhibit.

We watched the video on how the pieces are made, which was very informational and interesting.  I never knew how many people it took and the equipment used to create glass pieces such as these.

Everything about the pieces is incredible and is a MUST SEE!

Pictures to come!
author: Megan L.

description:
Most recent visit: Chihuly Exhibit! 

The exhibit speaks for itself... simply amazing.  LOVED the persians part of the exhibit =)  As for the museum.... the permanent exhibits are interesting and the new bright green garage makes it so convenient to park and just walk over to the museum....or the other places nearby, like the tea garden.

-1 Point: the lady at the membership counter was straight up rude! (If anything...this is how you treat members?!)
author: Kelley N.

description:
The missus and I decided to take in the new DeYoung museum after regarding its incredibly ugly tower from various vantage points outside the park. Between rain squawls on Sunday, we traipsed as a couple that was grateful to get out of the rain, as well as a couple of art lovers who might consider membership. Bottom Line: STAY AWAY.

The building is not what I would consider a "gift to the street". It looks more like a grain elevator that's been caught in some sort of mosquito netting for protective purposes. Inside, the layout is confusing to the point of off-putting. I'm willing to accept a certain amount of creative splitting up of galleries, hallways, stairways and elevators but this is ridiculous. 

Staffing was a mixed bag... Some people were incredibly polite and helpful. One kind person actually led us away from a long line at admissions and moved us toward self-service PCs that, among other things, asked whether we'd like to become members. I thought it might be a good idea (seeing as we've joined just about every other museum in town) but my wife sagely recommended a wait-and-see-if-we-like-the-place attitude. Good thing!

There's some kind of gray eminence that prevails over the venue. To my eye, the galleries were darker than they should be. Acoustics were LOUD. I like some peace and quiet to look at art and the hard floors and sourd reflecting walls and ceilings seemed to amplilfy any noise in the room.

But the museum's real problem is one of public relations and handling its prospects. There's an attitude there that is not friendly toward visitors. The collections are stunning. As a for instance, we tried to go to the Frank Lloyd Wright exhibit, only to learn that it costs an extra $5 per person or some such to attend. That would have been fine, but at four-thirty or somewhere around that time, the admissions desk where you could pay the extra money was closed. The museum was open for another 1/2 hour, so we figured that it might be a good opportunity for management to essentially "promo" a short visit, but NO-O-O-O. We were turned back at the entry. It isn't good publicity to not permit a person to see a gallery without a ticket and then not provide a way for people to buy a ticket, even if their visiting time would be limited.

Okay, rightee-oh, on to the next attraction. How about the fine collection of art of the Americas. Really pretty. Two floors up. Maybe take the elevator, Guess What? Elevator only goes up one floor. Have to change. No problem. But where. Guides don't know but one has enough presence of mind to tell my wife that the back pack that is hanging by one band over her shoulder and then cradled in the crook of her arm must be "hand held." Meaning, we suppose that neither of its shoulder straps should be laced over the shoulder. 

What's that all about.

We entered feeling good about getting out of the rain and harboring general good will toward the museum as a shelter from the storm. We left thinking, "Boy am I glad we didn't join! This place thinks way to much of itself."

Then we were outside. The sun was shining. And we looked back at a building that is a true eye sore and felt glad to escape to prettier parts of GGP, like the arboretum across the street.
author: Dan M.

description: I've been an annual member for some time now. I love the Friday events.
author: M R.

description:
Overrated, overrated, overrated. The museum building itself looks like an airport (complete with control tower), and a lot of the so-called exhibits are of questionable artistic significance (for instance, when I placed a half-empty pack of Marlboros on a stack of books, I had no idea I could have encased the result in a Plexiglas box and shipped it to De Young.) 

But what really detracts from the museum-going experience there are the rude, overly aggressive rent-a-cops there. Am I at a museum, or at Baghdad Airport?

Do yourself a favor and visit the Japanese Tea Garden instead.
author: Paul K.

description:
Unlike Los Angeles which requires you to drive all over clogged streets and gridlocked freeways to visit the Getty Center and LACMA, San Francisco is so blessed to have cultural attractions in Golden Gate Park.  I haven't visited since its remodeling, and De Young does not fail to disappoint.  Various things from my visit:

1.  The architecture of De Young is stunning:  the bronzed cladding and the unique V-shaped design of the building is a pleasure to admire.  The 360 degree view from the observation deck tower is amazing, and I didn't know that the view rivaled the one from Embarcadero Center.  All around you, one can see the Golden Gate Park, the various districts of the City, the Golden Gate Bridge, downtown, the Bay and the Pacific Ocean.  This view is worth the picture!

2.  Collections are superbly presented, yet slightly random:  while I enjoyed the well-organized and themed floors, it often felt that the De Young lacked a sense of consistency.  I was looking forward to seeing their Asian art collections, but I saw little of those.  There seems to be little sense of unity in their collections, and often seemed to lack of theme in what they are attempting to project to the visitor.  Perhaps they could introduce larger focal pieces that would direct my attention to any theme?

3.  Sculpture garden and random art pieces a surprising joy to see:  the modern art garden is perfect for taking pictures and on a sunny SF day, sitting outside at the De Young Cafe and enjoying time with those you came with makes visiting this star jewel of SF a pleasure.  To experience San Francisco culture, no visit isn't complete without checking out De Young.

Highly recommended as a must-see in SF.
author: JC K.

description:
I gotta point out that my other review was for the over-hyped and disappointing King Tut show.  In general, I [heart] the deYoung's shows.  Even the shows that I wanted to hate have often been exhilarating.  The Gaultier exhibition defies description.  In fact I always enter a fashion designer show wondering what the hell it's doing in a ART museum, goddammit?  But every one of them has been a work of art, not only for the amazing craftsman (woman) ship and imagination, but the way everything works together and explains the trajectory of the intention of the artist.  
Even the Dale "Las Vegas" Chilhouly exhibition was jaw-droppingly beautiful.  Each room presented a different way to analyze beauty and color.  I'm a member, and I'm glad.  
The only reason I dock them one star is that they almost always have an ugly white plastic party tent that totally insults the dramatic architecture of the outdoor patio under the huge cantilevered roof on the west side of the building.  The magnificent building, I should say!
author: Rob B.

description:
You know...my feelings are really mixed on this place. On one hand...this whole museum row has been spruced up from 10 years ago. The rooms are open and the collection is pretty extensive. However, it is pricey and if you go there during one of their special exhibits be prepared to elbow and fight your way to see anything. Today I went to see the flower exhibit and let me tell you...I had to hold my own with women over 75 yrs young. It was scary, annoying, and frustrating all at the same time. I don't think I took one picture without someone walking right into the shot. The whole photo album should be called "People of the de Young". 

So although it has special exhibits and goods one all the time it's hard to get to see anything or enjoy it because you're fighting your way through all the time. 

Final thoughts - meh
author: Sasha B.

description:
I've visited the De Young several times in the past year, but have never gotten around to writing a review until now.  If you haven't been to this world-class museum yet, I would definitely suggest doing so now because the new Chihuly special exhibit is awesome- literally, you will be awestruck by the beauty of his work and installations as you travel through the exhibit.  Even my brother, who tends to be both crowd and art-averse, thought the exhibit was gorgeous and well-worth spending a sunny Saturday afternoon inside.

The Chihuly exhibit showcases some of the greatest glass sculptures you'll ever see up-close and personal.  The beauty of this exhibit is that you can get pretty close to see all the various colorations in the glass, while also taking in the installation as a whole.  Photos without flash are allowed, so bring a camera or at least your cell phone, so that you can capture some of the beauty in front of you.  Be prepared for long lines though- both to purchase tickets and then going through the exhibit itself.  Make sure that you show up EARLY- tickets to the exhibit do sell out before the museum closes, since the last group gets to go in at 4 pm.

While the star of my visit today was the Chihuly exhibit, the De Young also offers the tower and observation deck, which is surprisingly free.  Its been great to be able to view the progress of the new Academy of Sciences building across the way, as well as to just get views of a part of San Francisco that you normally would not get.  Their cafe is also pretty good- you can sit inside if its a cold, foggy day or sit outside on the grass if its nice.

All in all, a great musuem that most definitely warrants a trip to Golden Gate Park.  Parking can be a bit of a hassle, but with enough patience and some luck, you'll be able to find free street parking.  The Chihuly exhbit runs until September, so you've got the entire summer to go!
author: Angela H.

description:
My favorite museum as an art lover and as a teacher taking kids on field trips. The education department is fabulous...the docents are volunteers so they are hard to judge as a complete reflection of the establishment. I love it!

Go to the Japanese Tea Garden next door after you are done!
author: Kristina H.

description:
This is a review on the space alone and collection alone.  The space is amazing, wonderful couldn't be better.  We had a corp event private viewing last weekend, and we were to view ''native American Indian artwork"  OK, so we all think stick people on bison belly's' great right?

wrong, broken pots from Mexico and bad ones at that, i was not impressed at all.  Made me feel like I was looking at bad Etruscan pots.  And the standing in house collection really lacked.  I assume when they have great exhibits, sure I could see how it would be ideal.  Yet as is, De young needs to step up the in house goods!!  Not impressive
author: Nicole F.

description:
mh, I have mixed thoughts about this place. I love it's design, I like being on the tower and I like the museum itself. I do have issues with the staff, which is unusual for me. I work with a Service Dog and once I was asked what breed my dog was. I was surprised when they told me that they need to know so I could get access to the museum...... That was the most nonsense thing I have heard in a long time.
Staff was rude and uneducated to the point that they stalked me around. The staff person paged the other staff and told them that "there is that woman with chopped off hair and a white shirt who refuses to cooperate" That stunned me. I just moved on. It was beyond rudeness.
This has never happened to me in all those years that I had Service Dogs. Jolanda is well known in the city and well trained. She is friendly and kind. It took me by surprise and I have not been back ever since, which is a shame, but I don't want to go through this again..

I wrote to the museum, reported this incident and educated them about the law. No one has responded. I find this disappointing and will file a complaint with the DOJ soon. 
Shame. I learned from another SD handler that she has experienced the same thing and also did not get a response from the museum..
This is something the majority of the visitors are not confronted with..
author: Sonja O.

description:
I am specifically reviewing a womderful exhibit  currently at the Deyoung Musuem thru March 28, 2010 entitled "King Tut." " As Howard Carter looked into King Tut's tomb, Lord Carnarvon asked, "Can you see anything?' Carter answered-"Yes, wonderful things."

Indeed this is the truth-WONDERFUL THINGS! And a museum exhibit so unique and mind-blowing that your mind just funnels back away into the time of the Pharohs ! Not that I would claim to be an Egypt-phile, but the sheer splendor of the curatorship had my head spinning.

The DeYoung is a very modern building with a whole heck alot of SECURITY! Everywhere! They check your purse good when you come in, but once your in...statutes, figurines, painted wooden vessels, decorated drinking cups, an elegant death mask of Queen Nefertiti.
Shanti's-or funeral figurines are awash in embellishments. The color turquoise is prominently featured as are lotus flowers because both symbolize regeneration and endurance.  Ankh signs are everywhere,  and I was particularly impressed   with all the bovine goddess statues-I guess cows were worshipped back then?

There was other magnificent furniture and balustrades depicting all kinds of royal scenes. I totally coveted a beautiful scarabv clasp bracelet-GOLD with a giant turquoise scarab beetle on it-TOO COOL FOR School! A 6 foot long gilded coffin was impressive and made for a nice-looking rest place for the afterlife.

Everyone into Egyptology should check this exhibit out.  It was pricey to get in-around $30 but well worth it! The gift shop had fantastic items but they were expensive too. I lucked out and found a defective serpent goddess statue  marked down! Oh-this place was so over-the-top GREAT-I didn't want to leave, But leave I did-and here's the story-GO CHECK OUT TUT!
author: Gail P.

description: Warning do not buy tickets to their exhibits at Costco- they do not honor them! Every admission voucher from Costco has a unique coupon ID which is supposed to represent a ticket but the museum can chose not to redeem it. I am now out $40 which the de young museum I'm sure was happy to add to their bottom line. Seriously talk about unethical business practices!
author: Caitlin B.

description:
I've loved the design even when it was under construction. Since my firm did the environmental impact report for the project, we got to do a tour while the art was being installed and learned from the architects that the reason behind the copper panels was so that it would look like "the skin of the building is having a conversation with the trees." Uh, okay... But now that the "skin" of the building is weatherizing and turning green and brown, it really does fit in with our little urban jungle. And the tower is genius--the view from there is almost eerie to me--like only birds and angels are supposed to have that vantage. 

But enough on the building--the art! With my Pop in town, I finally had the opportunity to go there to actually view the installations. I was mesmerized by the African exhibit--particularly the playful wood-carved statues with big smiles on their faces and arms upraised. These people didn't even have SUVs or video games in the 12th century, but apparently they were happy!! 

And you should go before December 21st b/c the temporary exhibit of quilts from the women of Gee's Bend, Alabama were heart-wrenchingly beautiful.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
The De Young has a little something for everything and even something for those that don't know what they want.  There was a surprise around every corner even an old man farting while his wife enjoyed the art.  I was not happy with the farting so I quickly turned around and headed to another corner to find a nice surprise.

The day GBF#1 and I went there was a bunch of artwork by some San Francisco school kids and I had to say there was some really nice stuff in there, good job kids.  One piece that I enjoyed was Gustave Herter, Mantelpiece for Thurlow Lodge there was something really powerful about it, and I loved all the details in it, but not a mantelpiece I'd put in my place.  The African Art was nice and kept my interest for a while but I wasn't a huge fan of the Oceanic Art it didn't move me or anything, I just walked right through.  The art of New Guinea was very interesting something I don't think I had seen anywhere else before.  I also enjoyed the Lichtenstein; normally I don't care of Roy's stuff but the Peace through Chemistry II was cool.  I hate to say it but the For Tent and Trade: Masterpieces of Turkmen Weaving was a bit boring and small which was a good thing I guess since it bored me after two rugs.  Something I learned on this vacation is that textiles aren't my thing, it's never too late to learn something about yourself so thank you De Young for teaching me this.

When you head to the De Young, make sure you plan enough time to also check out the rest of Golden Gate Park there's more than just the De Young there.
author: Me H.

description:
First, let me start by saying I love the de Young. It's a great place to spend a couple hours.  

This review is actually for the horribly misleading King Tut exhibit. SKIP IT.  Seriously, it's $30, a hour of lines on the weekend, and not a single sarcophagi of King Tut.  All the good stuff is safe and sound in the Cairo Museum.  Save your money and your time.
author: Lara O.

description:
Rising out of Golden Gate Park like a modern-day pyramid a la Chicen Itza, the De Young is almost breath-taking in it's architecture!! The collections, stunning and diverse! The observation deck: CLOSED.

Again. 
Hence the 4-stars.

That and the fact that the Hiroshi Sugimoto exhibit (while nicely representative of his work) was way too small.
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
I love the De Young - it's an amazing space!  They offer wonderful and unique exhibits (the Vivienne Westwood was awesome!), a really good restaurant, and the most amazing sky deck!

I love it so much I decided to do the family membership - can't tell you how many times I've brought out of town guests, my sister and coworkers here.
author: Christy L.

description:
This review is for the King Tut exhibit. Most common remark at the end of the exhibit was, "That's it?" Yeah, I allotted 3 hours to see da Boy King and was done in an hour. Maybe it was because it was a Thursday night and thus had only a smattering of people. It was interesting to me and I'm not a museum kinda person. It was a lot of this was his relatives mask, this could've been his grandfather's yadda yadda. The $7.00 for the self guided cell phone thingy was OK. We were told it added snippets that weren't on the descriptive plaques. Yeah, OK. Maybe 6 snippets. 

The fact that this stuff is 3300 years old and still well preserved is amazing. It is all well presented and perfect for us short attention span people. 

Became King at 9 years old? Ruled until his mysterious death at 19?Think about if that happened today. 

Buy the tickets in advance or you may not get in. Apparently weekends are packed.
author: Ken D.

description: The deYoung has great exhibits and I have to say that I wish I lived closer.  It's a bit of a hike to get here but even down in boring old San Jose we can stay informed of the lastest and greatest from the deYoung through regular Costco deals.  We came up here to see the King Tut exhibit which was pretty cool if i do say so myself (and I do).  My negative star is due to the fact that the building is just FUGLY!  It makes me kind of sad especially with all the beauty around it...aka Academy of Sciences...Shakespeare and Japanese gardens and just the beauty of the park around it in general.  At least you can go to the top!
author: Alena B.

description:
Favorite SF museum!
--Modern and Traditional
--Global and American
--Beautiful location in the Park
author: Bunny C.

description: Wow! The audio tour surpasses any I have experienced in the past, and I have experienced some excellent ones. Having seen this collection in Paris, and consequently having practiced and studied art, it provided depth on many levels. It was a perfect audio/visual course in the workings and background and placement in time of impressionist art--with all the potentially boring stuff cut out. The music lead ins and endings of each audio segment were perfect. The info. given was beautifully said while being clear and straightforward. The lighting was superb. The Bay Area is blessed to have gotten these works.
author: Barbara S.

description:
I haven't been here since King Tut was here maybe 30 years ago!  I should come more often.  Especially since my mom gave me a membership and all.  Of course, we all know of the makeover.  Be sure to head over to the Observation Tower.  It's nice to go here, since I am in some way related to M H de Young, according to my mom.

Today, I saw a bunch of artwork by San Francisco school kids, some of it was REALLY good.  

I want to see the glass blowing exhibit when it comes around in June.  The exhibits rotate from time to time.  This time there was a bunch of tapestries which was pretty interesting.  I would post some pictures, but my card reader is acting up.

Be prepared to spend most of the day here to see it all.
author: Michael M.

description:
Do yourself a favor and go to the museum and see the Chihuly exhibit before it's gone (in sept 08?)
Bring your camera and steady hand as no flashes are allowed
Lots of color
See some of the pics others posted
author: G K.

description:
I can see the De Young from my house.  When it was being built, I assumed that it was wrapped in scaffolding that would reveal a beautiful objet d'art when removed.  When it turned out that the supposed scaffolding was actually the building, I was stunned.

One of the truly ugly architectural misconceptions of all time.  Like a stubby choo-choo with the observation platform as a smokestack.  Did they run out of design time after they drew up the floorplan?  Couldn't be more out-of-place in GG Park if it WERE a smokestack.

Houses a first-rate collection of realistic American art which is, unfortunately, art's most boring genre.  A nice space for traveling collections.  Otherwise, worthwhile bits and pieces.  Strange to find a pre-Columbian fragment there.  Second-rate, but interesting.

Whenever there IS a traveling collection in place, the De Young is packed sardine-style.  

Final review: Ugly, Boring, Uncomfortable
author: Paul Q.

description:
Fun exhibits and well organized. The space itself is breathtaking and the 360 view from the tower is a fun way aerial way see the city in a new light. 
The Warhol exhibit was definitely a substantive collection of his works and the YSL exhibit was a great collection that exemplified his haute couture.
