The musem was crowded and many times I found myself having to push past throngs of people who deemed it necessary to stop in one giant group and discuss. Annyoing...keep it moving people! Aside from those choice individuals, it was a pleasant and educational way to spend a Saturday morning.
author: Stacy T.

description:
3.5 Stars. I was in a rush here so that might have influenced my opinion but I didn't think this art museum was so special. You can take the elevator in the tower to the 9th floor which gives a great panoramic view, but that was the only standout in my mind. 

One thing of note is that they have some glass on display in their permanent collection (mostly Chihuly circa 1980s), which, if you think about it, I haven't seen much of in major museums. So that's cool. I also did enjoy their Native American sculptures and their contemporary art but I didn't think anything was absolutely outstanding. 

Check it out if you're in the Golden Gate Park though.
author: Rita E.

description:
Like most recent reviewers, I journeyed to the de Young museum to check out "Van Gogh, Gauguin, Cézanne and Beyond: Post-Impressionist Masterpieces from the Musée d'Orsay". It was, in a word, fantastic. The line to enter the exhibit is just like being at Disneyland, with VIP members getting first priority. Once you are granted entrance, you then feel like herded cow.  Everyone's anxious to see the paintings, so clumping and huddling will naturally occur. Be cautious of the black tape, which keeps you about a foot and a half distance from some of the paintings. I unknowingly stepped over the line at one point, and the "museum police" were on me like white on rice! Eek! 

The museum is easily accessible via public transportation [we BART'd and MUNI'd it]. The staff was helpful and courteous. The café wasn't too bad, I'd say above average for museum food.  There is a Hot menu where you place your order for grilled items and sit down, and a Cold menu option where you can grab sammiches, antipasta and cold drinks. The museum stores are great. There is a store on the main floor, and another one located right outside of the exhibit (See? Just like at Disneyland..). I will say that the latter was better than I had expected. There are a variety of products to choose from that come plastered with your favorite painting. A sample list includes: magnets, postcards, note cards, playing cards, business card holder, and bookmarks. 

I walked away with a handful of favorite artists and paintings, and a newfound appreciation for Pointillism [think Georges Seurat's "A Sunday on La Grande Jatte"].

The other exhibits in the museum are good, too. But they really do pale in comparison to the main event. 

Other handy dandy tips when visiting the de Young: 
- Buy your tickets from Costco. It's cheaper and comes with an audio tour. The audio tour is a nice little perk. In lieu of a guided tour, this allows you to glean more insight into the artists and their works.  
- Be sure to reserve your tour time. Don't just randomly show up one afternoon because chances are high that you'll be turned away. 
- Visit the Observation Tower. It's FREE (woot!) and has amazing views of the City. 
- Take public transportation. It may take more time, but it's also more convenient. 
- If you intend on taking notes, use a pen & paper. I was innocently taking notes on the notepad of my iPhone and was scolded immediately because there are no electronic devices allowed.  
- Arrive early and take your time.  There is A LOT to see. And unless you're going to make a trip to Musee d'Orsay (highly suggested, may I add), make the time to truly enjoy these works of art. 
 
The Post-Impressionist exhibit is there through January 2011. And the line-up for the rest of 2011 is looking pretty exciting!
author: Shereen R.

description:
Saw King Tut show yesterday. I knew from other Yelpers that it was not a definitive sampling from his tomb, but I was thrilled, nevertheless, to see over 3,000-year-old artifacts looking gorgeous and exquisite in design, like his diadem with carnelian and gold, a great shield with Tut as a sphinx, his gold sword and his ceremonial crook and flail. I thought the installation was well done, lighting, and traffic flow were handled well. We paid full price rather than get in long lines on a weekend or free Target day. 

We enjoy the De Young very much, and I especially like the American 19th-century paintings by Sargent, Bingham and others. Whistler's scathing "Frilthy Lucre" ( that's how he spells it) painting of a creditor is great. Very out of character for him. Some nice marble sculptures too--love Penelope. We were pleasantly surprised by the Amish quilt collection. Really amazing how like op art these patterns and colors are. We enjoy the cafe mainly for the view of the sculpture garden and Japanese Tea House. Sat outside under the plastic tent covering the patio and enjoyed the rain. Looking forward to the impressionists show coming in the spring. And parking is a breeze off 19th and then Fulton, and you're in the garage which leads directly into the museum.
author: Emily G.

description: Gorgeous, fabulous location. Wonderous art. An inspired and key local institution. I've enjoyed many an exhibit here.
author: Sharon M.

description:
I went to the Chihuly exhibit with my momma and my twins on Friday.  

The work was phenomenal.  With every turn the displays get more beautiful than the last.  

We pre-ordered our tickets for the 1130 tour.  It was crowded but manageable.  I think the people that feel the need to walk in front of others taking pictures, decide they need to adjust their audio devices right in the front of the display or take pictures with their cell phones arms fully extended to my face are incredibly rude but that is probably because their momma's didnt raise them right.  

The exhibit was indeed breathtaking.  I'd love to see him blow glass in real life.
author: Peggy N.

description:
The Chihuly exhibit was beautiful.  It was interesting to have an emotional reaction to pretty pieces of glass.  On the one hand, of course it's going to be lovely, bright colors, different shapes, arranged in such a way so that each piece complements the others somehow.  What's not to like?

But how they were arranged and the sheer size of each piece made me progressively happier.  I was here for the last weekend of the exhibit, which coincided with a free day at the California Academy of Sciences so it was a zoo and kind of hot.  I wish I had made time to go on a weekday so I could enjoy it more.

My favorites were the Persian, Maccia and the Chandelier collections but it was all worth seeing.  Looks like I'm going to be making a trip to Washington sometime soon.
author: Seong P.

description:
I am afraid I must agree with the previous review by Paul Q. As someone who previously worked for this museum for many years, I witnessed countless times where real improvements for the patrons became secondary to some grand illusion in the heads of the administration. Besides enough internal scandal to fill a year's worth of local gossip rags, whenever I had guests in town and asked them to come by, they all had a consistently mediocre experience. 

On the plus-side, they do have occasionally interesting shows. The permanent collection is lukewarm at best. Is it world-class? No. Is it the best in the state? No again. I think they should have taken a cue from some other museums in CA and built something that looked more avant-garde rather than avant-tard.
author: Nick R.

description:
I like that they put the best of San Francisco in one park. If the sun could somehow find it's way to this area, I probably would move here. 

The museum is beautifully laid out. I really felt that each exhibit flowed into the next. Sometimes I wish they would just thoroughly explore one area--modernism, abstract, native--instead of dabbling in a bunch all at once. That's my complaint of large museums in general though. As it stands, I love it. Props to the architects who designed that tower. It's one of the best views I've had of the area.
author: Beth K.

description:
Went to Vivienne Westwood's show/party Sat night with some friends. I don't know what was more impressive....her work or the high fashion crowd. I spent much of the evening out in the back garden as it was a muggy warm night (for SF) and the sky was amazing. 

The museum itself is a favorite spot that I hit at least 3 times/ month. My only complaint is the girl on the top viewing floor who insists on keeping the lights on too bright and as a result the guests can't see the view outside at all - kinda defeats the purpose. 

The gardens are beautiful and the little corner secret circular open air room is pretty unique and allows for the coolest photography.
author: Amy E.

description:
The permanent collection is four stars, the consistently good special exhibits make it 5. I was also blown away by the Warhol exhibit, one of the best special exhibits I've seen at any museum.

Overall just a very interesting, diverse museum.
author: Mark A.

description:
Great New Building. 

I liked the 360 views on the 9th floor observation Tower. 
Exhibits still need some work, I feel like there isnt enough to see. 
Oh well, they are still in the process of adding more.

Instead of of General Admisssion add tix to see king tut.  Pretty interesting
author: Lucy L.

description: A beautiful museum with post-modern architecture. San Francisco doesn't have museums on a grand level like they have further south in Los Angeles  but the permanent collection  is interesting nonetheless for mainly american and african art. And the location of the museum is fantastic. Right in Golden Gate Park.
author: Amandie D.

description:
First, this museum gets great compliments for its wonderful location - Golden Gate Park.

The museum itself has a wonderful collection and I found it to be laid out very well.  My first visit was during my first week living here and I ventured over on a Friday night with a friend.  I love how it stays open late on Friday night and the special events on Friday nights are wonderful.  Music, drinks, crafts for kids - its a great evening out.
author: Jen K.

description:
C'est bon: an awesome building! Loved it!

C'est domage: shame that navigation in and around the museum is so very visitor un-friendly...

C'est bon: Oceanic art is the coolest! 

C'est domage: could we have just a little more ethnographic information about the African and Oceanic collections? Please? The pieces are more than just art for art's sake...
author: Andrea W.

description: Love the modern feel of the de young. It is a really beautiful building. We came here for the Van Gogh exhibit and whoops we forgot to check in on line! Eekkk we got here around 9am and the only available showing was the 5:30 one. Oh well... we found lots of other stuff to do in Golden Gate Park. I would highly reccomend checking in on line for a time slot when you are going to see a big exhibit. There were lots of other things in the de Young to look at. The observation tower was really cool. Check out the de Young and look on line for different exhibits they offer.
author: Kristin E.

description:
I like supporting local museums. I think the Friday night idea started in places like Chicago and New York and can be a great way to intro into the weekend. 

Invited a bunch of people to join me a few weeks ago out at the De Young. Very dissapointed. I'm sure it would have been a lot more fun with better weather. The music wasn't very good. The event promised food, of which, there was none. Bar was tiny and very crowded. Didn't bother viewing the art this time. Wasn't  too interested in vintage dresses and jewelry. Kid activities were also included in the event. I'm sorry, but this should be adult swim time only. Leave the kid stuff for Sundays or during the week when the rest of us have to be working.

In summary,  I had to travel too far (Golden Gate Park) for lame band, small amount of booze, and no food.
author: Mike V.

description: We avoided the Tut exhibit based upon several Yelpers indicating that it was overpriced. The general admission fee of $10 less $2 for showing a Muni pass was a BARGAIN. Although it does not compare with the Metropolitan Museum of Art in NYC, this place is a wonderful way to spend an afternoon. Be sure to go the tower to get an awsome 360 view of the city.
author: Joe M.

description:
God bless Bank of America for hooking me up with free admission for this place.  I've not been to the café, but the museum itself was an interesting attraction.  A large spacious place with TONS of different exhibits.  

When I went, they were showing Andy Warhol's work.  Interesting... I used to know a guy with a similar style, so it's nice to see where his inspiration comes from. 

The DeYoung is a large, great place, but the layout is pretty strange.  There's a lot to see, so give yourself a couple of hours at least.  Not a great place for kids, though some of the art really does make you stop and stare.  

And the tower?  Awesome view.
author: John L.

description:
You know what, maybe I'm not smart enough to appreciate contemporary art. I'm more than willing to admit that. I don't understand the Chair exhibit and I don't quite get the Oceania exhibit either. I think most of their traveling exhibitions are pretty good but their static showcases are lackluster.

The sculpture garden is nice, as is the view from the tower, but the outside of the building is one of the most ugly pieces of architecture I've ever seen (aside from many UC Berkeley buildings). Again, maybe I'm not smart enough to appreciate it, but who knows.

I would be willing to give this museum 4 stars, but they have a damn chair encased in concrete that's supposed to represent the urban takeover of agrarian nations. How the hell do you get that from a chair in concrete?!? I certainly don't and I don't think something that contrived should be considered art either...

But maybe I'm just not smart enough to appreciate it...
author: Stephanie H.

description:
When I came as a kid, the De Young had the feel of an old, European museum. It had lots of youth programs and I certainly came for field trips a lot, but it always seemed stuffy.

Well, it's not stuffy anymore. From the sleek exterior to the big open spaces and the large, well-lit galleries, everything is so much more appealing. And the tower. How could I forget? I love going up in the tower to look out over all of San Francisco. Plus, visiting it is free. 

The Friday-night programs are nice too. The themes vary, though they are often related to one of the current exhibitions, and they're a good place to hang out early in the evening.
author: Katie I.

description: Only $10 to get in.  Not bad for a museum.  They have one of the most interesting collections of contemporary art I have seen in a while, and it takes a lot to impress me with art.  :)   The observation tower is a must.
author: Meg M.

description:
Beautiful architecture.  Amazing installations.  

I was able to see the Vivienne Westwood collection there.  

Make sure to go up to the observation tower, and take in the gorgeous view.  

I need to go back sooner than later.
author: jen n.

description:
I went here on a first-date and it's something that I definitely would recommend to anyone who's looking for for something fun to do with that isn't your usual coffee and/or movie.

We saw the Yves Saint Laurent exhibit, and while the clothes were as awesome as I expected it to be, the layout was not conducive at all to the amount of people that were there and the fact that everyone wanted to see everything in their own leisurely manner. But everyone was so friendly and in such good moods (the power of fashion!) that it made the trip very much fun.

All in all, it was a great experience. The date and I ended up going to the museum cafe afterwards and enjoying tall glasses of orange and lime-infused water while sitting on a bench in the sun. Then before we called it a day, we went up to that tower in the mezzanine that gives you a 360 view of Golden Gate Park and everything beyond. It was pretty quiet up there and kind of romantic. A great place to have a great conversation with the date.

I love the De Young Museum. A magical place.
author: Judy F.

description:
Best girl date ever.

I have been living in San Francisco for close to 2 years. I first attempted to go to the De Young when it first opened and it was a nightmare to get in. 

We went for the Vivian Westwood and ended up spending close to three hours walking around staring at everything. My only regret was not taking the audio tour, but my friend and I had more then enough fun creating our own commentary as we explored. I was super bummed that we missed going up the tower by meer seconds and it was actually the NancyB tower! Damn those time limits. Luckily though it wasnt that clear of a day so I seriously doubt we really missed anything by not going up.

Cant wait to go back but this time go to the Tea Garden!
author: Nancy B.

description:
Museums are my absolute favorite places in the world. Art is my home. The De Young has definitely had a new fresh face put on... don't think of it as "remodling" or that they "ruined" the old beautiful delapidated De Young, but think of all of the artists that put so much time and talent into creating this utterly modern masterpiece. 
Just imagine, with the new Academy of Sciences as a neighbor Golden Gate park won't know what hit 'em. 
I loved the Friday Night Summer specials when you could venture round the museum at night, I went last year when Uni & Her Ukelele were performing during Vivienne Westwood's exhibit. Fantastico!
author: Mary Ella D.

description:
The stars are only for the architecture of the new building, which should be seen.

Maybe I am spoiled by having visited all the major museums in Europe, New York, and so forth, but the collection (at least what was on display in Dec 05), is pathetic for a city as large as San Francisco. The Hatshepsut exhibit was ok, but nothing compared to King Tut or even the standard collection at someplace like the British Museum.
author: Rob H.

description: One of my favorite places in the city, and to spend my off time. They have rotating exhibits that are all amazing, like Cartier, Balenciaga, YSL, etc. I became a member upon my first visit. Makes way more sense, and you get into the exhibits for free and can bring a guest free. Pretty perfect way to spend the day.
author: Naomi Z.

description:
Decent collection, but I've seen better at much lesser known & lesser "important" big city museums.  The photography exhibit was displayed terribly.  The work was interesting but displayed in amateurish mountings that made them difficult to see.  One of their more important pieces is the Rembrandt Peale oil of George Washington which is hidden upstairs in a poorly lit side hallway (dim, unflattering lighting is a problem in a number of exhibits here).

Biggest pain in the neck at the de Young is the security staff who are extremely intrusive.  If you're a guy, don't carry anything if you can help it.  Women can swing their pocketbooks & shopping bags freely.  Guys are subjected to a bag inspection (do terrorists visit mediocre museums?); and them further harassment in other rooms.  Over my shoulder I was carrying a small camera bag and I also had a small drawstring sack on my back.  First security guy informed me that I was not allowed to have anything on my back but he was fine with it hanging just from one shoulder.  In the next room I was told that wasn't ok so I moved my camera bag & sack to hang from my elbow and that guard said that was OK.  Later still a 3rd guard told us that bags can only be held in your hand and in front of you or they must be checked.  The guards explained that they are afraid people might back into a display if they forgot they were carrying something or they might swing a bag into some artwork if it was dangling.  Uhm, I wasn't walking backwards and I wasn't swinging anything.

I found this random, inconsistently enforced bag "rule" to be absurd.  In the hundreds of museums I've been to all over the world I have never, ever seen this issue before.  It's not ok that women aren't subjected to the same "policy" (which seems to be up to the individual interpretation of each guard anyway) and it seems even more preposterous that the guards are hyper-focused on this non-issue while not doing anything about running, screaming children or visitors ignoring the No Flash Photography rule all over the museum.  Both of these In the hundreds of museums I've been to all over the world I have never, ever seen this issue before.  issues  individually pose much bigger threats to the artwork than a small bag does!
author: Ken K.

description: awesome muesum. really big. lots to see. a lot of older works which is always a plus!
author: Pheobe W.

description:
We came here last week after visiting 2 other museums - MOMA & YBCA (all 3 were free as it was the first Tuesday of the month). We were pretty exhausted when we arrived, but we saved the best museum for last as MOMA & YBCA were huge disappointments. 

There is something for everything here at the de Young which is also why I had to take off a star - just too much stuff to look at. I didn't care much for the Western exhibits of all the chairs, dressers and other crap. 

The masks, dolls, & artifacts from Latin America, Africa & Asia were amazing. The glass-blown pieces downstairs were pretty cool (especially the gigantic fruits - I'll upload the photo later). 

I'll definitely come back for the Vivienne Westwood exhibit in the near future as that area was extra and we were exhausted from museum hopping all day. Gelato and wine turned out to be a better idea anyways after that long day.
author: E E.

description:
Just wanted to comment on the Van Gogh and Beyond Exhibit!  I just love the De Young Museum and am now a member so I bought my tickets early and planned way in advance so I can get a full tour of the Van Gogh exhibit without having to deal with parking issues and waiting in line.  I highly reccommend anyone planning to see this marvelous once in a lifetime exhibit unless you travel to NY or France to come see it before it ends in Jan 11.  I am going to reserve my tickets again because I want to see it again and bring other friends to see it with.  

For those of you who do not know the Musee D'Orsay in France is undergoing renovations and so they are having this VERY SPECIAL exhibit of Post Impressionist art here at the DEYOUNG only, and I believe so in NY too!   So- once in a lifetime!   I am so inspired whenever I see my favorite artists pieces in real life, nothing compares to seeing or reading it in text books.  The Post Impressionist begins with Renoir, and goes on to Van Gogh, Gaughin, Cezanne and more.  There is even one Picasso painting.  I loved the Van Gogh and will make my own rendition of STARRY NITE OVER THE RHONE (to paint and place near my STARRY NITE that I did a long time ago).  Gaughin is facintating in that his earlier influences weren't evident til later he even had a midlife crisis and is facinating in his self portrait with yellow Christ.  Not a fan of pointilissm but have to say there are some that really looked awesome!  Artists who veered toward symbolims are toward the end (some of whom I've never really knew of) but will check out. 

Very important also- once you are in you cannot re-enter.  So even though it is crowded take a break and sit on the coaches once in awhile to get from room to room.  

Definitely worth the money!!!! And definitely one of the best exhibits I've seen in all my museum experiences....I missed the earlier one though the Monet one :(....Am waiting to see the PICASSO one that I believe is showing in June/July 2011 at De Young.   And- I also would love to see an exhibit on Surrealism (Salvador Dali rocks!!!!!!)....someday hopefully

Here's more info:
http://deyoung.famsf.org/deyoung/exhibitions/van-gogh-gauguin-cezanne
author: cheryll t.

description:
1. Don't wear heels/pumps/boots to the museum. I wore boots and I swear it's dead silent in several of the rooms. I tried to walk quietly but every once in a while I get some serious hipster giving me the death eye because I was ruining his meditation. I'm sorry!!! 

2. Work the system and bring your old college ID, even though you graduated a year ago. Discounts, discounts, discounts...again, it's the Filipino in me. 

3. make sure and go to the observation tower so you can see the view of the city. Breathtaking!

4. check out the YSL exhibit, it's $7 more but it's worth it. I believe it will be there until early March, not sure.

+5 because I have a new appreciation to art and museums now that I'm older. I used to hate going to museums when I was in school because they made me write long essays and BS self reflection papers 5 pages long. Now that I no longer have an agenda going there, it's a much more fulfilling experience.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
I used to visit the De Young as a kid, about once a month, I loved it. 

Recently I was there at the newly designed De Young. 

WOWZERS! I loved it more than the Metropolitan Museum in NYC and that is saying  a lot!!

First Tuesdays are still free!
author: Laura F.

description:
Closes too early.  Museums should close at some time from 6-8, especially on a Saturday.  

The Warhol Exhibit = 5 stars  (My fave of the two and I LOVE FASHION, so that's saying a lot)
The YSL Exhibit = 5 stars

Having to rush through them and tower closed = -1 star

I haven't seen the permanent exhibits yet, so no comment on those.
author: F K.

description:
The Building and Tower View Is Itself A Work of Art

The De Young is now art in itself as it's beautiful architecture dramatically provides an eye-catching venue for the eclectic mix of pieces it holds.  Take a moment to admire it on the inside and out, stroll through the outdoor gardens and look up at the tower from below.

Sure the rotating exhibits like Chihuly are a wonderful draw, but the diversity of art here really surprised me. The Art in America to the 20th Century and Contemporary Art wings held several nice moments for me admiring paintings that have the ability to take you to another time and place, just for a moment.  The Native American, African and Oceania collections held blankets, masks, tapestries baskets and carvings all worth a view.  I had a lot of fun going up and down the extra fat steps which require two feet per step to navigate, working the leading leg extra hard by the time you reach the top step. 

A must see is the view from the tower, take the elevator up to the observation deck for a 360-degree treat that you don't want ot miss.  The view of the living roof of the Academy of Sciences building, Golden Gate Park and the skyline view are gorgeous. 

If you only have a few minutes rest on a bench in the garden and admire the building, but you could easily spend many hours here like I have.
author: Laurie H.

description:
Where ever you are from, what ever else you may like to do, if you love beauty JUST GO.  You've got to go to the Chihuly exhibit.  The pieces were so spectacular that you could not believe your eyes.  I just laughed out loud so many times, because I couldn't take in just how beautiful this art is.
 
So i tried to take photos using my cell phone camera, and was actually pleased with how brilliant the pictures came out.  

But, you can tell how I loved this exhibit.  Usually if I can get a free bookmark or a postcard from an exhibit, it makes me happy.  I sprang for a $30 splashy book that I love.  I read thru all 365 pages in 3 hours back at the hotel!  

You've got to go see this.
author: Diane G.

description:
The tower is a wonderous overlook of San Francisco neighborhoods, and the most entertaining view of the California Academy of Sciences for now, until the newness, the long queues for admission there dissipate.

Multiple retail stores lurk in odd corners about each exhibit, which can be a bit jarring to the senses.  (For the Warhol exhibit, not at all out of place; almost shocking after the Yves Saint Laurent exhibit.)
author: Mutant O.

description: The Balenciaga exhibit is fascinating for anyone who loves fashion. If you have ever sewed, you will appreciate it on a deeper level. It is well organized, not chronologically, but by themes of influences on his designs. The audio tour is excellent and highly recommended. The designs are strikingly structural and some absolutely breathtaking.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Very cool! I checked out the YSL exhibit and so glad I did. There are tons of pieces to "oooh" and "ahhh" over.  The Maya Lin exhibit is neat too. I can't wait to come back and check out the Warhol exhibit.  I grabbed some info about becoming a member. It pays for itself in just 4 visits!

The permanent collection stuff here was very fun to check out. Learned a lot. Make sure to also check out the observation floor. Very nice view of the city!!

We also grabbed something to eat at the cafe and it was not bad at all. I had the BLT with some sort of aioli, and fries were yum.
author: Andee V.

description:
This is a beautiful museum. While our kids weren't too happy about being dragged to it, we loved the Warhol exhibit here. The adjoining exhibit areas were spectacular as well and it was a great way to spend a cold, cloudy afternoon.

Note: don't go hungry, the museum cafe is not cheap!
author: Carrie S.

description: saw the 'Birth of Impressionism' this weekend. OMFG that was boring. it was like Elton John's yard sale of his Liberace couch painting collection.
author: ray m.

description:
Disclaimer: I know nothing about art and/or architecture, so what you get is the uninformed opinion of an average citizen about our newest museum.

I waited until last month to actually go into the de Young after marveling at its sheer ugliness from outside during its construction and the past six months that it's been open.  

Speaking of its sheer ugliness, the tower is hideous - I mean it really messes up the park for me (sorry copper tower lovers - I just can't dig it).  And the museum looks like a huge, uninspired block of copper - oh wait, it is a huge block of copper.  Which will quickly rust, given its proximity to a very large body of salt water.

Anyway, I decided to take the plunge and enter the de Young - hey, at least I would get a break from looking at that ugly tower while I was indoors.  

BUT, as the boyfriend and I were approaching the front doors, we noticed four mercedes SUVs parked on the sidewalk in front of the museum.   At that point I nearly vomited.  What were these horrible manifestations of EVIL doing parked ON A SIDEWALK in front of a PUBLIC museum?  Plus, they made the de Young even uglier because they were silver and they totally clashed with their copper background. 

But I digress....
I was surprised at how aesthetically pleasing the inside of the museum was - in sharp contrast to its outside (did I mention that the exterior is very ugly?).  However, I found the crazy confusing layout to be a big drawback.

Oh, and I took the elevator into the tower and the view was pretty good from there.  I give the de Young a star for that.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I have to say, I'm super-impressed. I'm not a museum guy, normally. I get bored and want to go outside a lot. But, this one is great for the easily-distractable Sagittarian. It is beautiful itself, it is in beautiful surroundings, the cafe is great, the outdoor space is great, the exhibits are interesting...I have nothing bad to say about it. In fact, gasp, we joined as members. Which, by the way, includes the Legion of Honor so the museum-fun never has to end.

The observation deck thing is worth at least fifteen minutes of entertainment. I am not, however, sold on the copper shell. Whenever I see it I wonder when they are going to take down the scaffolding and then realize they aren't going to. Also, patina is going to happen. I am sure they think it's a great idea, but when the entire building is streaked with greenish-blue...I'm going to guess it isn't nearly as attractive as they think it is going to be.
author: Brian B.

description:
I loved the old De Young museum, it was a wonderful museum for me to enjoy when I was a kid. I hadn't been there in 5 or so years when they closed it down, tore it up and put up the current Mayan Temple they call a museum. The crack in the pavement piece that run through the entryway is very cool and fun. I love it when architectural art plays a role in the design, and this one certainly did. 

The collection itself is good. I like Post-Modernism and the pieces they have on display are pretty good. The modernist stuff is good and the traditional arts area is probably their strongest. It's all done very traditionally with well-made labels and excellent way-finding. 

The two rotating exhibits we went to were a mixed bag. The Yves Sanit-Laurant exhibition was fantastic, one of the best exhibits of it's kind I've ever seen. They let the objects speak and did little in the way of set-dressing, which is a problem I usually have with exhibits of this kind. The dresses were amazing and the interpretation was top-notch. As a museum, it's th ekind of exhibit I wish I could put together. 

The Andy Warhol exhibit was OK. I wasn't thrilled, though there were some of the most significant pieces of his career there, like the Brillo boxes, but there was also a lot missing from it and it seemed to cover much of the same ground in multiple ways. The exhibit of album covers was the highlight, as was the coverage of his work with Merce Cunningham and folks. 

All in all, I liked the museum. It's a strong presence and I'm hoping that I'll get back soon. I didn't even get to the top of the viewing station!
author: Rev. Dr. Christopher J. G.

description:
during my stay in the Bay Area, i trekked across SF from Berkeley to eventually end up at the Golden Gate Park, and then visit the De Young Museum.  i don't know what it looked like before, so i can't comment on what the remodeled version looks like, but it is an impressive piece of architecture in itself.  the park surrounding the museum is a nice, relaxing, grassy area, that does well to make you start to forget that you're in the middle of a bustling city.

i've gotta say that i wasn't really impressed with many of the pieces that were on display during my visit.  i actually started to get excited about seeing some Van Gogh, Gauguin, and Cezanne, but i was disappointed when i got inside and found out that the section of the museum that housed this special exhibit was another $17 for college students.  i really didn't have all day to be looking around here, so i couldn't justify the more than double the price of general admission to go into that section.

the elevator to the top observation area was kinda cool (but it was hazy/cloudy the day i was there).

sidenote: one thing that was a little bit annoying was that nobody at the front said anything about my backpack, and then while i was walking around the different wings of the museum, the ushers kept telling me to take my backpack off and carry it at my side.  so there's a helpful hint for all of y'all: if you have a bag/backpack, check it in at the front lobby area (for free)
author: John C.

description:
Highlights-
Modern & beautiful building
Great view from the top floor
Great outdoor cafe'
Decent gift shop

Downsides-
Security guard barking at me to look in my purse before I even get through the door.
YSL exhibit is after I leave town :(
author: jennifer j.

description: I want to commend Chef Jason in the dining room/cafeteria for his gracious offer to create a vegan plate for me. He came out of the kitchen, discussed my preferences and delivered a meal I enjoyed very much. Thank you Jason!
author: Connie F.

description: I am fortunate to live close by and have taken advantage of this architectural marvel.  It is simply beautiful, inside and out.  The veneer is copper and is aging gracefully.  The gardens, fountains, and design was well thought of.  The observatory is 360 degrees (all glass).  It reminds me of being in a tree house.   I wish I lived in a house with that view!  The museum holds some of the best art work, however thats strictly based on your own opinion.  It took me a full two days to see everything.  I like to look at the art and experience in detail.   Thats just me.
author: S F.

description:
Great museum, high quality experience.  I would rate it just behind the CA Academy next door.  The key difference is that the De Young generally is focused on one exhibit at a time.

Many of theses, such as the King Tut showing, are prepackaged and the museum may not have as much input into the set up and the actually items that are represented.  Thus, minus 1/2 star for lack of a couple pieces that were not included and we wanted to see.

The other 1/2 star is because the place was packed and it was a little difficult to see all the pieces and grab a seat.

The staff was real friendly, as a consolation!

Tip:  Eat before you come. The prices are a little high and don't bring drinks in with you.  Parking at the museum is difficult.  Drop your party off in front and have one person park in the garage.
author: Chris M.

description:
I'm a member, and I have loved all the exhibits. 
The staff is a bit disorganized as are the logistics in getting members through. I found the amount of bathrooms to be inadequate for the crowd and odd parts of the museum were roped off making traffic jams. I"m waiting till the crowds die down so I can actually go on member's night and enjoy it.
Update: I went to the Vivianne Westwood opening party with a few GFs. My god it was fabulous with the snooty art types in full Westwood regalia. I didn't even care about the we're here to be seen types because the dancing, the fashion, the famous people, the exhibit were all fabulous. 5 stars for that alone!
p.s if you're a student, membership is ridiculously cheap.
p.p.s. First Tuesday of every month is FREE
p.p.p.s You can use your De Young ticket, to go the Legion of honor for free on the same day of purchase.
author: Kat C.

description:
My sister and I decided to pay de young a visit on one of their free days. Since my aunt had asked to check it for a wedding party in the summer. Figured hey its free and I can walk through the museum, look at things, and check out the place to see if it would work for my aunt.
First of all there are only a few areas for the general public to visit, which is basically the second floor. And there are no signs pointing to where people are allowed to go. 
When we arrived on the second floor we started looking at this painting when  this old woman, who did not identify herself as an employee but I later found out her name is Rebecca,started to tell me to put my purse to the side. I ignored her because I thought she was just some loony wanting to chit chat, mostly because she was standing right next to me and she was baciscally whipsering. I mean personal space man! Then she became agaited and told my sister the same thing. As my sister walked away she asked my sister if she wanted to get kicked out. How rude!! Speak  up if you want people to listen to you!
We complied but she kept following us throughout the second floor telling us to put our purses to the side or not to stand to close to the painting. It was creepy!
The annoying employee, Rebecca, also thought it was necessary to mention that we were on camera before we left to look at the other exhibits. I mean come on it's a museum of course there are cameras. I felt like a criminal. 
The paintings and sculptures are interesting but I'm not sure it's worth encountering Rebecca again. Rebecca was horrid and made the experience unpleasant. 
I told my aunt that she should look at other venues for her wedding reception.
author: cecilia a.

description:
I reviewed this with the Palace of The Legion of Honor since they are listed together and are linked museums.

Poorer than they have any right to be.  The de Young is crowded, very family unfriendly and expensive. The Palace is just hard-to-get-to with lots of big name artists but crummier examples of their work.

Our experience at the de Young recently was one of the worst I have ever had. We bought tickets at Costco for the Birth of Impressionism show and did not realize that strollers are not permitted inside the exhibition. With a 26 pound 2-year old, there was no way to enjoy anything in a set of galleries stuffed full of people, most of them in wheelchairs.

Just when we thought things could not get worse, the guards in the galleries told us we could not place the 2-year-old on our shoulders (possibly the only way to actually see any paintings). They were quite sharp with us and claimed their lawyers would not permit such a dangerous perch for her. It was awful. What we could see of the paintings was not all that impressive or well displayed. It was dark and crowded and hot. Like a bomb shelter. Not a museum.

So to sum up: Don't come here. Don't ever come here with kids and especially, don't come to one of their splashier exhibitions. There are better museums in SF. The SFMoMA is pretty good. You CAN use a stroller there. You CAN carry your child any way you like. They do have better special exhibitions too.

de Young = Feh!
author: Deborah M.

description:
I love the De Young!  

Original intentions for my Saturday afternoon included going to the Academy of Sciences.  However, it was too chaotic since it was FREE and also opening day.

But that was okay!  We just walked across the little grove and went to the De Young for ten bucks instead.  They had extra late hours (9 pm) to accommodate the Academy of Science rejects who could not get in (myself included).  I was double bummed out because the Dale Chihuly exhibit was sold out.  That's what you get when you wait until 5 pm!  Either way, I still enjoyed walking around the museum.  From ceremonial head dresses from New Guinea to coffins made in the shape of a cocoa bean, there is a little something for everybody.  The best way to tour the museum is to start with the upper level and work your way down, to the more contemporary works.  

I didn't get to go up to the observatory floor, but will do that first the next time I go.  Oh yes, there definitely be a next time!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Do you remember the time? When we fell in love? Do you remember the time? When we first met??

While a part of me wished for a little MJ tribute/Eddie Murphy to be introducing the tour, I was still very pleased with the King Tutanhkhamun exhibit.  There were plenty of facts outlined around the exhibit; from the lineage of King Tut, to the small paragraphs of facts that described each item within the casings.

My only critique would be that some of the rooms were rather vast and encompassed plenty of space.  Space for more stuff that is!! I mean, I don't know the details about where everything else is from his tomb, but seriously.  For example, one of the casings would read, "Here lies one of four canopic jars that housed King Tut's internal organs after mummification.  This one most likely held his intestines."  And in my mind I'm thinking...."umm...excuse me....where the hell are the other THREE?!"  Or another casing would say, "This is one shakti (miniature figurines displaying a spirit or god that will do labor for the pharaoh in the after life) found within King Tut's tomb.  This was one of literally hundreds found within the tomb."  And here's me....."Ok, seriously? You have the nerve to say hundreds, yet you can't even give us maybe even just 5 more??!"

I'm just saying.

And I know it's a lot to ask....ok, maybe too much.  But I must say I was just a tad bit disappointed that King Tut wasn't actually there.  Yes, you read that right.  I wanted THE sarcophagus of King Tut there....and the actual mummy wouldn't have been bad either.  ;-D

But, the exhibit did have a great video and projection image that displayed the many layers of coffins and encasings it took to bury King Tut.

Growing up, I was a huge fan of Egyptian history.  And this exhibit definitely brought me back to those days when my eyes would light up as we entered the Egyptian history chapters of our textbook.  Just to even see a few of his real life belongings, and the pure gold jewelry he used to adore....simply amazing.

What a life of glamour and wealth, eh?

Seriously.  Go check it yourself.

I was very pleased that our tickets included admission to the deYoung itself and our visit wouldn't be given justice without mentioning the amazing amazing amazing chocolate creme brulee and apple crisp at the deYoung cafe!!  Yum.  Skip the brownies and chips.  Go towards the glass casings under the registers.  That's where they keep the good stuff.

After indulging ourselves, my friend and I checked out the African and Oceanic art exhibits.  My anthropologic fix was satisfied, as we took in hundreds of crazy and unique masks.  Can we just say how obsessed these people are about the phallus in their art? Haha! It was definitely such a great way to confirm some of my anthropology studies back in college about sex, gender, and culture of south east pacific island communities.  Another weird thing about some of the masks we saw was that there were some masks that had skulls.  Yes, human skulls.  Crazy!

Lastly....the observation deck simply took my breathe away.  It was such a clear day, and simply an amazing 360 birds eye view of San Francisco.  The Richmond in front of you, to the Sunset behind you....it's a view not to miss!!
author: Vince S.

description: I am not a huge fan of going to museums because I'd rather be outside on the weekend days, but my parents are members and since it was mother's day, I really had no choice but to go today.  I was happily surprised by the Balenciaga exhibit today.  The dresses are really stunning and they're all on blank white mannequins which allows to imagine the women wearing the clothing.  There is one raincoat with an amazing hood that comes to a sharp point.  I wanted it.  Definitely worth seeing!  The observation tower is free and it's one of the best views of the city.
author: Julia D.

description:
The view from the top of the tower is beautiful.  As far as I know, you don't need to pay to get into the tower, so that's cool.

Otherwise, the De Young is disappointing as a museum.  I don't mind small museums; in fact, some of my favorite museums are pretty small (the Norton Simon in Pasadena, for example).  But the De Young seems like it's trying to be a big museum, and as such, it doesn't do too well.

I'd love to go back to check out more of the sculptures in the gardens, but otherwise, I don't think I'll be returning often.

Oh, if you show your Muni fastpass or passport, you get $2 off, which is cool.
author: John S.

description:
I still remember looking at the architectural model of the new De Young prior to the groundbreaking, and thinking "dang! what weird interior spaces. What will they do with all those angular little garden plots?"

Now I know. This is probably the most interesting and exciting architecture to rear its head in San Francisco in years. Aside from the ability to show off the collection so well (more on that in a moment), this building creates a magnificent interior space along with its gorgeous (and now heading toward gloriously patina-ed) exterior in Golden Gate Park.

I love the light in the galleries. I love the sweeping staircase facing the enormous Richter wall installation. I love the Goldsworthy atrium. I love the tower. I can be happy standing at the end of the center 2nd floor gallery, staring out at the Kiki Smith installation hanging from the ceiling. I love walking past the glassed in slices of garden---there are those odd angles from the model!---as I pass from gallery to gallery.

I dig the hot cocoa at the cafe.

This space has enough room (at last) to really give pride of place to the storehouse of surprisingly good and interesting pieces that the De Young has in its care. 

There was a lot of negativity voiced at the onset, in classic SF "anything new is bad" style; I think we've gotten beyond that, and I think that the museum proves itself without needing defense. It's beautiful now; in five years when the copper exterior has taken on a deeper patina, and the building begins to be even more organically entrenched in the landscape, it will be even more so.

I could still live without Oldenburg's enormous diaper pin in the back garden, though. Sigh.
author: sascha b.

description:
I am NOT an art museum expert.

This museum does have some interesting displays.  However I it is laid out in such a weird fashion that I find it hard to follow.  You have classic paintings, tibetan weave work, and contemporary american furniture all close together.  Odd.

The cafe is at the extreme end past the gift store.  It was very hard to find.  Once there grab something to eat which amazingly was reasonable in price and eat outside.  Then the funny part begins as children are playing on the sculptures and yet a museum staff person will come out once in awhile to tell them that they shouldn't be.  Which begs the question why put it out in a grassy field where people are going to eat that isn't roped off?  Don't miss the Hamon tower as it provides a great view of San Francisco.  Also there is a display just to the side of the out door eating area....it looks like a mound covered in grass.  Go to it...Find the entrance and walk inside to sit out down.  Its a very interesting view up through a hole as the light crosses it.
author: Brian M.

description:
We went here today for the King Tut exhibit.  I knew ahead of time that King Tut's mummy is not part of the exhibit but I can see how people would be disappointed if they didn't know that in advance.  The exhibit is well marketed and that important tid bit is not mentioned (good PR peeps I guess).  They do charge quite a bit extra to get into the exhibit so I recommend purchasing tickets at Costco for a substantial discount.  The Costco tickets also include the audio tour which I do think is worthwhile.  

I found the exhibit to be interesting and it was a nice way to spend a Sunday.  We breezed through parts of the museum afterwards but I really wanted to go up to the top floor of the tower for the view of the city but they were having elevator problems and it was closed.  Sad about that.
author: Carrie L.

description:
I can't stop staring at the giant bowl of glass fruit. Why do I like it so much?

About the De Young... I don't know what to say. I have been in SF for 4 months, and have been here 10 times.
author: Rachel B.

description:
I was invited as a VIP guest, so I didn't have to pay for anything.  Because of my generous friends, my evening was more likely to be better than most.  But I think, despite having said that, I would still give the experience five stars.

The venue was beautiful.  Fun, eclectic crowd.  Drinks were strong.  The staff were all professional and courteous, too.  We watched cultural dancers, saw a couple of exhibits, shopped for gifts, and enjoyed a magnificent 360-degree view of the city from an adjoining tower room.

I would definitely go back, VIP or not.
author: Skye R.

description:
Visited on one of the free Bank of America days. It is a nice size, you don't get to tired walking around each of the exhibit hallways. I really liked the Oceanic exhibit which had wood carvings and displays of cultures from Papua New Guinea, New Zealand, etc. Not something I'd seen before in such a large quantity.

There is a quite large Obata painting of a lake, which I really liked along with a portrait made of money.

Check out the tower, it is free and provides one of the spectacular views of the area. It's also enclosed, so you don't have to worry about being cold.

The museum store is nice, there are a few posters of paintings that you can purchase.
author: Glaciala A.

description:
De Young... from the modern architecture...to the great exhibits... classic art.... contemporary art...painting... sculpture, mixed media... 
As you walk towards the museum you're greeted by the herzog and de meuron building. It takes a while to take it in and not be overwhelmed by the architecture. 
I was lost with Nix in this museum for hours. It's well organized and the flow from the classic to the contemporary is intuitive.  My review cannot clearly convey the awe that I felt walking through the museum. 
A true world class museum. A must see if you visit or live in San Fran.
author: Joseph C.

description:
So I went to check out the King Tut exhibit today and was disappointed.  You get to see some of the Egyptian artifacts that were from his tomb, but you don't get to see any of the actual gold caskets and sarcophaguses.  I.e., you don't see any of the gold boxes or coffinettes.  There was a gold coffinette of another mummy, but it wasn't the beautiful one from King Tut.  You do get to see it on a video though, but what's the point of that when I can go home and google that myself.

Don't waste your money on buying the audio tour either.  You can pretty much read the descriptions yourself off the placards instead of paying for that extra $7 nonsense.
author: Louis V.

description:
Ug ... Chihuly schmihuly.  I understand that his work is beautiful, but he gets too much credit for it.  He barely blows glass anymore himself because he ruined his shoulder and lost an eye in a motorcycle accident (or something).  I will give him credit for large public installations and bringing art into the public sphere, but cummon ... I gotta give a shout out to all his gaffers that actually do the work, which IS difficult.  It should be a Chihuly, et al show.  I blew glass for a year, and sell the stuff for a living, so I there are quite a few more people out there whose work is amazing and attainable. 

/rant.

Even with out the Chihuly exhibit, the De Young is an amazing museum.  They have a huge collection with something for everyone's taste.  There are beautiful landscapes upstairs, including one of my Grandpa's favorites, Thomas Moran.  There are the cultural arts, with artifacts from the Americas and New Guinea, Oceanic Art, too.  And you want to talk about glass check out the section of Contemporary Craft. There is a Chihuly from his Venetian series done in collaboration with glass master  Lino Tagliapietra, and a cool piece by Toots Zinsky.  Even the building itself is a work of art.

There is a lot to see, but not so much that you can't do it in one day.  And if you are going for just a quick jaunt, but haven't gotten enough of an art fix, your DeYoung ticket will get you into the Legion of Honor for free on the same day.

There is ample underground parking, but if you want to stay green the N-Judah light rail line will drop you at 8th and Judah, which is about a 10 to 15 minute walk to GG Park, through the botanical gardens, to the DeYoung.  So don't miss this Museum even if you are a peninsula dweller like me.  Take CalTrain to the light rail, buy the $1.50 ticket, pretend you are in Paris, and take in some art!
author: Karly L.

description:
I almost always love museums, and I was really excited to visit the new De Young, so I have to admit that I was a teeny tiny bit disapointed when I went there for the first time this Sunday.

It's a great place -- how could it not be, it's filled with amazing and beautiful and bizarre and really old things that were made just for me  (and you) to look at -- but still, it lacked a personality. The big room that's at the center of the museum was cold, and I really didn't like the lighting. 

The Vivienne Westwood exhibit was incredible. I went out and bought a corset afterwards. (almost)

One of the most interesting things for me was in the observation tower ... my friends and I were instantly compelled to locate where we lived on the big satellite map. I mean, I know exactly where I live and how to get there, so why was I so eager to find it on the map?

It is definitely worth the admission price, and I like the architecture, but my favorite is still the MOMA. It feels like home to me.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Despite almost getting into an altercation with an idiot who tried to steal my parking spot, I was impressed by the Friday night festivities at the De Young. Its nice to see that they are able to use the space for a DJ, a live band and best of all, a bar! 

A great place to unwind after a long week at work, you get to drink a well deserved beer or sangria among some very fashionably dressed people.
author: Abhi S.

description:
i've only been here once & it was for the Picasso exhibit but i fell in love with this museum. since my mom is a member, it was free for me to go (which adds to why i love this place so much)

i am a huge fan of Picasso & have seen his works in Paris & the fact that they were brought to San Francisco and the de Young is fabulous. 

the audio for this exhibit MADE the exhibit-i can't even explain what a difference it made...i felt like i was being walked through his life and the exhibit was organized and explained perfectly. i can't wait to return next time i'm in SF-my new fave museum there!
author: Jane S.

description: Like the museum, love the room with the Gottardo Piazzoni murals that looks out over the concourse. They have a decent collection of contemporary art on the ground floor. Special exhibits are are a mixed bag. Love shows like Louise Nevelson and Ruth Asawa, but for some reason they keep doing these stupid clothing shows. Just got the latest member news and they have another one coming up! Guadier or someone. Who shifted the definition of art to include this stuff? I'm sure they do this because some society women on the board think this is art, or that it makes money by bringing in people who won't actually come to see art, but isn't this crap compromising the reputation of the museum, and won't that make it harder to get real art going foward?
author: James T.

description:
I enjoyed the excitement, entertainment, the autograph session (stood in line 2 hours) of the opening day of Dale Chihuly.  He's amazing.
The first time I saw his artwork was at the Mayo Clinic.  Can't wait to view the whole display without the crowd.

I noticed the volunteers and staff were especially kind and friendly.

Oh yes, after Chihuly autographed my book I told him I loved him and he looked up and said "thank you".  Made my day!
author: Patty H.

description: The Georgia O 'Keefe exhibit this weekend at the De Young Museum was very inspiring.  The De Young is a great place to spend a Sunday afternoon.  Don't miss the observation tower, the view is a sight to see.
author: Cindy N.

description:
It's nice to see that San Francisco isn't entirely built on Victorian-era nostalgia.  The architecture of the DeYoung is everything you could want in a museum: futuristic yet natural.  Plus there's the signature tower, with a great view (though nothing to rival Twin Peaks).

What I really love about the museum is its breadth.  In addition to an extensive collection of American art ranging from the 19th to the 21st century, it also holds no less than 3 indigenous art exhibits: the Americas, Africa, and Oceania.  I'm sure Marshall McLuhan would agree that it's a great design for today's increasingly integral world.

Also, I've been to the Pompidou Centre in Paris, and I'll put the contemporary art here up against that stuff any day.  A great philosopher once said, "The problem with being avant-garde is knowing who's putting on who".  And while it's easy to take potshots at modern art, I really felt the exhibits in Paris were simply daring you to reject them as meaningless, whereas the works here really speak for themselves, while still being mind-bogglingly original.
author: Wes M.

description: I just bought a one year membership! The art that comes through this place is outstanding. A big plus about the de Young is the observation tower with panoramic views of the city. Access to the tower is free, but I only wish they would extend the hours later so I could stop by after work.
author: katrina w.

description:
We went here to view the architecture because we heard there was a free area / tower that was open to all and to take a quick look.  

When we walked in, someone asked if we were members of the museum.  We said no, and then she handed us two free members only tickets.  Whoever that lady was, thank you!  

If we lived here, I would recommend becoming a member.  We were able to go see the impressionist exhibit without waiting in line!  How cool is that?  Did I mention we got in for free!?

The visiting collection on display was magnificent.  They even had Whistler's Mother.  It had Claude, Monet, Renoir, and others.  Top notch, first class, true art!  My two year old daughter also enjoyed it - by taking a nap on my shoulder throughout the entire collection.  Unfortunately, strollers were not allowed.  I believe I would have enjoyed the collection more had it not been for 30+ lbs on my shoulder the entire time.

Their permanent collection had some beautiful pieces as well, and of course the modern art garbage so prevalent in most museums now.  Of course, beauty is in the eye of the beholder. 

I would recommend dressing up for the museum.  We were in jeans and a t-shirt. While this wasn't frowned upon, I felt out of place.  Also, I'm sure it goes without saying, but if possible, leave the kids behind.
author: Noah B.

description:
The new de Young is a place worth visiting.  Its steely, copper exterior while formidibale, invites you into its treasure chest to view its wide variety of art.  I strolled in on a sunny Sunday afternoon, and was pleasantly surprised by the how easy it was to navigate the various exhibits, take in the vistas from the tower, and enjoy a refreshment at its terrace park after a good two hours of walking around.

Its important to remember what the de Young is not.  It is not the Metropolitan Museum of Art.  I hear countless complaints about the de Young's shortfalls and I think that they are unfair.  The de Young is a great museum, with innovative design, and a great amalgamation of interesting art that should be observed and enjoyed.  Its open design and integration with the natural artistic beauty of GG Park makes it unique.  So get out there, spend a sunny afternoon enoying what SF has to offer.  You'll be glad you did.
author: Kevin J.

description:
It's hard to live up to hype, fanfare and flash -- forces of publicity that seemed almost antithetical to the de Young way of olde.  But that's just why in some ways the "new" de Young wins me over, and why in some fewer ways it falls flat on its face.

The exhibits:  mostly magnificent, almost rogue in selection by comparison to what the de Young used to be known for.  November 2006, for instance:  Ruth Asawa, Ed Ruscha, the Quilts of Gee's Bend (which drew crowds in almost club-like density).  Then an engaging permanent (but still hungry for broader representation in certain regions) collection of works from the Americas and Africa.  By strict convention, the museum's exhibits are usually 50% craft/artifact, 50% art.  

With its quality of exhibits, the de Young has quickly captivated a wide range of patronage in its rebirth.  But, just as easily -- too easily, it almost always leaves me wishing for just a bit more, as if the exhibitions are incomplete.

In a connector gallery displaying a small and unconventional collection of "portrait photography" they exhibit Warhol, Avedon, Arbus (OK, portraiture by a stretch), heck even Radcliffe Bailey.  But not a single Mapplethorpe portrait.  They waste wall space on Karl Lagerfeld, but they overlook Mapplethorpe.  Hell, an Anton Corbijn photo would have been infinitely more relevant and valuable to this exhibit than a freakin' Lagerfeld puff piece.

Next door in the African art collection, they have a stunning collection of tribal masks.  I mean wonderful and broad in representation.  But not one single piece representing the Songye people.

The Gee's Bend exhibit was so wildly popular, they extended it for almost 3 months, but what was clearly the biggest attraction at the museum this season was crammed in a claustrophobic corner gallery.  The quilts deserved a better space.

All told, I'm not at all impressed by the museum interior and gallery layouts.  Most feel like enclosures, some are downright crammed, and all too often works are displayed with the same significance as merchandise at an Old Navy or EQ3 furniture store.  Compare it with how the Asian Art Museum in SF lights and displays their works and you'll know what I mean.

Perhaps the single most annoying element of the whole place:  the security collective that behave like the fucking gestapo.  Yes, I appreciate that they take their job seriously, but Jeezus H., someone  teach them the simple fact that politeness and compliance are not mutually exclusive.

There are a few things about the overall museum design that do stand out remarkably to me.  The dimpled fascia of the building doesn't move me as much as the huuuuuge Richter photo-mosaic in the main interior plaza that was probably commissioned to mirror that building's feature.  Then there's the sitting room adjacent to the American painters gallery overlooking the sculpture garden -- a wonderful piece of space.  Best in show:  the Andy Goldsworthy stone work outside the main entrance of the museum, in which one continuous crack works through the tiles and boulders scattered in the entry atrium -- so subtle and fantastic that most people will never even notice it.
author: Alfonso E.

description:
I've been to three museums in San Francisco, and this one is my favorite.  It took me way too long to make it out to the De Young - a shame since it's so close to my home.  I'm SO glad I finally made it out.

I read an article about the museum in San Francisco Magazine describing the building arcitecture - apparently it's supposed to resemble the canopy of the Park.  Very cool.   

As a student, tickets were only $6.  If you show them a muni transfer ticket or bus pass, you get another $2 off your ticket.  So, I went to a great museum today and only paid $4.  What a deal.

I don't know if it was the exhibits or the architecture or that its situated in Golden Gate Park, but I liked the museum a lot.  The featured exhibits were very cool (i know they change, so I won't go into them).  The other permanent exhibits were good too.  

I sometimes feel like MOMA is a little too avant garde for me.  The De Young was a good compromise for my art tastes.  

There are great views of the western side of the city from the observation deck.  I imagine on weekends it gets pretty crowded up there (I went on a Wednesday afternoon and I thought there were just enough people - bordering on too many).

I also went to the cafe and enjoyed a snack and glass of wine.  You can sit outside and enjoy the park and the sculpture garden.  Also, I'm not a big coffee drinker, but I noticed the coffee/espresso prices weren't over-inflated.
author: Angie C.

description:
Beautiful art museum with a great collection of tribal art from Africa. Highly recommend that part of the exhibit. A good choice to visit out of the list of museums in SF. 

Can't speak for the Tut exhibit there right now. I went to the show in LA, and it was cool, but expensive. I think it's one of those things that you suck up the money to go to because when are you ever going to have that opportunity again?
author: Susanne M.

description:
The permanent collection can be seen once and even then it's "meh."  Their special exhibits can range from fantastic to more "meh."  I really loved the Chihuly exhibit, it was beautifully done. 

My boyfriend is a member so when we heard there was going to be a Tut exhibit we were stoked.  We went on a Wednesday because the tickets are cheaper if you go after 5 (score!).  We waited in a line, to go into a room, to watch a movie narrated by Omar Shariff, and then the doors magically open to a statue of the boy king with a spotlight over him and the inevitable "OOOOHHH" and "AAAHHH" from the crowd.

Unfortunately, that was the only "ooH" ing and "ahh"-ing done for the next 45 minutes or so.

We cramped ourselves into a series of galleries of egyptian artifacts: mirrors, cosmetic boxes, tomb trinkets and the like.  We even went into a room that had a huge sarcophagus of a mummy that was Tjuya (Or something).  We kept thinking, THIS IS A SIGN WE ARE CLOSER TO HIM!!

"HIM" turned out not to be one of tut's coffins, but instead a tiny little baby tut coffin that held his liver.  YES, that is what is on all the posters.  It looks remarkably like the inner coffin, but it's not so don't expect to see that there.

We were baffled when we noticed the exhibit was over and we were nearly in a gift shop.  Then we saw an attendant:
"Excuse me, but where is the coffin?"
"Oh there is one in ..blahblahblah.. and the mummy is in Cairo...."
"Why is it on the poster?"
"Oh that's the tiny one that the liver was in"
"...."

Blah.  Maybe I am crazy because I expected to see a coffin that was on a thousand posters all around the city?  Maybe I expected a little more for my higher ticket price?  

Seeing these reviews I know I am not the only one... many people were in the gift shop asking eachother "DId we miss it?" or "What did we just pay for?"

If I had known that, I might not have gone.  I sure am glad I went on the cheapo night and avoided the crowds though.
author: Jenn F.

description:
What a perfect way to spend a late Saturday afternoon! The Andy Warhol and Yves Saint Laurent exhibits were well worth the extra admission; I enjoyed Warhol Live in particular. I had no idea he'd done so many album covers, and thought his jazz work was fantastic. The Studio 54 room was a kick, I loved the huge roll of VIP drink tickets displayed next to Warhol's membership card and his opening night invite. As a multimedia experience, it doesn't get much better than Warhol Live.

Due to the late hour I wasn't able to see the rest of the museum, but suffice to say the de Young will be a must see any time I'm in SF.
author: Daniel D.

description:
I enjoyed my visit to the new DeYoung much more than I had expected.  Although the building is rather hideous from afar, it's quite attractive up close.  It's often compared to the Tate Modern in London (another Herzog & de Meuron project), which is unfortunate, because they are such different animals.  Whereas the Tate Modern got its imposing scale as a remodel of an old power plant, the DeYoung's scale is totally contrived (and poorly contrived at that).  If someone forced me to choose one of these over the other, I'm afraid the Tate would win.  But whereas the Tate's galleries are generally very plain, the DeYoung is filled with fun corners and strange nooks.

As for the DeYoung collection, I think that San Francisco has to be quite proud.  It's eclectic almost to the point of schizophrenia -- which sounds just about right for San Francisco!  I discovered some regional artists that I'd never heard of before -- again, very apt for a city museum.  I really wish, though, that they didn't pack the walls with art right up to the bathroom doors.
author: Roger L.

description:
I thought the de Young stunk. I've been twice now, this last time on a date. The building is unbelievably poorly designed. There are these stairs down to the lower level with treads about two and a half feet wide. You naturally take two paces for each step and always descend on the same foot - gets pretty old after a while. We ended up taking really big steps - kind of fun. So the architecture is awful, how about the art? What there is is ok, there just isn't enough of it. You can seriously look at every work in the place in a couple hours. They do have some pretty cool skulls from the south pacific that have been adorned with feathers and jewels n' shit. Dope. 

What the hell is in all the space underneath that observation level? Why can't we go there? 

I bet the place falls apart, leaks, or both.
author: hugh f.

description:
This is a very beautiful museum in a stunning setting. Unfortunately, I believe today is the last day for the excellent Warhol exhibit, which far surpassed my expectations. But King Tut is coming next, and that should be fascinating as well!

The De young does a great job of rotating exhibits that really speak to a wide variety of interests. Fashionistas had their chance at the YSL exhibit, for example. Friday nights are pretty cool because the museum is open later with live music and cocktails - so if that's more your speed than the actual art, sink your teeth in!
author: Kiesha R.

description:
I will preface this review with fact that i have great contempt for the elitist art establishment.  Although they have in thier permanent collection many fantastic works.  The musuem is a classic example of less then stellar themed arranging of their art.  The garden is the most obvious.  A miss match or as the kids call it a mash-up of art.  Pop art next to japanese simplistic next modern next to who knows.  Inept.  That is all i can say.  Throughout the musuem there seems to be less then perfect flow.  I see very little effort to stay within some kind of a theme.  This is what happens when you allow credentials to dictate your hiring and choices in art.  Goldsworthy?  He did the front crack down the sidewalk???  Oh please.  This not what he does.  His art is enjoyed in photos before it disolves back to nature.  He laughed all the way to the bank.  Goldsworthy's work is in the similar vein to the Quetzalcoatl in San Jose by the late Robert Graham's Frankly or as I like to call it "poop in the park" ... I am sure as his staff cracked the sidewalk they were snickering at the art establishment.  

Furthermore, I am a big fan of Ikebana.  However the flower exhibit is absolutely hilarious.  Current to spring 2011.  There are some wonderful flower exhibits that are mauled by absolutely horrid work.  One word for you: EDIT.  The horrible flower works destroy any ability to enjoy the regular art in the museum.  


I will say it contains some of the greatest artwork on the west coast.  But as a whole we seserve more.  

Please hire someone to run the show who has some actual ability to theme the museum.  Jeezus christ.  Friggin' Joke.  

By the way I am a member.
author: Christopher F.

description: I took an "Images of America" humanities class at Sacramento State U and that's where I found out about Landscape artists especially those from the Hudson River School. The De Young museum didn't disappoint in showing some of his nice art pieces. I can't remember the old De Young museum design because I went here during a grade school field trip, but everything is spaced out evenly over here. Yay for Thomas Cole. Your paintings rock and thanks De Young for displaying some of them. I'm not an art major, but I still remember something from that class.
author: Gerard Y.

description: A visit to San Francisco isn't complete without stopping at the De Young Museum.  If you plan your time wisely, you can follow your stop at the De Young with a trip to the Legion of Honor without paying an additional entrance fee.  Two museums in one day for $10 . . . where else can you get entertainment/culture for that price?!
author: Janet S.

description: A wonderful, well thought out museum after the rebuild. I was slow to like the copper skin, but it has grow on me as the patina morphs to natural brown! The tower to the galleries is great. I wish it were more accessible $$$. The free day is okay if you can go then, but even for a member, the charge for the special exhibits can be a bit pricey as well. I still like to watch the tourists/visitors try to figure out the Andy Goldsworthy art piece at the entrance. "My god Marge, an expensive museum like this you would think they could replace these cracked stones" (for real).
author: Joe Bob J.

description:
After being one of the lunatics who waited (and waited) to get into the De Young when it was open all night, (which was much more fun and bonding than it sounds  :)  ) we decided to go back -finally - because of the Arts & Crafts exhibit.  

The A & C Exhibit - as advertised!  Loved the focus on how each culture took Arts & Crafts in a different direction.  The only downside was that we went on a rainy day and it was packed.  The space did not accomodate larger crowds very well.  I found it worth the extra fee and would recommend it to anyone interested in the era/movement.

The rest of the museum - ...odd.  I would love to come back when there weren't so many people (not that I would complain about folks visiting a museum - go for it, especially with kids).  I felt as if the flow was choppy - another reviewer has already mentioned the strange juxtapositions of permanent collections and I have to agree it is off-putting.  Some collections (Meso-american for one) seem oddly depthless, too.  I do look forward to seeing this unique building weather and change.

I must mention the friendliness of the staff at the doors.  We were met by a lovely lady carrying bags for our wet umbrellas and advice on how to avoid the huge line at admissions (hint - go downstairs to the secondary admissions desk!).
author: Suzanne B.

description:
The observation deck should definitely be your first stop.  The views really are breath-taking and the finishes are top notch.  I would have loved to been part of the team that built this thing.  

The fern grove is also really nice.  I just wanted to be inside it, on a little wooden bench listening to windchimes and being all zen-like...

Overall, i'm impressed.  I won't review the collections as they aren't all permanent but I did enjoy my perusal (is that a word?) of the current exhibitions.
author: Kyla B.

description:
My dad used to live in San Francisco when he went to law school at Hastings, and, incidentally, when he claimed to have started the hippie movement by wearing his old army jacket and sandals, growing his hair out, and trying to turn banana peels into a controlled substance because of "Mellow Yellow."  Consequently, he loves San Francisco to an enormous degree, and I have gotten far more visits from him in the last 7 months living here than in my 2 years living in L.A. (and he lives in Santa Barbara). 

So, he'll come here, and he wants to eat dim sum nonstop, and drink wine, and walk around, and visit his old haunts.  He used to live in the Richmond, but he confused me by saying he wanted to go to "the Avenues," because apparently nobody under 40 refers to it as the Avenues anymore.  After visiting "the Avenues," he wanted to go to the "little" de Young museum and see their jade collection that he used to always go visit.

Mind you, this was on a Saturday in the middle of the day.  We get there and it is crazy busy, and apparently, no jade collection of which to speak (I am fairly certain that this is the jade collection on display, and apparently, also in storage in the basement, at the Asian Art Museum).  My dad is shocked that the de Young museum is no longer a largely empty wee pup with a huge jade collection, and his vaguely autistic reaction to noise kicks in to all the people and all of their screaming children.

We shuttle him out of there, because even D can recognize how this is trouble.  It was sad, really, because they had an Egyptian art exhibit that was apparently fantastic.
