We decide to go to the Botanic gardens instead, and start walking to where we think an exit will be, D in the lead, me keeping an eye on the troublemaker, and the troublemaker lagging behind.  As we do so, we pass a cement cocoon with people sitting inside.

"WASSAT?" my dad exclaims.  "Oh, it's just an outdoor exhibition space, they have a video or something playing," D said, as we continued to walk.  "It's...it's...the circle of insanity," mutters my father.  That, apparently, was not enough for him, though.  He pokes his head inside in such a manner that he elicits the attention of the seated visitors. 

"YOU'RE SITTING IN THE CIRCLE OF INSANITY," he bellows.  "YOU'RE ALL GOING TO GO INSANE IN 10 MINUTES."  I clap my hand to my forehead, D practically chokes with laughter, and mission accomplished, my dad continues happily ahead.

But all that aside, it is a fantastic museum - great exhibits, parking is easy, and right next to the Botanic gardens so that you can make a day of it.  Just don't expect a jade collection.
author: Tanya N.

description: As a student (coincidentally an art history major), I paid $6 for general admission here, which was well worth it. There is no military discount, but the full adult admission price is $10, again, nothing for such a great place. Galleries included art from all around the Americas, from Inuit and eskimo religious pieces to south American pottery; the largest collection of African art I have ever seen; and art from across Oceania. There were many galleries of early American (as in the USA sense) paintings and furniture. I found a few Bierstadt paintings notable. De Young also displays some contemporary art, which I did not actually spend much time viewing except for one gallery of glasswork featuring several Dale Chihuly pieces. It would be easy to spend an entire day here. I absolutely love it.
author: Kate H.

description:
I'm glad to see that San Francisco has some really cool modern museums now that are getting face lifts.  They give me something to look forward to visiting in the city.  Especially this summer with Chihuly at the de Young.  This museum is so trendy inside and out.  I love the copper/bronze facade with the gold leaf combo.  I love the view from the tower atop the museum.  I also love the sculpture garden outside by the cafe and all the ferns around the museum. 

I only wish this museum were bigger.  I walked around the main floor up the stairs and said, that's it?  It seems so big from the outside, but you forget that it's not a big place really.  I only wish they had more huge exhibits to see.  Seeing Chihuly is huge, but I know that it's just a special exhibit that will eventually disappear and leave a big hole where it once was.  With its new exhibit through September, it will be well worth a visit or even two.
author: Stacey C.

description:
Wonderful colors, lines, and designs basically everywhere you look.  Unfortunately I didn't feel any real "flow" to this place.  It seemed jumbled.  I felt lost a lot and the lack of signs/arrows to be frustrating.  I left feeling like I missed a lot of stuff but just didn't know it.

Also, not to sound lazy, but there is a lot of stairs here too.  And hell, I am all for stairs.  But I'm not really one of those "on a mission" people when it comes to museums.  I like to stop and read shit.  So, after like an hour (or two) of standing and walking around a museum my leggies get achey.  Toss in multiple stairs and friends going off in different directions and it's tiring. 

I would recommend the museum yes, definitely.  Really nice exhibits and informative reading materials.  I just am so exhausted from my excursion there today that I feel really happy right now to be sitting on my ass in a computer chair.
author: Mary R.

description:
I'm not a big fan of the museum's permanent collection as my aesthetics are more of the Legion of Honor variety.  However, I love the building and the traveling exhibits that have made it inside over the past three years.  Come here for the free view of the City from the tower.  You can't get that vantage point of this corner of SF from anywhere else.

I love that we have our very own Herzog and de Meuron designed building. I first heard of them when I went to the Tate Modern in London back in 1999.

There are currently two big name special exhibits (special admission fee): Maya Lin's Systematic Landscapes and a retrospective of the work of Yves Saint Laurent.  The latter will most likely be a blockbuster.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: A crowded, uninspired, tourist trap. The tower and cafe were closed before they even let us in. The security guards watch you closer than they watch their paintings. Especially the one that looks like Omar Epps from House. It's difficult to appreciate the art with people staring at you and clamoring about with their children. Look at paintings in your art history books and spend your money on a good dinner instead. You'll enjoy yourself more.
author: Jesse H.

description:
i'm not verY much interested in Museums that mucH until this one caught mY eye last year. And NoW it haS becOME mY favorite. I liKe the way it waZ designed, the copper skiN, the Palm trees planted around it, and the besT featurE, the Observation towER on toP. frOM a distance it looKs like a Mayan Pyramid in the Middle of the AmazoN jungle ( I have a kitcheN magnet to prove that, haha!)

If U do go to this Museum, plan to spend an entire daY therE becuZ there is so mucH to see. And also to Have a break at the Cafe, to admire the wall to wall glass walls and the views. U can EveN see across the road, the almost finished structure of the STEINHART AQUARIUM which will have a planTED forest on its roof!!!

So comE here if U are bored!!!! My friends froM Sunnyvale might comE up somedaY, haha!
author: herm p.

description:
We viewed the Dale Chiluly exhibit which was beautiful and enchanting. The last room was the best (and least crowded) and the *fun* part was being in the retail store at the end of the exhibition ad seeing how much a Chiluluy glass bowl could cost for the average shopper. $6,600.00 for my favorite bowl. We were joking, if you want to buy one, do you pick it up in the store and take it to the service counter yourself??? Do they sell it with accident insurance? Does it come with a box??

BTW, the parking garage needs to have more than one pay machine, especially on the weekends.
author: Lulubelle L.

description:
The de Young museum is a nice piece to the mosaic of places to see in Golden Gate Park.  I am always awed by the big copper drape of a building when rounding the corner.  The tower juts up above the trees and I get excited for the multi-hour stroll I'm about to embark on.

Inside there is a ton of natural light.  Sure, it's not super bright, but I'll take muted sun light over a bulb any day of the week.  The works are spread out quite nicely giving you a lot of space to mull about and not have to jockey for position.  There are many different eras on display and there is usually something for anyone you might have in tow during your visit.  The first Tuesday of every month is a great reason to check this location out each month--FREE MUSEUM DAY!

This is for the King Tut exhibit.  1 Star.

I went with some family from out of town and was completely underwhelmed.  The crowds are unbearable the first few rooms.  The artifacts are nothing special.  You don't get any actual Tut items until you reach the final room.  It was very disappointing and I think you should not be expecting much when and if you go.  I think the fact that the image on the promotional poster is not even something that is in the exhibit says all you need to know about this.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I love coming here and observing the new exhibits. The newest one i've seen is the Yves Saint Laurent Exhibit. And might i add it was superb! For a girl who loves art and fashion, i was in heaven. YSL's original sketches were framed and it still hasn't hit me that he drew those and i was staring right at them! The extra cost didn't do me wrong as well...because that day we went all Bank of America customers got in for free! so i just ended up paying 10 dollars for the YSL exhibit. I was so happy about that...anywho even if i didn't get free admission i would totally pay 16 bucks for that. it was so darling and i wish i can take the clothes off the mannequin and take them home. i'd get arrested but just touching them would make me melt. 

I am also looking forward to the "Warhol Live" exhibit...uber excited!!! it starts on feb. 14!!!! everybody go check it out!!!
author: Suzan L.

description:
Great space surrounded by Golden Gate Park - love that you happen upon it while surrounded by greenery!

I saw the Vivienne Westwood exhibit & wandered through some other parts of the museum.  I am not super into art, but it is a tranquil space with enough interesting pieces to discuss with a friend.

Also stopped by the cafe - a little pricey, but good mac and cheese (skip the caesar salad).

I am excited to stop by a Friday night for the weekly happy hour/event held there & will update this review after!
author: laura g.

description:
This review is for the Tut exhibit-

We love the DeYoung and are members. We were excited when we saw that Tut was coming to town. We bought our tickets months ago. My daughter ended up needing emergency surgery on the night we were scheduled to see Tut. Even though they said no refunds, or changes the DeYoung was great and worked out another time for us to come. Our original time was a 5:30 spot, so they were able to accommodate  us pretty easily.

We went tonight and we were one of those families expecting to see a bigger Tut. I wish we had of read the reviews before we went, because it would have made it feel less anticlimactic when we got to the end. I really feel like the ads were misleading, and we had not read anything to know differently. 

My kids are going into 7th and 8th grade and studied Egyptian history in 6th grade. They knew a lot and enjoyed seeing the things they had learned about, in real life. The exhibit was set up very well. The artifacts they had were very cool. We went at 6:00 pm on a Wed. and it was not crowded. It is FREEZING in there, so bring a sweater or sweatshirt. 

I still recommend going. Go during the week. They have a special rate on Tuesday and Wednesday nights. Enjoy!
author: Keri V.

description:
Yves Saint Laurent Exhibit

"Fashion changes, but style remains. " YSL's motto was ever so alive as I stood before each ensemble....each work of art. The exhibit encompasses a chronology of garments from the House of YSL, starting in 1962. 

As the successor to Christian Dior, YSL imposed his own style, which is evident in all garments exuding utmost feminity, power, class, and elegance. Each piece albiet simple or complex, was definitely crafted with much attention and creative thought. I was utterly amazed at the construction and intricate details of each suit, gown, or coat. More importantly, the articulation and silhouette between the human body and the garment is simply beautiful...which I'm sure is the YSL aesthetic.

Most of his iconic pieces where inspired by artists such as Mondrian, Warhol, and Matisse. It was mind-blowing to be inches away from those dresses and coats, which have their place in fashion history.

This exhibit ends FIRST WEEK of APRIL. HIGHLY HIGHLY
 RECOMMENDED!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Kat M.

description: Website said it was open until 5 but was closing early today AND the Hockney show was sold out! How do you sell out a museum exhibition, made me VERY angry...don't think I'll rush back OR become a member ant time soon.
author: Barbara M.

description:
great building.
nice collections, especially the african and polynesian.
unacceptable entry prices ($25 for the temporary picasso exhibit???)
don't miss the view from the tower, best in the city in my opinion.
author: Vlad G.

description:
I love this building but it is very much a mausoleum for (dead) cultural artifacts. The colors and textures say exactly that. The layout of the place is also very confusing. We had NO idea which way to go, or whether we'd already seen whatever was around the corner or down the blind alley in front of us. 

Also the arrangement of the collection seems to be more about honoring donors and benefactors than about making a coherent statement about the relationship of one era or art form or region to another. There are no transitions, and the jump cuts make no sense.

On the positive side we saw an astonishing photo show (by Hiroshi Sugimoto) that was beautifully arranged and lit -- quite easily the best photo show I've ever seen, period. So they do know HOW to run  a museum if their dons would just give them a little slack.

On the negative side, the cafe was cold, impersonal (which is actually one of the central qualities of the whole joint), badly organized, confusing, and way way substandard for a culinary destination like San Francisco. 

I'm not arguing for way expensive or overly chi-chi cuisine, but would it be too much to ask for decent interesting food offered in a logical enough manner that native speakers could figure it out and feel their money was well spent? I pity the poor [non-native-speaker] immigrant. 

And there's no excuse for food this corporate and mediocre from a company which (according to the chest-beating poop sheet on the tables) promises fresh local quality offerings.
author: George M.

description:
Well, I guess I'll be one more review for this museum. It was raining a lot when we came, and I erroneously figured a lot of people wouldn't want to come out in the rain (stupid thought). We got there around 10:30 on a Sunday and there was still a good amount of parking. Lines were still short, too. And it happened to be a free day, thanks to Target! We had no idea, even after looking at the website first. Consequently, it was VERY busy, but we were still able to check out everyone we wanted to see comfortably. The King Tut exhibit was closed, but no worries. I was fascinated by the Papua New Guinea and African exhibits, which had so many items. I also loved the American Revolutionary Period exhibit, the pottery, and the Amish quilt exhibit was very interesting. 
I felt like the store was as big as the museum, taking up almost the whole bottom floor!
The observation floor was wonderful, too, with great views even in the rain.
author: Sara W.

description:
OMG!

I intended to go on opening night 'round midnight when a friend in line called to say the wait ahead was expected to be 4 hours.  I shelved it and was told by a major donor not to go for at least 2 months if I wanted to enjoy the crowd.  

I have run by it in awe, I like the tower and I like that you may not like it, its art, its not supposed to be easy, its suppose to challenge and shift your thinking.  Well, then you learn the whole museum is set up that way, from the broken line running from the curb to the door, from the reverberating atom displayed on the wall.  It's all about shift.  

You can learn this as I did by taking an official tour from a docent who is found in the Wilsey Court and apparently on the 2nd floor as well.  The docent who led us was named, Michelle, I believe, and she was absolutely terrific in taking us through the museum's first floor.  She was so warm yet whipsmart, I wanted to invite her over for dinner.  She had an awesome task of taking us through the Contemporary American/Western displays and explaining the history of the museum to us, a rag tag group of tourists, art aficionados, artists and clueless wanderers which she did flawlessly.  

You learn a lot on this tour and it inspired us onward after.  My mother, an observer of abstract who says "What the hell is THAT? You brought that stuff home in the 1st grade" was satiated though she still sniped " ok maybe I see the boat, I see a parrot but everything else is a mess"  

The space itself is the furthest thing from a mess.  The mess hall, the cafeteria is just that, not a simple, polite cafe. The food is surprisingly good, the service friendly and efficient. On a sunny day you can sit outside, enjoy the outside art (The Paperclip!!!) and eat, so art for the peoplesque.  

Rumor has it, Herzog and deMeuron have hired one of SF best architects to lead their next project, a museum in Napa.  The Bay Area holds its breath... but until then we have hours and hours to enjoy this jewel in our midst.  

Go today and go early to avoid the line to the 7 degree turning tower with the great view.  It will make an art fan out of a couch potato. I look forward to going back again and again, though that would be easier if the museum was free like they are in DC.
author: Sean S.

description:
4 reasons to visit:
1. The observation deck
2. The fantastic mac n' cheese at their cafeteria
3. The Oceana exhibit (lots of skulls that look like shrunken heads)
4. The architecture (the lights look like ear wax pickers - if your Asian, you know what I mean)

The pluses: get a yearly membership - bring 3 other friends with you throughout the year! And the membership also includes a yearly membership to the Legion of Honor.

If you don't want to wait, go downstairs to get your tickets - there is another admissions desk there (and the bathrooms too!).
author: Judy L.

description:
It's a beautiful setting ... you can hop on over to the botanical garden to see beautiful flowers or have a picnic on a bench to admire the architecture of the museum.  The museum itself is gorgeous and will leave you wanting to come back to explore some more. 

It'll be busy on weekends you'll find -- so I prefer to go on weekdays to check out a particular exhibit or area.  Make sure to get a membership or to pull out those student discounts if you apply.  I've been to a couple of comedy shows here as well ... and I love that they bring some very cool cultural shows that are politically progressive.  It doesn't just stick to "art" but branches out to bring the performing arts too!  Make sure you check out their calendar ... you'll definitely enjoy my friends!
author: Roni R.

description:
Both of the special exhibits I've gone to at DeYoung were great.  I went to a fashion one and Chihuly (amazing!).  I don't find the permanent exhibits to be that great though.  There's a lot of African artifacts that I'm just not that into, maybe it's all those years working in an import store?
Go when there's a good special exhibit, then head over to the Legion of Honor.  Your admission covers you for both.
First Tue of the month is free, and you can also get in free the first weekend of the month with a Bank of America card!
author: Sarah M.

description:
We're here for the first time, and for the Tutankhamun exhibit!  A definite must-see with regards to artifacts; however, we were a bit disappointed when Tut's sarcophagus wasn't anywhere to be seen.  Not a big loss since there's a lot more to see.

If you're in the area, go now!
author: equation l.

description:
I love the new remodeled DeYoung!  I agree that it looks somewhat strange/odd on the outside...but I've gotten use it now.  But I like the more spacious free to it inside.  It also seems less cold/dark inside...definitely more inviting and makes for a more enjoyable visit (I remember being a creeped out second/third grader visiting the mummies in the old DeYoung).

The courtyard is a nice touch.  And the cracks along the cement outside leading inside is COOL.  The viewing tower is free everyday to the public.  I don't think many people know this.
author: Mick S.

description:
What is a gigantic massive structure doing in the middle of the park? At first I wasn't the biggest fan of the architecture. I mean, what other things are dark brown? Think! Plus, it was just so massive compared to the other buildings in the park that seem to have a more classical style. But I've gotten used to it - and even like its unique structure now. It feels like a good fit to the park. 

Their art collection varies from Latin American art to African art to contemporary and some classical art, as well. The sculpture garden is fun to visit. And the views from the tower is awesome. This place is turning into one of my favorite museums in the city. 

I've always managed to visit when it's free. This month BofA is sponsoring a free visit to SF museums in the month of May so if you bank there, it'll be worthwhile to take a trip to see what you may possibly have been missing out on. Otherwise, I try to make it on the free Tuesdays of each month. In a city this expensive, at least some things are still free.
author: Lorraine D.

description:
I can't write a decent review for this place (but of course I'm gonna write one anyway). Why? Because every time I try to visit this place, it is JAM PACKED and not so cheap. I guess the wise wouldn't attempt visiting the newest addition to Golden Gate park on the weekend (but then, do the wise have a normal work week?). 

So... from what I've learned:
2 stars for accessibility
3-4 stars for exhibits, I did like a good deal of what I got to see
4 stars for the cutesy museum cafe
5 stars for the lookout at the top of the museum (highlight)
and... 
5 stars for the golden gate park location (minus 3 stars if you want parking)
author: Erin M.

description:
This is one of those art museums you walk out of debating how strings of metal shards hanging from the ceiling constitutes art. There are arguably some great pieces but I was generally unimpressed. I did, nonetheless, find the collection amusing and appreciate the whole art in the park for a nominal fee concept as a totally cool idea for promoting local artists. I might even go again just to see what quirky new pieces they might have in store.

With your admission ticket, you can also take a tour of the observation deck, which offers gorgeous panoramic views of Golden Gate Park. That alone was worth the visit.

TIP: De Young admission tickets will grant you FREE admission into the Legion of Honor if you go the same day, and vice versa.
author: Cat L.

description: I wanted to check out the Picasso exhibit and it did not disappoint. de Young has a great collection. The location is also great. Golden Gate Park  has some other museums and botanical gardens.
author: C K.

description: Came here last Saturday to see the Picasso exhibit and the Balenciaga exhibit.  I didn't really care for the massive amount of people in the Picasso exhibit, but I guess that's to be expected on a holiday weekend and not to mention gorgeous weather in the city.  The exhibit itself was well done with a good amount of artwork from Picasso.  However, I was definitely more impressed with the Balenciaga exhibit.  I am becoming more and more a fan of fashion exhibits and think it's so interesting to see how a designer evolves over time and the influences they take from every day life and culture.  Unfortunately I think this exhibit closed as of July 4th.  I appreciated the de Young for always having such a wide range of exhibits and look forward to going back again in the future.
author: Evie B.

description: Don't bother with the membership. The member services is pretty bad. Website isn't much help.
author: John S.

description:
I love the De Young Museum because of the amazing collection!!! The upper deck which gives you a nice 360 view of the city is an excellent addition. I also enjoyed the huge print out of google maps. I had a good time locating places. 

I saw the King Tut exhibit here--and it was great. There are about 10 rooms. I wish the facts were more detailed, and the artifacts be more diverse. The wait was not too bad. It is hot there--maybe due to the crowd.
author: Chatree T.

description:
"The De Young Museum is plated in copper?  In a few years, it'll turn green like the Statue of Liberty!" 

Although first impressions of the museum seem like a copper facade of scrap, stepping inside the building brings about a whole new light.  From the art nuveau to the observation deck with a 360-degree view of the city of San Francisco, there's something for everyone at the De Young.  Where the museum lacked a large collection of works from the more well-known artists such as Picasso, Renault, Van Gogh, O'Keefe, and Monet (it had a few), it made up in showcasing several local artists who have used the museum as a platform for their art.   

As an aspiring (yet amateur) artist, my favorite parts of the museum were the landscape paintings and the photography exhibition upstairs.  My friend Pauline, on the other hand, tended to veer towards the Veracruz terracotta artifacts and the ancient mahogany furniture.  Though I have to admit, a solid oak mantlepiece which stood tall at around 15 feet, was a sight of awe to everyone in the room.

I would recommend the De Young museum for anyone who appreciates contemporary art and wants something more novel than just "classic" art.
author: Anjali M.

description:
I like to think of myself as somewhat cultured, so I was always a little embarrassed to admit that I'd never been to the De Young.  I took care of that little chore last weekend, and what a wonderful experience it was!  I'm still on the fence about the look of the building, but the collection totally blew my mind.  The Louise Nevelson special exhibit was awesome and really well-done (she was alive from 1899 to 1988 and created some incredible thought-provoking cubist-inspired sculptures) and there are some crazy mind-bending drawings in the next gallery over.  And I can't forget the viewing tower, with some really unique views of the bay and the bridge and the city.  

I only have enough stamina for about two hours of museum, so there's a ton more that I didn't get to check out - a great excuse to go back!
author: Rachel B.

description:
The De Young's a cool place. $10 general admission, discounts for youth, students, and seniors. The admission fee also includes entrance to the Legion of Honor. Last time I was here I didn't have enough time to check out everything I wanted to see. I missed the textiles and American pre-20th century art. They have contemporary art, textiles, photography, and ethnic art. Flash isn't allowed in the museum, but if none of the employees are around, you can get away with it.

The 20th century and contemporary art section has some pretty cool paintings, glasswork, and sculptures. A little bit of this and that; Georgia O'Keeffe, Thornton Dial, Dale Chihuly. They've got some amazing glasswork. The pieces are really beautiful. Their photography section is small and it was a bit disappointing; not too special. Connections upstairs also has interesting stuff. It's not as cool as the MOMA, but still worth the trip.
author: summer k.

description:
I haven't seen the King Tut exhibit yet, but i'm planning to some time in August.  
I love museums.  Something about the idea of preserving the past to help us move forward is commendable and beautiful.  I visited this site a few months back, several times just the exterior and once actually inside.  I was amazed at the architecture and design of the building, it looks like a spaceship crash landed on earth with historical relics inside.   The blend of Modern, Victorian and Tribal art was present and its exhibits were clean and presentable.  

I wish i was able to take pictures and good luck finding help from the staff, it seems like there only there to remind you to stay back from the tapestries and nothing else.  But I really didn't mind because I love to explore and find things out on my own... its more adventurous that way.  I took several of my church youth group with me, and everyone seemed to have a fun time.  I cant wait for another visit.
author: Riko H.

description:
The architecture and experience at the De Young Museum were quite confluent. Had I not been spoiled by the grandness of the Met in New York, I would give this museum five stars.

My family enjoyed viewing the "American Painting, American Sculpture and Decorative Art, Art of the Americas" collections. 

If you're into fashion, make sure you check out the "Nan Kempner: American Chic" exhibit. It is very impressive. This woman boasts an array of one-of-a-kind haute couture get-ups from the likes of Yves Saint Laurent, Chanel, etc. 

Nan definitely has bank. Must be nice.
author: Miles G.

description:
Went to the Friday night featuring local drag diva Peaches Christ. It was a proud moment to see drag queen gay boy rock bands busting out in the Wilsey (Oh the Glory of It All) Hall of the gorgeous De Young while tourists, befuddled straight folks, and kids mingled with sparkly queens and gay boys in business casual and orange patent leather pumps. Rock on!

Great exhibit there by photographer Deborah Oropallo that night too, her work is not to be missed.

I heard that the exhibit flew in under the radar and when the board found out, they threw a fit! Congrats to those brave souls at the museum who want to honor all of the art and artists produced in SF, hope you didn't get fired. And shame on the board for the homophobic freak out! You should of had this during Pride month.
author: Krismet C.

description:
I spent an afternoon here last week wandering around the tripped-out enchanted glass forest/ocean/greenhouse that is the Chihuly exhibit.  What an amazing collection of work.  My friend and I were pretty much in a constant state of wonder as we walked through. If you haven't seen it yet, go. Now. Before it's too late. (And try to play hooky and go on a weekday afternoon. There are hardly any crowds.)

The permanent collection (or what we managed to see of it in the 45 minutes we had left after the Chihuly) had a pretty hard act to follow.  We tried to be fair about this, and I think we did a good job of appreciating the merits of the work displayed. The African masks are super cool. There are many surprisingly disquieting pieces of modern sculpture. The building itself is intriguing, with all the weird angles and strategically placed windows and rusty looking metal. Kind of "Alice in Wonderland" meets "Blade Runner".

Minus one star because it is damn hard to find your way around. It's kind if neat to be lost for a while, but then, as you turn the corner and see the giant Strontium atom photograph thing on the wall for like the 15th time when you thought you were actually walking away from it, it can be a little frustrating. Also, I wish there had been more context for the indigenous art pieces. I mean, I am glad to know that a mask comes from Lake Turkana and is made of mud and wood and feathers, but I am a lot more interested in what the people actually used it for.

We avoided the cafe because my companion has a aversion to areas where people are instructed to "feed" (his term) at public venues, so I don't have any pearls of wisdom to share about the food and beverage part of the museum.
author: Angie R.

description:
This review is for the general exhibits.  I have not experienced any of the special exhibits.

The museum itself is expertly put together.  The architecture is interesting and unique, and the interior is clean and simplistic.  I will say that the layout is very confusing and was lost a few times.

The reason I didn't enjoy this museum is the art itself.  Most of it just seemed uninspired and lacking style.  There were a few landscape paintings that I particularly liked but everything else was meh.  

Go to Legion of Honor or San Francisco Museum of Modern Art instead, both of which are excellent.
author: Ryan F.

description:
The most impressive collections this side of the Mississippi can be found at the de Young. After bailing on the line at Cal Academy of Sciences across the way (it was free third Wednesday there and the line was an hour long), we ducked into de Young.  Being a member of the SDMA (http://www.yelp.com/biz/san-diego-museum-of-art-san-diego) got me and a friend in for free-- bonus!

The architecture of the building and the grounds alone are masterpieces. I couldn't find any right angles, (except maybe on some of the stairs).

The vast diversity of the collections is jaw-dropping. Everything from indigenous arts of Oceania and the Americas, to modern/contemporary collections, photography, to massive room-sized sculptures.  It took me two separate trips to see everything.

Currently (April-May 09) there is a special Warhol exhibit, which for an extra $10 from the museum admission is a must see. King Tut will be appearing starting on June 27.

The de Young is an absolute must-see every time I visit SF!
author: Austin D.

description:
Beautiful.  I especially like the fern garden just outside the windows and causes a green glow through most of the downstairs.

The fashion section upstairs was neat too.  

I really liked a painting that took up a whole wall of Lake Tahoe.  It looked very Japanese by the style of the painted waves.  The blue draws you in and you don't want to walk away.

The tower was a little overrated, maybe because it was a drab day...but the windows seemed to be dirty or coated with mold or something which didn't help.
author: Susan C.

description:
First time at the De Young was on Friday and I really enjoyed it. It was nice to be in a museum that housed American art and culture a very big changed from the typical euro or Asian inspired museums I have been to recently.

I spent a couple hours walking around from top to bottom viewing the American art and the really interesting African exhibit upstairs.

My favorite piece by far was the mini cathedral that had been constructed from over 200 guns and over 1000 rounds of ammo depicting everything that goes into war and religion.  Really good piece!!

it as a bit of a bummer as our friend had told us to make sure to go to the observation tower but as we made our way to the elevators they had closed the tower for two hours as they were getting ready for the special Friday night events that go on.  We wish we would have known about this so we could have planned our day around it and stayed the nighttime festivities which I hear are usually pretty good. We had to pass on that but hope to come back and check out the Friday night events and the observation tower.

The real big bummer but not for us was as we were leaving we passed the bike and in between next to a green helmet was a set of bolt cutters which had to have been a very big bummer to the person who owned from the bikes next to it a very nice mtn bike.  Nice place but be wary of locking your bike up with nothing short of a fort knox of bike locks.
author: Robert S.

description: The "Observation Tower" is where you want to go and it cost nothing. "You get the feeling that you're on top of the world." Sit back, relax, and take in the view......
author: P J.

description: Visited the de Young for the Balenciaga exhibit which was amazing. The energy was on point yet avant garde. All clothing was very intimate and carefully preserved. Loved my visit, will come again for sure.
author: Guia d.

description:
OK, first of all, contrary to many reviews here, the building is a new building. They demolished the old DeYoung b/c it was a seismic disaster waiting to happen.

That said, it's a beautiful building with a decent collection. As an architect, I went to see the building, so I guess I'm biased. 

The copper skin  has an interesting story: Digital photos were taken near the site looking up through the trees. The images were thinned out and simplified. The pattern was applied to the overall elevation of the building and holes cut out where the sun was poking through the leaves in the image. Every copper panel is unique.
author: Mason M.

description:
Just saw the King Tut exhibit and it was great!  I learned so much and it was all organized very well.  I got the audio system which was super helpful because I feel like I learned all these inside historic tips, so I would certainly suggest this.  The artifacts were so well preserved making this exhibit even better.

On the down side, it was so busy.  So so busy.  I would suggest going after 6 because a person who worked there said it was dead then.  I could barely walk around and it was 4pm!  

Other than that, I defiantly recommend going to see King Tut.
author: Cara D.

description: When I found out that the De Young Museum was having a showing of the birth of Impressionism: Masterpieces from the Musée d'Orsay "I just about died. My friend and me just had to see this incomparable collection. Walking around looking at the exhibition, "Birth of Impressionism, we both felt like we were in Paris, France again. When it comes to seeing great Impressionist painters such as Monet, Manet, Degas, Renoir, and others you just become mesmerized by such fine work they've all done. Each piece of art you look at has meaning. Moments of modern life captured with color, light and immediacy. I can't wait to see the second exhibition in September.
author: Gwendolyn M.

description:
The observation deck here is hilarious -- even though it's way high up, it's often so foggy that you can't see jack.  So people just end up crowding around  the giant aerial wall photo of SF.

My favorite painting in the permanent collection is  "Dinner Table at Night," John Singer Sargent's informal portrait of Mr. and Mrs. Vickers. It's red and softly lit like a romantic valentine, but husband and wife are sitting far apart, not looking at each other, and the husband is so far in the corner you barely notice him.   I found it kind of amusing:
http://search.famsf.org:8080/view.shtml?record=133286&=list&=1&=&=And

Later this summer definitely do not miss the Hiroshi Sugimoto exhibit!  I saw this same show at the Hirshhorn in DC and absolutely loved it. For example, he'd photograph wax museum figures of Henry VIII and his wives -- these giant portraits are incredibly lifelike, and they make you do a doubletake because for a split-second you think, "What the hell? Did they have cameras in the 16th century?!"  Sugimoto also has  a mesmerizing photo series of different oceans and seas around the world. Yeah, they all look pretty much the same, but still there's something hypnotic about looking at oceans. I also loved his photos of thousands of Buddha statues called "Sea of Buddha."  Finally, math geeks will love his elegant series of "mathematical models" -- 3-D sculptural versions of  trigonometric functions. Don't miss it.
http://www.thinker.org/deyoung/exhibitions/exhibition.asp?exhibitionkey=658

In the spring and summer, the museum is open late Friday evenings with $5 admission!  Plus free tours/lectures/music/performances and a cash bar. An interesting and affordable alternative to happy hour. When I did this last summer, the Friday activities drew quite a crowd:  the International Arts and Crafts show was packed. Surprisingly, though, the other galleries were pretty empty at the time. So even if you don't like big crowds, you might still take advantage of the discount if you stay in the permanent collection
http://www.thinker.org/deyoung/calendar/day.asp?categoryid=32
author: angela n.

description:
Have no interest in art? Then go to the observation deck and stare at our beautiful city from 360 degrees. Then buy the poster with the google map type image of SF. 

Love art? Then you will be quite happy for hours here. Their permanent and visiting collections are always fascinating. 

Love architecture? Just sit outside and marvel at the ingenious design of the museum.
author: Ali L.

description:
I purchased the ticket with the audio tour from Costco, and chose a very good day (for a weekend) to go see the King Tut Exhibit. It was Super Bowl day, so there weren't as many people there as I assume there would be if it had been a normal weekend day. The King Tut Exhibit starts with a brief intro on two small TV screens, and then the doors open into a dark mysterious room (!), where ancient treasures await to be oogled at. 
As many yelpers have written, I too, had expected much more King Tut  artifacts so I was slightly disappointed, but I was still awed by the craftsmanship, the quality of preservation, and the similarities between now and then in what constitutes beauty - in many of the pieces that I saw in the exhibit. The audio does add a bit, but not much, to the overall experience. 
As for the other parts of the museum - I didn't look too thoroughly. They have some interesting pieces, but not anything truly captivating as far as I saw. I also went up to the 9th floor observation tower - it's a good place to get a nice view of SF.
author: Orie M.

description:
One of the coolest museums in San Francisco. Amazing art and a spectacular 360 view of San Francisco from the tower. Located in Golden Gate Park, walking distance from the Japanese Tea Garden and across the way from the California Academy of Sciences (re-opening soon).  Worth a visit just for the view and the special exhibitions. Parking though expensive is really convenient at the underground parking structure. The audio tours can be rented for a fee (free for visually impaired visitors). Members are also required to pay a fee for the audio tours.

TIPS:  Your admission ticket to de Young can also be used at The Legion of Honor so come early to give yourself enough time to visit both museums.
A limited number of wheelchairs are available to borrow for those visitors who might not be able to walk through the many of galleries.
The tower closes a half hour before the museum closes and there is usually a short line at the elevator so visit the tower early.
Teachers can get a yearly membership for only $45.  It includes bringing one guest with each visit, 10% off at the museum store and covers both De Young and the Legion of Honor.
author: Rachel R.

description: This is probably my favorite west coast museum. I have been here several times and even had a membership. The Yves Saint Laurent exhibit was to DIE for and the King Tut viewing was mesmerizing. Try to come on a weekday or Sunday to avoid the crowds. Saturdays in the summer are especially packed with kids.
author: Morin O.

description:
I had heard much of the remodeled De Young Museum, and was looking forward to seeing the new and improved structure (anything would be better than that terribly retrofitted building, with the ugly metal bracers on the outside and the chicken wire at the top).

My first reaction upon seeing the museum was, "Oh that's too bad, it's still under construction."  But as soon as I got closer I realized that what I had taken to be dark construction tarp wrapped around the building was in fact the dark exterior of the museum!  Which lead me to my next impression of the evil science fiction fortress.

Personally I think that the exterior of the museum is pretty gross, especially when contrasted with the gorgeous surroundings of the park.  Call me nostalgic, but I miss the old entrance to the museum, which ascended around a nice pond and fountain.  Heck, I had trouble even finding the entrance the remodeled museum!

The interior is nice, though, and the view from the top of the tour (on a sunny day, ha ha) is beautiful, if you can stand the wait.  As for the actual exhibits, I particularly enjoyed the Hudson River paintings which were beautiful.  

One odd thing about the museum, though, is that there is very little transition between one exhibit and another.  One second you're looking at ancient artifacts from Papua New Guinea, next you're looking at American paintings.

Oh, and I say "Boooo!" to the cafe which made me wait in a huge line behind folks ordering food just to get a soda!
author: Corey C.

description:
My relationship with the De Young had a rough start. My first visit was a couple years ago when I wanted to check out some exhibit that I have zero recollection of now. What I do remember, though, is going up to the counter to buy a $20 ticket to the special exhibit and then being denied 5 minutes later at the entrance because visitation hours were over. How rude! 

A couple years later, which brings us to today, I'm pleased to say that I have had two amazing visits to the De Young. Once for Dale Chihuly (wow!) and more recently for Maya Lin and Yves Saint Laurent (wow wow!). Both times, however, I haven't felt compelled to check out the rest of the museum. If the De Young continues to attract such amazing artists, I'm sure I'll get to the permanent exhibits eventually.
author: Susan L.

description:
Back in December, I came here to see the Yves Saint Laurent exhibit.  Two words.  Super fab.  I really enjoyed the layout and the atmosphere in which the garments were set.  The lighting was nice, and I really enjoyed the runway video projection near the glass cases.  I walked away with a YSL poster, t-shirt, and book.  It's a bit pricey, but it's well worth the money I'd say.  

The rest of the museum was nothing compared to the YSL exhibit, but it was a cool experience.  I even had the chance to go up to the tower and take in the view, which was exciting.
author: Ravo Y.

description:
The building, particularly the view from the tower, she's a beaut. The collection, she pains me...
 
I Agree with Tammy N.
author: Sita B.

description:
Not Boring!!

You must visit the Observatory! You are at the highest level and you can see a good amount of San Francisco's charming scenery.
author: Oanh N.

description:
Oceana exhibit! This makes me a very happy girl as it is comparatively challenging to find information on this part the world.

If no particular exhibit particularly strikes your fancy not to worry. This is still a lovely place to hang out and not just because it is within the park. It's portion of the park has an outdoor modern art exhibit. The lobby itself contains select pieces along the walls and as seating.  There is also an observation tower.  See the the park and the city!
author: Joanna B.

description:
Five stars in a three star art Museum. I guess it's just not my kind of art or something. 

The Dale Chiluly exhibit  was awesome! This is what made the Museum five star for adding such a great artist. The visuals were insane! The facility itself is okay. A bit drab even for a girl who enjoys going to the museums when she can. It was quite busy for a Friday afternoon.  Dale Chiluly exhibit  is about to leave.. go and check it out for that reason alone. I hope they bring more memorable exhibits in there because without it I don't think this place is worth it. Just my opinion.
author: Shana A.

description: Love, love, love de Young. Went here with a friend about two months ago for the Flower Show and we had a grand time. They had music, wine and tons of people showed up to catch the annual exhibition. Their overall collection is decent as well. If you haven't been here, it's a must if you're in SF. Go now!
author: Becky O.

description:
Love it here: culture, people, and Art all in one place.  My most recent visit was during V-day for the Andy Warhol and YSL exhibits.  Both were terrfic but I was really drawn to the YSL exhibit (I'm a fashion fanatic).  

Their exhibitions give you a well-rounded glimpse into the subject.  Case in point, the YSL exhibit didn't simply display the fashion but video footage, interviews, and samples of his sketches.  Really enjoyed it.  

The Warhol exhibit was just as in depth.  It showcased his works throughout the years and showed examples of the different mediums he used.  Fab.  

The De Young is perfect on the weekend when you've got a few hours to spare.  So easy to lose yourself here and let the day go by.
author: Dorothy F.

description:
They have a Miro sculpture here! Yay. Funny thing is, it's titled La Maternite and has a giant vagina -- hmm can I say that on yelp? -- and there are always all these little kids playing in it. 

Anyway, for SF, I think it's a decent museum. It has a lot of American art, which I can appreciate, and a lot of Oceanic/African/textile art, which I can't appreciate. But all the good stuff is in NY, DC or internationally, so I forgive the DeYoung.

I was there for their Friday night event - it was pretty cool - last week it was bands, a fashion show featuring local designers, cash bar, etc.
author: serena l.

description:
There is something for everyone here and the de Young museum.  Old or new, they have it.  My faves were the Baroque still life and the teapots.  The view from the tower is also pretty cool.

Museum ranking, I'd put Legion of Honor [http://www.yelp.com/biz/legion-of-honor-san-francisco#hrid:nekwr0eqBcyekWFXCNedyw] first, then de Young and SFMOMA [http://www.yelp.com/biz/san-francisco-museum-of-modern-art-san-francisco-2#hrid:GwSokjZ3TCRTCmLB5VRHlQ] second.  Is that cheating putting two in second?  It really depends on whether you like modern art more or not.  I say, just visit both. ;)  de Young might be a little bit better because it's smack in the middle of Golden Gate Park.
author: M C.

description:
I am always, always surprised at how easy it is to get parking inside Golden Gate Park.  It's a frustrating nightmare come to life when trying to find parking just to grab a bite in the Mission, but a few miles away in this amazing park, there's maybe 1 car for every 4 spaces.  Wow.

The DeYoung looks small from the outside (to me), but inside it's just the right size.  They seem to always have a special exhibit and the ride up to the observation deck is always worth the view.

My favorites at this museum?  Any of the dozens of paintings that are enormous.  I don't know exactly how many there are, but these giant, 15x15 or so pictures with all sorts of abstract graphics are just so cool to me.

Okay, off now to Union Square to suffer through traffic and bad parking, just to have lunch.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
When reviewing an exhibit I review the exhibit displays, choice of artifacts and features such as in this most recent case King Tut. Well laid out and presentation signage was clear.  The choices of artifacts nicely inter-related to the size and shapes of Egyptian architectural proportions and room sizes.  The flow presented the artifacts in a chronological order giving audiences and the crowds well handed visibility.  There was nice places to rest and relax and you got a formal presentation of discovery with history.  Well worth the money to see items used by a young boy King, but not only that, you get a feeling of what it was like in those times.
For those that need the sensationalism of Tut's mask present, it's in Cairo and never leaving there again.  This happened because so dork damaged it when moving it on a previous tour.   Personally I would think it's a smart move on Egypt's behalf, besides I don't see the United States let the Constitution, signed copy of the Declaration of Independence or for that matter Betsy Ross' flag go abroad.   If you have a problem with that, go see your mummy.
Speaking of mummy: the gift shop.  I felt it kind of absurd to buy a Chinese made mummy wine rack for $450 or a replica Senet game for $35, but keep in mind that this is best you are gonna get, and also it will cost lots less than your trip to Cairo and getting your wallet stolen from you.
author: Tito Y.

description: Fun location, ok with artwork, and love the cleaniless and security.  Not much to say about this place.  I'm glad i went on first tuesday of the month when it's free.
author: Daphne A.

description:
Probably my most favorite museums in the city.. I just love the location and the design of it. (I used to be an architectural geek - blue prints still get me disturbingly turned on)  I'm sure the engineering nerds love the way the earthquake crack was engineered to run all the way down the entrance.  You, Geeks.

Free day on the first Wednesday of the month are fabulous.  You can spend a stroll or run around GG park and soak up some art.  You can also check out the special exhibits all for $10 on the free day.  There's a garden, a cafe, a museum store, stairs everywhere, big ceilings and even a coat check!  I personally just like sneaking peeks and when they're not looking, walk in.  This time was Andy Warhol and YSL.  I personally like the South American pieces and the US history ones.  If I knew if I was going to stay in the city longer I'd probably sign up for a membership $45/year for a student + a friend! Sweet!

I always like going up to the top floor just to look out into the city.  It's where I hide if it's raining outside because it's free. :)  City view... just absolutely gorgeous.
author: Christina C.

description:
I hate museums solely because of that bearded guy who stands behind you and says things like, "His brushstrokes clearly express anger," or "The medium tells a story of ogres being chased by swans atop a cloud of castles." I like to stand and look at a painting that catches my eye, skim the four-sentence blurb next to it, then, if I'm still interested, maybe take a mental note to try to catalogue the name of the artist. This process takes about 15 seconds.

Even after living here for 5 years, my first visit was during the YSL exhibit. Was it worth the extra $10? Eh. I actually enjoyed the featured art in the main gallery downstairs more. I am the type of person who likes to make sure they do a thorough sweep for this type of thing, and the layout and design make it really easy. I must admit that the tribal/ethnic/indigenous collections didn't hold my attention for long, even though I usually like that stuff. Even still, I plan to go back to check out the Warhol exhibit.

The De Young's true gem is the Observation Tower...spectacular 360-degree views of the City from a unique perspective. Overall, I think the De Young is great for a sunny Sunday afternoon...afterwards, walk around the grounds and look for all of the classes (like swing dancing and tai chi) held in Golden Gate Park for some amazing people watching.
author: Sachi T.

description: Saw two awesome exhibits in this museum already: First, the "Tutankhamun and the Golden Age of Pharaohs" (2009), and the "Van Gogh, Gauguin, Cezanne and Beyond" (2010). I had a wonderful experience viewing these two exhibitions. The museum's own permanent exhibits are also interesting. One of the best spots within the museum building is the Tower Observatory, where you will have a breathtaking view of San Francisco. This museum is truly world-class.
author: Venice S.

description: Its alright but I really don't think its that great. I had not been here in years until recently for one of the nightlife events. The touring show was in transition and I had seen all the permanent collection before. There were tons of security guards. I recall one of them saying I could not chew gum in the main entry way where drinks were being served and a beach blanket babylon performer was singing. The performer was singing the same song for the second time that evening, once out of costume and the second time in costume. That was it. It was not a very good show. The $10 nightlife price seemed ok if you've never seen the permanent collection before. Otherwise regular pricing is considerably more. I was disappointed there was no main show featured at this time. The Georgia O'keefe show had just ended. My date and I went to the café during this visit as well. The food was overpriced and cafeteria style. It wasn't that good. The best thing about this museum in my opinion is the gift shop in the tower just because of the view and that is free.
author: L. A.

description: I want to give the museum 5 stars for the building design and every friday events, but they don't have a treasure master piece.  How can a fine art museum not to have Monet and Picasso?
author: Jacqueline X.

description: This is one of my favorite art museums. While it does not have a large number of famous names in its collection, the quality and variety keeps me coming back. After visiting several times I invested in a membership which has paid for itself. The special exhibits are always fascinating and the de Young does a wonderful job of selecting paint colors and arranging the set up to enhance the art.
author: Kari G.

description: I love the exterior more than the interior.  The interior I find a little confusing and have gotten lost many times.  They have a great exhibit going on which are pieces from the collection at the Musee D'Orsay....but can you say cramped (just like the Musee D'Orsay)?!?
author: Jay A.

description:
Warhol at Friday Nights at the de Young             5-8:45pm

WARHOL Live  (til May 17, 2009) 

WARHOL Live, was a delightful and entertaining scene. No host Bar is available, for cocktails. Cafe is also open late. I did have a light dinner snack. I had the Tomato Can soup..... Soo Warhol. Soo Yummy. nice creamy hot, served in a large bowl topped with fresh homemade croutons and a dollop of sour cream... and only $5 very DELI-SH!

Cost is $20 but got a $2 discount for showing my muni pass from Bart station, so paid $18 it was soo worth it. 
***(FREE for FAMSF members. 
Member pass starting at $80 tax deductible)

2 bands from Amoeba Music were in the lobby area playing Warhol inspired music and notes from Velvet Underground band. 

My roommate called it "Artsy Fartsy" but I loved being in SF and experiencing this exhibit. The exhibit is Awesome    

Major Warhol silkscreen paintings, album covers, illustrations, and photographs inspired by music and the performing arts, along with films and sound recordings, will provide a visual and aural score to Warhol's extraordinary work and life.

Love you Andy.
author: Lady O.

description:
The design of the new de Young has definitely grown on me (especially after going up into the tower to see the amazing view), but does anyone else totally miss the old brick building? My favorite collection here is the modern art.  They have one of my favorite Ed Ruscha paintings in the exhibit.  But all the tribal and early California art do not do much for me.  
I recently visited to see the YSL traveling exhibit and it was so beautiful.  He truly was a visionary and all of the clothes are so intricate and unique.  Plus there was the added bonus of the Warhol exhibit downstairs.  Him and I should totally be bffs cause my favorite thing in the world is Campbell's Soup too!  but it was really interesting to see other sides of him than his screen printing like his tv show, movies, and magazine.  
The de Young is no Met or Getty, but it is a beautiful space and worth a visit.
author: Caroline B.

description:
I love their selections of pieces and collections. They have a wide variety from different time periods of the past and present. 

I was fortunate to take a class at CSUEB from one of the curators of the museum as a art history minor. He required that we go to see the pieces discussed in the class and to write papers on it. The background info made a huge difference as nothing really is what it seems to be. 

Recent exhibits I've visited: 
- Maya Lin: "Systematic Landscapes:" I didn't go to see this exhibit. It just happened to be showing when I went. I wasn't too excited about it, but it was a nice sculpture (my boyfriend took a greater interest than I did). 

- Yves St. Laurent: I thought the idea of fashion in a museum was silly at first, but I was so impressed with how many pieces from history at the exhibit. This exhibit certainly changed my perception about fashion that it could be an art form. One of the pieces I remember was a tribute to Van Gogh. He beautifully translated Van Gogh's painting to a dress and something so wearable. I was amazed. Each piece was like a painting in itself. This exhibit was probably the most crowded in the whole museum.

- Asian/American/Modern Art: "Shifting Currents:" as an Asian American, I was pretty disappointment with this exhibit. I thought they missed the whole concept of being an Asian American or the process of discovering their identity. Most pieces were either very Asian or very American. Few represented the two concepts as one entity. Perhaps it is a new idea from this generation. I do appreciate the pieces from the Japanese internment camps as there are few photographs to capture their persecution. Their paintings reflected what happened externally in the camp as well as what the Japanese experienced internally. 

I am always delighted to go to MOMA. 
They also have an awesome gift shop that adds another hour to my visit. :)
author: Lori L.

description:
Architecturally, this is one of the best places in an otherwise design conservative San Francisco. 

Content-wise.....it's a little schizo. The collection at the De Young has to be one of the most random ever. There's your South American folk art, your Kiki Smith's, your American Colonial portraits. There's no focus here at all. I know it must be hard for the Director here to try to reign in such a large variety of pieces, but come on! 

I'd also love to see more exciting acquisitions here. Much of what is here is ho-hum.
author: Jackie I.

description:
:::: WARNING :::::
:::: WARNING :::::

IF YOU ARE AN "INTELLECTUALITO" AND A STUCK UP SNOB ABOUT ANYTHING, STOP READING AND MOVE ON TO THE NEXT REVIEW.
PLEASE, WE DO NOT WANT TO SPOIL THE EXPERIENCE

:::: WARNING :::::
:::: WARNING :::::

Ah, Chihuly...the great Chihuly! We saw his amazing glasswork back in the Botanical Gardens of St. Louis and stood there humbled by the incredible display of raw talent and a craft amazing beyond description. Until now...when we saw what will be described as "The Thunderdome".

After you walk through the Chihuly exhibit and carefully snake around the maze of bad looking, rude and pretentious people with their digi cams trying to 'capture the power' of the artwork you have to see the 'making-of' movie! Please do so. While you meander through, ducking down and getting dangerously close to asses you don't want to be near of, take a quick look for some good glass vases, some cheesy glasses that possibly came from the set of "Miami Vice" or "American Psycho" (Christian Bale went to the set director after the wrap: 'nah, don't want this...i'll be huge one day and need batman-coolness' and ended up in this exhibit), some nice glass forest, etc.

When you have finished catching glimpses from the back, visit the movie.

:::: WARNING :::::
INTELLECTUALITOS AND SNOBS, REALLY MOVE ON NOW
:::: WARNING :::::

Welcome to Thunderdome, but 'uncool' {no Mad Max, no glorious Tina Turner with telephone chord ear wear :( }. The little theatre by the museum shop was showing a 'making-of' movie showing the amazing creation of Chihuly artwork. It was hard to find a seat and space, more so after the "look at me, how pedantic I am in my Segway" lady went in. Standing by the door, we see this video with a lot of people cheering in an industrial dome backed by the horrible music of something similar to "My Life with the Thrill Kill Kult". In a very tactful way (for the kids, I'm sure), the close-captioning was turned on displaying the lyrics of a highly sexual song. Kids, now you can go back to your 1st grade class and tell the teacher what a 'sexy kisser' you are!

In the video, we see this muscled up, dark, long white hair, 80s Meatloaf video-style man (call him "Glass God") working the glass. Sweaty and working hard in front of a furnace, it will make women and men swoon alike and break all boundaries of straightness. This man enlists the help of other dudes to carefully mold the glass, move it around and make it a "WOW, THAT'S DAMN GOOD TALENT" piece. One problem...NONE OF THESE GUYS ARE CHIHULY!!!!!!

While all this hot action is going on and the Kill Kult clones' bass is throbbing, Captain Lou Albano is sitting on a desk AWAY from the furnace. That's Chihuly! He doesn't do anything! He sits there in a Tony Bahama (or imitation) hideous shirt and scribbles on a pad with pencils held together by a rubberband. Wow, what a gimmick, I need one like that. At the same time Chihuly is doodling with the skill of a 3 year old on an Etch-a-Sketch and possibly stuffing his face with Twinkies from one of his 'signature' bowls, his interns (i suspect) and what we call "Glass God" are really busting their asses and then showing him the finished work. 

It is to note at this moment, that Chihuly wears an eye patch. However, this is not because a piece of glass flew through it or was anything related to his art. Supposedly, this accident messed up his depth perception. I must wonder if he then really knows how the bowls look like...hmmm..

After "Glass God", a.k.a "The Real Talent Here", is done and shows the piece, Capt. Lou Chihuly gives a thumbs up and people in the Thunderdome cheer! I mean, they go all out like they saw Gene Simmons spit fire during "God of Thunder". This is pompous and ridiculous.


Oh, what have you, my kitten just did a chaotic piece of art in the floor:
"Untitled Friskies 1: My Volatile Existence"
Let me call DeYoung, someone has to see this!

2 Stars because overall I like the DeYoung museum and some of their collection (in a vacuum, away from the rude visitors) and is one of the cleanest places in the city.

:::: END OF WARNING :::::
INTELLECTUALITOS AND SNOBS, YOU WERE WARNED
:::: END OF WARNING :::::
author: Jesus G.

description:
I'm fan enough to opt into 'student' membership. Great location near the entrance to GG Park, the Academy, the amphitheatre and the tea garden. Love the art shows outside when the weather permits.

The Dale Chihuly art glass exhibit was the highlight of my fall 2008, while the YSL tribute my Winter 2009... but I've been a fan since the museum reopened. Lately, the museum has been pulling in HIGH PROFILE exhibitions like YSL and Warhol that 'justify' a $10 premium over the usual admission. 

Whatever, I have enjoyed headliners like the Quilts of Gees Bend as well as the 'supporting bands / opening acts' like the Michael Arcega wooden clubs and Timothy Horn's chandeliers made from sugar. Those were better than Nan's closet. 

Anyway the temporary exhibits are great...as is the rest of the museum. Extensive, amusing (at times), thought-provoking. Take in all of the building -- including the outside. I got goosebumps when I heard the copper mesh would oxidize and become a beautiful patina. Not to mention the (free) observation tower that makes one feel like 'king of the world'... or at least, one the world's more amazing cities.

I especially love how family friendly this museum is. Start the art appreciation lessons early... BTW your admission gets you into the Legion for free, if you go the same day!
author: Sunny T.

description:
The de Young Museum in its new incarnation is fascinating. I am pleased to see so many people enjoying this newly fashioned treasure. My only reservation is that some times the programs and attitude can seem a little bit too up-scale, often giving an impression of aloofness. 

I hope the de Young will continue to reach out to the people and that it will be a place where everyone feels welcome and enriched by visiting there. 

See the article I wrote about the de Young when it first opened. 

http://www.sfrichmondreview.com/archives/richmondreview/2005editions/Oct05/deYoung.html
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Right across from another nice museum, the De Young museum is set in the wonderful Golden Gate Park.  The permanent displays are o.k. but I am not about to shell out the $ required for the special exhibits.  Going up in the tower is cool and the cafe and garden is quite nice.  
Overall it is a pleasant experience, especially when you go on first Tuesday of the month because it is FREE.

For more information about FREE museums, visit this link:
http://www.examiner.com/x-20478-Oakland-Museum-Examiner~y2009m8d20-Top-5-Bay-Area-museums-with-free-days
author: Tim D.

description:
Last Sunday I gingerly stepped into the De Young Museum as I have been know to break a few windows and lamps in my time.

While I was waiting to get in they were checking people's bags.  When it was my turned I was pleasantly surprised they were allowing people to come in with cameras, but not my bucket of rocks.

It was free to enter that day (happens consistently) and the Chihuly exhibit was free, but tickets were limited.  What a great way to encourage people to come to the museum.  The exhibit was so great that I spent a whole 3.5 hours there pissing off the guards.  I haven't been yelled at this much since elementary school.

"Sir! Sir! Please stand behind the line."
"Please do not lean over the line."
"Please do not point at the exhibit"

I really wasn't that close or was I?  Good thing I didn't bring the bucket of rocks.
author: Po L.

description:
What's one of the best ways to spend a rainy weekday afternoon? The De Young of course. I'll admit, the layout was kind of confusing (even with a map) but the effort is worth it. 

The collection of marble spread through the museum was really cool, and they have one of the best collections of American art on the west coast. Pretty awesome. Don't forget to check out the amazing 360° views from the observation tower. You'll spend a serious amount of time trying to find your apartment, your work, the place you ate yesterday... Super addictive.
author: Thomas S.

description:
We have a membership to a bunch of the SF museums, and the DeYoung is probably the most worthwhile. There are tons of different exhibits. I've gone in on multiple days and wandered around until I couldn't take in any more visual information, and I think I've finally reached the point of having seen it all - after a year. ...I could be wrong about that.

I'm definitely renewing before the Tut exhibit gets here!

The observation tower is fun, and kid-friendly. I love the early American art section, and the native exhibits are also awe-inspiring. 

The Andy Warhol exhibit was irritating and crowded, filled with blaring music and horrible "art" pieces that were basically repetitive simple objects with no feeling or meaning to them at all. Warhol would have loved it! (I didn't)

Negatives?
They charge WAY too much for some exhibits, even to people who have already paid A LOT for memberships. (I'm speaking here mostly of the upcoming Tut show)

Not a lot of activities or interactive art. Even the sculpture garden is filled with art you're not supposed to touch. It's an eyes-only art museum, which is always a little disappointing.
author: Owen L.

description:
Andy Warhol Exhibit - I think the Andy Warhol show is great. I really liked how it was setup with the different rooms and all the music they were playing. We went on one of the docent tours and it is really the way to go. They are at 10:00 and 1:30. The docent was so knowledgeable and the little insights you get are priceless. Then go through again and take your time reading and looking at his works. This show really makes me want to go to Pittsburgh, just to see the Warhol museum there. What an interesting time he had in New York. Also a lot of sadness with Edie Sedgwick and how Andy Warhol's life ends. Do not miss this show. 
I would reccommend the Museum Membership so you can go to these special exhibits both at the De Young and the Legion of Honour. 
And go up the elevator and look at the Academy of Science building and panoramic view.
author: Mark S.

description:
I'm Chinese which explains why the only museum membership I own is for the Fine Arts Museums.  It is like getting two memberships for the price of one (the Legion is included).  

I was working at the Board of Supervisors when the controversy over Herzog and deMueron's avant garde design was being waged.  I didn't love the architecture at first but it has since grown on me; what do I know, it is not like I've won a Pritzker or anything.  I believe that as the years pass and the copper exoskeleton will oxidize into a lovely patina that will become more beautiful with every passing year.  

I went to Chihuly earlier this year and it was like oompa loompa land.  The colors were gorgeous but I felt like I needed to be lit to fully appreciate it. 

There are no need for psychotropics to enjoy the YSL exhibit.  C'est Magnifique!    I would have loved to walk away with the Bell de Jour dresses designed for Mme. Deneuve.  Seeing the orignal Le smokings you understand why he was such a genius.  Most of the designs (with the exception of the floral arrangement wedding gown) can be worn for any occassion at any age.  He was the first to invite ethnic dressing into the world of fashion.  Who else could make a mien-nap (silk quilted house coat) chic?  

To paraphrase the master, "This exhibit is fleeting, but style is forever."
author: Monica L.

description:
After attending the concierge reception at the California Academy of Sciences, Raechelle and I decided to walk across the street to the De Young Museum. Surprisingly, the museum was quite busy on a Wednesday morning. We followed the crowd in line to purchase tickets. The not-so-friendly cashier mistakenly charged us for two tickets to the Chihuly exhibit. We had only planned to check out the museum itself. But since she had already rung us up, we decided not to argue and just go. After all, Dale Chihuly is the world-renowned artist that did the famous glass flowers in the Bellagio Hotel's lobby in Las Vegas. So why not? 

As soon as we walked in, we were astounded by the bright bold colors he used in his collection. It was crowded but everyone seemed to be in the same state of curiosity and amazement as we wandered from room to room. If you haven't seen his artwork yet, please do. It's definitely a sight for sore eyes! 
 
P.S. The Chihuly exhibit is in it's final week now. So if you plan on visiting, you must buy your tickets in advance at www.museumtix.com. 
Last exhibit day is Sunday, September 28th.
author: Anne E.

description:
One point for cool architecture. 
One point for the awesome view from the Tower. (Please can we have a Yelp Happy Hour there!)
One point for the rockin cafe.
And one point for stocking huge amounts of my friend Shayla Su's art:  http://www.shaylasu.com/attable.html  (which you can buy direct from her web site, but deYoung still gets the point).

That's it. Four stars.
author: Jess S.

description:
Love it, I take my kids here at least 3 times a year, they never get bored.
World Class Architecture and beautiful grounds. The cafe is delisiouso!
author: ron j.

description: On behalf of us who have decided to breed, thank you De Young for providing us poor, beleaguered people with somewhere to go on a Friday night where we can feel good about exposing our children to culture while slamming back a couple of tasty pomegranate martini's!
author: Drea L.

description: The de Young Museum tower is great. You can use the members entrance, you don't need to pay for admission to the museum and you can see a long way from the top of the tower.
author: Edward B.

description:
*blink blink* 
*blink*
*blink blink*

if you've been to the DeYoung, you'll know exactly what i'm talking about. that maybe-3D-maybe-not-3D black and white circle wall mural that just envelopes the entire center atrium. you can't take a picture of it because it'll come out blurry, yet the longer you stare at it, the more you can't take your eyes off of it.

that pretty much sums up my experiences at the DeYoung. we went on the weekend of Vivienne Westwood (viva la fashionista!) and a feature of children's art from san francisco schools (super super cute). the mix of eras featured in VW's show was great, though i wish they would have spent more time on each. i really like the mix of media they had on display (video, enclosed outfits, displayed outfits), but all the gorgeous outfits kept making me want to touch fabric! i'm a girl! i need to touch clothes!! haha! the childrens's art in the mural room was soooo adorable - ranging from 12th grader art to kindergarten creativity. it totally made me wish i was 2nd grader again taking that pottery class.

we ended our time there with a visit to the tower. the last time we went, the tower wasn't open yet, so me was super excited :) and oh my, it was NOT what i expected - the tower opens up city-wide full circle views! not wanting to leave, i circled multiple times and tried to absorb the landscape.

after re-staring at the maybe-3D-maybe-not-3D black and white circle wall mural a last time, we left another fulfilling visit to the DeYoung! it has a range of medias for anyone and everyone to appreciate, which is perfect for a novice art appreciator like myself :) be it city views or "my great grandma in vietnam", or traditional american art, this museum just exudes creativity from every angle.

*clap clap*
*clap*
*clap clap*
author: Diana L.

description:
Do Young's strength is that it gives you a little bit of everything - a little American art, a little folk art (colonial chairs), a small photography gallery, you get the idea. This is not a museum where you'll need to spend the entire day. 

I love all the little nooks and crannies - each window gives you a completely different and beautiful perspective on the park.  Yeah, the building resembles the death star, but once you're inside you can enjoy the beauty within, without thinking too much about what the building looks like.
author: Alyssa S.

description:
I enjoyed my afternoon at the de Young and really loved some of the peices.  I don't understand the boxy, angular structure of the building inside, though; I think it takes away from the true experience of the art itself when you don't have enough space to look at things or are distracted by the building around you.  I also felt that previous reviewers were accurate in saying that the Oceanic and African exhibits were stereotypically and ethnocentrically laid out - why are all of the western collections so bright and airy, while the ancient headmasks and New Guinean statues masked in near-darkness?  This may not have been intentional, but it seems a little ignorant to maintain that "primitive culture" image.  

Despite that, I loved walking through the textiles section, the modern art areas on the main floor, and the oudoor sculpture garden (Pellegrino in-hand).  It was a nice surprise to find the blue/black monolith, previously indoors at the Palace of the Legion of Honor, outside in the sunshine...a neat place for anyone, even little kids (who were going crazy for those big apples on the grass).
author: Catherine F.

description:
Amazing space!  I love the tower overlooking everything.  The exhibits were all great but I really loved the sculpture garden.  The apples especially were fun.
I will be interesting to see the patina on the walls changing with the years.
And I LOVE the underground parking!
author: Holly L.

description: This building is absolutely gorgeous and a credit to San Francisco. Long live Dede Wilsey, can we all now forgive her for the whole Pat Montadon thing? This woman single-handedly got this museum built after all the cheapskate voters sounded like Amy Winehouse, saying "no, no, no." It will be especially spectacular when the place across the way is finished. I can hardly wait to see the building age and have the copper develop a green patina. A wonderful addition to San Francisco scene. Cafe is not half-bad either.
author: Robert M.

description:
We went on Sat. 6/28/08 to see the Chihuly Exhibit, but i definitely enjoyed the entire museum.  

We were there for about 2.5 hours which included a coffee break at the musuem cafe. 

I love GG park and all the different museums and places to go....  *sniff*  i'll miss the city...
author: Ella B.

description:
We came here for the first day of Andy Warhol and the lines were looong. We decided to get a membership, which is also valid for the Legion of honor and if you go a couple times a year, it's already paid for. Plus no more lines.
