The Warhol exhibition was very comprehensive and interesting, the audio tour was not worth the money. It did not tell me anything that I could not read on the walls too.
Very nice museum and the shops are inspiring.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
The de Young gets some wonderful 'blockbuster' exhibitions, but after visiting 3 times in the past 12 months (most recently for the Olmec show), we've noticed that the didactics - i.e. the explanatory panels that should provide a coherent background and lead you through the objects of the exhibition - are really letting the exhibitions down. The texts are often confused and fail to provide fundamental information at the beginning, leaving the visitor to muddle together what they can from room to room. In the case of the post impression exhibition, the organisation of the artworks had no clear, logical structure, and sometimes seemed completely arbitrary. 
It's wonderful that the museum has the vision to undertake challenging exhibitions, giving the public has access to important works of art and cultural objects, but to do justice to these objects, the museum would do well to invest a little more of their budget to ensuring that the exhibits are presented as best they can be.
author: RP P.

description:
Our family finally made it to the De Young this weekend. 

We liked:
  - The new building
  - The view from the tower
  - The sculpture garden and the new grounds
  - The cafe
  - The ease of access
  - The museum is child/stroller friendly. 

The collection is not on the same level as what you find in New York or Chicago, but it is still interesting and worth the visit. I also agree with the previous post about the display of the Oceanic works.

Overall, the De Young was what we were looking for. A brief 3 hour outing and a place to expose our young children to works of art, architecture, and sculpture.

My favorite work is by Andy Goldsworthy. When you arrive, be sure to go in through the main entrance off of Tea Garden Drive. Look down at your feet and you'll notice that the stone pavers are already cracked. Or are they...?

We had some extra time so we strolled over to the Japanese Tea Garden which was also nice.
author: Steve S.

description: definitely a bucket list must-see of van gough's starry night...finally :)
author: Charmian D.

description: The Observation Tower is a must-see for visitors. It provides a fabulous view of the City. We were at the De Young for the Birth of Impressionism Exhibition which was a bit crowded but the audio tour was well worth it.
author: P S.

description:
Currently (updated 03/11/07): I'm not terribly fashion forward so the Vivienne Westwood exhibit bored me. The exhibit itself was impressive, great lighting and good layout and lots and lots of objects -- good narrative too. I just wasn't inspired by it, I suppose.

That said, I finally saw Cornelia Parker's "Anti Mass" (2005), part of the deYoung's permanent collection. Make a point to see it when you visit.

* * * * * * * *

On the whole: My mom and I cheat (shh) and get a family membership to the Fine Arts Museums of SF, which means we can take guests with us into the de Young and the Legion of Honor. It's a great deal.

I find something new to love about the de Young every time I visit. My memories of the old de Young are pretty fuzzy - just a big ivory building with an Asian art wing. When I first came on member preview weekend last October to the new de Young, I felt pretty ambiguous about it. The non-contiguous galleries weren't easy to navigate, the Oceanic/African art was unsettlingly displayed, and the site-specific installations that I'd gotten so excited about (Andy Goldsworthy, wow!) were just okay. Now that I've been back several times, I appreciate the small galleries. I can come to see a blockbuster exhibit and pair it with one of the permanent galleries, or just come by to see the textiles and furniture and call it a day, guilt-free.

The collections here are sort of schizo (erm, eclectic?) But that's all well and fine with me, because it means I get a little of everything. Of particular note is the photography gallery.

As for the African/Oceanic collections... this is tough. A museum that's as old as the de Young, that dates back to when it was a-okay to drop into another country and buy up antiquities to put behind glass - how do you deal with a legacy like that? I don't agree with the way that the de Young has chosen to display these works, backlighting and dimlighting them (though this may be for conservation purposes, I don't know) and giving them this haunting, primitive quality. But on the other hand, what solutions are there, really? Dioramas and such "living history" displays can be equally demeaning. I only hope that the curators at the de Young will continue to think about how this work is shown.

That said, two things that are unquestionably cool at the de Young -- the Bouquets to Art event every March, when local florists & ichibana artists create works inspired by the art, and the Connections Gallery, where contemporary artists respond to art in the permanent collections or the rotating shows.
author: Marisa L.

description:
It was ok. I think the area is a bit large compared to the number of items they display, so it gets tiring. The most exciting parts to me were contemprary American art and the newly acquired pieces, which really conveyed their special meanings somehow much better than expected from modern art pieces. 

I give 3 stars because I think MOMA SF is much better than here. I am not sure about the architecture meaning of the building but it looked like a rusty piece of wrecked ship to me...

Overall, it was a fine day trip and the surrounding area definitely deserves some exploring. Parking is pretty easy on Fulton street.
author: Burcin T.

description:
Parking is HELL. I ended up parking in a residential area about a block away from GG Park.

I went in on a Friday for the YSL and Warhol exhibition. I definitely spent more time for Warhol than I did with YSL. 

The Warhol exhibition was more "chill," which I guess is one way to put it. & YSL was just... oh dear. Crowded as hell and loud [thanks to the little teeny boopers]! A good amount of women [yep, it was a fucking sea of estrogen] spent about 5 minutes looking at one dress. Seriously? 

If I had more patience, I would have spent more time in there.

I can't wait for the next exhibition though!
author: Stacey T.

description:
Since we recently purchased an annual pass to the Legion of Honor, we were able to go to the De Young Museum for free. It is very similar to the Legion of Honor in that it has a lot of paintings, sculptures and amazing furniture craftsmanship. 

It also has a very neat tall tower that you can take an elevator in and see a 360 degree view of San Francisco. I went recently to see the King Tut exhibit, but didn't realize you needed to buy your tickets in advance. I arrived around noon and tickets were available to see the 5 pm show, but we could not wait that long.

It was a lot of walking and again, I was glad I brought my stroller for my 3 year old. I really liked some of the contemporary exhibits of bright colored glass. They also had a very neat miniature gothic-type home made of bullets and guns.

The cafe had a delicious soup of the day "dungeness crab bisque". It was ok, but wasn't very creamy for a bisque. I saw parents who sat in the cafe area and had brought there own lunch instead of buying it there. Very smart, because the cafe is kinda expensive.

On the outside of the cafe is a neat photo opp area for kids. There are several large apple sculptures that little kids can sit on and being photographed with. There is also the largest blue safety pin that you will probably ever see in your lifetime as well out there.
author: Francine S.

description:
I have a membership, a huge fan!  I love everything about this museum, it truly is world class!

The architecture is amazing, it looks like a spaceship from Aliens. :)  Their Oceania private collection is the largest of its kind in the world.  Plus all the visiting exhibits are phenomenal: Vivienne Westwood collection as well as most recent YSL were the only showings in the States, and King Tuts's Tomb in the Summer of 2009 is going to be out of this world!

Friday nights at the museum are fun, very stylish crowd attends.  Its even more fun when you are a member, full bar is free!

I am an eternal fan!
author: Anya T.

description:
great building, great space.
Came (finally!) after talking about it for years.
Reminded me of home, and the Walker in design, but nothing else.
The YSL exhibit was a bit of a cluster fuck with all people going every which way, sudden dead ends (by the spectacular knit wedding dress that bjork would wear).
rather painful layout.
oh well, great museum anyway.
the al farrow pieces blew me away, and I was surprised by the strength of maya lin...photo's don't do her justice.
author: Zachary S.

description:
Really incredible fine arts museum.  We just went to an exhibit there that involved elaborate floral arrangements done as interpretations of the permanent art.  So if you were looking at a painting of a woman in a dress, right next to that would be a floral representation of the same piece of art.  My mediocre description isn't doing it justice, but lemme tell ya, it's awesome.  

Really awesome.

The Warhol exhibit is worth the $20, and I'm not even a fan of Warhol.
author: Jessica H.

description:
We're members of the Fine Arts Museums of SF so we get admission to the DeYoung and a few other SF museums.  This one is always fun with kids since it is right in the middle of Golden Gate Park, is a great, sprawling space for them to explore, and they always like to go up in the tower.  The cool, metallic exterior is fun for them to look at and bang on too.  

There is a wide variety of exhibits from African and Oceanic art to colonial furniture to pop art and multimedia sculptures.  We all really like it.  The grounds are lovely too.  The cafe is pricey but the food is quite good and you can sit in the well-lit cafe or outside.  

The DeYoung sometimes has very cool exhibits like Dale Chihuly, which the kids absolutely adored.  We are looking forward to the upcoming King Tut exhibit.

We often pair this trip with a visit to the adjacent Japanese Tea Garden or the Arboretum.
author: Merry P.

description: The de Young Museum is a great place,especially with its various exhibits from countries all over the world.
author: Leo T.

description:
I freeking adore this museum.   from the rusting exterior, the twisted tower, the crack up the entry, all of the arcitecture!  love love.  the collections...omg.  the meso-american stuff has a few really special pieces that make me go to pieces every time I see them.  the modern stuff striking and again, certain pieces just slay me every time.  plus lots of changing lithos and printwork.  love it!  then upstairs, love the big bench overlooking the backyard.  so many interesting areas to peek around.  love that!  then I could go on and on about the lower level traveling shows...also great regardless of snobby critics.  and then there's the top of the tower.  for sho the coolest spot west of twin peaks.

let me summarize by saying I love love love this place.

oh yeah, forgot to say I wish they had a whole wing for their photography collection.  the small area they do have is ever-changing and very interesting!
author: Celia S.

description:
Made a visit this past weekend to check out the Warhol & YSL exhibit. We paid $16/student (make sure to bring your college id for the discount) which covered the "special" exhibits plus the general entrance. Though it seems a bit pricey, you can use your ticket for same-day entrance for the Legion of Honor. Definitely a huge plus! 

I don't recommend going during a long weekend because it gets REALLY crowded. Over the weekend, it was so crowded I couldn't even get myself to walk through the entire YSL exhibit. Also, it was raining cats and dogs out and they made us line up outside of the museum for security check. Did I mention it was raining cats and dogs? Then, once we got inside the museum we had to wait in yet another long line to pay for admission. Oh and I forgot to mention that after waited in line for admission, they directed us to coat check to wait in a 3rd line because we weren't allowed to walk around with an umbrella in tow. 

I felt like I spent half the time WAITING... If you can, go on a weekday and you'll enjoy it so much more. Either that, or don't go on a long weekend.

On a different note, if you want to see Warhol it just started on 2/14 and should be available for the next month or two.
author: Melissa P.

description: Always some fun exhibits and the permanent collection is nice every once in a while with a friend who's never been. The Van Gogh, Gauguin, and Cezanne exhibit was quite interesting. I definitely suggest the audio tour if you know nothing about them (like me!).
author: Timothy L.

description: The extended hours on Fridays rock. I was actually very impressed with the specimens they have on display. I got lost in there (in the art).
author: Mario C.

description:
I visit one of the museums in the Bay Area once a month, on average.  I was really excited to see the "Birth of Impressionism" exhibit yesterday as one of the highlights of my summer stay-cation. 

First of all, I called to find out the cost of tickets the night before.  I was told that it was "free", as part of the first Tuesday of the month is free day - great, I hadn't purposely planned to take advantage of their free day, but free is better than $25 / person.  

Yesterday: after driving around in the parking lot for 15 minutes - apparently everyone else must have had the same idea - we arrived in the very loud and crowded lobby of the museum.  We bought tickets (discounted to $15 / person, as part of the free day benefits, I guess) for the next available time, which was an hour away.  Then, we saw the line ups.  It looked like about an hour in the first line, which was in the main lobby.  This brought you downstairs to the second line up, which I would guess took another 45 minutes to get into the actual exhibit.  We decided we did not want to spend the majority of our time in the city, in a noisy line up.  On trying to return our tickets, we were told they were nonrefundable.  Luckily, we caught a couple just about to buy tickets for the next available time (almost 2 hours away), and they were happy to buy our tickets for the earlier time we had purchased.  

All in all, I have enjoyed visiting the De Young Museum in the past - it is an impressive building in a beautiful location.  The collections are well worth taking the time to explore.  

NEVER GO ON FREE DAY, unless you love a noisy, large crowd.  The staff all seem grumpy, and not happy to offer any kind of assistance - I experienced this both on the phone and in person.  

I really want to see this exhibit, but not sure if it is worth another attempt.  Does anyone know when the least busy time to visit this museum is?
author: C M.

description:
I just became a member today, so I could see the YSL exhibit. For $95 my boyfriend and I got a dual membership, which lets us both bring a guest for free each time we go for a year. You can't beat that deal!

The YSL collection truly blew me away. I knew it was a large showing, but I had no idea how many pieces they had...and the information was compelling (complete with pictures, videos, a written 20-question survey from the 80's, quotes, etc.). 

I spent 2 hours on that exhibit, so I didn't see any more of the museum on that trip. I can say that the entire museum and outer gardens are immaculate. The view from outside, with the gardens and Sciences museum across the way, is stunning!
author: Anne A.

description: I liked this museum almost more than SFMOMA. This museums architecure is stunning as well.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Favorite part of the whole place is the tower, reminds of the space needle in seattle from inside. They really have so much to see in here, it literally could take some people the whole day to get through the place. Great art, though. I especially liked the room with the glass sculpture, and the room with all the colonial paintings. When you look at the colonial paintings, look at the eyes, it's like their looking right back at you. No joke. I literally was staring at a few of them for several minutes wondering how the heck did they get it to look so real?
author: Linda H.

description: Nice assortment of stuff, great building and the tower view is amazing even for long time SF residents.  I like all the views you get looking outside at the nicely decorated grounds, especially today when it was pouring rain.  Tough to give 5 stars when you compare to The Met or Smithsonian museums, but this one is definately got some great thing to enjoy.  Their collection of landscape painting were a favorite of mine.  Oh, and the cafe is bad news.  I had a $10 pre-made "fancy" roast beef sandwich because I was starving and it just wasn't good, but I'll review that in another seperate spot since they shouldn't take away from the main purpose of the visit.
author: Marc S.

description: Okay there's plenty to rave about the De Young, so I'll try to just give you my favorite parts.  If you have visitors in town the tower is a great place to take them so that you can show them a bit of the west side of SF (golden gate, entry to the bay, UCSF, USF, a general understanding of the layout of the west side).  It's handy as a bathroom pit stop and a relaxing walking area in the gardens area right outside the museum entrance.  This you all get for free.  Of course if you head in you'll find at least one exhibit that you like and on Fridays the events that I'm sure someone else has already yelped about.  It's a cool spot I'd recommend every SFer to get to know.  Also the $10 fee will give you entrance to the Legion of Honor exhibits too on the same day.
author: Aaron W.

description: I love love love this museum! It is in picturesque Golden Gate Park and houses an incredible collection of permanent pieces that leave one drooling. There is an interesting combination of various forms of art to enjoy and I just think the special exhibits are always fascinating. It is a wonderful place and if you go on a Friday night you get a bar and dj's!
author: Mandy L.

description: My friends and I went here Friday night and it was awesome!! My first museum experience couldn't have been better. Well ,it could have been better, had there been naked women..... Super cool vibe, live music, drinks and very interesting art.  Our friend Aira (thank you sista) has been working very VERY hard to introduce us to new environments, rather than the same old same old, and this was one hell of an experience. I didn't think I would like it, but I loved it!! Not to parents, get a sitter and leave the kids home, for once, please!!!!!
author: Hector G.

description: At times, beautiful and breathtaking. As others have mentioned, you don't even need to pay for admission to view many of the displays, unless you are particular about an exhibit. The viewing platform is also free. Make sure to bring your own food and drinks because a basic 7-11 sandwich is $9 here...and a bag of chips $1.75.
author: Jan P.

description:
I went to the De Young on a Free Tuesday and was pleasantly surprised that it wasn't ridiculously crowded. I had a nice time walking through the well laid out exhibits. I appreciated the sense of humor that the curators have in placing some really different kinds of art next to each other because they have a similar theme. The view from the tower is nice enough, but certainly not mind-blowing. The exhibit with blown glass was really beautiful. There was one room with a strange, totally abstract installation that I didn't like because it felt like the artist was trying too hard. 

Later, I returned to the De Young with a member who got me into the Balenciaga exhibit as a guest for free. This exhibit was super cool! Great music and other pieces of art that provided inspiration as well as thorough explanations of what things to look for. We didn't pay extra for the head set and still felt like we got a lot out of it. Note: if you go on a Free Tuesday, you'll have to pay $15 extra to see this exhibit.
author: Amy L.

description: The museum building is gorgeous but the exhibits & collections suck.  It's almost impossible to park a car on weekends and your bike may be stolen while locked outside the museum. At least one bike per day is stolen on sunny weekends. The cameras do not deter the thieves. Security does not watch your bike. It's a place where cyclists are regularly separated from their bikes. Skip this place if you don't bring your own bike security guard.
author: Jefferson P.

description:
This place is pretty damn hot.  Went for the Chihuly exhibit (which in itself is the most erotic thing I have seen since....)  Went inside and chilled at the host bar listening to Salsa music- danced with a couple of unknowns to me...just because. Got completely filled with culture and art and all that good shiznet.

Great time, great atmosphere...all around great stuff...thanks to my date for the night....good all around kudos :)
author: Stacy L.

description: Love this museum, and the view from the top on a clear day. I always bring guests from out of town into the city to show off the park and the de young. So lucky to live near The City with places like the de young close at hand. On a personal note, I love the glass dress!
author: Anne H.

description:
I met a very good friend here for lunch. I ordered the cauliflower risotto, she ordered a BLT.  Both were really good, and we sat in outside in the sculpture garden. Then after the yummy lunch we headed to the YSL exhibit. The clothes were impeccable and inspiring. 

After YSL we wandered around he permanent exhibits including the African hall.  All I know is someone really needs to whittle or weave a bra for the African ladies.  They have some serious knee knockers.   It just looked so painful, even if it was being depicted in a woodcarving. 

I will definitely be back to explore the rest of this museum and attend more exhibits.  I've also been informed that the museum hosts happy hours from time-to-time on Friday.  Yay for happy hour!
author: Kim S.

description: go to the observation tower--it's FREE and gives an amazing view of the San Fran skyline. i didn't have a chance to go in the museum the last time i was there, but they have a lot of interesting exhibits that i would love to check out.
author: Betty W.

description: Even though the outside of this place looks more like a sewage plant than a museum it still has a nice collection of artwork inside. The observation tower is also a must see.
author: Joshua L.

description:
CJ wrote exactly what I thought about the de Young. The architecture was fantastic. I also thought the traveling exhibits were fantastic. The permanent collections left something to be desired, sadly.

I had seen Georgia O'Keefe advertised in their brochures. They had one small O'Keefe painting. They had one small Hopper painting. They had one of just about anyone, but no real collection.
author: Heather H.

description: I like the De Young Museum. We have membership (really because we wanted to see the Bouquets to Art show they had and felt it was more worthwhile to buy a family membership) so we frequent this museum a lot.  My favorite place to go is the tower (which is free, by the way) to look at the 360 degree view of the city.  The exhibits change so I make it a point to go often to check out the new stuff.  Sometimes we go eat at the cafe and just people watch.  The sculpture garden outside the cafe is really neat too.  The nephew loves the apple sculptures (look, but don't touch!), but I'm more partial to the giant safety pin.
author: Kris L.

description:
The De Young is truly an amazing addition to Golden Gate Park and San Francisco in general.  Certainly one of my favorite pieces of architecture in San Francisco.  Since the De Young opened I began walking from my home in the Inner Sunset to the Inner Richmond every Sunday, in large part because the walk past the De Young is beautiful.  

Spend a few hours here when you get a chance.  The observation tower offers stunning views of the entire city (and it is free).  The galleries offer unique paintings and photography exhibits that are reguarly updated.
author: Matthew H.

description:
This was my first time at the De Young and I showed up a bit early to check out the exhibits on the second floor before the music and events began.  I appreciated the bar serving drinks (yes they were pricey, but hey its SF) and the live music.  This last week it was Native American tribal songs and the performers were amazing.  I forgot how physically moving it is to listen to the chanting and drumbeats, which I never get at any of the other music concerts I go to.  
I also had the opportunity to go on a tour of the Native Arts gallery on the first floor with a guide, which made the experience so much more enjoyable.  What a great collection of Mayan Art!  
This is a great way to start off a Friday night and with Outer Sunset so close by you can't go wrong!
P.S. I noticed the snooty folks, but just ignored them...I am good at rolling my eyes right back!
author: Sheila Y.

description:
I want to make love to the art and the docents turn me on.  Is that sick?  No because for any art lover, the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco are just fun places to get lost and immerse yourself in the beauty of someone's creation.  

Chicago may have the architecture and the Art Institute -- both insanely awesome and New York may be where all the great legends reside and the creative spark may be visibly apparent but there is something wonderful about the De Young and how close it is to the Academy of Sciences.  Gosh, I could live in these places and never tire of all the wonderful things to see and just how much inspiration one could gain from all the stimuli!

If you're a member, it's even better.  No waiting!  Just flash your card and you're in.  You don't have to pay for the special exhibits and you snag a discount at the shop.  In addition to those perks, you can bring a guest!!  The exhibits are always exciting (i.e., Louise Nevelson, Dale Chihuly, Maya Lin, etc.).  The design is considered sustainable, which may not appeal to some people but I do like it a lot more than the SF Moma.  In any case, visiting the De Young is a must!  Be prepared to show your bag and for a long line about an hour after opening!  Otherwise, De Young is a great experience for natives, out of town visitors, art lovers -- everyone!  Just go!
author: Dorothy S.

description: Reviewing the King Tut exhibit. I was disappointed with the lack of artifacts....they excavated 500/600 (can't remember) and the exhibit showed about 50!...many of them not even from the King Tut excavation. What was crazy  it that they didn't allow me to wear my 16 month old son in a backpack carrier or use a stroller!  That was insane since there were plenty of kids crying as a result (they were uncomfortable, their feet hurt, they were tired/wanted to sleep in a stroller, etc.) I would understand if there were a possibility of strollers being in the way, but frankly everything was in about an inch of glass elevated 4 feet off the floor! Eek, won't be going there with a child again!
author: jamie j.

description:
I like:

The copper skin, that it has so many different patterns on it that you can spend a while just walking around the exterior just looking at how they blend together.
The modernism of it, simply because San Francisco does not have many buildings that do modernism well.  This is because our planning commission is obsessed with preservation and some bad choices in terms of architects.
The layout.  Ok, I only merely like the layout.  It doesn't do anything amazing, but it doesn't get in the way of enjoying the exhibits.

I don't like:

The Tower.  I want to like it.  Really I do.  I like looking at it from afar, but when I'm actually in it the copper skin overhangs RIGHT INTO MY SIGHTLINE.  Why?  They designed it for people who are less than 6'3" to look out onto the city.  I am well above this height, so I've got to bend down the entire time.  So disappointing.
author: Beau G.

description:
The new De Young is great. The best stuff they have there is the collection of New Guinea and Oceania arts. The most uninteresting collection is the 20th Century American Art. zzzzz...zzzz...zzz.

Their cafe is excellent too. If I still lived up there in the Sunset, I'd come here for lunch on the weekends.
author: Scott M.

description:
4 stars for the De Young.  Dale Chiluly exhibit completes the 5th star but it is worth 5 stars itself.

Sweetie and I went yesterday. He said he agreed to go just to please me but  we both really enjoyed it.  I was in a trance looking at all the shapes and colors of the glass art work.

It was such an honor to see the works of a contemporary master. 

Sweetie bought me a book about Chiluly and a  glass necklace to remember the beautiful date day.

I enjoyed the De Young more when I went by myself.  Whenever I go to museums, I like to be hypnotized by the art works.  I stare at and read every single display. It is my way of relaxing and feeding my mind.  It is difficult to do that while with another person.

Anyway, go see the Chiluly exhibit now before it ends!  It is so unique!  It is very much worth it!
author: Leah E.

description: My top pick in SF art museums. Always great, diverse collections that don't try to be anything than organically spectacular. They offer a same day deal with the Legion of Honor. Also, a great event venue!
author: Robynne W.

description:
IT'S ALL ABOUT EXPECTATIONS

Fortunately or unfortunately I am old enough and did see the King Tut exhibit 30 years ago and thought that I was going for a little refresher when I visited yesterday.  I should have read some reviews or read up about what is actually in this current exhibit.  It was NOT like the old days but it was still wonderful. 

There is a lot about his probable lineage, which as an avid genealogist, I really enjoyed and there are many items that correspond with his ancestors and their times. I kept on thinking....wow, this is so much better than before and was salivating at the thought of what was to come when we proceeded to the area that was actually about King Tut's tomb.  Here is where I was disappointed, and I would say that it is partly my fault for not preparing for this visit. I just assumed that the items would be as before....mainly King Tut's funeral mask....NO. When I was in the last room, I actually started to backtrack into the other rooms once again, thinking that I had missed something!!  My expectations were not on target for what I saw. Those adds showing the huge face of Tut's mask I think also throw a person off on what they think they will see. I believe that the posters may be of the little carved figure that once held his liver......quite exquisite, but small.

All that said, I really enjoyed the exhibit and I think if you read this before you go, you will be better prepared for the fact that King Tut is NOT there!!
author: Susan M.

description: Just went to the D'Orsay Impressionist Exhibit and it was my first time seeing the new de Young. Loved the strange architecture. Very modern and interesting. Museum has tons of exhibits, all very interesting and they change about 1-2x per year per my calculations. Definitely need to check out the observation deck on the 9th floor of the tower, stunning views of the city and beyond if it's a clear day. All in all, a great thing to do for tourists or city dwellers. Word to the wise...parking is a PAIN if you can't get into the garage so head over early to avoid the hassle.
author: Jnzl D.

description:
i feel ripped off after paying $32.50 (plus an extra $7 for an audio tour) and not see king tut on friday. i was expecting to see the mummified remains of king tut or his sacrophagus...but none of those where present. my husband told me after the fact that i should have done my research and checked out what would be on display. i should have done that and will do that for any future exhibit i see. 

on display were small items from the tomb, all of which could fit in 2 large balikbayan boxes. and because of that, i am terribly disappointed.

ok, so the items were 3,000 years old. many of them were quite beautiful. i particularly liked the senet because it was a glimpse of what ancient egyptian kids used to play. but still. it was too darn expensive and VERY misleading. KING TUT IS NOT THERE! they have a laser light beaming on a board where you would expect him to be lying, but that's all it was, an illusion.

they should have called the exhibit, ANCIENT EGYPTIAN ARTIFACTS and left it at that cuz that's all it was. the british museum has more items and a better collection, but i gues $40 bucks wont get you to london...bu still, save your money and wait for a better exhibit.
author: Almira C.

description:
King Tut Review:

I came to the De Young to check out the King Tut Exhibition, something I've been waiting to see for many years! Having heard that the De Young has some of the "treasures" from Tutankhamun's tomb, I went nutty and lined up a day to view the exhibition. 

Setup:

The setup is pretty typical for most exhibition dealing with Egyptian artifacts. I liked how they based the exhibition on the family lineage (or said known lineage) of Tutankhamun's family and or rulers prior to his ruling.  So another words you do not start right off looking at his belongings and his tombs artifacts. Instead you travel from the top and slowly make your way into his time of ruling. I thought this was pretty neat but again it is typical in most exhibitions.

Artifacts/Treasures/The Meat:

The exhibition is nicely laid out so that viewing of items is some what easy, especially for larger groups. However, if there is a good crowd you may find that viewing the items can be a bit hard. My best advice to anyone going to check out any exhibition; be sure to wait 5-10 minutes and be at the end of the group, that way you have no issue viewing items. Nothing like seeing someones head instead of the cool jewelry!

Anyhow, the items were pretty neat and I thought they had a good amount of items from each ruling period. Remember, you will go through a good 3 galleries before reaching the climax of the exhibition, tut's stuff. Before reaching his gallery, you will see some really nice stuff from chairs, a full sarcophagus, and several other items. Really, just enough to get you going and ready for the main event.


Tutankhamun's display:  

I am personally satisfied with the overall items on display from Tutankhamun's tomb. I honestly did not expect to see too much and I think what was displayed was good enough for me. NO you are not going to see the famous mask, nor his sarcophagus, and neither the mummy himself. If you know Egyptology, you know that the Egyptian Government has put a lock on a lot of Tutankhamun's items (amongst others belongings), and especially those which are extremely fragile. That noted, all these items are fragile but Tutankhamun's items are more or less the most popular.  So I was surprised to see that there were a good 100+ items from his tomb on display. Hey, I am not complaining... I'd rather see a one then none. I am not too sure what people are expecting but to me this was a good enough score to satisfy my crave for Egyptology!

There are a few galleries within Tutankhamun's main display. Again, each slowly climb up to the actual burial room. His gallery is setup as if you were entering the tomb itself, not visually but the order in which items were found and the rooms they were found in. This is pretty nice since you can get a feel where each item was found and its overall placement in the tomb.

Without going too much in detail and ruining the overall treasures, I must say this is a great exhibition to visit. You will see just enough items to really appreciate the overall culture, art, and ways of early Egypt. 

It took me a total of about 90 minutes to fully view every items, read its description, and leave the exhibition. Not too bad, it is a bit on the short end but I expected this for the most part. 

Want more? an hour drive to the south will put you into the San Jose Egyptian Museum which holds a ton of Egyptian Treasures and Mummy's.
author: Jay D.

description: Good museum even if you dont know anything about art. Great variety and great view!!
author: Alex L.

description:
i have to say...after you go to europe, every museum is not going to compare. so apologies if im harsh in any way..

the de young museum really does do a good job in trying to show off the art in a very modern setting. the museum is really really clean, the building itself is artistic which makes it more enjoyable to view the pieces. i JUST wish it was bigger. yes. i know, but what can i say, you can really go through the place in a 2 hour session, and that's including reading all the stuff on the cards etc. 

we went specifically for king tut. the attraction was as expected, limited number of pieces, but they did a good job explaining the origins, the story etc. (minus the audio tour w/ the funny accent, you'll have to hear it for yourself)

the best part of the attraction in tut was seeing old B&W photos of pieces taken when discovered in 1920, then seeing the damn piece in front of you. pretty amazing.

good family spot. lots ...LOTS of kids. if you are lucky, find a spot in the park for your car and not pay for the underground parking.
author: Justin L.

description:
I used to live a few blocks from the DeYoung and I remember when the structure was going up I thought "what is this hideous brown thing???"  After learning more about it I think it's pretty dang cool.  The copper panels on the exterior of the de Young are covered w/ a dot/perforated pattern that represents the negative and positive space of light coming through leaves when you look up through the trees.  pretty awesome if you ask me!

the observation tower gives you an incredible 360 view of SF in a way that I haven't seen it before.  The exhibit space is separated into manageable rooms with quite a variety showing at any given time.  I didn't get to check out any of the special exhibits but I will definitely go back.
author: Kelly K.

description:
Can a building take away your breath? Yes and yes. My first visit to the De Young was yesterday, and I purposely stayed away from the the site until I knew I was going to walk into the doors to get that full effect. And it didn't disappoint. 

We wound up sneaking in through the side of the cafe, which was a little weird. A bag check later, we were in. The ghetto part of me wanted to just sneak away into the galleries, but I wound up paying like everyone else. Once you're in you get a sticker to wear (remember the foldable pins you had to wear before? That would have been fab!) and you're off and running. 

The galleries were light and airy, and you'll recognize some of the familiar pieces from back in the day (the old De Young), which makes you wonder if they truly rotate the pieces. The special exhibits were wonderful: the Gee Bend Quilts and the Chicano Experience exhibits were lively, but the video media portions were a bit small for my tastes. 

The venue itself is the star here, the copper not quite ready to blend, and the dotted walls invite you to touch them and dig into the divots. The mini atriums were a nice blend of metal and nature, and the flat rocks (shale? who knows) looked more like leaves than rocks. There are some vantage points you should see, like the floor to ceiling window behind the Hudson River painters that overlooks the sculpture garden is worth a check. The benches make you feel like you're in church.

The tower deserves a lot of time and you could spend a good few minutes alone looking at the big map of San Francisco trying to find your house but not mine, apparently, because the hood doesn't represent! Aiyah! Anyways, great 360 views will take your breath away as well. 

The cafe? Suprisingly good. TIP: go early or go later, but don't go during lunch hour. Crowded as all hell. Tomato basil soup and grilled cheese (I added tomatoes!) was amazingly good and FAST!

Despite a largely positive experience, there was one negative: the staff. They maintain a very heavy presence and I suspect that two of the young men were following us not because I had a camera but because like the many objets d'art, we were to be admired. Cute but a little annoying. 

TIP: you can buy tickets online if you want to fast track it in!
author: Charlene L.

description:
Very nice place to visit.  Nice location and lots of space inside and out for a stroll. They have all types of art.  Some, like the modern art, I don't care for, but others, like the early America artists exhibition is fabulous.  Each to his/her own, this place is sure to please. 

Hint: you can go to the top observation deck and get a great view of  the city FOR FREE!  Just go in, get in line, ride up the elevator and you have the bird's eye view.  Worth it, for sure. 

Nice cafe with some tasty snacks. We ate out on the patio. 

Nice architecture to observe,and an all around good feel.  Great way to spend a Sunday, or any other day.
author: John G.

description:
Seeing Jello Biafra speak here was truly bizarre.

Outside of that. the de Young is a great museum to waste a few hours in.  It's also really cheap if you have a student ID and a Muni pass.  Their exhibits are usually pretty interesting and it's location is quite nice.

It's even nice to ride your bike through the park and stop to go up the observation tower on a clear day.
author: daniel m.

description:
I have not had a chance to visit the entire De Young, other than the observation tower and the Chihuly exhibit - but I was more than impressed and can't wait to go back again to see what I missed out on!

The Chihuly exhibit was absolutely amazing. In college, I was lucky enough to have a few friends who were glass blowers and got to witness first hand how delicate and intricate (and difficult!) of an art it is. Most of the walk thru the exhibit was with my eyes and jaw wide open in awe of the amazing colors and shapes. What a treat!

The free observation tower is one of the must-sees when I have out of town visitors - a great 360 view of the city that takes your breath away on a sunny day.
author: Kate Y.

description: The museum itself was awesome, however I cannot understand how they have a museum that brings in things like Van Gogh, and sells out tickets. They should really figure out a way so that everyone can see it....
author: Nantas S.

description:
The various skylights, windows, and wall perforations open up the museum space, and may be why it feels so accessible.  The natural light dapples the museum interior through the copper holes as it might through trees.  Also the building invites you to respond to it, even if it's just the desire to touch the stamped circles in the exterior, as I saw a few children do on my visit.  I wonder if they were also thinking of grating enormous cheese blocks against it ;-)
I was not able to explore the entire museum, but particularly enjoyed the pottery art from Central, Meso, and South America.  I also really liked the Saxe collection, especially the Petroglyph Urn with Horn.  There is much to see here, and I will probably have to buy a membership and come back often.
author: CAKE E.

description:
I absolutely loved the new Chicano exhibit - gives you a glimpse into art that is never really showcased in other more mainstream museums. I recommend getting the audio tour and it'll give a great cultural background to all of the pieces - you have til October 22nd! I justified paying for the audio tour, since going on the first Tuesday of each month is free!!!

But besides this temporary exhibit and the Quilts of Gee's Bend exhibit (that I also enjoyed, yet not nearly as much as the Chicano exhibit) - the rest of the museum and its permanent collection is BLEH. I was really really bored with it. It could have been because I was tired at that point. Or perhaps it just wasn't vibrant enough for me. Or maybe I'm just not artsy enough. I also didn't get why there were so many young children running around and touching the pieces - way louder than any other museum I've been to in a while, even with the speakers over my ears.
author: Dalia K.

description:
I really love this place. I love looking at all the different art and I love the architecture of it. I like the Africana or whatever ethnic thing they have in th back. I just dont remember. Oceania? Anyways, there is always something new I find, even though I have been here a bajillion times since it re-opened. 

The only thing is that it can get really noisy depending on what day you go there, and especially if they have some sort of event. The people at the front desk scare me. And for some reason, it''s always some German or Russian person. I have yet to figure out why that is so. 

For me the highlight is the tower thing which you can see a good portion of the city. Definitely worth waiting in line with all the other tourists and old people.
author: Dustin H.

description:
Glass. Who ever knew glass would be the talk about town? The Chihuly exhibit was excellent. The exotic designs and colors brought gave visitors a glance into the mind of an amazing artist. I advise to skip out on the audio tour. The extra $6 is not worth listening to explanations that you can read on the placards. 

I grew up going to the De Young on "Free Wednesdays" and still to this day, am amazed by the architecture and collections of this museum.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
To those who have not yet endeavored to go here, it is a MUST! The museum is located in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park which is totally huge! If you are traveling by foot, it is worth the walk but I just prefer driving.  It's recent showing for the month of August is the Chihuly exhibit. It is so worth it! Make sure you get an updated sticker if you are a student. 

The architecture aside from this miraculous exhibit is astonishing.  There are other things to see aside from Dale Chihuly's but it is the best thing to see and experience.  At the very top of the building, you can see S.F. at it's fullest.  Unfortunately, my boyfriend and I attended a day that it was very smoggy and cold. They also had a live band which was cool but paying bon appetite was not worth it to pour my coke which cost $5 per can. (wow) Aside from this, it wasn't bad because the whole place was a wonderful experience.  I'm from San Jose and I've gone to the MOMA in SJ, but compared to S.F., De Young is the icing on the cake. :)
author: Janeth B.

description: Ive been here multiple times, and its been good every time. I would probably spread out my visits based on the featured exhibit, but its always a great place to go to on a nice day!
author: Alan C.

description: a wonderful museum with a lot of really cool art located perfectly in golden gate park.  be sure to check out the observation tower.  it gives an awesome view of the city.
author: Amy L.

description: My first visit to the de Young was very pleasant. I rode Bart and Muni on a "Free Admission Tuesday." The building is quite impressive from the exterior to the interior. I arrived around 2:30 p.m. and was pleased that it was not crowded and I had lots of time and space to experience the "Olmec" exhibit. I rented the audio headphones which simulated a personal tour, giving in depth details about collection pieces and also filtered out any idle chatter, not that anyone was loud or annoying everyone was respectful of their surroundings which I appreciated. I was considering a membership and this visit has definitely made my mind up to go for it. I want to go on Friday nights as well as become a regular of the featured exhibits. Oops, forgot to mention the spectacular view from the tower, a must see even if you're a native of San Francisco.
author: M. T.

description:
KING TUT EXHIBIT

Okey dokey... I love the DeYoung and have seen some really fantastic things here. The KING TUT exhibit is very well laid- out and the artifacts labeled... they have some interesting sculptures and beautiful gilded artifacts. Everything was very well organized and lit. 

PLOT SPOILER: There are 7 or more sarcophagi that entombed King Tut's body... you know... the really famous ones that are gilded and the death mask of solid gold... probably the main if not only reason you came to the exhibit... IT'S NOT HERE. Even though it's all over the advertising and even on the tickets... it's not in the exhibit at all!

Read a book or watch the national geographic show... you'll get more information and things to see. It was a huge disappointment to me, especially because the exhibit tix were PRICEY. Where the heck is all the money going?
author: J B.

description:
Weird stuff but fun architecture. I think I went on a BofA free museum day and it wasn't crowded, which was surprising. If you go to the Legion of Honor museum you can also use the same ticket to get into the De Young and vice versa. There's a parking structure underneath that's a few dollars per hour.

I would definitely recommend going up to the observation tower.
author: Retired B.

description:
I went to see the Tut exhibit on Saturday and was pleasantly surprised by how fabulous they showed it off. I remember seeing the Tut exhibit back in the 70's and we stayed in line for about almost 2 hours. There was a mob of people at the exhibit and it was frustrating for me since I was little and it was hard to see everything.
This time they had it organized where people go in certain numbers at a time. We had the 2:00 showing. My mom is a member so we had will call tickets, and a different line to stand in. When we entered the first area it was a darkened room with dim lighting and a big wooden door that led to the exhibit. The spokesman talks about the exhibit and shows you a 90 second movie about King Tut and how Howard Carter found his tomb. Then we entered the exhibit and wander around. The displays are great, with the description in more than one place on the casings so you can read it either close up or farther back from above in larger lettering which is nice. There are some relics that are quite exquisite with the jewels that were worn, the copper coffin and the alabaster jars.
One thing you must know is that the big pieces of the exhbit like the main coffin, the mummy and the golden mask are not in the exhibit. That is because, after 3000 years they are now too delicate to travel. I'm glad I got to see that in the 70's! 
They do show them on video screens throughout the exhibit. They even have the one rectangular slab that shows the mummy in it's tomb, and effectively show what pieces were in the tomb with the mummy. Very interesting. They have a video that shows the 5 layers within the tomb before you get to the actual mummy. 
The gift shop was great, with some unique stuff and fabulous jewelry. I got a couple of things there. Now I wish I had gotten the calendar!
The cafeteria is indoor outdoor. That day it was member appreciation time and they had a $12 lunch deal which is a turkey sandwhich, a cup of soup, salad and a nice little custard desert. Drink is not on that special. I had a beer. Mom had diet cola. They also had a member appreciation reception with free beverages and appetizers in another room.
There's more: The newly rennovated museum now has an elevator that takes you to the tower where you can see the whole park and the city. I am not sure if you can go on Friday night, but it's worth a shot.
There are twilight tours on Friday evenings which is nice. There is a free shuttle service that takes you around the park so you don't have to walk or drive everywhere. There are muni lines as well. The 44 line is just outside going towards inner sunset, and accross at the Steinhardt Aquarium the 44 goes to 6th and California. We took that bus to the California Stop and took the 1 California. It worked out okay for us since we didn't have to wait long for the buses. It would be hell to park and expensive for a cab. 
Go early on the weekends because there are a lot of people. This will be going on until March 2010.
http://www.tutsanfrancisco.org/
author: Fog City Girl L.

description:
This is both for the museum and the King Tut exhibit.

This is probably the worst organized museum I have ever been to in not just the way that they direct lines for the exhibit, but also for the flow of the exhibits themselves.

Let's start with the King Tut exhibit.  A King Tut exhibit with no King Tut just bad advertising.  I realize that the Egyptian government doesn't want any of the sarcophagi or death mask traveling, but include that fact in the exhibit itself.  The video that National Explorer put together animating the various tombs that covered the final sarcophagus was too fast as ultimately useless.

If the real thing can't travel, I see nothing wrong in making replicas that people and kids can touch.  On some level I would prefer it.

The rest of the museum seemed randomly thrown together.  While there were a couple of exhibit areas that were organized by geography, most were just all mixed together in a mishmash of random artwork.

Then there is the staff and their stupid policies.  You can bring your backpack in, but you have to carry it as your side.  What purpose does this serve?  It doesn't make it any less likely that you are going to knock other people or exhibits, it does just the opposite, it makes you more unwieldy and awkward.  I have never been to another museum that requires this, not even the Louvre. 

The staff is rude and they can't keep their story straight.  One will tell you cameras are okay in that section, another will come rushing up to you almost screaming at you about no cameras.  All the staff are rude and just have an unprofessional attitude.
author: Mogwai G.

description:
My 101st review!!  Whoot!  In honor of my milestone it's time for an update of the DeYoung museum review.

I love this museum!  Truth in advertising requires I admit my skepticism of the design when first revealed.  In manifestation this is a beautiful museum.  The galleries are well portioned, appropriately flexible and flow well one to the next.  My only big beef with the overall design is a lack of planning for the huge crowds drawn by the fantastic exhibits.  The entry doesn't allow for an easy flow in/out when it's busy.  That said this little frustration disappears once inside.

We have seen several major traveling exhibits here.  Tut and the French Impressionists stand out for us.  These events brought stunning priceless and famous works to our view.  We saw Tut three times finding new and fascinating things each time.  The French Impressionist exhibits have just floored me.  Like so many I had seen for years photos of Blue Boy, Whistler's Mother, Starry Night and a host of other famous paintings.  The opportunity to see them so intimately was an incredible joy.  Photos never do paintings justice.  Brush strokes invoking sense of movement and the sense of light are so often lost in transference.  Seeing them so close was a privilege I'll treasure forever.  All the major traveling exhibits have been housed in the lower level galleries.   Aside from the cattle chute entry, each exhibit has been unique in gallery design, flow and feel.  I've forgotten each time I was in the same space.  

I once enjoyed a delightful dinner with Nancy Hamon.  She is the wonderful soul who funded the tower now bearing she and her husbands name.  Because of her gift admission to the tower is free in perpetuity. The observation floor is amazing.  Its vantage point as one of the tallest structures on the west side of the city affords 360 degree spectacular vistas.  Many thanks Nancy! 

The DeYoung is one of SF's greatest treasures.  It enriches our city and our lives.  I'm proud to say I'm a member and look forward to many more years of wonderful art.
author: Russell D.

description:
The newly designed De Young Museum is U-G-L-Y. You'd think with all the money spent on building this museum, they would have built something prettier? Oh no, they had to go w/ an ugly copper look. I tried to convince myself that the copper was interesting and artistic, which made it unique and beautiful. I'm calling what it is, which is ugly.  I'm not one of those art snobs that likes everything they see and call it art. 
Despite the arhictecture of the museum, I love the landscape that surrounds it. It would be nice to lay around on the green grass underneath the trees on a breezy spring or summer day.
I am sore that they closed the roof top view at 4:30. *sigh.
The museum's collections were ok. Nothing that really stood out to me, except for this cement head that looked like Stewie from the family guy. If we could only post pictures.
author: Andrenaline R.

description:
Free Museum Tuesdays changed my life. 

Exposure to works of visual art as a child painted upon the canvas of my mind with the indelible colors of the creative. Museums have always been a sacred space for me; a place of tranquility, contemplation, and reflection.  

The De Young Museum in the Richmond District is such a place, a colossal mesh structure that juts into the foggy skies of Golden Gate Park, and one of my favorite places in all of the city of San Francisco. The interior design of this art showcase is unobtrusive and decidedly warm yet contemporary.  There is a distinct minimalist touch to the space that allows the art, not the museum itself, to be the focal point in each section of the gallery. 

The De Young museum is spacious and welcoming. It's a comfortable place for visitors to spend countless hours viewing wonderful works of art. Visit this lovely space and see the outstanding collection.
author: Jessica D.

description:
It's impossible to review the exhibits inside the museum since they change all the time, so I will only discuss the museum as a structure.

You either love or hate the exterior of the museum.  To some it is a hideous piece of metal attempting to be overly modern.  But to others (such as much self) it is a beautiful work of art that is on par with many of the fantastic pieces that frequent the building.  

What many have to realize is that the copper plating on the surface has a purpose.  Over time as the copper reacts with the air (mostly with the sulfur dioxide and carbon dioxide) it will oxidize to form a blueish-green coating over the surface.  Decades from now (it's a slow process) the entire building will blur into the surroundings, making it look as-if it has literally grown out of the ground.  

This effect is further influenced by the spiral tower protruding from the East-side of the building, in a way resembling a spruce tree that twists as it grows.  And as Ashton mentioned below, is an engineering marvel on it's own.   Be sure to take the elevator to the top so that you can enjoy the view from above.

The overhang that sticks out to cover the cafe is nothing short of breath taking.  It may look trivial from the distance, but once you are standing right under it and gaze upwards, you start to feel the collosal impact it delivers.

As you walk in you pass through a hallway which has the names of all the contributors set behind a glass plate.  Perserving their names for the life of the building.  What may look like a structural defect, the floor has a large crack that runs through the large stones.  An interesting concept that is well understood to San Franciscans.

The middle of the building has a garden that is visible from virtually any part of the museum.  A beautiful touch.  Beyond that the rest of the interior begins to lack in style and design.   Navigating around it becomes confusing, even to repeat visitors.  The walls are bare and some of the spaces oddly shaped, for no apparent reason (not even if you are taking into consideration the exterior's shape).  The set-in fluorescent  lights make for an interesting feature.  Their repetitive placement yields interesting photos.
author: Serge S.

description:
Okay so I don't remember the art exhibitions except for the Jacob Lawrence exhibit and the abstract art in the entrance foyer but I love the building and the 360 view from the observation deck.

Got free parking on the street on a weekday but the next time I'll walk or catch the bus. It took a couple of passes to find parking. You get a discount on museum admission with your Muni Fast Pass or if you say you caught the bus. 

I was hoping the modern art collection would be better but it was smaller than expected. The building itself fulfilled any lost expectations for modern art.

Good museum to take out of town visitors to see Golden Gate Park and of course, the Observation Deck.
author: Wendy B.

description:
Cafe:
Bon Appetit "food services for a sustainable future"
This is the same corporation that is contracted at the Monterey Bay Aquarium, the boxes at AT&T Park, University of San Francisco, and Oracle among other places.

Their service varies, but at the De Young it is very good. They are a company who TRIES to be socially responsible while providing gourmet quality food. 

Prices aside, the staff is very nice and the actual cafe with indoor and outdoor seating couldn't be a better place to have lunch in a city.

Museum Store:

Standard. Having a main floor and garage level locations is convenient.

People:

It is a mixed crowd. Some people stumble upon the museum while visiting the park, others are your older go every week crowd, there are art snobs and your Etch-a-Sketch-ers. People from the other side of the world and some that live on 10th Ave.

Architecture:
From the exterior, there may not be a better design for a museum of its size built in the middle of an urban forest. All the materials used throughout the building are beautiful. I just have one complaint... the main entryway once you are inside the building. The ceilings are too low and it feels like you are inside one giant concrete slab. As you walk farther in finally the space opens up!

Art:
Hmmmmm, what is an art museum without good art? Answer: the De Young. 

There are some very fine pieces at the DeYoung, but in general it falls short of most world-class museums. Some collections are too large and others too small. 

Here is an article that well summarizes the De Young's pitfall:

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/09/02/MNSMRQ8I5.DTL&hw=de+young&sn=001&sc=1000

This alone justifies only 3 stars.
author: Lee M.

description:
Finally! I hadn't visisted the De Young museum since the upgrade and it's a sight to behold! I like the new copper skin on the building and the entire architecture is just very cool. There's always something new look at....and it's no different on the inside. I was a little dissapointed as my past memories of the museum made me believe that the place is smaler than the past, but it's probably not. 

We could only take so much of culture and contemporary art in one day, so the amount of exhibits was just right.
author: Brad S.

description:
The next best thing to Friday night happy hours.  I've done Thursdays at the MOMA, 3rd Thursdays at the Aquarium, and Matcha at the Asian Art Museum - this by far has been the consistent winner among cool artsy fartsy things to do after 5 pm at the city's major cultural institutions.  A live band, impromptu dancing, a bar, and art - what more can you ask for?  I've come here mostly just to view their special exhibits since they usually cost a little bit extra to see when you go on a normal day.  Some of the cons - it can be a little crowded and they don't let you bring your drinks with you into the galleries so you kind of have to chug that drink so you can move on to the art part.

They also have lectures, poetry readings, and film viewings.  I haven't had any interest in going to any of these, but maybe one of these days I will.  I do however love when they have those DIY creative art stations.  Last Friday they had the floral art exhibit in tow (very awesome btw!) and visitors got to make paper flowers!  I know, I'm a child.

I recommend that you get there as early as possible if you want to be able to enjoy everything as they close at 8:45 and there really isn't enough time to see all the museum's art.
author: Jean A.

description:
It took the Chihuly exhibit to finally get me over to the De Young.  I was very very impressed with both the museum and the exhibit.

Dale Chihuly's glass installations were absolutely amazing.  Shapes, colors and arrangements were all incredible.  I'm sorely tempted to describe my favorites, but I'll just hold my tongue and let you figure what my top 3 would be.  If you have not made a visit yet, I highly recommend checking it out before it goes away at the end of September.

The permanent collection at the museum has some great sections and pieces as well.  I probably sped through about half of it after my 30 minute Chihuly viewing so I'll need to make another trip to take in the rest.  

I took my parents who were in town visiting so we made a point to go to the top of the tower.  From below it doesn't seem all that high, but it was pretty cool, even if you've lived in SF for a long time.  Its a great view and great perspective of the city.  You can pretty much see every building in the Richmond and Presidio.  I would definitely recommend the tower if you're visiting or have out-of-town guests.

Try to see the Chilhuly exhibit on a weekday or I would suggest buying an advance ticket.  I went on a Thursday @ 2:00 and it was crowded, but very manageable.  Combined with a nice stroll around the park, it was a great day.
author: Zach J.

description: For Tent and Trade was a surprisingly good show about Turkmen weaving.  I love any excuse to walk through Golden Gate Park.  I'm a fan of De Young's observatory floor view.  The sculpture garden is fun for picture-taking.  The building is okay but the interior windows that allow you to peek at other galleries is a beautiful idea.
author: Ai M.

description: I went to the King Tut exhibit.  It was my first time at the De Young, I won't be rushing back.  It was a good experience, but  the place was crazy busy and expensive, but I enjoyed the exhibit, especailly with the audio tour.  The cafe was a pleasant surprise.  My son LOVED their mac n cheese,  the sauce was, as they say in LA "to die for."
author: Jen W.

description:
Your status quo fancy museum with all the resources at its disposal, I basically did a drive-by on this place, time is precious: no stop and stare at painting, stand back, stand more to the side, across the room stuff. no extra for the "special exhibits". Hey, hey, we're in a recession, did you not get the memo, what the heck is that?! 

I liked the African stuff with all the artifacts like masks, furniture - for some reason my African people were big on neck rests, not sure what that was about, perhaps this was before the pillow. 

Um...I liked the sky tower that over looked SF, but, I could have done that on top of twin peaks, but thanks homie, did I pay for that by the way?! Oh, when I saw up there, down below facing South, I think it was, people were walking through some stream, it looked like the museum passed gas on them, very disturbing, very confusing. 

This museum is sort of a lost soul, po' thang. Aah, good enough though.
author: Brian S.

description:
ON AN OLMEC HEAD SCULPTURE 
Santiago del Dardano Turann

The watcher in a mask of stone looks on
With cold and wary eyes of blank basalt 
That still contains within it shades of fire
Which burned inside a long extinct volcano. 
His gaze is fixed on scenes decayed in time
And now is left to haunt perception's edge. 
The face is reminiscent of a full 
And heavy winter moon above a vast
And empty sea in somber steaks of gray.
What lay there on the dark side hidden from
Our vision in its stony sleep paralysis 
Peers out into the black of space with longing
While grumbling with disdain at chatty viewers.
author: Santiago d.

description:
crowded & i cant even sketch?  am i at the louvre?  the ufizzi?  the guggenheim?  no, but i bet i can sketch in there!

boo de young, BOO.  the 3 stars are for getting some of the impressionists in sf.
author: Lady K.

description: A wonderful museum, with equally wonderful staff! Absolutely adore the architecture of the building itself, and all of the beautiful art that's displayed for the world to enjoy. Came the other night to view the Tut Exhibit. Amazed at the beginning, where they played about a minute long video introducing everything- and then the doors opened up automatically. Like a ride at Disneyland, it reminded us. Anyway, glorious pieces. The many different placards of descriptions proved helpful, although we were blessed to come when it wasn't that crowded! Gorgeous pieces, really, especially at the end. Glad that I had the opportunity to see such an amazing exhibit!
author: Mina S.

description:
Want discounted King Tut tickets?  Forget membership, go to COSTCO!  Via "membership" I bought tickets in March, thinking that they would be as difficult to obtain as they were the last time in SF.  Wrong, I saw them  ~$5 cheaper at Costco.  What a rip off, so much for "member privileges & they held our money for 5 months.  

The Exhibit:  Right, the chair/thrones were cool, as was the dagger.  The projection of a photo of the sarcophagus on a platform reminded us of  This is Spinal Tap's Stonehenge:  a comic/hallow representation of the original, that just doesn't cut it, thus completing the cheesiness of the exhibit.  But hey, we saved money in not buying tickets to Egypt.  See Kenneth Baker's 6/27/09 article at: http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/06/27/DDS318DH4T.DTL  1979 was much, much better.

Audio Hint:
If you have a guest with problem hearing, don't rent the audio tour:  Omar Sharif's voice was not good for hard of hearing, his voice was too soft.  Especially in the presence of  the noisy crowd.  

Shopping: If you want to "buy local" and support the museum, make your purchases at the stores that say "de Young".   At the end of the exhibit you're dumped out into a store that's a for-profit, and staffed by non-museum employees.  The shop goes on tour with the exhibit.
author: F M.

description:
King Tut.   A once in a lifetime view into the past.  His last resting place in 3 coffins at age 19.  Thanks to modern day CT scanners, we now know he had a several fractures including one above the left knee acquired 2 days before his death.  The cause of death is speculative but may have been due to an infection from that fracture.
The museum hosted several gala events for members for this exhibition before the official opening tomorrow, Saturday.  The Wednesday nite event was attended by many city celebrities and deep pocket donors.  Thursday evening's gala was for contributing members willing to fork out an additional $35/pair for a buffet in addition to the cost of the tickets.   

We were led downstairs to the exhibit where digitalized photos with captions of the 1920's discovery and treasures hang on the wall.  You enter a darkened room much like the one at Disneyland's Haunted Mansion and watch a short video and then the doors automatically open and the tour begins.  I like to read and look at every item and it takes me longer than most folks when going thru an exhibit. 
There are so many things to admire and they saved the best for last. Gold necklaces, crown, dagger and a CT image of the King within the coffin in the last room.  The painted wooden bust of the boy king when he ascended to the throne at age 9, is still vivid with color, just as if it was made yesterday, so well preserved.  

The end of the exhibit leads you into the bookstore with books, jewelry, posters, t-shirts, postcards, magnets, and all sorts of memorabilia related to the exhibit.  It's been 30 yrs since the exhibit last came to SF in the 1970's and it may never return again. There are new items not seen before of many of the King's relatives.  There's even a kiosk outside the bookstore where you can print your own cartouche (converting your name) for $1.00.  

Afterwards, we were back in the lobby level enjoying the ample buffet of fried chicken breast pieces, couscous, vegetables, lox and capers, pita bread, meatballs in tomato sauce,  dolmas stuffed with rice, etc.  There were at least 3-4 tables of the same foods in the lobby and another room with the same spread and a band playing old time music.  A room near the bookstore was filled with desserts - fruit, cookies, baklava, little tea cups with lemon, butterscotch or chocolate pot o'cream.  Unlimited wine, beer, soda, sparkling water, green apple martinis and some blue drink (like blue toilet water) were were available. Folks were dressed in suits, some jeans (invitation indicated "business casual"), black dresses and some party dresses, pants, etc.  A couple of dancers dressed in Egyptian-type clothing were dancing about from room-to-room.  By 10 PM (the show was scheduled to end by 11 PM) the majority of the folks had left for home.  It's really a great exhibit, don't miss it.
author: Ry T.

description:
Hats off to the curators of the Warhol exhibit. I may have been tainted by having gone to the Factory remake over in Emeryville two weeks before, but this show was awesome. I thought it belonged in the MOMA, but we thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Gave me a new appreciation for Andy Warhol, and tested my art history. Also sent me down a portal on what music I was listening to in the 70s. 
This exhibit was very alive. 

Yves St Laurent was great . It helps to know what goes into Haute Coutre to appreciate some of these gowns. The different era's were cool.
author: Lola S.

description:
This review is for the Amish Quilt exhibition which opened recently and continues until June, 2010.  There are about 50 quilts displayed upstairs in the Textile gallery.  Amazing!  They come from both Lancaster Penn. and other mid-Western Amish communities.  There are distinct differences between the quilts created in the different areas.
These quilts were not made for daily use and incorporate amazing colors, patterns and craftsmanship.  Docent tours at 11:30 and 1:30.  We took one and gained a lot of additional insight into our visit.  
The Tut tickets are good for three days to the deYoung's permanent collection.  Definitely use that to check out these quilts -- no addl charge.
author: Melissa A.

description:
Beautiful museum in golden gate park.

I have seen the Vivian Westwood exhibit, the Chihuly and just saw the YSL (Yves Saint Laurent) exhibit yesterday. All three were wonderful! They seem to have a lot of fashion exhibits, which I love...keep them coming!

Be sure to go up to the tower and see the stunning views of SF as well as take a stroll through the Tea Garden.
author: Elaine S.

description: Went to see the Hockney exhibition "A Bigger Exhibition". Should be called "A Bigger Exhibition Than the de Young Can Handle". Waited in line to get in the parking garage. Stuck in traffic inside the garage (narrow, one-way loop). Lucked out and got a space. Waited in Member's line to get a ticket. Went to the cafe and waited in line there while waiting for my designated time slot to get in the Hockney exhibit queue. Waited in the Hockney queue. Waited in a "post queue" holding area where they scanned your timed ticket. Exhibit was excellent but packed. Waited in line for elevator for continuation of exhibit. Waited in bookstore to make a purchase. Waited for rest room. When leaving, waited in line to use ticket machine to pay for parking (one machine was broken). Waited to get back in endless loop of traffic in garage. Waited to get out of garage. All in all, an excellent exhibit, but I spent much more time WAITING in lines than seeing art! Never go on a weekend when there's a big exhibit!
author: Stephen M.

description:
Oh, I have never loved a museum the way I love the deYoung.  

I never tire of the permanent collection as they do a good job rotating it ever so slightly upon each visit, and the tower/integration of location to space is the best art/archetecure example I've expereinced AND has doubled as a great tourist attraction for your out-of-town visitors. This is also good for the visitors who are not really art-goers, and the diversity of the collection usually has at least one thing of interest for any group member.  

Be aware, the museum closes earlier than I'd like, and almost every time I've gone on the weekend I've felt dumped early.

Also, every time I've gone on a date here, we broke up soon after (three times, I'm not kidding!) Maybe my love for the deYoung holds new relationships to a too-high standard :)
author: Sarah X.

description: I checked my nice pea coat during a private event that was held there, and when I went to pick it up, I discovered that they had given it to someone else.  To make matters worse, the attendants tried to convince me to take someone else's coat in place of my own, rather than offering comparable compensation.
author: Leora H.

description: Just want to update and say that I saw the Impressionists from the D'Orsay last weekend.  It was great!  It was in the same place that the Tut exhibit was prior to that, but the space looked completely different.  I went with my kids, and kept saying to them "this one's really famous."  What a coup for the deYoung to get this exhibit!
author: june b.

description: I wish they would have left all the wonderful park museums alone. The new de Young is cold and an architectural night mare. It's ugly and uninviting. I may be back, for the right show, but I'll never just wander in like I did before the remodel.
author: Larina M.

description: With gorgeous views both inside (from the top of the 5th floor looking out over the golden gate bridge and park) and outside (the copper plating of the building), I loved my experience at the DeYoung Museum. They have some exhibits that rotate in and out, which often require an additional ticket. We opted just for the museum's permanent collection and enjoyed a good 2-3 hours of viewing before we decided to head out and get some food for a picnic in GG park. 9th and Irving is close by walking to grap any one of a million types of food to bring into the park and eat on the hillside or near the museum itself. Parking can get congested and costly.
author: Kat T.

description:
I've been to the De Young a few times and on my last visit to San Francisco I stopped in to check out the Andy Warhol exhibit. I'll admit, I was a little reluctant only because I've been to the De Young and seen how it looks and I was skeptical that they had what it takes to put on a really wonderful special exhibit. Still, I've never seen Andy Warhol's work up close, plus I got FREE ADMISSION through Bank of America's first weekend of the month free museum pass with BofA card program, so I hopped on the Muni and checked it out.

My main beef with the museum is that the layout and organization seems scattered and random at times. Turn to your left and you'll see an Aztec stela, and turn to your right and you can see some delightful blow glass in the shape of a fruit dish! Something about that pairing just doesn't seem right...
