I was, however, completely wrong about the special exhibit. What I witnessed was truly worthy of (and I'm going to be a total SoCal snob here) the LACMA. Not just prints and photos, this truly was an total sensory experience. As you walk through the exhibit you can listen to the music Warhol's favorite musicians pumped in through speaker, look at actual furniture from his "Factory", lie down on a psychedelic round sofa with plush pillows and look at a light show, and watch creepy videos of Lou Reed staring at you unblinkingly. A great exhibit and one you should check out if you're in the area.

So really: 3.5 stars for the De Young, and 5 stars for the Warhol exhibit. A King Tut special exhibition is coming soon so check that out!
author: Eva V.

description: Reviewing the King Tut exhibit. I can't believe I wasted $22.50 (American Express cardholders rate) per person to see King Tut on the video? I was so excited to see King Tut's mummy and his tomb. But all we got at the end was a projection screen of the mummy and a video sample of what his tomb looked like. The artifacts were limited and nothing too special. I didn't even see any statue of the cat guardian. It was a disappointment.
author: Chris R.

description:
As a museum space, this is clearly one of the more well-designed and well-curated experiences in San Francisco. I visited in Dec 2006, and the modern art and Oceanic art collections are quite striking. There's a wide variety of types of art, spanning about a hundred and twenty five years and  a few countries.The museum building itself is worth a trip --- the walls on the outside have an industrial feel, and the grounds outside the cafe have sculptures by Joan Miro and others, and a skyscape by James Turrell.

On a summer day, the de Young is a great destination to add to a tour of the park --- volleyball, lunch on the grill, a bottle of wine, friends and art. Parfait!
author: Sameer S.

description:
I enjoyed some of the art paintings in the first floor rooms, but got a bit bored waiting for my friends, so I started walking laps around that wing... or, should I say speedwalking laps for over thirty minutes.

Then we went upstairs, I spedwalked the entire floor, up and down all the aisles in a matter of minutes. Then stood over the vent grates cooling down. I enjoyed the vintage photos of San Francisco. The bathroom was a nice shade of green.

I enjoyed the tower of terror. Too bad we couldn't walk up or down. The view was awesome on this foggy afternoon, I barely saw USF's church tower. The gigantic satellite photo map was awesome.

Will return on a better day to take in the tower's sweeping views.

Admission was free, no money spent!
author: qirk z.

description:
I'm frankly surprised at the number of five-star reviews. Yes, the architecture is nice (though, as someone else pointed out, seems out of place in Golden Gate Park, unlike the older building). Yes, the view from the observation deck is beautiful.

But the exhibits? An extremely mixed bag. Haphazard would have to be my best description -- pieces are thrown together seemingly without much rhyme or reason. There are (pretentiously written) unifying statements that open each collection, but there's precious little else to explain the inclusions or arrangements. The museum strongly touts its Georgia O'Keeffe, but a) that's the only one in the collection, and b) it's thrown up with something else. Are they connected in some thematic or historical way? Who knows? There's nothing to indicate so.

Don't get me wrong -- there are definitely great things to see here, but I wouldn't call this a five-star museum.
author: Cheshire I.

description:
STUDENT MEMBERSHIP IS A TOTAL BARGAIN!
I have been a museum member for a few years now, and the membership is one of the best things I purchase every year-even more than my costco card!  It allows me to bring a guest with me to the museum, which i always do everytime I have an out-of-towner staying with me.

The exibits they've been having, particularly recently, are fresh and cutting edge and defy the stereotype of a stuffy old museum.   The new remodel (as of 05) is stunning, despite my original opinions.  There is no better place to be in the city on a clear day than on the top of the observation tower, seeing in all directions.  

I love the freedom my membership brings me, since i can drop in for an hour when i've got a little extra time or just have one particular exhibit i'd like to investigate further.  Perfect place on a sunday morning
author: Monica B.

description:
GO HERZOG & de MEURON! [Update: it just occurred to me that most people probably have no idea who these guys are - THEY ARE ROCK STAR ARCHITECTS who designed the deYoung]


 I love this building! GREAT example of what modern architecture should be: sleek lines and sharp angles that balance visually and do not disrupt but play into the surrounding environment. The exterior material is perfect for the project. The perforated copper will oxidize and turn green in the humid San Francisco air, and as time goes by will blend ever more beautifully into the Golden Gate Park. The perforations themselves are made in an organic pattern, to mimic the play of light through foliagealthough I must say that they do make the tower look slightly like a cheese grater.


 I can't say anything about the collection, because I am always too distracted by the building itself


 The space is simply beautiful!
author: lizok

description:
- Take a date on a hot summers day
 - Have a drink while appreciating the huge safety pin outside
 - Look at all the tourist
 - Listen to the live symphony playing across the street
 - Pretend you knew 8 languages
 - Cherish Chihuly and all of his students work
 - Wonder about his BONG collection at home

Sometimes Museums make me depressed while doubting my own intellect.
author: Justin C.

description:
I went to the De Young to see the Chihuly exhibit and it was amazing! His artwork is truly beautiful. I liked how they offered the option of the self-guided tour with headphones. 5 stars for the fact that I saw Demi Moore there waiting in line for the restroom...woohoo! Also, they allow you to take non-flash photos of the artwork displayed in the exhibit which is supercool -- I now have a snazzy new cell phone background of his glass garden! Lastly, you get a discounted admission if you took Muni there! Whoever came up with that really has the right idea going. 

I went during the week, so not sure how crowded it gets on the weekends. The cafe was a little crowded, and the line was pretty long due to their credit card machines being down...but the other awesomeness I experienced there made up for it, hence 5 stars. :)
author: A G.

description:
It has been quite some time since I've been to the De Young.  But I must say that despite the fact that I'm not much of an art fan, they have some very interesting artwork.  I loved the tribal arts, masks, shields, etc.  It gives an eerie cool feeling.  Some of the stuff was quite intriguing yet kind of scary.  Especially the human skull masks.  The glass galleria was quite interesting also, I would never expect such beautiful pieces can be constructed of glass alone.  Its a great place for kids, adults, and people of all ages.  For $6 with a student ID, you can spend easily spend 4 hours wandering around (a total of $1.50 an hour), you can beat that for some cost effective entertainment.

Some things you should keep your eyes peel for would be the Tiffany's box, the pair of smooth butt cheeks, and of course the penis cover.
author: Clifford C.

description: Love the deYoung. My fave SF museum by far because they have amazing exhibits! I've been three times for Dale Chihuly, Balenciaga & Spain, and Jean Paul Gaultier. All were amazing. Love love this place! The conservation tower also has a sick view of SF.
author: Jeanne C.

description: When at the museum be sure to take it all in, explore the permanent collection, go to the top of the tower to overlook the city, buy some fun stuff at the gift shop, and be sure to grab some lunch at the amazing cafe.
author: Cassie P.

description: What a beautiful museum!  We saw the impressionist exhibit a few weeks ago on a Saturday.  It was very busy, but somehow they had it so organized it wasn't bad.  Actually, I had bought tickets for the wrong day, and they let me in anyway.  Whew!  That would've sucked if we had gone with our friends and not been able to get in.  The cafe inside is awesome too.  We had some really great food and wine afterwards.  My favorite, Goodie Goody Cookies even has their cookies there!!!!!!
author: Suzie R.

description: This review is for the Tut Exhibit:  We didn't get the audio tour, but in the end I didn't feel as if we had missed out on any important information.  The exhibit has artifacts from Tut's father, grandfather and mother and grandmother in addition to those that were found inside his tomb.  I was in awe of the intricate detail in the sculpting and etching.  I realized today that the Egyptians were story tellers.  I had expected to see some of the larger artifacts, but what I saw was amazing.  Just looking at each piece and knowing it was 4000 years old and wondering what the carvers were thinking at the moment the piece was made took me on a journey all its own.  Definitely worth a visit.
author: K G.

description: I like this museum.  A lot going on, one can easily spend a few hrs there.
author: Oriana C.

description: On a recent visit to San Fran I stopped by the De Young to see the Impressionist exhibit. One thing to warn you is there are lines for this featured exhibit. I did feel like cattle at some points being prodded along by the museum employees. I typically prefer going to an empty place to see art, however, this is a great way to see many pieces of art that one would normally have to fly to Paris to see. I will defiantly be back in the fall to see the second half of the exhibit.
author: Ashley S.

description:
I had an archaeology professor once who used to enjoy going here and pointing out to the staff which of their mesoamerican and andean artifacts were fakes ... it drove them nuts!

I give them 3 stars because SF needs more museums and their location gives an excuse to go to the park.
author: Matthew M.

description:
Up till now I thought the best museums were in NYC, Paris and Moscow. I can add this museum to the list.
I love it!
My favorite so far is the feathers/masks/bones art exibit on the second floor.
author: City G.

description:
Yet another museum where rich people get to show people they're rich. 

 Gift shop: Don't get me wrong they have some pretty cool stuff but its extremely over priced (they wanted 20$ for a glass rock smaller than a kiwi fruit.)  then I saw the exhibit that featured Mexican rock art from 600-750 (Maya I believe).  I don't care what anyone says, the room that the  art is in has a very angry feel to it, maybe because it was stolen?  you NEVER steal stuff from ancient civilizations.
There are some interesting pieces there, the tower is awesome can spend all day looking out of it, the quilts are nice as well.
author: Winter Lee S.

description:
Something most people might not know: if you have your MUNI transfer, you get $2 off admission! If you're also a student, this means you get into the museum ridiculously cheap!

Being a sucker for uber shiny objects, I love Josiah McElheny's "Model for Total Reflective Abstraction," which some unlucky worker must polish every day... Bruce Nauman's "Double Poke in the Eye II" cracks me up every time, and I like standing in front of the Diebenkorns for a while.

I admit I tend to like contemporary art, but the museum has a surprisingly large collection of native art from Africa and Oceania. There are some interesting masks and daily use objects in there. My favorite is the bright orange coffin in the shape of a bean (?) pod.

The observation tower is overrated since trees and hills obscure most of the view, but at least you don't have to pay extra to go up there. The huge satellite map of the city is pretty cool though.
author: Jin Z.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE the giant Richter in the lobby. HATE HATE HATE any and all the Chihuly stuff.  LOVE LOVE LOVE "The Wild Swan." HATE HATE HATE $15- admission to the general galleries and the special exhibits.

Funny and depressing: the fashion-damaged students from FIDM parading around the Vivienne Westwood show.

Funny and entertaining: the ladies who lunch trying to sort out the crinkly-wrinkly scarves and felted wool chain items in the "shop" at the Westwood exhibit's exit.

Just plain fuckin' funny: the option to purchase the Sex Pistol's "Never Mind The Bollocks" CD at the same end of exhibit shop.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Bf brought me to the New De Young on our first special occassion because we're both museum fans.  I have never been to the Old De Young so no comparison at all.

At the first sight, the museum itself was so modern and different as I could tell.  When getting closer, I noticed it was Copper!   Always amazed by copper and its rustic shine but had never imagined a museum made of copper.  A big contrast is sculptures and decorations of fine details next to it, such as French vine sculpture.  There are also many trees surrounding the museum and they seem to be trimmed to unusual shapes to go with the place.  

A surprise from Bf was to bring me to the top of the tall tower as soon as we got inside.  We had a great view of Golden Gate Bridge and SF city and of course the museum area and Legion of Honor.

Inside were different exhibition rooms for American, African and Oceania arts.  Bf's most favorite was the room with murals of early California.  After a tour of their exhibitions, it seemed to me they host quite a big collection of tribal arts.  

We had lunch in the museum caf. Its design is as modern as the museum, with metal roof, tables and chairs.   We sat outside, bathing in the sunshine and enjoying the great view of the sculpture garden.  The sandwich was good and I still remembered their potato chips with olive oil. 

We have seen many people in the museum, couples, family with kids and tourists.  Wonder whether they would think the same, it's such a museum of creativities in architecture!   Or  creative works are for those who know what creation is about?
author: Ile F.

description:
The museum is amazing! The over all architecture and patina finish on the building is absolutely unique. I went for the first time since the much needed revamping of the museum several years ago. It took me several visits just to see everything in the museum! It's huge. Definitely try to get to the museum a bit early, on a weekend day is even better. 
I attended the Egyptian exhibit. It was a great experience, a little scary but well worth it! The artifacts that were found and preserved from these tombs were awesome! I also visited the De Young during the Vivienne Westwood exhibit which was incredible. Seeing all of her yearly works from the legendary "Let It Rock' shop in London to all of her original couture gowns and all of her amazing years of collections, so glad I got to see that!
author: Suzette R.

description: Just went to the Musee d'Orsay Post Impressionist show and did not get a chance to see the rest of the museum this trip.  The show was amazing and will be the only North American stop for this collection.  What a great chance to see these pieces!  The exhibit was very crowded even though I was there at 10:30 on a Thursday morning.  It was pretty easy  to get a chance to get up close to the pieces if you waited a little bit.  There were a few major paintings that I felt were shown in awkward spots that caused a bit of gridlock.  Overall though I thought the show was beautifully presented and I left on an art High!
author: stephanie l.

description:
WHAT A RIP OFF!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!1(*^#$(*@^$#*&#@^#@
The King Tut exhibit is the most disappointing exhibit I have ever seen. And I used to go to the Smithsonian numerous times a year. 
Through all the rooms you think, "Where are the artifacts from Tut?"
Most of the artifacts are wood or wood with a little gold foil or painted gold on top of it. Or they're made out of kind of precious stone. No precious stones or amulets. And I know there must have been them since the actual tomb remained unrobbed. There were only four artifacts in the exhibit from the actual tomb. There wasn't even a tomb. There was a projected image of it with kids climbing all over it. There wasn't even a video of the tomb. There was a video of COMPUTER GENERATED IMAGES of the tomb. 
The boards with little blips about what the room has in it...each said "The cause of death is still unknown." Talk about filler....
Once you exit the exhibit, there are pictures of the artifacts that you wish you'd seen. 
I cannot emphasize enough what a waste of money this was. It was worth maybe ten dollars (considering the shipping to get all of the tiny artifacts over here). 
As for the museum, I can't say I saw the rest of it. What I did see was the 5 or 6 shopping opportunities on my way out.
author: Anya F.

description: I have to agree with the underwhelming King Tut exhibit.  I also understand the need to divvy up entrance times in half-hour increments, but when groups are super-packed anyway, it was hard to move from room to room and see and enjoy the artifacts they had.  And yes, no sarcophagus--instead a hologram; I suppose I wouldn't have minded, but not at $30 a ticket with those kind of crowds.  My friends and I were under the impression there would be more based on the advertising and price; one person brought up how he went to the Frida Kahlo exhibit at MOMA and it was the best thing he'd ever seen for $18.  So, sorry, have to give this a 2-star rating.
author: M. H.

description: Great museum and always an interesting exhibit to see.
author: C. K.

description: This is simply a great museum with a fantastic location. For day trips it is perfect as you can check out all the fine art and then just stroll over to that California academy of Sciences. As for the museum itself, all the rooms are orderly and arranged in a manner that makes it simple to navigate from one area to the next - you basically walk in one big circle and see everything on each floor respectively. The do get some pretty amazing and notorious exhibits for display, so this is not by any means a run of the mill museum. I'm particularly fond of the more large scale contemporary pieces they have on display. My one regret is not having gone up into the tower they have on site, would have loved to do some HDR work from up top, but well ... maybe next time. Overall, I highly recommend visiting and doing so early in the day so you have time to see not only de Young but the Cal Academy and beautiful surrounding area.
author: Amik A.

description:
This new DeYoung Museum is, OK, by no means spectacular. Is it just me or is this place boring!? I remember the old DeYoung having way more offerings in regards to art, and natural sciences. Instead, this place has a hyper mish-mash of everything similar in one room, then, after you are done, ok rush into the next room, and lets smash everything together with no regard if it made sense.

The one thing I was impressed with was the glass sculpture exhibit, too bad it was in an awkward corner of the museum. On the second floor there was a total waste of space with photographs of people wearing red rain coats. Seriously, what is this? I did not understand any of it, was it supposed to be a recreation of a famous photographer, a social experiment on weirdness? I tried to understand it from reading the material, and I decided I was not going to spend any more time with it.

Sadly, the best art in my opinion was the Greek / Roman room, a tinsy itty bitty room with an impressive display of art. Equally impressive, was the Latin American art exhibit. I was thoroughly impressed with the highly important pieces they had in that display. The rest of the place is either a hit or miss, more hits than not. The rest is just superfluous filler.
author: Equis U.

description:
OH MY. THE CHIHULY EXHIBIT IS UNBELIEVABLE.

[if you haven't gone and seen chihuly, i highly recommend that you spend those fifteen bucks AND reserve your tickets. admittance into the chihuly exhibit is timed (per half hour), so be sure to pre-order tickets.]

Chihuly, unbelivable? of course. all that special lighting and dark arrangements inside adds to the mood. all that glass inside, it's amazing to see that everything is just... undefined. 

[loads of security hanging about to make sure you do not use that annoying flash on your camera and that you absolutely do not poke your finger beyond the marked boundary lines.]

anyway, as with the overall deyoung facilities, their permanent collections are pretty diverse, though, if you've been here multiple times the exhibits get a little redundant, but be sure to check all the non-permanent  exhibits, as they are wonderful works of art from all over the nation and world. 

for those who wish to visit the deyoung but not the collections, it's a simple trip to visit the sculpture gardens or the observation tower. [no admission fee necessary to visit the sculpture gardens and observation tower.]
author: Court L.

description:
3.5 for the Tut Exhibit

it was just okay... i expected a lot more, especially for the price you pay. luckily, i bought my tickets at costco for $30. AND it comes with the audio tour. 

the exhibit really lacked the "story" of Tut's life, his death, and then the discovery.  It seemed like a random mish mash of egyptian artifacts that they had on hand.  the lack of a story was so prevalent that one member of our group bought one of the many books on tut from the gift shop.  she said she wanted to learn more about his life and his death, things that the exhibit failed to do.

tips:
1. we went at 7:30pm on Saturday. BEST time to go. there was hardly anyone there.  we got to spend tons of time looking at each artifact up close and personal.

2. get the audio tour - the $32/ticket isn't worth it without getting to hear the background story behind the artifacts

3. buy your tickets at costco - for $30 you get entrance and the audio tour
author: Jessie H.

description: Took 13yr old on Tuesday. Waited about 1hr to see the King Tut exhibit and it was pretty dull. I've been to the Egyptian Museum in Cairo and it blows this small exhibit away. This exhibit did not even have the famous burial mask which was all I really wanted to see. If you are interested in Egyptian exhibits I recommed the small one in San Jose - way better than this one and a lot cheaper and way more interesting. As far as the rest of the Museum, pretty boring stuff. I love museums but it felt like De Young is just trying to fill space with any old junk.....Skip it, save the money, and just visit some of the smaller Museums around SF....
author: lee j.

description: I come here for the artifacts. I love to read about the ancient stuff- The African exhibit upstairs and the Mayan stuff downstairs. I can never get through it all here because there is so much to see. This museum never dissapoints.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Today i witnessed an event at the De Young Museum that was unacceptable.  It was raining and small children on a field trip were sitting on the floor outside of the cafe eating their lunch.  they were not allowed inside to sit in seats or able to go outside due to rain.  The security guard was rude as she was telling them not to leave crumbs, do not block any doors, and that they should not be eating there.  The children were not allowed to go anywhere else.  one class eventually had to leave the museum and return to school to eat their lunches. these children are on a field trip with their teachers and the museum did nothing to accomodate the rainy weather and 5 year olds who have not eaten since breakfast.  it was appauling.  as much as i understand the museum's circumstance, the staff was not accomodating and the security was just rude to the children and teachers in front of the parents and students.  i am embarrassed as this is an educational experience for the children and a poor reflection of the museum.  this type of treatment is unacceptable.
 
i never thought that the museum could be so non-child friendly.  i'm disgusted.
author: cindy n.

description:
I've been to the de Yong twice now, once to visit the permanent exhibits and once to check out the recent batch of special exhibits (Asian American Modern Art, YSL, and Maya Lin's exhibit). First, I have to say that the building itself is stunning. I go running regularly in Golden Gate Park and I always make it a point to go by the museum, especially at twilight when it's light up because it truly is an SF architectural gem. I've heard the view from the tower is great too; unfortunately I've only been when it's rainy/cloudy (actually by design, I like to be outdoors when it's nice out) so I haven't ventured up yet.

As for the exhibits, I'm really impressed by the quality and variety of the collections. I normally go for standard oil paintings, but the de Young's diverse collections (diverse both by region of the world and by medium of art) were a treat. From the permanent collection, the New Guinean sculptures were out of this world, and I can't imagine many other museums around the country having a similar exhibit to this extent - definitely a "must see". The African art exhibit was sort of a yawner; I was hoping for something more eye-catching. The exhibit on American paintings up to the 20th century is pretty solid and I especially liked the room dedicated to the Hudson River School of painters. 

Downstairs, there is an exhibit on modern American art that seems to rotate, because when I went I couldn't find any Hopper or Diego Rivera paintings, which I was really looking forward to. However, there is this really cool room displaying three sculptures by Al Folsom - each one is a different house of worship (cathedral, synagogue, and mosque) built exclusively out of war-related items (bullets, sub-machine guns, etc.) to highlight religion's connection with war. Conceptually, it's an easy shot at religion and a theme that's been explored ad nauseum, but nonetheless a must-see just for the sheer physicality of the exhibit.

As for the special exhibits I would HIGHLY recommend the one on Asian American modern art. I had a little trouble coming up with a unifying theme for the whole thing, but some of the paintings are worth the trip alone (my favourites included ones by Yun Gee, Chiura Obata and Chang Dai-Chen). If nothing else it is a good chronicle of the history of Asian-American art in the 20th century, with particular attention to the Bay Area.

The only downside is that the special exhibits cost an extra $10. Regular admission to the permanent collection is $10 but you can get a student discount with an ID ($6 admission) and a further $2 discount if you have a Muni pass. (Compare to $25 admission and long lines at the neighbouring California Academy of Sciences.)
author: Nicolas L.

description: When I went to see king tut. I went to see king tut not his aunt... Also not as nice as the hype was about it. Happy we did not get the audio walk through. It was kinda amusing though the crowd was being rushed around a bit but it didnt stop us from enjoying the exhibit. we took our time and just fell back with the next showing behind us.
author: George B.

description:
Went there to see the Chihuly Glass Exhibit, free parking on the street, a lovely new building, with a lot of space, and quite a varied collection of exhibits, with something interesting around every corner.

I didn't care for the band playing in the lobby, so one star deducted.
author: Eric H.

description:
Attention families with strollers:
I went to the de Young Museum today with my sister and baby. Yes, baby. I did not have anyone to watch him and did not want my sister who came in for the holidays to miss the Masters of Venice. I was a regular at this museum before I had my baby and believe it is beautiful, great viewing tower (on a clear day) and has wonderful exhibits. HOWEVER this time I was upset when I was not allowed to take my stroller into the exhibit. I have never heard of this, also NO WHERE on the website (which I have reviewed at length) says you are not allowed to bring strollers, it only asks you check oversized jogging strollers of which my stroller is NOT. So not family friendly. I feel bad writing this review since the museum manager did comp our tickets for today and I am grateful. I just want other parents to be aware strollers are not allowed in the exhibit. Even tough, I looked on line before going to the museum, spent all morning trying to get there, walked through a bag check with an employee who did not question the stroller, only to be told at the TICKET COUNTER strollers are not allowed and it has to be checked!!Sorry but this is not a family friendly policy!
I have posted the policy from the museum web page which does mention strollers but does NOT say they are NOT allowed in the exhibit only that SOME exhibits have restricted access, I guess they meant Masters of Venice. 

SEE Museum Policies on the de Young website as of 12/30/11

All parcels and bags are subject to inspection by security. Standard-size backpacks and strollers allowed. Bags larger than 8" h x 8" w x 5" d must be carried by hand. Some exhibitions have restricted stroller access.

Please check:

metal-framed backpacks
oversized packs and bags
long umbrellas
rollerblades and skateboards
Baby-carrier backpacks (unless convertible to the front) and oversized or jogging strollers
Bicycles can be secured at outside racks.

Shirt and shoes are required (no cleats or wheeled shoes).

Still photography allowed except in special exhibition galleries. No video, tripods, or flash photography.

Food and beverages allowed only in the Cafe and adjoining terrace.

City ordinance does not permit smoking in the museum or the park.

Please silence cell phones and pagers.

Only service animals are allowed in the museum.

Sketching for individuals with pencil on a small (9" x 12" or smaller) hand-held pad is allowed during public hours in the permanent collection. Sketching in special exhibition galleries is by permission only, subject to lender and gallery restrictions. Please read our sketching, photography, and painting rules/permit application for more information:
author: julie q.

description:
The tower view is OK - the ceilings are kind of low in parts so watch out.

The building itself is nice to look at, the shows not so much. I'm still disappointed with the lack of depth of the Vivianne Westwood show. Their treatment of her early work was especially sparse and one dimensional. It's nice to see them try so hard to reach out to younger audiences but they should explain why something is important and not just present it out of context. Because I'm so familiar with Westwood's career and especially her iconic pieces, it calls into question the way they're treating shows I don't know as much about. I haven't been back since - haven't written them off entirely because it was awesome that they tried at all...
author: Quartknee K.

description: The De Young is still 5 stars for me, guys. I went to see the Yves Saint Laurent exhibit last night, and I'm continuously impressed with how the museum manages to secure international fashion icon retrospectives here in San Francisco over New York or LA. The Vivienne Westwood show's only US stop was here at the De Young as well. I won't ponder anymore -- just bring on the haute couture, dahlings!
author: Nicole G.

description:
we came on the last weekend of the YSl exhibit and it was packed.  i didnt really care for it.  the exhibit was hard to follow since i didnt know which way it flowed and it was so crowded and a bit stinky.

the andy warhol exhibit though was great!  they had a ton of stuff.  of course his famous silkscreens. but also drawings, photos, record covers etc.

if you show your bank of america card on the first weekend of the month then general admission is free and the special exhibit admission is half off.
author: claudia y.

description: The grounds of this cultural campus are entertaining, exotic, and enlightening.  A free Friday night offered a crowded but relaxing music and drinks party atmosphere.  It is a different experience to wander the floors and galleries of the De Young at night accompanied by feel-good fiddle music.  No doubt a cup of mellowing wine before viewing and the presence of numerous baby strollers facilitated appreciative and well-behaved visitors.
author: Poet D.

description: We were fortunate enough to come to the DeYoung on free days and see the Tut exhibit for free as well before it left SF (thanks SL!) -   They have a lot of special programming that add to the already existing exhibits.  They have live music, and a great view on their 9th floor.
author: Nicole D.

description: FAMSF, if you're listening, I dropped our membership - who wants to go to a museum and leave brooding about your most recent bad experience. Seems like at least 75% of the time I go to the DeYoung, I end up leaving unhappy. The collection is fine and they have had some stunning special exhibits recently, but the visitor experience leaves a lot to be desired, especially if you have any kind of vision impairment (mild in my case). I have suggested multiple times that they need to make the large print booklets more available, but the number seems to diminish with each exhibit, so do they assume that just because you have a vision issue you are incapable of enjoying art? The Girl with the Pearl Earring had two booklets for the entire exhibit and if Rembrandt's Century had any, I couldn't find them. And one of the security guards  made me get in line to have my bag searched because I was standing near an exit door even though I had not left the museum and was arguing with another visitor while I waited. If you manage to offend that many people in such a short time you should not be in a position that requires interacting with the public. At least the Girl with the Pearl Earring exhibit was not ridiculously overcrowded as were the impressionist exhibits.
author: Cathy C.

description: Beautiful building right in the heart of Golden Gate park.  Saw the Tut exhibit today, and it was pretty good!  Saw an xray of a mummified baby....weird but cool.  Don't pay the extra $7 for the audio tour though...not really worth it.
author: Miss L.

description: I have been to the De Young on a few occasions. The first I couldn't really enjoy because I had a very sudden stomach attack and had to leave (damn that burrito!). The second was for the Vivienne Westwood exhibit which absolutely blew me away. And the third was for the YSL exhibit which blew me away even further! I was so impressed with both of them that I almost cleared out their entire souvenir area. Not really, I only bought a poster from each which are now framed and going on my walls but I wanted to purchase much, much more. Damn this economy. Damn my broke ass.
author: Julia N.

description: The art left a great impression but the crowds left a bad taste....
author: A. B.

description: This is a really great space. Lots of cool exhibits and located in Golden Gate Park.  What's really cool is to ride your bike here/in GGP and then come here to look at some art.  It'd be a fun Sat/Sun or really any day!
author: Ka C.

description: I miss the old De Young. Newer is not always better, though I can understand the need for retrofitting the building. There's something about the new galleries that I don't really like, but there are some definite wow factors here. I love the Goldsworthy piece that leads you into the museum, as well as the zen-like garden that flows alongside the stairs. But it's the tower that stands out (literally and figuratively). Next time I have visitors in from out of town, I'm taking them there. On a clear day you get the most amazing 360-degree view of San Francisco. It really is breathtaking.
author: Julie K.

description:
The museum itself is a 4-5 star experience. Following review is for the King Tut exhibit. 

King Tut = lots of hype, but not enough to back it up. But they sure have lots of crap for sale when you leave the exhibit! My friend saw it about two weeks ago in Barcelona and said they didn't have lots of stuff for sale there. I guess it's an American addition to the exhibit... To be fair, the exhibit was well-laid out and explained lots of stuff, which most people will need to read to know what they are seeing. There is also an audio thingie you can rent that tells you about it all. I've read mixed reviews from other cities about that part. It was nice that they had the explanatory plaques on each side of the boxes holding the art, so many people could read at once. My main quibble comes from the fact that I saw it at L.A.C.M.A. in Los Angeles 29 years ago and it was fabulous -- this time around it had less Tut and more context with stuff from his predecessors. No solid gold mummy mask like before -- WTF! Apparently, Egypt didn't want to loan more than they did -- they want you to go to Cairo to see it all. Still some very nice pieces to see if you've never been to the NY Metropolitan and other museums with good Egyptian collections. I paid member's price at $22.50 -- not worth more than that IMHO.
author: Dana B.

description:
REGARDING THE KING TUT EXHIBIT ONLY!

Terrible, terrible exhibit.  Contrary to other posts, the exhibit is NOT immense.   (Can you really classify any exhibit in the DeYoung as IMMENSE?)   For what they are advertising, the DeYoung should be fined for mis-leading the audience into what they are getting.  There is nothing at all special about this exhibit.   First of all they barely have any of the good stuff.  They barely have any exhibits at all, they have like 10 gallery rooms, but what you don't know is there's like only a few  items in each room.  In fact, one of the major pieces (mask) on posters all over town isn't even in the exhibit.  Many of the items aren't even from Tut's tomb.  The two major parts of the show aren't even exhibits, but videos about Tut and a projected image of the famous coffin (that can't travel anymore because of insurance reasons).    It was so cheesy and almost like an amusement ride.  I'm not wondering if it also wasn't just a big advert for National Geographic at the end.  From what I saw, the DeYoung should really be ashamed of themselves.  If you are a total nut for Egyptian art, I'm sure you'll love the show, how could you not, you love Egyptian art.  But if you are looking to attend a block-buster art show and have seen past Tut shows, you are going to be soooo disappointed.
author: Big Toe ..

description:
If you are local, the membership is worth it, $80. per year and you get in to all the special exhibits free, no need to buy advance tickets and you can bring a guest with you. I got my $$ worth in a few visits! I went to the Warhol, Bouquets to Arts and the Birth of Impressionism exhibits and never had to wait in line. Can also use the membership at the Legion of Honor. 

I enjoy the permanent collection very much, which is never as crowded as the special exhibits. The only time the crowd made me feel claustrophobic was at the Impressionism exhibit. The food at the cafe is quite good but a bit pricey.
author: Denise B.

description:
The de Young is one of my favorite places in the world. The Birth of Impressionism exhibit is one of my all-time favorite shows. I'm going to return on a weekday morning, try the audio  (only $6 with member discount), try to catch the docent tour.  My overall impression (ha!) was positive for the show; I was disappointed that some artists were not represented, but thrilled at the variety that was curated. Putting off any major criticism until the September companion show opens. 

We were four on Father's Day and enjoyed a minimal crowd at 11:00 a.m., no line to speak of in the cafe (portions are still way too small for the prices, but the food is still good quality), and saw the show in about 90 minutes. Next time, I'll spend at least two hours with it. 

Parking was $13.00, which seemed high, but we did catch the Sunday afternoon free concert in the park for a few minutes and took a walk, so that's our own fault.  On Sundays, it's best to use the garage here because the streets are especially congested and the street closings inside the park tip parking even more towards the neighborhood. 

Some comments have been made about the "no photo" policy and the security at the show. We thought the staff a bit militant, but one has to think of the special privileges FAMSF enjoys by being the only museum the Musée D'Orsay allowed to exhibit both this and the event beginning in September. Once through the cordons (and the "no bathroom, no exit" repeated warnings), it's all yours to enjoy. If people are not accustomed to toe-lines in front of paintings, well, what can I say?
author: joyce h.

description: The best thing is free.  Go, I say, to the above-the-trees lookout tower and check the panorama.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
first of all Golden Gate park is beautiful. you can spend the whole day there and always find something to do. whether it's visiting the Japanese Tea Garden or taking a stroll to the Academy of Sciences. right across from there is the De Young Museum. the fine arts museum of San Francisco. the building itself is organic yet modern. collection includes: american paintings, textiles, oceania, african, and americas decorative arts & crafts. 

i'm not very much into their collection but i know that they host pretty important exhibitions. i came here for the Yves Saint Laurent and Maya Lin (designed the Vietnam Veterans Memorial) exhibition. hurry.  because the YSL exhibition ends April 4! it's a must see. De Young is the only museum hosting YSL's collection in the US. when will you ever get to see the famous Modrian day dress? 

current exhibit: Warhol LIVE. $20. ends May 17. silk screens, music recordings, films, photographs inspired by music, the VELVET UNDERGROUND. i will be taking a trip to the bay area to see this. field trip anyone?
author: Marilu R.

description:
The DeYoung is awesome!  We've had memberships at different museums in the city at different times, and I have to say that the deYoung really gives you good "bang for your buck."  Plus, the FAMSF membership also gives you free access to the Legion of Honor, and you don't have to pay extra to see the special exhibits.  

The special exhibits are always SPECTACULAR.  They are interesting and curated beautifully with fantastic lighting, etc.  I usually get the headsets for the special exhibits as well - it's worth the few extra dollars as the recorded content is always informative, and I prefer listening while looking at the art, rather than reading the little exhibit signs.    

The permanent collection is a little haphazard, and the flow from one exhibit to the next can be a little funky the way it sometimes jumps  continents and eras, but for the space they have and how they've used it, I've got to give them props.

The deYoung's outreach to the community is stellar with tons of interesting and FREE stuff offered.  Friday Nites at the DeYoung are a ton of fun.  And they also do concert series with great local acts.   Plus, if you have kids, they offer lots of free Saturday and after school classes and events that bring even the youngest of art lovers into the fold. (Be sure to check out the Youth Arts Festival every May - it's incredible!)
author: amy b.

description:
Update 5/11/08

For Mother's Day (for my wife, Susie, and her mom Glo) we arranged a trip to the de Young following a nice breakfast at Park Chow and a stroll thru the Strybring Arboretum.. It was a big hit with Glo.. She has not been particularly happy here in the Bay Area after moving up from San Diego last year.. but her Bay Area loving son, daughter, and son-in-law.. continue their campaign to make her love it eventually..

Anyway two additional items I'd like to note: 

(1.) They have a room of oil portraits by early American artists.. Benjamin West, Charles Wilson Peale, John Singleton Copley.. from the colonial times.. and the neat thing is that these portraits are just hanging on the wall.. not behind glass or set back out of reach. You can gaze at them from afar (meh) or you can get right up next to them.. your face inches from the canvas and observe how they applied their brush strokes to the canvas to try and capture so-and-so's five O'clock shadow.. or so-and-so's gleaming eyes, or so-and-so's delicately formed lips.. and when you get this close and observe so closely, it almost *seems* as if you are actually getting a notion about how those painters must have felt at that instant, applying a little white, just here.. to try to capture that gleam, or shading their subject's lip just so.. almost as if you *are* them.. gazing at their subject's face and trying to capture the elusive detail that will convey who that person is.. And so it is that Charles Wilson Peale.. though long dead.. and perhaps quite accidentally.. managed to sort of capture the likeness of some Naval personality name "Mordecai Grist" .. but more than that conveyed *to you* what he was seeing and observing and even feeling at the moment he applied that stroke to the canvas.. over 200 years ago..
(2.) It is refreshing to listen to the tourists.. especially the foreign tourists.. enjoying the striking views from the observation deck atop the tower.. and asking the employees what was the name of this beautiful park that surrounds them... Yep.. 'Frisco.. whatever its contradictions, whatever its pretense, whatever foolishness and pettiness its residents might often be guilty of is still a very notably beautiful, friendly, and celebratory place to experience. And we are lucky to live so close.
(3.) If you *are* in the museum, and the munchies strike *really* hard before you're finished with your visit.. the alternative to the 10 - 11 dollar prepackaged sandwiches and salads.. is a vendor's cart just outside the museum at the corner of John F Kennedy Drive..and Tea Garden Way.. Just keep your visitor's sticker on and you can wander in and out of the exhibits or the museum itself as you so desire.

==original review===============

I feel a little like Rip Van Winkle. Wandering up from San Jose.. like I do periodically and coming upon the metal-sheathed *new* de Young after oh decades and decades of being used to seeing the old de Young.. (and the *old* California Academy of Sciences) situated around the concourse and bandshell.. and now everything is different .. or different enough that I wasn't too sure which direction I was walking!

Well, the changes- as radical as they are work well. The building, of course is striking.. memorable.. the outside gardens and sculptures are inviting and playful. The viewing deck atop the tower gives you some wonderous views of the surrounding park and parts of the city beyond. The rooms for the exhibits are much airier and much less cramped than before.. Maybe part of that is just having the Asian Art collection, whose prominence always seemed to dwarf everything else, moved out, across town, in its own building, leaving more room for everything else.. and.. uhm.. high ceilings!! seems to make a difference..Oh  the $10 regular admission fee is quite reasonable these days.. although the *free* parts.. the outside courtyard, sculptures and gardens.. The inside lobby and some exhibition rooms are worth the visit in themselves.

The one caveat I would throw in.. you *might* want to handle your *hunger* issues before hand.. mebe have a nice picnic or something in the surrounding park before you enter the building. If hunger strikes during your visit.. you will find yourself munching on $6.50 cups of potato salad, $10 pre-packaged sandwiches and lettuce salads, $11!!!! Vietnamese banh mi sandwiches ($2.75 at any Vietnamese sandwich shop in San Jo).. Lunch at the Museum costing more than the ticket itself.
author: Weide Z.

description: Are you kidding me!? $13K to just rent the place and I can't start my wedding here til 6:30!? Forget it!
author: Denise L.

description: If you or anyone you know purchased a membership to obtain free tickets to the two impressionism exhibits (Pre-Impressionism in early 2010 and Van Gogh late 2010) and were unable to obtain the free tickets or had to pay for tickets that were supposed to be free, please contact Flo Samuels at flosamuels@msn.com. I believe that the museum's advertising does not meet the truth-in-advertising standards and any monies paid for tickets might be legally refundable to the purchaser. I have complained to the San Francisco District Attorney Consumer Protection. More complaints will support my contention that many of us were outright scammed.
author: Flo S.

description: I enjoyed the viewing tower the most, but nothing really stood out for me. I didn't have enough for the Tut exhibit, so that might explain my rating. The layout for the rest of the museum seemed scattered. On the first floor, there are lots to see on the right hand side. Then, on the left closer the cafetaria, there is so much wasted space. Upstairs, there was so much African and Asian art that was a little creepy, but interesting.
author: Susan D.

description:
A sister museum of the Legion of Honor, this place is simply great! It has its own charm I suppose. More artifacts, more diverse collection while the Legion has more paintings. 

More American and Contemporary Art, Native American, Art of Africa, Oceania, Textiles, Photography. 

Now, to my personal fave? 
-Native American, Africans, Oceania, New Guinea, Textiles.

If you can, check out "the Mermaid" & Judith Schaechter's "Resurrwreckage" it was a trip! It's right before you go upstairs to the African Art section.

If you are into Fashion, Textiles great--Nan Kempner "American Chic" From all the famous designers (Dior, Missoni, Ungaro, Ferre, Valentino, Yves St Laurent) 

You can also check out a partial 360 view of SF on the 9th floor @ the observation floor, not like an aerial view, but a decent view, hm, mini version of Twin Peaks, but Twin Peaks is byfar better. 

You only get to see the 2 tips of the Golden Gate Bridge. It's free, so check it out.

Tower hours: Tues-Sun 9:30-4:30, Fri 9:30-8pm 

You can also check out this Japanese Tea Garden, a conservatory of flowers, & the SF Botanical Garden as you walk out the de Young. 

You're better off in going to the Huntington Library for the Japanese Tea Garden in Pasadena (read my review if you're curious!)
author: Jennifer S.

description: The featured exhibits are always good. While I believe in paying for art and being supportive, I feel like admission is a little bit too expensive. You might want to go on the free day first, if this is your first trip to a museum.
author: Ramon E.

description: Love the location and the layout and design of this place.  Love it even more on the first Tuesday of the month 'cuz its free!  And loved seeing and learning more about the crazy life and works of Andy Warhol.  But I think that's where my love for this place stops.  Unfortunately, some of the exhibits cost extra money and even though I thoroughly enjoyed Andy Warhol, I found the Yves St. Laurent exhibit to be incredibly disappointing.  As for the rest of the museum, I didn't find it particularly attention holding (perhaps because the last museums I visited  were world famous such as the Louvre and the Reina Sophia, which really are no comparison).  Great for a sunny afternoon visit when you can also take a stroll through the park (it was raining, therefore I did not), but I do regret taking a day off of work for something I could have easily breezed through on a weekend.
author: laura q.

description: Saw the Chihuly exhibit yesterday which is truly beautiful. One of the guards said they have 20K people coming through each day of the weekend. Thus my strong advice is to avoid the place on weekends; with that dense of a crowd it's only a matter of time before someone goes postal in one of those dark rooms full of glass. Truly spectacular though.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: OK,   yeah it might look like the rebel base on Yavin IV but it's twice as cool!  The exhibits are soooo kick ass and if you go on certain days you don't have to pay !  Sweet!  Arrive early and park on the street. The photography gestapo (small old Asian women) will chase you if you attempt to use your camera. I always wear my running shoes and wear a couple of different colored shirts as disguises to throw them off. I mean... they're old, they can't keep up, and their eyesight is lacking. So picture taking was a "snap" Har Har !
author: Mark B.

description: I love the de Young but will never pay to go to a special exhibit again.  I recently treated myself to a Thursday afternoon at the museum and the D' Orsay show.  The show was so over sold that the entire gallery was packed liked a sardine can.  One could hardly move and it was stifling hot.  It was nearly impossible to get close to see any painting with out having to elbow someone out of the way.  I'd be willing to pay a bit more if they allowed half the number of visitors in at a time. Otherwise, don't bother because you'll barely see the art. And if you're in a wheelchair, think twice because you will be doubly challenged to get around.  It did leave the rest of the museum nearly empty and I had a wonderful time visiting the permanent collection.
author: Margott W.

description:
Great museum and introduction to various arts from around the world to our young daughters and us, although a few creepy masks of the Papua New Guinea collection could be a little scary for a 2 year-old at times :-)
Listed as the 4th most visited museums nationally according to Wikipedia, it is worth visiting to get a glimpse into
- African art
- American fine arts and painting, modern art
- Oceanic art with some impressive murals

Plus: Hooray, they don't charge the general admission fee for kids younger than 12!
Minus: Driving round and round before findind a parking space in the underground parking. Perhaps due to the crowd on that first day of the Impressionism exibition
author: Roger L.

description: Love the observatory tower!  Great place to bring a date or folks from out of town to see the FULL city.  I also like their sculpture garden outside.  The exhibits are strong, but I'm not as big of a fan for large museums-- their special exhibitions have all been worth going to-- always amazing.
author: Tina C.

description:
Would like to go see how museum looks like when there is no king TUT exhibit.

TUT exhibit was OK but I had higher expectations. After coming out  I had the same feeling I have when I come out of IKEA. Too much walking through a long winding maze for too little gain. Should we call it the "mouse in the maze" syndrome?

The highlight of my day was Observation Deck view and the Asian shrimp salad in the museum cafe.
author: Floating R.

description: I'm a huge fan of museums and I loved this one. I went there to see the Tutankhamen exhibit because Egyptian history is extremely fascinating. My favorite thing in this museum was The Jolika Collection of New Guinea Art. I never knew much about that neck of the woods but they carved some really neat figures and masks out of wood. I liked one so much it has been the background of my phone for about 6 months. There is also a really neat piece that was a big church made entirely out of gun parts and bullets. It was really cool. The museum was awesome and I would recommend it to anyone sight seeing in the area.
author: Tony S.

description:
Look.

I'll admit that there is for sure a level of false advertising present with the Tut exhibit. Yes, there is a giant gold mask on all the posters, and, no, there is no such mask anywhere in the exhibit. 

But I honestly find it rather shallow that because that one piece isn't there, everyone seems to be able to write of the exhibit as "awful" and a "letdown."

I just think its kind of sad that people can't get past whatever initial disappointment they may feel to see and appreciate what a great exhibit the DeYoung is presenting with their Tut collection. Yeah, none of the iconic pieces usually associated with Tut are there - as people have mentioned, the mummies, sarcophagus, and mask can't leave Cairo. But, clearly, those aren't the only things that Tut had. 

The exhibit is IMMENSE, and full of beautiful artifacts from all facets of Tut's life. When you look at those pieces and recognize that they sat in a tomb for thousands of years, and before that were touched and used by people who lived thousands of miles away - literally, were used and touched by King Tut himself - how can you not appreciate how amazing the exhibit is? 

So get over it - the sarcophagus isn't there. Instead, just enjoy the pieces for what they are, an extraordinary glimpse into Ancient Egypt. Ancient-freaking-Egypt, people.

And if you can't appreciate how awesome that is, then honestly I don't feel much sympathy that you didn't enjoy the exhibit. 

That ALL being said, definitely go after 4:30, because otherwise you'll be craning your neck over people crowded around the pieces, or else hearing obnoxious people asking where the sarcophagus is and then grumbling about how the exhibit is a "sham." I heard that at one point while I was in the exhibit. We were surrounded by about a zillion pieces of glittering gold that came out of an Ancient Egyptian tomb. I just laughed.
author: Isabel S.

description: The King Tutankamun exhibit was amazing!!!! It was amazing and worth the price of the ticket!
author: Lynn C.

description:
I love it when I can go places for free.  My sister is a member here, and while I was in town over the weekend I poked my head in.  I actually like the building (I've been a fan of Herzog & de Meuron since they designed the Walker Art Center expansion in my native MPLS), though it is a little out of place in the park.  At least, it does very few favors for the nearby bandshell.  The observation deck in the tower has some very impressive views of the city in all directions.
But it's an art museum, so on to the art:  I really enjoyed the native art and the American painting.  I would have liked to see slightly more European and Asian art, but that's just my own personal taste.  The collection they have is quite impressive, and could easily take up a full afternoon to appreciate it all.  I didn't get a chance to see the sculpture garden, and I wish I had, because what I could see from the second floor wall of windows above the cafe area looked like I would have really enjoyed it.  A recommended stop for anyone traveling through Golden Gate Park with a few hours to spare.
author: Kevin M.

description:
I went here for the first time a couple of weeks ago.  When I lived in the Inner Richmond the museum was being renovated thus the long delay in visiting this forum.  I'm kicking myself for not going sooner.  We chose the time based on the exhibit by Hishiro Sugimoto who is a world renowned photographer and noted Japanese National Treasure.  How one obtains this status is beyond me...

Nevertheless, we meandered around the museum through different exhibits while waiting for the docent tour of the exhibition to start.  I have to admit that of the many different salons we observed the least inspiring was the African art.  It seemed out of place with the rest of the exhibits.  I'm no art historian but after recently visiting the Louvre I was very impressed with the collections, the space and the presentation of the works here save for the African art.  

The highlight of our visit was the trip to the observation deck.  From the 8th floor of this annex to the museum you get an unobstructed view of the Golden Gate Bridge and a panoramic view of San Francisco.  It was breathtaking watching the fog roll in and then turning 90degrees to see the downtown area clear as a bell.  Another thrilling aspect to the observation deck that was the ability to admire the artistic flair with which the botanical gardens surrounding the museum were put together.  From up above, the gardens evoked a spirit of calm and soothing and serenity so much so that I drifted off for a few moments in imagination with these thoughts....
***
She sits on the bench among the array of pristine violet, blue and yellow.  The surroundings are the best that nature puts forth at the height of springtime.  The scent of florals is in the air magically blanketing her as she brushes her dark colored bangs away from her deep brown eyes.  I walk towards her on the pebble laden path lithely plucking one of the floral creations.  I hand it to her, initially she recoils slightly at the notion that I caused detriment to such a serene setting and then the import of the gesture hits her with full force and I am forgiven in an instant by the gentle smile and captivating look that telegraphs mutual caring. 
***
Visit the De Young and see what aspect moves you.
author: Richard R.

description:
During it's evolving construction I absolutely hated every aspect of this museum. The entire concept of a copper You Sunk My Battleship just didn't mesh with the natural, established beauty of Golden Gate Park. It's proportions seemed Kong-like, where only a chimp was required. The monolithic tower's height made trees seem insignificant. There was a new bully on the block, or in the park rather. When construction was complete, there was the copper aircraft carrier in all it's glory. I knew that someday I would be forced to make my peace with "Rusto." Well good news, the de Young and I have kissed and made up. I'm happy to say that the de Young is a marvel of architecture successfully complimenting the collections in a way that MOMA just can't. Where MOMA's architecture directly competes with the exhibits, the de Young partners with it's collections. The rich woods assist displaying most of the art, particularly the African and New Guinea displays. The length of the museum spreads the crowds out more, creating better viewing space. There are varying room sizes too, providing different views and settings for the art. Nice! 

There's so much to see. The 900 plus foot Gerhardt Richter mural that demands to be seen the minute one enters the museum. Joan Mitchell, the female Pollack minus the magnitude of controlled disaster. The Tromp L'Oeil room. Karen Ontes "Dress 3." Imogen Cunningham's photographs. And of course no museum is complete without a hint of Hockney somewhere. The Ruth Asawa collection is fabulous.y stunning!! One starts to look at the copper mesh mobiles believing them to be simple, but then recognizes pre computer graphics designs and shapes. The Osher Sculpture Garden is a great place to take tea, or have a bite.

One funky thing, there aren't enough signs to assist the public. Two examples, a guard kept running around the Asawa exhibit telling people they couldn't take photos. Signage would have helped. There is no sign telling people the cafe closes at 4:15 sharp, leaving staff frazzled after having explained kabillion times that they're closed. 

Well worth the price of admission. First Tuesday of every month is free. Fab date place.
author: Johnny C.

description: Apparently, today I give everyone five stars.  Perhaps, it's the copious amount of candy I've eaten today, but I love the DeYoung Museum.  My husband and I are members.  I like being a member of something.  They invite me to cool parties on Friday nights, which are not in my honor, but I pretend that they are.
author: Bert M.

description: Now this place is an awesome structure outside but inside lacks architecture; but does however fill its walls with art. LOL So I guess that evens things out at this place. The tower has okay views but not worth it either. For some reason you get better views at some of the downtown hotels. LOL If you don't mind paying a lot for street parking/towed or in the underground parking structure that charges so go ahead and risk paying at least an average of $40 bucks per adult when considering parking/hours/admissions and etc. There is other things like BofA card holders and memberships to this place but I will leave that to others to Yelp about it :)
author: Michael H.

description:
De Young, so, I know that maybe your problem is the fact that you don't have much decent competition around, being that only SFMOMA is here to give you a run for your money, but man, you pretty much suck.  I love art.  I do.  And when the building is constantly the center of attention, you've pretty much failed at your main goal of displaying art and letting ti speak for itself.  The Guggenheim in New York is the only place I've ever seen that is more guilty of this than you.  You have rooms inside that are tiny--something like 10-12 feet wide and paintings on those walls that require you to stand at a distance to take it all in, but I just can without standing in a doorway.  Room after tiny room I start wondering if you were crunched for space, but then I walk into this MASSIVE lobby with MASSIVE stairs that lead up to some random boring chair exhibit that is displayed in narrow, claustrophobic hallway.

So, De Young, you get two stars because you have a great sculpture garden with a Claes Oldenburg and some other neat stuff.  Also, you've got several Wayne Thiebauds, including gumballs and San Francisco landscapes, so, for that, you don't completely suck. 

Your building is ugly, your parking is expensive, you staff is not knowledgeable, and the park areas surrounding your building are more interesting than you.
author: Josh Z.

description:
This review is for Chihuly rather than the De Young overall, which would only get 4 stars for their lack of background information and context for a lot of their interesting (and cool!) pieces.

But, as for Chihuly, I really only have one word: WIZARD!!

I'm pretty sure that he's like Mad-Eye Moody from Harry Potter, and when he takes off his eye patch he makes magic happen with glass!!!

**As a disclaimer, I have no idea what Chihuly's story is, and I hope something terribly didn't really happen to his eye that would make my above statement incredibly gauche and offensive.

But, in short, WIZARD!
author: Natalie M.

description: Beautifully designed museum in a great location. Be sure to check out the observation tower on a clear day. The view shows a great cross section of the city.
author: ryan c.

description:
Huh ??? Museum ? The permanent exhibits are boring !!! 
However, the King Tut exhibit that's going on right now is well worth your time and money. We went on a Wednesday afternoon, Tut at Twilight costs only $20 per ticket (until Ticketmaster adds its own charges - but that's another story), and is only on Wednesday nights. The Tut exhibit is superb. You have to go to the observatory. On a clear day, you get a 360 degree view of the city. Tickets to the Tut exhibit, allow you to visit DeYoung and Legion of Honor for 3 days following your Tut visit, which is cool ! However, I would just go to Legion of Honor. The rest of DeYoung is terribly boring, probably only the San Jose Tech Museum is more boring.
author: Rasta K.

description: I wish this were better than it is.  The online member site is impossible to use (do Not join this museum and expect to be able to get your free member tickets online with any ease at all!) and the parking is just miserable.  Until they improve these two items, I cannot recommend this place to anyone.
author: Kitty R.

description:
This is for the King Tut Exhibit.

We were excited to see the exhibit and went at the 4:30 showing on a Saturday afternoon. Although the artifacts were incredible to view, the entire experience was ultimately disappointing. There were way too many tickets sold per each time slot, and so you had to wait in long lines for absolutely every thing. We waited in line over 30mins just to get into the exhibit, went downstairs & were herded into another long line before getting through the exhibit doors. Then the packed us like cattle into a small stuffy room for the introduction before seeing the exhibit. You had to wait in more long lines before getting to view each glass case, and there were so many people crammed into each room you were constantly getting bumped into or your view blocked. It almost seemed unsafe, and it took nearly 2hrs to view the whole exhibit which is supposed to be done in a 1hr time slot. We were exhausted and disappointed by the time we left, because the crowding took away so much of the enjoyment of the exhibit. I understand the museum wanting to make money & accommodate as many people as possible, but this event was completely oversold.
author: Jameela G.

description:
This is solely based on the CHICANO exhibit.
I *heart* Cheech Marin for this... not that i don't love me some cheech
This exhibit blew my mind and it was awesome to see all the tourists really getting into the subject matter. I think that was the best part for me was watching the Anglo reaction to a very empowering discussion about race, ethnicity, hegemony, integration, and pride. It was a very positive twist on what it means to be a "Chicano" in California and in the U.S. I especially liked the bouncing low-riders and the video about low-rider culture. That was so cool to watch old white ladies playing with them. My favorite portion of the exhibit were two things. The video on "Rasquecho" because that IS my family! And the painting on the Zoot Suit riots b/c that is a very neglected and overlooked event in our history and the repercussions of those riots are still felt today, especially in L.A. 
I am thrilled that I got to check it out again before it closed yesterday! 
De Young you did good!!!
Can I work for you????
author: o. c.

description: My favorite part of the museum is the modern art exhibit. I don't care much for the Hudson School exhibit which is really large and tiresome. It is boring and not challenging art. I call it grandmother's art. It is a very busy museum and hard to find parking.
author: N G.

description: Amazing museum! A great permanent collection, wonderful special exhibitions, housed in a fantastic building. This is definitely at the top of the list for entertaining out-of-town guests.
author: Jim T.

description: The permanent collection is wonderful - the King Tut exhibit, however is a complete ripoff. I guess if you've never seen any Egyptian art before it might be worth the crazy expensive price tag and the crowds, but if you've seen any of the permanent collection at the Met in NY or museums in the UK, this is a very polished display of a few Egyptian artifacts, nicely packaged to attract the tourist sect. Definitely skip it, see the rest of the museum instead. King Tut ripped me off.
author: G G.

description: I went here to see the Yves St. Laurent and Mya LIn exhibits. First of all, I loved the location. It is so beautiful there in the park and right across from the Academy of Sciences (which I have YET to experience..darn busy schedule). The exhibits were great and we especially loved the Mya Lin one. I can only give three stars because we didn't get a chance to check everything out. I will for sure be back again. It was a lot of fun, especially on a beautiful day. I've heard that it's not so great on a rainy one. You may want to keep that in mind.  =)
author: danae k.

description: Hot damn, I give this place 5 red-hot stars. The architecture is breathtaking and thought has been put into the smallest of details here. The collection is solid and unique with amazing exhibits like Jasper Johns collection of prints. The Oceana exhibit is unlike anything I have ever seen, so mystical and haunting, the word sublime can't describe it. I'm definitely coming back to check out the observation tower that looks like something out of Jurassic Park. It was jam packed with people when I was there, but that's just a testament of how amazing this place is.
author: Michael E.

description: My mother and I went to the King Tut exhibition for her 60th birthday celebration. Overall, I was impressed with the exhibit but yes I knew that King Tut himself is NOT at the museum. He is currently entombed (again) in the Valley of Kings in Egypt. I would recommend the audio tour ($7). The audio tour enhances the exhibit and gives you a nice crash course into the life and times of Egypt as experienced by Tut and his relatives. I was also impressed by the artifacts on display at the museum. Overall, a great way to spend the afternoon. Parking was not an issue and the cafe was surprisingly delicious.
author: Paul A.

description:
i agree totally with emily s. in that de young is one of the most boring museums that i've paid money to see, though it strikes a nostalgic chord in me due to yearly parochial middle school field trips to the damn place.

granted, the observation deck is absolutely stunning. the interior is awesome. and though i am beyond excited for maya lin's upcoming "systematic landscapes" exhibit and was thrilled to see dale chihuly's work recently, i still feel ambivalence for the new museum. 

yes, i love the science behind the seismic "retrofitting" and its unique engineering of a system of ball bearings and dampers to absorb energy and convert it to heat, an underground moat, and cables and pulleys to avoid overtwisting. 

HOWEVER, the design aesthetic still doesn't agree with me. i read somewhere that the copper casing was designed "to replicate the impression made by light filtering through a tree canopy". umm, no. it looks more like giant speakers made into a jungle gym. like a prettied up version of sf zoo's lion exhibit. i also read that the final outcome of the design had to do with climate and and safety control, but it's a shame that a beautiful building (you can tell when you actually enter) is encased in military tank-like ugliness.

2.7 stars.
author: Vanessa D.

description: Gorgeous.  It's very hard for me to let go of things, so even though I "knew" it was best to demolish the old De Young Museum, I still didn't want to see it go.  Fast forward to present day and I'm so glad that they did.  This new museum is absolutely stunning.  I love the observatory deck, the magnificent garden on the east side of the building, new cafe and everything that they've done with the space.
author: Christie X.

description: The observation tower is great to watch the Blue Angels and see views of San Francisco. The artwork and history from many countries expanding the globe are amazing to look at, study, and appreciate. The artwork and history come mainly from the American continents, the African continent, and Oceanic. The place is family-friendly. They have a restaurant and a book store.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: The De Young Museum's observation tower is my favorite place to go for a perfect view of San Francisco. Go there. Especially if it's a clear day...go...now...
author: meagan m.

description:
Love the art, HATE the building.
While the interior is a clear improvement over its predecessor, that is more a factor of space than anything else. 
It would have worked in a parking garage (which is what the concrete inside feels like).
As a neighbor and regular Park visitor (2-3 times a week) and occasional/rare DYM visitor (1-2 times a year) I have to look at this overwhelming, wall-like tower every time I go into GGP. (I guess San Francisco doesn't have enough views so they had to build this hideous one)
It will always symbolize to me the bullies who lied again and again about their plans, who lied about the effect of closing the park to cars on Saturdays (the attendence actually went up on Sundays when the Park was closed to cars), who promised to preserve the pedestrian tunnels and then destroyed them at first opportunity, who promised an exterior entrance to their parking garage and then tried to change the plans (and were only stopped in court).
This was a prime example of how money rules politics even in this progressive city.
I'll go back to see shows I want (like the present show of Chicano art) but otherwise I'll avoid this beast and go to one of the other many museums in San Francisco.
Fortunately, I have friends who are members so at least I won't be giving them my money.
author: Stannous F.

description: 3 stars for the King Tut exhibit itself.  Waited in line for almost an hour and was disappointed with the lack of artifacts from King Tut's tomb itself.  The exhibit was smaller than I expected and did not have any bodies (I should have read yelp reviews before I went because I was looking forward to this part).  The freakiest part was the tomb of his stillborn child of 5 months and the coffinette of his liver.  Not worth the ridiculous line $30+ to see overall though.
author: Saha N.

description: Took my 3 1/2 year old son yesterday and was really impressed! Beautiful architecture, great views of SF from the tower, lots of interesting art for kids, yummy (although pricey) cafe, and even on their free 1st Tues of the Month--it wasn't crowded.
author: Preston S.

description: Okay, culture-vultures, I haven't been to the Louvre yet, but I still know a thing or two about art.  The one thing I liked about this museum was the view from the observation deck.  And yes, I did like the architecture, but I found it to be grossly out of place in Golden Gate Park.  I found the former De Young's architecture to be more in keeping with the beauty of the park.  I couldn't help thinking that this tall structure was like a big middle finger sticking it to the park and surrounding neighborhood.  The cavernous space inside seemed way too big for most of the installations, and finding one's way around was a bit of a challenge.  All in all, I thought the installations were pretty boring.  They pretty much paled in comparison to the real beauty of Golden Gate Park outside.  My biggest gripe with this place, though, was the unbelievable rudeness of the security people or staff or whatever the heck they were.  They made a deal about the stroller, then they made a deal about putting my daughter on my shoulders.  They weren't nice about it, either.  The cashier who gave us a ticket looked like she had been sucking on lemons, and had the sour personality to match.  When did it become fashionable to be rude to customers?  Do they take lessons from all the reality shows on TV now, where the meaner you are, the more people admire you?  I love this city and I love this park, but for museums, I would take the Legion of Honor in San Francisco, the Met in New York or the Art Institute of Chicago any day over this one!
author: Norm G.

description: Go see the GAULTIER exhibit.  It is terrific.  The pieces are stunning and the curation is so innovative and compelling without detracting from the artwork.  The ticket sales folks are a bit curt, but worth enduring to see the show.
author: S M.

description:
Whoever manages this museum has no idea how to manage ticketing or crowds, especially when hosting a visiting exhibition. 

If you walked in from the street for the Van Gogh, Gauguin, and Cezanne exhibition there was a line just to get into the building. Then, once inside, there were separate ticketing lines for members, non-members, will-call, the first of two exhibition staging areas, and audio tours. But they were all in the same lobby, so there was lots of confusion as to which line to get in.
