That's because there was no one telling you where to go, hardly any signage, and they didn't have any of those soft barriers (i.e., stanchions, like those for airport check-in lines) to control/guide the thongs of people trying to get tickets. And it wasn't until you got close to the ticket desks that you could see a small sign saying the exhibition tickets were already sold out. Also, if you want coat check, you have to take an elevator downstairs and then come back upstairs to access either the permanent collection or the first exhibition staging area. 

If you walked in from the adjacent garage, you would almost immediately find a line for the exhibition, but unfortunately, it is just the second staging area, so you still have to go up to the lobby and join the chaos up there. 

What they really need to do is install a lot of ticketing windows at the front of the building and where you come in from the garage, install permanent stanchions to control/guide guests, put up more signage (and multi-lingual signage), and add a coat check service in the lobby.
author: P B.

description: In the interest of full disclosure, I must say up front that my boyfriend is a manager with the catering company which means that when I go to Friday nights at the De Young, I get free booze. And free booze makes EVERYTHING better. But even without the free alcohol, I would still think this is a great way to start the weekend. There's always live music and interesting displays and events (like fashion shows) in the lobby area. Even if you don't pay for admission, the lobby area is free and is usually a blast. Plus the mix of people is truly bizarre -- middle aged people mixing with young hipsters mixing with parents and kids mixing with artsy types. I have never had a bad time when I went here -- even on the one occasion when I had to buy my own drinks.
author: Rebecca H.

description: The new DeYoung bulding is beautiful. It is an amazing piece of art in itself. Actually, I have to admit that I like the building more than the exhibits inside. The view from the tower is great and allows you to appreciate the landscaping around the museum so much more.  The cast/blown glass exhibit is worth checking out and the artifacts from Oceania and Africa are very interesting as well.
author: Maria V.

description: This San Francisco landmark is one of my favorite places to visit because of the location and the odd pieces that live outside the museum walls. I think the best attraction is the not to well known sound installation located in the rear of the musuem. This place is very cool if you feel like blowing a day or just want to see some artwork. Most definitely recommended.
author: J B.

description:
Even though I took an art-writing crash course during my briefest of days in journalism school, I find it hard to put to paper what I see hanging from a wall at a museum.  I mean, a painting/installation/sculpture is worth a thousand words, you know?

Museums themselves are perhaps equally difficult to describe, but let me give it a go, starting from the outside and working my way in:

The parking garage at the De Young is confusing.  It's easy to find the entrance from Fulton, but easier still to lose your car once you're inside.

The grove of dead trees out front?  Dead.

The cracked-stone walkway, and large, bench-like rocks, on your way in?  Sit on the rocks if you need a rest, and contemplate the meaning of the cracks.

Once inside, things start to look up---and out, and over San Francisco.  Head up to the tower and spend as long as you wish checking out the spectacular (assuming the day is fog-free) 360-degree views of the city; it's also endless fun to look at the Google map on the inner wall, and locate your apartment and the apartments of every one you've ever had a crush on.

Back down in the main museum rooms, the modern art and photography, etc., isn't exactly overwhelming in number.  Or in "Wow."  But it's worth a walk through---as is the cafe, on your way back out into the world to find fresh air and non-museum cafe grub.  And make sure that once you get far enough away from the building, you turn around and pause for a second to appreciate the architecture that is really the De Young's crowning glory (Speaking of crowns, what will happen to that copper siding?  Will it oxidize green, like the Statue of Liberty?).
author: Hannah J.

description:
ok.  so, rainy sundays are generally NOT the best days to go to any museum.  factor in the main thoroughfare through GGP being closed on sundays (which hugely impacts parking and accessibility) and then throw in a somewhat newly opened Academy of Sciences across the way with a mile-long line of impatient screaming children and about-to-lose-it parents and you get a long wet walk from the car to the museum and then the realization of why are there so many children under 5 in an art museum?  DESPERATE PARENTS.  oy.

as excited as i was to bypass any sort of line AT ALL to get into this deal, it did make me rather suspicious.  no line?  at all?  it gives you the same feeling of WHAT DON'T I KNOW??!? that comes over you when you sit down to eat in an empty restaurant.  with caution.

anyhoo, mandatory security search, mandatory plastic umbrella bags, followed by mandatory umbrella checking downstairs due to oversized umbrella (take that, Winter Antiques Show souvenir)  and by that time i was totally lost.   

 luckily, there was the andy warhol exhibit right in front of us... to TOTALLY CONFUSE ME MORE.  strolling languidly through this labyrinth of pop art complete with video displays of warhol films in all of their drug infused weirdness... but just topped off by the three-year-old plopped down on the floor mesmerized by the half nude modern dance piece on the opposite wall.  NOT APPROPRIATE, PARENTS.  then there was the couple who was letting their one year old toddle around the strobe light seizure inducing dizzying room of weirdness.  you KNOW he's going to have nightmares.  come  ON.

once i escaped Warhol's den of bizarre things i had already seen before (mostly), i wanted to see something a little more classic, but, stumbled into the YSL exhibit which, again, made me question if i am not cool for thinking a lot of what was in there was ridiculous.  maybe so, but i'm NOT getting married in a crocheted wedding dress that resembles a ginormous ivory thumb.  i don't care how cool you say it is. no. no thanks.
 
again, booked it past the girl scout troop snickering at the black beaded cone-boob dress (a la Madonna circa 93), pointed out the 3 dresses that i would wear (and, ok, i would totally rock that feather coat thingee, i don't CARE how many roosters died to make it) and headed for exhibits less crowded.  

FINALLY.  walked right into the african room.  full of masks, phallic symbols, fertility figurines, a coffin shaped like a (bright orange) cocoa pod, and, save the pod, i swear that all african rooms in all museums around the world have the same stuff.  

ok ok ok, cynical and myopic, i know. but by this point i was so disillusioned with the joint i think that if rembrandt himself would have been giving a lecture on his own stuff i would have rolled my eyes, but man, once i spied the ENORMOUS SAFETY PIN outside, i was done.  DONE.

plus, i was hungry.
author: Alison R.

description:
The de Young Museum itself is nice, although I wish that the exhibits were better defined.  I really enjoyed the African masks.

On to the Tut Exhibit.  I was sorely disappointed.  All of the posters and fliers advertising the exhibit show (what I though was) the death mask of King Tut.  What it ends up being is a 12 inch coffinette for Tut's liver...don't go if you expect there to be a huge grand finale, because it isn't there.  Although there are great artifacts of the period (I mean, they are 3300 years old for gosh's sake!) don't be surprised to find very little of Tut's actual belongings, because most of the artifacts belong to "family members" (although it is not really know who his mother and father were).  

My biggest complaint, even bigger then not seeing the death mask or one of the coffins, was the LARGE crowd inside of the exhibit.  I had to skip over some of the artifacts because I could not get through the crowd.  Also, the audio tour is not worth $7.00.  You get just as much information from reading the posted signs.
author: Faye N.

description: I love this museum!! Especially for the special exhibits like Vivienne Westwood and YSL. It's well worth the $10-20 you will spend for admission because there's plenty to see. Also, they sometimes do happy hour events on Friday nights with performance artists. That's a fun thing to do with a group.
author: Kandace K.

description:
intriguing.  love how it's in the middle of golden gate park -- who doesn't love an excuse to drive through the best strip of grass and trees in san francisco?  

anyhow, i'd sum it up like so:
+ super eclectic collection...from ancient mayan tablets to african artisan coffins to semi-modern european paintings
- variety to the point that the exhibits don't seem to link up right...or at all.  something's missing in the organization and/or the collection.
+ unique architecture with great accents (check out the cobra-head-like front lamps and the giant blue safety pin in the garden)
- not as classy-looking as it could be
author: Catherine H.

description: A sight to see in San Francisco! If not for the wonderful middle-city view atop the skytower, then for the great gem of architecture and the contents it carries. We enjoy it time and time again, bring a bag of wine, bread, and cheese for an after-tour picnic in the park.
author: devin s.

description:
OK, i'm reviewing the Architecture of the museum only, not the contents and objects within.  The DeYoung leaves a lot to be desired from the interior, and finding your way around the building is not easy.  

Having said that, the exterior is really spectacular.  Typical to Herzog & DeMeuron's work, the best part of the builing is the skin.  The perforated and CNC etched copper cladding will patina to a beautiful green over time, it will continue to gain texture and beauty as well as integrate into the surrounding landscape.  The concept is quite opposite of traditional museums which strive for a monumental character.  This building integrates, almost camoflauges, itself into the landscape.  What does this civic building say about our society today?  It sits defensively, poised and ready for an impending attack.  The twisting tower is an engineering feat, and a wonderful opportunity to survey the surrounings.  Without this tower the building would be a strange rusty old piece of metal hiding in the bushes.  The massive cantilevered projection at the Cafe side is equally impressive in terms of engineering.  Wow.  

But the interior is so stripped down that it's boring and soulless.  The floor in honed stone with the painted walls and ceiling is just not enough.  Even activated with people and artwork the space does not sing.  The detailing is underwrought on the Interior, especially the kiosks and benches.  I am not talking about the detailing of the glazing or skin.  That part is rendered & resolved nicely.

Finding your way around this museum is like navigating the Tokyo subway system (and not knowing kanji).  OK maybe not that bad but compared to the SFMOMA this place is a labrynth.  All the sharp angles are cool and edgy and all but will it stand the test of time?  We'll see.  

The Entry lobby with its stone paving and boulders strewn about is attempting to be zen I think but it does not come across like this.  It seems empty and unfinished.  The Goldsworthy cracked joints in the pavers leading through the boulders is interesting and reminds me of the seismically active land in which we live.  The 'forbidden' gardens crossing through the interior like a DNA double helix is a nice way to let in natural light and color. The ceilings are cool and edgy with the recessed fluorescent strips that create a rhythmic pattern overhead.  The bathrooms are totally unremarkable.

If the Architects would have given as much weight of thought to the Interior spaces as they did the shell of the building it would have been a 5 star world class structure for sure!
author: ashton c.

description: The YSL exhibit was one that I had been looking forward to for a while. I decided to take Saturday and check it out by myself. Upon entering the exhibit I felt like I had died and gone to the most glamorous afterlife filled with silks, satin, fur, and the most amazing oufits I have ever seen up close. Yves Saint Laurent was a genius, his clothing was not only beautiful but I loved learning about how he chose to empower women through the clothes he designed. I had to really fight the urge to reach out and touch the clothing however I had no problem continuing to say "wow" out loud because whether the pieces were costumes, haute couture, or runway designs the clothing was impecably made and beautiful. It was the perfect way to spend the afternoon even if I did get lost trying to find it. I blame my iPhone for that.
author: Alana A.

description:
I remember when Ian Pei's Pyramid in the Louvre not onl dissected the art world but the Parisian community as well .  Now here in SF- I see the same friction- well its here- so we have to make use of it ;-)  I have to try going here at different times of the day- just to appreciate the level of work and imagination that went into building this edifice...
I love the African Art collection- I remember an exhibit on Picasso linking his work to the very face masks here- I wouldnt be surprised if his art was influenced by them... I like the American Art collection- from Church to Thiebaut :-)
The inside of the building harness light by the cathedral like windows placed in specific areas of the place- I like the way the halls direct you to each wing and the lighting draws your eyes to the other end of the room...I like how the cafe looks out to the gardens...Magnifique ;-)
UPDATE:
On a sunny day- Bright Bronzy hues from beaming brick to burgundy and when the sun shines just right on the surface- tiny speckles of light reflecting it...Reminding me of Hockney's Swimming pool series...
On a cloudy day- It has a sombre and macabre industrialized feel- cold a little foreboding- mysterious cerulean mimicking the opaque clouds above- perhaps Picasso's blue period?
On a sunset- gorgeous layers of blood red oranges fading into the sunset like Monet's Sunset in Venice...
author: Arissa C.

description: So much to see other than King Tut! This is a very visitor friendly museum as with the Academy of Sciences I would suggest going on a non-school holiday weekday and definitely not on free day. This is a must see for any trip to Golden Gate park and a must for every kid growing up near the city!
author: wendy p.

description: The new De Young is amazing! It's been years since I've been to this museum, and I was so glad to experience it in it's new form. This is review is long overdue, and it was the Chihuly exhibit that drew me to the De Young. Exhibit was FABULOUS--not much more you can say about Chihuly's work, along with the glass structure outside of the De Young. Anyway, I recommend if you haven't gone yet or have ever been to the De Young, to get your butts over there!
author: Fern D.

description: Despite my original ambivilance about the exterior, the de Young has really grown on me! They always have amazingly curated exhibits, the Friday Night events are stellar and hello....the Tut is coming, the Tut is coming!!!
author: Colleen B.

description:
went to the de young for the very first time for college night.. they had asian art exhibitions which was pretty cool.  me and my friend got there around 6:30 (he was running late, as usual)  i loved the whole section devoted to Maya Lin!  the wood blocks were super cool..  

i just wanted to touch everything at the de young.. i'm a very curious girl.. however, one time my curiousity got the best of me and i just had to touch one of the wood city thingies.. the guard saw me and reprimanded me.. haha

me and my friend tried to see everything within a span of 2 hours and 15 minutes. but we just couldn't do it.  our feet were so tired afterwards..  the de young definitely left me wanting more.. can't wait to go again! =)
author: JUDY L.

description:
I love museums!
Obviously the De Young is an art museum, not a history museum so even though there are lots of beautiful artifacts to be seen in the permanent and special collections, there is not as much information as an anthropologist like me would like to see.
The BF and I played hooky on a Friday and decided to check out the Tut exhibition. It's pretty pricey, but totally worth it, I think. They do a pretty good job of managing the crowds. You purchase tickets for a specific entrance time, then stand in line and they let you in in groups. It's crowded, but not completely horrible.
We arrived about 11am but tickets were sold out until 12:30 so we took the opportunity to look at the permanent collections. I don't really know anything about fine art but there were a few interesting pieces including a model of a Gothic cathedral made completely out of dismantled guns and ammunition. Creepy cool.
There was also a large collection of Meso-American art pieces, Mayan and such. I was terribly interested in all of it since the BF and I will be headed to Cancun in a couple weeks. There was even a rubbing from the walls of Chichen Itza! What a cool preview of what we're about to see in real life!
The Tut exhibit was AMAZING! I loved every minute of it. For those who complained that there was no sarcophagus or death mask, it was pretty well documented in local newspapers, including SF Weekly, that those will never again leave Egypt and would not be part of the traveling exhibition. So it's not really the museum's fault that you're uninformed.
Besides the sparkly, glittery pieces there were lots of models, vessels and things that were used in everyday life. Some of my favorites were all the little models of fruits and scrolls that were supposed to become real in the afterlife if needed. One of the most amazing pieces is the golden shrine which is engraved with scenes from the daily life of the king. I think I could spend forever in there just staring at everything. Love it.
author: Melanie V.

description: Wonderfully airy museum in a serene location (Tea Garden).  I would like to have seen their permanent collection (I was there for Picasso), but enjoyed the viewing nonetheless.
author: Frankie G.

description: During my apartment hunting trip to SF in May 2006, my mum and I stopped here to check out the Arts & Crafts exhibit that they had going on. Unfortunately, we didn't have time to check out the permanent collections, but the featured exhibit was nice. There was a lot of good info about the items they had, as well as a wide variety, but it still wasn't as big as we were expecting. I plan to visit the museum again in the future to take a gander at all the other beautiful pieces they have.
author: Victoria K.

description:
It was such a treat to come back from Hawaii and experience some real culture.
Stop reading if you took offense to that statement as it wasn't meant offensively.  There just aren't many museums in Hawaii and none of them stack up to the De Young in terms of content and exhibitors.
Bruno and I went today to catch up and immerse myself in an environment more familiar.  A museum.  I am a museum whore.  I love all museums and, while no means an art expert, know and appreciate much about art.
I was giddy with excitement since I had not had the opportunity to visit the De Young after it opened and before I moved.  It did not disappoint.  The Chihuly exhibit was truly phenomenal.  Never have I ever seen glass blown into such amazing and creative structures and shapes.
We moved on to the rest of the museum and, while the collections are smaller than many larger museums throughout Europe, they still have a healthy representation of many genres and styles.
We ate at the cafe and I found the food to be decent as well.  I had the lamb curry and my friend the pasta pomodoro. The cafe utilizes seasonal fresh ingredients that are also organic so I think it's somewhat justified in charging the higher prices.  This isn't Burger King or Mickey D's!  We ate outside and were treated to the dulcet tones of the Golden Gate Park Band in the nearby unfinished amphitheater area.
The outdoor area is really quite lovely and reminded me so much of Paris's gardens and the view of the city from the observation deck is not to be missed. It brought a tear to my eye as I looked out on the vista I know and love so dearly.  I can't wait to watch the copper siding of the building age and oxidize to that glorious green shade that will blend into the landscape so well.
Here's a tip for avoiding the crowds at admission: go downstairs (where the Chihuly exhibit is currently being held) and purchase your tickets from the desk down there. There are no lines!
author: Jill D.

description: I'm really rating this for the architecture and not so much what's inside it. The building is beautiful--beautifully designed and beautifully unique. I love that it looks simultaneously futuristic and primitive. The tower structure itself twists so to view downtown SF head-on, and the observation deck is magnificient, complete with a satellite map for reference. All in all, the de Young makes a great addition to San Francisco's array of art spaces.
author: Patrick G.

description: Ive been here once when it opened after the remodel 4 years ago.  It was so much fun I don't even remember what it looks like on the inside.  Go across the street to the Museum of Science.
author: Fatty A.

description:
This is a review of the King Tut exhibit only.
$32.50 is a bit much for a ticket, even if it does include admission to the rest of the museum. However, being that i wasn't alive the last time it came through, it was just something i had to do.  After poring over every detail of the Tut exhibit, I didn't have museum stamina needed to go through the rest of the museum. A person can get museumed out, you know?
We didn't have any trouble getting tickets for the first entrance time on Labor Day. Parking was a breeze in the garage, but very expensive. I guess that was kind of the theme of the day. I didn't do my research and was expecting more objects to be from King Tut's tomb itelf, but the objects from the other tombs were no less interesting or fantastic.
There were a lot of things that were so right with this exhibit. 
The short videos playing throughout were great and the perfect length.  The benches were well spaced out, and there was a lot of thought put into the height of the displays, and especially the information panels. It was so convenient to stand back and read the panels up high, then come in from all sides and get a closer look, or stand close and be able to read the same panel right under the object.  Each panel was appropriate in length and size, and was good about reminding you about the family relationships frequently. I even enjoyed the cool darkness of it all, which was probably simply to protect the artifacts, but it gave the whole place an atmosphere of mystery and intrigue.
I felt bad for the people with kids. It wasn't the most interesting thing for them, and without the strollers or baby carriers, you could tell they were irritable. I also hate it when people read the information panels aloud to their kids when i'm trying to read silently to myself. 
Overall, it was worth it. Maybe leave the small children at home, though.
author: Krista F.

description: Went for the Chihuly exhibit in September, it was breath taking. I saw my first Chihuly exhibit in Tacoma Washington a few years back.  Even on a weekday the place was packed.  The parking garage was nice - avoiding street parking in SF is always great.
author: Stacey G.

description: Cavi, I tell you.  This place is hella good.
author: rerun w.

description: It was an okay museum. I was bored a lot though. The only part I liked were the building models made out of guns and bullets.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
The new De Young is a sad fall from the previous incarnation.

The upstairs is tolerably aesthetic, however, the lighting is mediocre, at best. But no history of the artists or the art works is provided as part of displays.

The ground level redesign succeeds wildly, if the goal is to recapture the experience of viewing art in the walk-ways of an airport. There is no way to present events on the ground-level stage without jamming up foot-traffic. Likewise for other activities that are sometimes staged in the entryway. The acoustics throughout the ground level, including the cafe, are atrocious.

The basement level with the Tut exhibit is a mixed bag. The layout is poorly considered for the traffic that will be involved in some exhibits. It is idiotic that tickets are sold on the ground level, but checked down a very long flight of stairs. 

The Tut exhibit layout is lit for theatrics rather than thorough appreciation. And, it falls apart in the details. Many items are lit only from the front, not from the back. Descriptions and accounts of history are extremely superficial. Glyphs should be translated everywhere, but are not. Once you are in the exhibit, you have to exit to use a restroom; one is not allowed readmission after leaving. The optional recorded audio tour equipment does not come with headsets, so to use it one has to keep it held up to the head for the entire visit.

The entire museum is child-unfriendly (something it has in common with the new California Academy of Sciences, just across the way). Almost nothing is accessible to children without lifting them up; and, if you put a child on your shoulders, guards will ask you to put them down (for insurance purposes). Like many art museums (but thankfully not all), the De Young totally missed every opportunity to be friendly to children and people who have children -- it wouldn't have been that difficult to make displays more appealing to all ages, and to have topic-relevant activities for kids that allow adults more time to enjoy the art (not that much time is needed to absorb the idiotically superficial descriptions of the art).

The De Young cafe is way over-priced, as one would expect.

Frankly, I'd score the new De Young a near-zero, if not for the quality of the art on the upper level.

I can't wait until they rebuild it again. I hope I am still alive. I hope they do a much better job.
author: Lou N.

description: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet. I've visited this museum several times now and I really love it. The layout really works and I enjoy walking around the permanent collection and visiting special exhibits. The building itself is lovely and I can't wait to see how it looks when all the copper turns green. Also their African art exhibit is world class and worth a visit in and of itself.
author: Cathy T.

description:
Gray, rainy, drizzle all day...best to head over to the De Young to see what's going on, and stay dry. It was great! We are so fortunate to have this treasure, despite what the detractors have to say regarding the design...The observation tower is worth the price of admission alone.

Caught the Louise Nevelson Exhibit, as well as some tribal bead-work exhibits today, and they were each breathtaking. It was especially fun to take my kids to see the Nevelson show first, then go upstairs to see the Oceania Room...all the monolithic pieces just staring out (from human skulls, etc...). They were enthralled! They wanted to stay longer!! What more could a parent ask for?! The large (really large) penises on many of the ceremonial works did not go unnoticed by my 3 sons...if any of you happened to be there, I apologize now for their loud commentary and guffawing...I have a tendency to be very matter-of-fact about body parts (I AM a nurse...) and they just looooove to see if they can get me to say something to up the ante. Well, today they failed. So they also got a big charge out of all the "head-hunter" daggers, shields, masks, costumes...It is so impressive. I can't emphasize enough how blessed we are to have this amazing collection right here. So, there's my plug for the museum and a fine outing on a rainy day. Go! Check it out! And while you're at it, take a walk through the park in the mist...the ferns, the plants, and the relative lack of traffic make it very special indeed.
author: Suzanne F.

description:
..mhmm.....layout of the museum is a little messy, could have used a little more explainations for some of the African Tribal artifacts, " It is a statue of a girl, by the look of the mark on her cheeks, she is PROBABLY from this this tribe, her facial expression shows PROBABLY she is in pain"  

other than that awesome gift shop, awesome collections.  

Also if you arrive 1 hour before the closing time of the museum, the admission fee is free.
author: Ting R.

description: The 31 hour opening bash was one of the most fun things I have done in a while, for that alone I will give this place 5 stars.  That's regardless of the fact that the museum space gorgeous, Everything is spacious and well lit, even at 3 a.m.  There's tons of great artwork, of course: it encompases all cultures and styles, from the Hudson River school to the giant Olmec stone head.  If you missed the opening bash, that sucks, but you can still make up for it by seeing the breathtaking musuem.
author: Herbert S.

description: the building designs and materials are so well done.  imagine if the collection was so good.  Herzog & DeMeuron deserve 5 stars the collection deserve a mere 1 star.  i have been to many of the world's finest museums and you leave awe inspired and think about your ethereal journal over and over--this ethereal journey of wonderment did not live on like a fine Malbec.  San Francisco is such a snobby city with little reason for such an attitude.  it would be nice to have museum that was of a world rank.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
The Chicano Visions exhibit is a must to see! Absolutely wonderful collection that should not be missed. 
The "new" De Young is pretty impressive. Building design is a piece of artwork itself. The tower has a wonderful 360 degree view of the city. The hanging wire works of Ruth Asawa by the elevators to the tower are beautiful. Don't miss the James Turrell dome outside by the sculpture garden. It is hard to find but once inside of it, it is a moving experience to look at the sky throught the dome. I think at night it is lit with neon. The older exhibits of regions is extensive. I've seen them so many times before since growing up in this area they are pretty ho-hum. They seem to get great exhibits (like Chicano Visions) and have a leg up on SFMOMA in some aspects. The Andy Goldsworthy Faultline at the entrance and gardens are great too. 
 San Francisco museums have a ways to go on the food scene. I just came back from NYC and the food at the MOMA and Met were out of this world! The food at the De Young is okay. Kinda pricey, even for a hot dog. Cookies sucked, coffee good, variety slim. And the SFMOMA food---forgetaboutit:  blah.  We went back to both museums in NY just to eat the food at the museum restaurants!!! I think SF museums would increase their attendees greatly if they modeled themselves after the Met or NYMOMA.
author: Barb B.

description: My first museum in SF!  It was smaller than i expected, but i thoroughly enjoyed it.  My two favorite parts were the special sculpture exhibition and the black and white photography.  I didn't like the special landscape section, and i was falling asleep during the quilt documentary.  I always love looking at artifacts as well.  You'll definitely want to check out this beautiful museum, with a mix of old and new art.
author: Merredith L.

description:
I love you De Young, but did you really have to make us wait outside for over half an hour when the fire alarm accidently went off yesterday?  that really sucked!

I hate to think of all the drink orders you missed out on as a result.
author: J B.

description: Amazing. I could spend all my free days here and as a matter of a fact I might just resolve to once I move to the other side of the bay. This is just an amazing place to spend a day and to enjoy everything life has to offer. I'm serious. The exhibits were great, the view at the top of the museum is pretty much worth the whole trip and the courtyard is a great place to get lost in a book... I really, really like this place.
author: Andrew W.

description: Would've never thought I'd become a fan of the hideous rust looking eye sore jutting above the tree line in Golden Gate Park (i.e. the observation deck) b/c it ruined my view of the once gorgeous unobstructed view of the Marin Headlands from my office window...but fan of it I've become after visiting for the first time today.  In fact, it was my favorite part of the de Young.  I'm no art connoisseur by any stretch so the exhibits didn't captivate me as much as they probably should've but the structural design of the place is cool.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
It's not really fair to hate on an entire museum because one exhibit falls short of your unhinged fantasy of being transported to Ancient Egypt. 

The De Young consistently features captivating art in an incredible variety of media - I include Tutankhamun and the Golden Age of the Pharaohs in that evaluation (No, there aren't any mummies. No, the Death Mask isn't there. That's explained in detail on the web site and is more than compensated for by the expansion of the exhibit with equally cool pieces).

My first trip was for the Sugimoto exhibit a couple of years ago. It was masterfully curated, and the placards and printed guide were well-researched and insightful. I've found this to be true for exhibits I've seen on every subsequent visit. 

I've also always found the staff to be extremely friendly and helpful. Though they weren't at all obligated to do so, they mediated my Tutankhamun Ticketmaster disaster (too boring to detail here - suffice it to say that it sucked and they made it go away). 

The De Young strives to reconfigure popular concepts of art; in addition to providing a space for the consideration of modern and contemporary art, they submit the relics of ancient civilizations to patrons not merely as artifacts, but as art. Every time I go, they've found a new way to demonstrate that the volume of great art in the world is varied beyond imagination and completely inexhaustible. For quality and for breadth, I don't think there's a better museum in the city.

As far as the Tut Exhibit goes - read the web site beforehand, avoid going at 10 AM on a Saturday with your dSLR dangling from your neck, and accept that Americans are not entitled to see all of the priceless artifacts in the world consolidated into one museum for their convenience. You'll probably have a good time.
author: Morgan P.

description:
We had the City Pass for free admission, but we didn't want to miss the King Tut exhibit which runs through March of 2010. With the City Pass we got a discount off the regular $32.50 admission down to $15, plus access to the permanent collection. 

We were disappointed that King Tut's coffin and mummy weren't actually in the King Tut exhibit, but there were plenty of other awesome artifacts to check out. It blows my mind that these things are really thousands of years old! I really loved the way the exhibit was laid out and all the informative tidbits posted on the artifacts. We felt it was really special. 

I thoroughly enjoyed the permanent collection. Days later, my mind is still buzzing with the images seen there.

Don't miss the observatory - take the elevator up for a spectacular view.
author: Nicole W.

description: Saw the Tutankhamun exhibit yesterday, and although many saw it isn't as good as the 1979 exhibit (which I also saw), I thought it was excellent.  The sarcophagus and death mask weren't on display this time, but they had a number of other items from the Valley of the Kings that were traveling with the exhibit and made it a well-rounded "show".  I thought it was excellent, and definitely worth seeing.
author: Nancy C.

description: It's hard to give a new museum in SF any less than 5 stars...it's just plain exciting!  The building quite impressive and while they have a few kinks to work out in terms of efficency, I really enjoyed my first visit.  The amount of local art is amazing...you're just walking along and you think, "that looks like Mt. Tam,"  "Lake Tahoe?", "I swear that's Marin"...and it is!  I'll definitely be back...I didn't even get to eat in the Cafe!
author: Sarah D.

description: Last summer when I was walking through Golden Gate Park for the AIDS Walk, we passed behind the de Young while it was still being finished, and I thought, "What is that brown ugly building?" Since then, I've had the chance to visit and I have a completely different opinion of it. I think the architecture is very interesting and I am curious to see how the copper siding will age over time. The tower is great -- we enjoyed the view early one Sunday morning. You get a great view of the Park and the city beyond. I hear that the wait for the tower is long in the afternoon, so I suggest getting to the museum early and starting with the tower. The collections are pretty cool. Our tastes lean towards modern art, so we were happy to find some interesting pieces there.
author: Joel A.

description:
love the building so so much, and the view from the tower-thing is one of the most amazing views i've ever had of the city.  really amazing.  

but the art colelction felt just -eh- to me.
author: Sharon M.

description: Love this place.  I went to a wedding there last summer and have been wanting to go back when I had more time to check out the museum in its entirety.  Went this past weekend and it was great.  Be sure to check out the painting by Wayne Thiebaud - Three Machines  (he is from my home town!), the Turkmen Weaving, and David Seymour's photos.  Those were my favorites.  Parking was a breeze if you enter from Fulton.  You get a discount for the museum with a muni pass - a little bonus.    They were selling some neat items in the museum store and had a coat check.
author: Catherine B.

description:
I guess its a love/hate thing with the building. I personally love it and I think all the naysayers are going to eat their words when the copper tarnishes. My uncle the crane operator/paella chef told me it was super pretty up close when the siding had just gone up, but that in a very short time the copper lost its luster, so it shouldn't be all that long. 
The inside of the place is just as nice as the outside. I was there opening weekend and didn't have all that long of a wait because some friends were holding a place toward the front of the line. Sorry folks, but thats just what you had to do that night to get in. They only gave us a taste that night, which was cool, because it definitely piqued my interest. It was disappointing to smell smoke inside the museum and see that people had littered beer cans around. I doubt SF will ever do something that cool for us again. Definitely not with the new Steinhart....though thats what I am really waiting for...
author: Andrew B.

description: I give this place 5 stars on the architecture and space planning alone. It is one of the most inviting spots in the city (on a non-crowded, tourist day).  I could spend hours in the tower checking out the view or mapping out every spot I know on that wall map.  Right now they have an inspiring exhibit on quilts, not dowdy country quilts, but beautifully crafted abstract style quilts from plantation workers in the south.
author: courtney W.

description: Came to see the Post Impressionist Masterpieces on loan from The Musee d'Orsay.  Our appointment for the exhibit was 10am so were where able to park on the street in Golden Gate Park within about a 5 minute walk to the entrance.  This certainly beats paying $4 per hour to park in the garage below.  I had been to the De Young in '06 not long after it had been renovated and the first thing I noticed was the exterior can-opener treatment and the rust-like appearance.  Not bad but certainly not great.  Upon entering you are greeted by a security officer instructing what you can bring in and what needs to be placed in supplied plastic bags supplied at the entrance.  Once inside you are free to wander the permanent exhibits, find out about becoming a member, or head to the cafe (see my review of the De Young Cafe).  The museum  gets a great amount of traffic and can get cramped along the walk ways, staircases and rest rooms.  We were fortunate to get up to the observation tower with a lighter crowd.  Though it was overcast and foggy we were still treated to some great views of surrounding neighborhoods, the park and the Academy of Sciences.  Though it was a blustery day, still quite enjoyable to be up in SF.  I had forgotten how lush the foliage is along with the numerous water features in GG Park.  I look forward to coming back when the next exhibit opens.
author: Perry W.

description: As far as the museum goes, there isn't much among the free exhibits that's actually worth seeing. Our group saw a trio of women playing traditional Chinese instruments in the theater, very interesting. What makes De Young worth the visit is the observation tower. You go about a dozen floors up and get an amazing view of San Francisco. Best of all, it's free!
author: Byron C.

description:
I went here for an art class assignment which was cool because it's one of those places I probably wouldn't have gone to if I wasn't forced to.

The outside of the building is ugly. It is art. Some will like it, some won't. The tower, from the outside, is the worst part. But from it's best from inside looking out. The tower offers amazing views of the park, golden gate bridge and other parts of the city I don't know by name. So beautiful.
The other part of the building I enjoyed where the random windows throughout that "framed" views of the park. It was late November so the park was filled with trees changing colors... golden, red, orange, and green just popped out like a work of art in itself. 
Despite my art class I am not going to pretend like I know art or anything but I know what I like. 
The early american art was beautiful! Watch out for familiar landscapes of California during the Westward Ho! time. Like the golden gate...without the bridge, mount tam., donner lake and more.
The 20th century art and beyond collection was interesting. Some I didn't "get" but thats art right?
I would check it out if I were you. 
For $10 its a nice way to spend the day or afternoon.
It's pretty interesting to see what makes you go "wow" and what makes you think "meh".
author: Edi B.

description:
We went to see the Post-Impressionist exhibit the day after Christmas. I found the experience rather frustrating, as the museum suffers from a lack of signage, and there don't seem to be a lot of maps showing where you are or where you should go. It starts in the parking lot, which is a long, rectangular space, which was full when we got there. There is no signage indicating that a second floor of parking exists upstairs, and after goiig round the garage twice, following a couple of other cars in a similar predicament, an attendant in a golf cart actually came out and told us that we could go upstairs, up this unmarked ramp. A simple sign with an arrow would have sufficed. Once we got upstairs, we found a space quite quickly. 

You walk into the museum down a long corridor which has no signage whatsoever on where you are or where to go, for example, to get to Will Call which is where we wanted to be. Turns out, on asking a rather diffident attendant, that it is upstairs. So we trek up there, and eventually find the right Will Call line (there are separate ones for members and non-members, for some obscure reason). Got our tickets ok. The Will Call lady then directed us back downstairs to the PI exhibit. We went downstairs and showed our tickets. "Oh no, the line for the Exhibit starts upstairs", the same diffident attendant said. "But we were told to come down here", I said. "No. it's upstairs". "No, I don't think so", I said. So he let us in. "Haven't they done this before?", I said to my wife. "After all the Exhibit has already been open six months". Anyway, we got in, and found the anticipated masses of people, which made viewing rather lengthy. Also, there was nothing to tell you that it was one-way traffic through the event, so if you only see one side of a room on the way in, it is rather difficult to see the other side by doubling back, unless you want to feel like a salmon swimming upstream against the current. 

Having said all that, it is a spectacular exhibit, and one not to be missed. But why do they make it so hard to find things there? We even had to ask where the Cafe was after we had come out of the Exhibit - again, no obvious signs. Most other museums I have been in have excellent signage, or at least hand out maps at the entrance. Why not the De Young?
author: Malcolm C.

description: Truly amazing, the number and depth of collections represented at the De Young Museum. Although one acquaintance was not keen on the Vivienne Westwood exhibit, I found the representation of her various styles/periods to be surprisingly deeper than I expected. The ethnic pieces are just very cool, too. Even in the overcast weather, the views from the tower were just gorgeous. While I can't truly claim any great knowledge in any high art/ethnic art, I can say I enjoyed my time at the De Young.
author: Ryan T.

description: I ditched work today so I decided to take advantage of free Tuesday and visit the De Young.  While I think the museum is beautiful and the presentation is great (good lighting, love all the wood details, excited about the architecture of the building itself), I think they could have spent more time/money acquiring and focusing their art collection.  While I like the juxtaposition of many types of art, many of the collections seemed weak (particularly modern art).  And who out there really likes colonial art enough for it to warrant two rooms?  I think this would get three stars if I'd actually paid to get in.
author: Katie S.

description: Gilbert & George Exhibit. If you're a fan of Andy Warhol and mixed media with their height of work being in the 80's then you'll love it! GO check it out, very massive pieces of art/prints and very FULL of symbolism.
author: Rob L.

description: i had a wonderful time at the deYoung museum this past saturday. it was definitely one of the most relaxed and visitor friendly museums i have visited with the exception of the exploratorium (you can't get any more friendly than that place). museum curators did not accost patrons for taking pictures or studying the art up close. of course you could not touch the pieces, but at least you were allowed to examine them in detail without fear of being yelled at. i was able to wander around the building freely, taking pictures of some incredible pieces. the layout of the museum was a little strange, and sometimes you missed small rooms full of art by accident. i had such a great experience that i think i may just get a membership.
author: Aly L.

description: Fantastic place for outdoor art; and the exhibits are interesting too.  Some parts of the museum can get a bit overwhelming.  The view from the tower is great, but smaller than I expected.  I'm glad I became a member, I can zip to the front of the line!
author: Vera D.

description: the de young is a great place even to just hang out.  saw the picasso exhibit today, not a bad collection.  not sure if it was worth $25/person.  overall, it's a great place in a great location.
author: Alex J.

description: I was underwhelmed with the building and the collections.  I had such high hopes before going there.  I prefer SF MOMA & The LACMA.
author: Alex L.

description: I like museums, and art and all that, but this museum did not exactly amaze me.  It was nice: it had some good art.  I appreciated the African art and some of the more traditional paintings.  I do not know a lot about contemporary art, but my friend said their exhibit was pretty sorely lacking.  It seemed a hella lot bigger than necessary; I kept looking around at the cavernous rooms and the massive hallways thinking to myself that there was a surprising small art-to-available-space ratio.  It seems to me that with all the amazing museums around the country that also would be rated on a five-star system, this museum would maybe pass into the three-star realm: passable,leaning towards sad.
author: Claire R.

description: For those who haven't seen the Chihuly exhibit yet... GO GO GO!  It's closing this coming weekend and it's truly a spectacular collection of work.   Like the Frida exhibit at the MOMA, the tickets are time sensitive so groups are let in every 30 minutes. I went last weekend and it was pretty crowded, but I think the De Young will have extended hours to accommodate the closing.  Oo and P.S. photography is allowed (just no flashes)... and Chihuly's organic free flow pieces transform beautifully across film.  It's definitely muse for some stellar photos.
author: Mischen C.

description: Amazing art museum . I can't wait for the Tutankhamun exhibit this June.
author: christy l.

description:
OK a few things. I LOVE the deYoung and the Legion I have been a member to FAMSF for many years and I HIGHLY recommend it for the benefits. 
I went to the King Tut exhibit on Weds. at 11:30 am, and I was glad to have tickets ahead of time because when we finished with the exhibit (and it's not like the Diamond Skull by Hirst where you have only a limited amount of time, so don't be fooled by the time on the ticket) the lines were much longer. 
SPOILER ALERT-
It was a very well put together exhibit and it showcased all of the artifacts you've seen on Discovery and the likes. I was disappointed that the Funerary mask was not there (although I could've done my research) nor was the sarcophagus itself.  Only the mini liver scarcophagus, so when you're going through the exhibit take time to really study that one, it's in the 9th room. Luckily I did so when I got to the 10th and final room I wasn't too terriably disappointed to see the hologram(graph?)/images of the actual one. 
I still love the museum for the permanent collection so I can't write a bad review. The Tut exhibit is still a MUST SEE!!!
author: sophie p.

description: Not my favorite museum because it just ain't the Frick or the Met or Orsay, but I really really really like the architecture and the Tower. The view on a clear day is breathtaking. You feel like an eagle on top of the city. It's a great perspective. And occassionally they have an provocative exhibit.
author: Ann P.

description:
Second stop of our 2009 Museum Tour--

The De Young Museum. I didn't get in on the opening day due to the masses, so I vowed to come back with Marilyn T. in tow. We came on the first Tuesday of the month, which is the free day! My favorite part of the whole thang? Modern Art. My least favorite part? Colonial art. We snuck cameras in and took pictures w/o the flash. We were undetected until Marilyn T. decided to snap a picture of this African mask and this loud booming voice above us said, "Please, no pictures!". We put the camera away, got on our knees and repented. 

Please be warned: do not come here on an empty stomach. MT and I did and we were about to pass out by the time we got to the Indonesian art section. 

Final Verdict: A nice combination between history and art, though the modern stuff has already stolen my heart. You could spend hours here and still not be done. You can spend hours here without spending a ton!
author: Dana F.

description:
I can see my house from here!

Actually, I can't.  But that doesn't stop the observatory tower from being cool (regardless of what it looks like from the outside).  

The new layout and architechture are so much better than it ever was, and let me tell you, I was intimately familiar with the old architechture.  Why?  Well, my mom worked here in the mid to late 80's.  I used to meet her here after school to get rides home - I'd walk from my high school in the Haight to her office.  I would get let in to the museum the back way.  It was pretty cool to be let in the back way of a museum after hours when no one is there and walk through sculptures and paintings in mostly dark rooms in complete silence (other than my footsteps on the marble floor) to get to her office.  But you know what?  The exhibits were o.k. but the space was kind of cramped - and her office was gross.  Everything felt old and dusty - there were lots of silverfish running around.  Eewww.  It was everything you ever think about when you think of "museum" and "stodgy" put together.  The new museum feels so open and airy with high ceilings and windows and natural light and plants and trees and.... aahhhh.

And the exhibits are awesome - the recent Chicano exhibit was frickin' great!

Why not five stars?  The food in the cafe (like all musuems) is too expensive.
author: Susannah M.

description: 5 stars on the insanely cool Herzog & de Meuron (the folks of Beijing's Birst Nest and London's Tate Modern fame) building . The observation tower is a must see. Good collection. It's no NY Met but very good collection. Visit the Moss room at the Academy of Sciences across the garden for drinks.
author: sanjee w.

description:
fantastic museum in a great location (golden gate park has too much to see and do). no complaints with their permanent collection. and the public observation floor is a must visit in order to get great views of SF. plus, if you buy tickets for the special exhibits at deyoung, you can head out to the legion of honor and explore another fantastic museum.
but the reason why i gave this place 5 stars is because of their van gogh exhibit not too long ago. for me, any place that gives the public an opportunity to see van gogh's paintings deserves 5 stars. hands down, one of the most memorable experiences that i've had. 
and just to warn, their special exhibits are crazy and you will face obstacles: it's overcrowded, people randomly walk in front of you while you're looking at the displays, lines move incredibly slow, heads will block your view, you will feel claustrophobic, people will breathe down your neck and invade your personal space, and there will be the occasional aggressive grandmas and grandpas who push you out of the way in order to get a better look. but mark my words, it's worth it.
author: Becky K.

description: Visited the Warhol exhibit last week and it was fantastic!  I have been a Warhol fan since the late '80's and really thought I knew most of what there was to know about him, but I still learned a few things at this exhibit.  Setting his life to music was such a great idea and they did a perfect job.  I also tried the cafeteria for the first time for something besides coffee and the food was impressively good.  I usually expect to get ripped off at these places, but the prices were very decent for the food quality and location.  I think I need to buy a membership to this place.
author: Maria V.

description: I enjoyed being at the DeYoung  Art Museum .It is quite special.I thought that the Picasso exhibit was  Superb-a fine retrospective of his paintings.Their permanent collection has a wonderful array of American paintings.Personal favorites were;Inness'"Moonlight",Hitchcock's"Tulip Garden",Hassam's"Seaweed and Surf,Appledore",Vedder's"Sphinx by Seashore",Benton's"Susannah and  the Elders",and Thiebaud's"Diagonal Highway".This art museum has a very nice cafeteria.It is open late on Fridays.
author: Barry I.

description: Located in the beautiful Golden Gate Park, the De Young Museum is one of my favorite museums in the city. Last time I was at the de Young was this summer when I went to check out Dale Chihuly's exhibit, which was amazing! No complaints, go check it out!
author: Narina A.

description: Went for the Picasso exhibit running through October 9th. They manged to get quite a good sampling of works. The audioguide was fine, not wonderful. The museum itself was no different than many other art museums in the US, same feeling and all.
author: Ben G.

description: I've been here twice.  First during the opening weekend where I got one of those cool green stretchy bracelets (my husband threw his away - looser!).  The second for our department team builder.  We came, we toured, we ate in the cafe, it was a fine afternoon (including getting paid for it).  The outside is exquisite as well.  I could explore the details of the exterior almost longer than the inside art.
author: Tracy A.

description: A great way to spend your Sunday afternoon. I loved the photopgraphy exhibits as well as all the modern art. Seeing all the artifacts from Oceania and Africa were very cool too. $10 is definitely a fair price for as much culture as you get out of the museum. The best part, however, was the tower which gave you a 360 view of the city, bay and surrounding areas. Definitely the coolest thing Ive seen so far since moving here!!
author: Erin F.

description: When is it gonna turn green, like an old penny?
author: J J.

description: It's all about the stunning architecture because their permanent collection is a snooze fest.
author: Michael A.

description: This museum was a welcome relief to a person like me that doesn't know much about art.  The modern-themed paintings and Native American carvings were much easier to swallow than the repetitive European Medieval art I've seen in other museums.  I think de Young's hook is its variety--if you don't like paintings there is a ton of 3-dimensional pieces, an artistic architecture embodied in the museum itself, and plenty of interesting readings on the walls.   But the coolest thing was de Young's observation tower--it's truly mesmerizing.  You can see nearly all of SF from it including the two bridges, and there's an enormous aerial picture of the entire city mounted on the wall to boot.  I recommend visiting the de Young to anyone (but in small chunks for novices like me).
author: Ziv T.

description:
Oh man, where do I begin. Okay, so I came here for the Chihuly Exhibit, which, by the way, was mind blowingly amazing. 2 friends and I decided to go see the exhibit on the last Friday it was here--smart, I know. And, I'm not sure if I should be posting this review, but, here goes!..:

So the three of us get here, and we'd been dying to see the Chihuly Exhibit. But turns out, they were completely sold out of tickets for the rest of the weekend--that WOULD happen to us. But being in our early 20's, mid 20's, we felt that we should culturally enrich our young, post-college minds on the beauty of art...or so we used as justification for what we did. You see, we realized that to get in, all you needed were these little squares that you stick onto your shirt. They had time stamps on them, but the people checking for stickers weren't paying attention to the times. Being the resourceful kids that we were, we decided to look for squares on the ground. We engaged in distracting the employees, pretending like we dropped something on the ground to pick up a sticker, and lo and behold! After 45 minutes of searching for stickers, we finally found three, stuck it onto our shirts, and strutted right in. Everyone knew what we were up to. In fact, a security guard was laughing at us, and one of the other patrons came up to my friend and told her she saw what we did and thought it was hilarious.  At the end, this exhibit was totally worth what we did.
author: Sami A.

description:
I'd have to rerate the DYM another time... I feel this review is a little bit premature.  I went there for the first time today on a UCSF Staff Appreciation Day event.  I decided to buy a membership ($70 entitles membership, which allows you to drag along a friend for free with you whenever you visit the DYM or the Legion of Honor museum)--I want to come back here on my own time, when I don't feel as rushed to see everything in there.  We went to the tower to view a 360-degree-panoramic view of San Francisco... there's a wall there that shows a huge aerial picture of the SF bay... try to locate your street/house on that map... it's very cool.
If you have a student ID, by all means, BRING IT... so you can save $$$ on membership ($45 is what I woulda paid if I had my ID... but alas, I didn't).  The membership will totally pay for itself in 4-5 dates (heheheheh).  Thasss right!  Who wants to go!?
author: Grace M.

description: I just wanted to say "been there, done that".  Go on Friday evenings. Admission is $5 and its like a hybrid of the following: dance club // happy hour // mixer // museum all wrapped in a cool, modernistic building in GG park.  Way cool!
author: ITesh J.

description: I saw both French Impressionist exhibits in 1986 and 1991 and was blown away.  I have yet to see the new space but I have enjoyed myself everytime I have been here.  Really lovely surroundings.
author: Denny R.

description: Definitely check out the Oceania section on the second floor! I've never seen anything like it. Some of it is scary as hell. The modern collection seems kind of hodge podge. Love the new building, although I didn't get a chance to go up the tower (i'm going to assume it is a great view, and will go back to confirm that later). Oh, and the Olmec head was amazing to see.
author: Amy E.

description: It just an extra star for the Chicano exhibit. Honestly, I was happy that I didn't pay full price. Dont ever buy food from there, ridiculously over-priced. I missed out on going up in the tower (will have to do that). The permanent exhibitions were ok. There were a few amazing ones, that were worth the visit.
author: Anita C.

description: This museum can make up a big part of an amazing day in Golden Gate Park. Definitely go to the top floor and look at the great views of the city, and definitely check out the sculpture garden and play with the giant apples (however, play from a distance, i learned the hard way on that one). check out theyre random short term exhibits, theyre vale la pena but why, oh why, do we have to pay extra for them? i already paid to come in, im just trying to be cultured and you have to make it cost so much money...
author: Lisa M.

description:
i'm not a huge art buff but i do love learning new things - and both times i've been to the deyoung i've walked away with a new appreciation of something new.

a couple of months ago, we checked out the egyptian exhibit, about the only female pharoh - i won't attempt to butcher the spelling of the name - and yesterday was a very eclectic special exhibit about vivienne westwood, a pioneer in the fashion industry.

take advantage of the month of may - all bank of america cardholders get in for free.  for details, go google "bank of america museums on us."

the museum itself is gorgeous - again, i'm not an architecture buff, but it is striking, sitting in the middle of golden gate park.  i overheard that the copper that lines the outside will eventually turn green, blending into the green treeline of the park - pretty cool, i thought.

the tower is definitely worth checking out - huge glass panes give you an amazing view of our city.  the golden gate bridge pokes out to the north, the skyline of the financial district to the east, and man, there are some HUGE churches or mosques or something in SF.  i had no idea till now.
author: brian w.

description: I used to come here a lot as a kid, so it was nice to see that they were able to take over the Asian art museum side and redo the whole exterior.  They have a good collection of Latin American, African, and Oceanic art.  I liked the view from the Tower too!
author: Kit E.

description:
i love the spire

argue about it all you want

and i love their events

and i superheart vivienne westwood
author: Seiji C.

description: I haven't yet had the opportunity to enjoy the museum.... but I have been lucky to visit the FREE observation tower. The large windows offer a fantastic 360* birds eye view of the city - a perfect place to bring out-of-towners and show off San Francisco from a unique viewpoint. I highly recommend a trip to the tower before or after a fun afternoon in golden gate park. Sit back, relax, and enjoy the scenery!
author: Caroline J.

description: We "accidentally" got in free one time when we went to check out the very top floor/viewing area where they have another gift shop and an awesome 360 view of the Golden Gate Park. There was not a lot of people there that day and it was just so nice and peaceful with the bamboo floor and full glass window that surrounds the whole top floor.
author: Joselita T.

description: Love the building. Hate that shit inside they try to pass off for art.
author: James J.

description: I'd like to move into the De Young.  I'd put my bed in the quiet, sun-dappled room on the first floor, in front of the floor-to-ceiling view of the garden and the blue and green glass sculptures.  On sunny mornings I'd eat English muffins on the observation deck; on cloudy mornings I'd curl up with a book and sip coffee in front of Diebenkorn's Seawall, in the modern room.  In the evenings I'd throw swank parties in the breathtaking, dimly-lighted room that houses the gorgeous textile exhibit.  Afterwards, I'd lead my guests out of doors to the duck pond so that we could dance under the moonlight near the enormous gold Chihuly sculpture while the caged bronze animals look on.
author: Heather P.

description: It looks like a huge chimney coming out of the ground...fabulous architecture inside and out and the exhibits are to die for.
author: Lee S.

description: This is a very large museum with good shows. The King Tut exhibit is great, some of the trinkets could almost pass for new, for they were in really good condition! This museum has a relaxed atmosphere and I am highly impressed by it!
author: Veronica F.

description:
Edit 2: They lose a star for the awful Dale Chihuly. I was unprepared for how just horrible it is! Hideous, bright '80s colored bowls and vases make up the bulk of the show. I can accept that his work is not my thing, and I was at least expected a bunch bright colored glass sculpture but this is nothing but an overt cash grab.
Note to the director:
If you want money from the general public then put in some rides and replace the bookstore and cafe with a Walmart and McDonalds.
If you want to be an art museum then please be more serious. 
Also, take some care with the sculpture. The Sculpture garden really needs to paved - an unfortunate fact is irresponsible Bay Area parents think ANY patch of grass = playground for their undisciplined brats. 
Despite large and prominent "DO NOT TOUCH" signs both kids and adults were dry humping early  every sculpture. 
The so many people had fingered up the Miro that it looked like a smudgy iphone screen.


Edit: they get 2 more stars for having the balls to do the Gilbert and George show. I doubt they will ever do anything that good in the near future. Back to bad carpet and fashion shows. 
The Gilbert and George show was very good - unless you are an acute homophobe.
To the idiot complaining about exhibitions not being suitable for children:
This is an art institution, not Chucky Cheese or the Exploratorium.
For centuries art history has often featured nudity, sexuality and violence. The responsibility of the De Young is to present important artwork, not appease you and your kids. Two minutes of Google research could have told you your kids and Gilbert and George were not a great match. 
Museums compromise enough as  it is. Grow up, do your own research, take responsibility for your own parenting.

Pretty weak collection overall, hopefully that will change in time. I like some of the permanent site specific pieces like the James Turrel and Ed Ruscha and there are a few great paintings in the collection.
They have some OK traveling shows but also too many that are just pandering to people who have no interest in looking art like quilts and fashion shows.
The building is great and the food is decent.

They are also really lax about kids, I understand wanting to be family friendly but they let kids climb all over the sculpture which doesn't help the kids or the art.
Exposing kids to art is a great Idea but unfortunately it rarley works out well in reverse.
author: Damon S.

description:
My girlfriend and I went to the King Tut exhibit this weekend, and it was a mildly disappointing experience. We had VIP tickets which was great for skipping the brutal lines, but unfortunately, they didn't help much once we got into the exhibit rooms. The exhibits are very crowded (it was a Sunday) and we spent most of the time bumping into people and excusing ourselves.

The artifacts were very impressive, as was the build up to the final room. Highlights were the sarcophagus of Tut's relative, and his burial items, including his dagger.

The big disappointment is realizing that King Tut's Sarcophagus and death mask are NOT at the exhibit. The posters and advertising are totally misleading. As you proceed through each room of the exhibit, you are brought "closer" to Tut's personal items. When we reached the last room I thought "next is the big payoff... the man, himself". But once we turned the corner, we were greeted with the gift shop in stead. 

Show over. Buy stuff. Go home. 

Overall, some impressive items. But they should be much clearer in their advertising. It was a bit of a letdown.
author: David A.

description:
sorry, i lived in manhattan for too long, i'm used to museums you can get lost in.
observation deck-very nice
i like what they got, i wish they had more. (asain exhibit and yves st laurent exhibit are fabulous)
decent deal on student membership which includes legion of honor
author: kiki b.

description: Recently went to the remodeled De Young to view the King Tut exhibit Enjoyed the exhibit, minus the tourists and kids on field trips. I didn't like the new museum thought. Thought it was way too modern and missed the old De Young. It was actually confusing when you enter. The exhibit is downstairs. I had to ask. There was an area that was sectioned off for the lines entering at different times, but it was upstairs (main floor) and the exhibit was downstairs ???? Anyway, I only went to the King Tut exhibit. I wasn't sure if I could go to the other parts of the museum because there were staff/security at each area going into different parts of the museum and they looked like they would stop you if you entered.  It didn't feel like you could just roam around like the old De Young, which was more classical-looking when it came to museums and had different galleries where you could sit and look at a painting or sculpture for hours and feel relaxed. I'm a native San Franciscan and like I said, the new De Young is way too modern and I miss the old one.
author: Neni E.

description:
I have been here twice, 1) Chihuly & 2) Yves Saint Laurent/Warhol.

If you're going to get a membership (vs. say California Academy of Sciences), get it here, it's cheaper, too. Not only do special exhibits change (obviously), but the permanent exhibits have a lot of interesting displays and feel very thorough. You won't walk through and feel like: "that's it?" ALSO, the food was surprisingly amazing. Actually one of my better lunches, Happy Chinese Chicken Salad== delicious.

You can also go up into the observation tower, nice view of SF, but a little too crowded. Beautiful building, spacious, except for the special exhibits there was lots of room to just browse around without being bumped and jostled by other visitors. I would think that this place is definitely worth going to for their Friday Night events, but I have yet to check one out.
author: Aris Y.

description: I am a member of the De Young Museum and recently ordered tickets for the Picasso Exhibit. Tickets are free for members but I accidentally ordered them on the non-members link (rather than the members link).  I thought the discount would be applied before my final 'click', alas my credit card was charged $52 so I called and emailed the De Young to ask them to void the charge and assist me with the free order.  The next business day a very nice woman, Nancy, called and cheerfully credited my account in minutes. No hassle at all.  I found the correct link over the weekend and also ordered my free tickets.  Great customer service!!!!
author: Amy S.

description: Love this museum they have great exhibits! But I only gave it four stars for one particular reason: I feel like I kinda get ripped off at this place!!!! I mean for the King Tut exhibit even though I am a member I was charged!! plus all they had at the museum was statuettes not even his tomb! so I was disappointed in the exhibit that was all the rage!! I mean why call it the King Tut exhibit if you dont even have his sarcophagus!  Anyway, I hate the architecture I mean I love modern but not this building it looks like its falling down but inside I like the architecture better, I mean I love the staircase it has with the glass walls around it and so you can see all the trees around you inside. I also love the room where it is just a HUGE window so you have a spectacular view of the city! All in all, I would visit it to see the Picasso exhibit but probably after tourist season and after everyone else has seen it and all the hype has died down, and also the Balenciaga exhibit is not to be missed! the garments are divine!!  Also they have a alright main gallery which consists of eccentric  native American pieces, and few rooms with  cool European statues and oil paintings. Anyway visit it you'll love it I am just too much of a tough critic!!!
author: Sophia C.

description: The Van Gogh, Gauguin, and Cezanne exhibit was the focus of my last visit to the the de Young.  I went with a dear friend, and we had an eye-opening time on that day.  It was a last minute decision, and I'm glad we went.  The paintings were spectacular, and the audio tour made it even more informative.  There were quite a few people in this exhibit, but much less throughout the rest of the museum.  We basically stayed until they corralled us downstairs, and back into the stark world of reality.
author: Jaime J.

description: I went to the observation level on the ninth floor yesterday, a sunny, clear amazingly beautiful day in San Francisco.  The views are spectacular. Definitely a must-do on a clear and sunny day in San Francisco.
author: Natalie S.

description: Lines, lines, lines that wrap around forever so that you spend more time in lines than seeing the exhibit! I expected that I would be seeing more of the really great Paris pieces but was disappointed. Maybe 7 art book favorites and as many artists and then way to many hum drum landscapes  and okay paintings. But we thank the Impressionist for starting the movement and teaching future painters some great skills that made for some great contemporary painters!
author: jan s.

description: Well worth the trip out to GGP.  I hit the museum on their free first Tuesday this month, and there wasn't a line.  Score!  It was one of the best decisions I've made in recent memory (not sure how much that says, but anyway...).  Very large building, and I loved how they had so many types of exhibits and artistic styles.  Really something for everyone.  I'm glad the doorperson directed me to start with the modern art section.  How did he know that'd be to my liking?  Read me like a book.  Their outdoor fountain and garden area is beautiful bonus, too.
author: M A N I K.

description: It's a five star view with some three star art, which brings us to an average of four stars.  The facility itself is a fun place to play.  The paintings of streets of San Francisco and the perception of how steep they are were my favorites.  I'm not art connoisseur, but I enjoyed everything the De Young had to offer, especially because it was such an eclectic hodge-podge.  Oh yeah, my other favorite was the crack in the sidewalk and rocks in front of the door.
author: ellyk E.

description:
UPDATE 5/26:  definitely check out the vivianne westwood exhibit while you can!  its at the deyoung until 6/10.  i went today and it was great.  i especially loved her evening gowns and the display of corsets.  sure it was crowded because its the feature exhibit, but it was worth it.  just take your time and be patient, navigate around the crowds and be sure to read the wall plaques.  they have great insight to her history, influences, and inspiration for each of her shows.  i loved it!! 

original review:
as an avid museum-goer i was excited when the new deyoung museum opened last year.  when i first went, i signed up as a member because it was only about $80 and then every time you go after that, you and a guest are free!  totally worth it if art is your thing.  i was definitely impressed with the exhibits i saw there, and if not for the fact that i still have yet to explore the entire museum, i would be giving it 5 stars.  the tower is a must-see, great views of the city.  i love the architecture and layout of this museum - its so cool.  
i recently also went to the 1st anniversary party (members only baby!!) which was fun.  it was definitely geared towards an older crowd, but it was cool to do something different on a saturday night.  didnt see any of that champagne that was mentioned in the invite, but the hors d'oerves and signature cocktail were delicious.  the orchestra that played was good and lots of people were dancing.  membership has its benefits!
author: Carolyn B.

description: i love the new de Young! it's spacious and modern and love the observation deck because you get a good 360 degree view of the park and the surrounding area. I'm also giving it 5 stars because it's just a few blocks from home too, so I never have to deal with parking especially on weekends when the tourists want to come out and play.
author: kristin e.

description:
awesome museum with even more awesome architecture!  i particularly enjoyed the photography section.

note: expect a bit of a wait in these opening weeks.
author: Jill k.

description: I really only had a few minutes to go through here, but there were a lot of interesting exhibits! The glass art was crazy! Also, I really enjoyed the wooden sculptures and the quilts! I never knew it was so hard to make a quilt until I tried. I liked how they were not all box-y but full of random edges and colors. The best part about the museum though, is the Observation Tower! You see an awesome calming side of San Francisco with the tip of the Transamerica building showing at the horizon at one vantage point. It is so gorgeous I would want to have my loft on that floor! -Matt
author: Matthew C.

description: The De Young definitely has a diverse collection of art, from non-western to American to 20th-century/modern. Check it out the same day you check out the Legion of Honor-- if you're up for it. They compliment each other perfectly! The De Young building itself is pretty eclectic. I especially love the tower with the 360 view of the city. This place has pretty much got it all: great art, great location, great atmospher, great cafe...the list goes on...
author: Natalie T.
