description: I can see this from my house, so it is a constant joy.  A stunning and interesting museum, I must say that it is one of the most engaging and interesting I have ever been through.  From ancient to modern... they organize this in a way that all the art blends together in a way that keeps you stimulated, attentive, and excited.  Instead of letting a wash of art come over you, they position it so that it is a dichotomy enough that you are forced to reawaken with each different exhibit you stumble across...  Lovely, and a nice aesthetic approach to the design and form, function and pragmatic layout of this museum.. making it one of my favourites!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: I remember way back when the De Young was a boring museum filled with Chinese vases and not a lot else. I would literally sneak out during school field trips. But now....the amazing copper building, the mix of modern, classic and local artists, the sweeping panoramic view of the city...what is not to love?! If only I had the $$ I would plan a birthday party here.
author: Sara W.

description: The King Tut exhibit was fine until we found out the Death Mask was not there.  Bogus.  Of course they bury this info in the FAQs and still use the Death Mask in some of their promotional posters commemorating 30 years.  If that's what you're going for, sorry, the thing stays in Egypt. What a giant disappointment.
author: Richard D.

description: I really liked the de Young museum, but fell short of truly loving it. The new building is fab and all (the interior and exterior views are truly breathtaking), but the collection seems a bit minimalist. I thought that the chair art in the center was a nice touch; it is interesting to attempt to unify such a disparate collection.
author: Dana L.

description: Reminds me of the Getty in Los Angeles: the building itself is far more impressive than the art collection. Perhaps I am biased; modern art appeals to me far more than the majority of antiquities that fill this new museum. Still, the facilities are top-notch. Having something like the de Young open in San Franciso definitely instills a sense of civic pride (or maybe just snobbery); it's good to live in a city that (still) supports art.
author: Aaron L.

description: I love how eclectic this museum is.  It's got an array of sections that take more than just one (or two) visits to see.  There's a cool section of dresses that track changes in Western fashion.  There is also a coffin in the shape of a cocoa bean from Ghana.  I also really enjoyed the New Guinea wing.
author: Mahogany G.

description: Ok, so I didn't really enjoy the de Young that much. They took a long time renovating this place and there wasn't all that much going on. The art is only okay. What I was most disappointed with was the top observation floor. I wish they put something else up there. The view is not the best and you only get a good view of USF and more construction. Boring!
author: Andrew Y.

description: There is something very glamorous and soothing about this incredible space. In a word- breathtaking. See the elevator to the observation deck on 8 first. The art is a good mix of textiles, photography, paint and furniture. The grounds are also very beautiful. The baby pin adds whimsy. This is definitely worth bringing out of town guests to see over and over again. $70 for a membership is well worth it.
author: Sherie R.

description:
Been a member since the old days when they were still stuck with the Asian Art Museum in Golden Gate Park.
Generally, I like the new space.  It's much more open and airy.  I enjoyed the observation deck the one time I was up there.  I miss the big enclosed courtyard at the old museum and the layout.  With the new space, I kept wandering around and somehow misses a lot of the exhibit rooms.
I enjoy their Friday night events all summer long.  I like the food at the new cafeteria (they even serve wine!).  
The Oceanic exhibit rooms upstairs is amazing.  This is not an area of art that I know much about, but the overall space and lighting's great.  I have to admit that I'd always find that particular portion of the museum to be a little unsettling to me.  Probably from fear of finding a shrunken head in a display case somewhere.  So far, I am happy to report, I haven't seen one yet.
The costume exhibit area (permanent fixture) is also quite stunning.  I can't help being glad that our modern clothing is so much more simple.
author: Winnie C.

description: I absolutely adore this building. The architecture is fascinating and the collection almost makes me not miss the Met so much.
author: Valerie G.

description:
2/19/08: great museum. once members when we lived in sf - we did the free tour today for old memories sake. we trekked up to the tower (admission ticket not needed to enjoy the serenity of the fog rolling in). great views of the science museum during its re-construction. we walked around the ground level and the museum shop. dont miss the james turell installation in the sculpture museum (also a freebie) and great on a rainy dreary day - we got to enjoy it by ourselves without any other visitors!

building has held well since opening night and the underground garage looks great (my wife was the project architect)...
author: Jesse W.

description: I live near the DeYoung and have always enjoyed loving to hate it.  Once, I read a letter to the editor that summed up my views pretty well: "The DeYoung is ugly and boring".  To the museum's credit, they're trying to remedy this.  They're open late on Friday nights, when they try to do "cool" things-- last week, they were demonstrating traditional Maori tattoos.  I also think the DeYoung is very pretty at night.  But the permanent collection is...random.  And I haven't been excited by one of their visiting exhibits in a long time.  I feel mean giving it two stars, since I generally love museums and will cut them slack.  But I have, indeed, experienced better (like Moma and the Legion of Honor).  The DeYoung is obviously seeking its niche and identity, but until it's able to articulate what that is, I will probably continue to be vaguely confused by it.
author: Lego S.

description: I returned another Friday night and the energy was gone. As were all of the cool things we had come across that one awesome night. I did go into the museum this time though. They still get to keep 4 stars because of the wonderful exhibits. :)
author: Candy C.

description: I definitely enjoyed going to De Young especially seing the Quilts of Gee's Bend exhibit, which were quilts made by four generations of African American women in the South.  I definitely recommend seeing if it comes around again.  Also, they have Ruth Asawa exhibition that it is worth checking out.  De Young's architecture is interesting and the observation deck is a must see for visitors for the gorgeous views of  the City.
author: Belle M.

description: Fishbits is right, the De Young is a constant joy and a consistent inspiration. On a beautiful day the view from the tower is just stunning.   The exhibits are always interesting and the space is energizing. I love to go and get my creative juices flowing. Side note; they also have great children's education toys in the museum store.
author: Val G.

description: Let me just start out by saying that I am still kicking myself for missing the Westwood feature last summer. I was short on time the day I visited, but the African/Oceanic art section (why I was there) is impressive, I still feel as though I missed out on more of it! I am definitely going back, and with lots of time to hopefully view the featured collection :)
author: Danielle D.

description: Come on people, it's an amazing museum.  The building is completely cool and modern, everything done with immense amounts of thought and care.  The main lobby space is huge and spacious, and Gerhard Richter's Strontium piece takes up a giant wall.  Go this week for Bouquets to Art and see all the incredibly cool florists' pieces that are juxtaposed with all the art.
author: Leo C.

description: This building just doesn't contain beautiful works of art, but is itself a work of art. Does that make sense? Hahahahah... I'm not the most articulate person in the world, but I do recognize great art, and the De Young Museum is a great work of art. Each time I'm there I'm always able to enjoy the beauty from inside out. When you get to what I think is the observation deck, you're treated to a breathtaking view of the city and you can't help but be thankful that you live in one of the most beautiful places in the world. A definite must see for tourists and locals alike.
author: Rommel N.

description: You could easily get lost, absorbed, here. The museum itself is a work of art...note the perforated, computer-designed metal skin. Don't miss the tower-- great views of the city.
author: Inigo M.

description: Always a great rotation of exhibits and the friendliest security guards.  Every time I go to here I find something new that catches my eye, or if I happen to miss it I have had the security guards point out some things to me as well.  I had an experience recently where I was in a room looking at certain things and the security guard pointed out something in the room I had missed.  I appreciated him pointing that out to me.  I get disappointed when I miss something and someone in my group talks about it after we leave.  The parking to get here is just like anywhere in Golden Gate park.  You will have to walk a bit, but if you don't like walking you probably shouldn't be in San Francisco.  The tickets can be a bit pricey, but that is what you can expect for a museum, it's a bit necessary for them to charge a fair amount.  Also, if the price is too much for you, there are always free days that you can check out.
author: Jennifer H.

description: We had a great time on Sunday doing the tour through Golden Gate park. It was fun, easy and informative. Our guide Devin was great
author: laura l.

description: I want to love the De Young, but, the collections and exhibitions -- snooze fest...
author: Camille W.

description: Go at night; it's waaaay cool.  I love the way this museum looks and feels.
author: Jenn S.

description: Eh it was ok.  The best part of the museum is definitely the architecture.  The collection is pretty hit or miss, for me.  Some of the stuff was very cool, but I found a lot of it boring.  The giant stone head was pretty neat (I want to say Mayan, but I am probably wrong).
author: Dave M.

description: Awesome space.  It is like walking around a computer simulation...it seems unreal.
author: Jerry C.

description: A great place to visit. I went there to see the Nan Kemper -American Chic exhibit.  It was a wonderful opportunity to see couture fashion.  The exhibit itself was small, but you can use the rest of the time to see their permanent collection.  Definitely take the time to visit the observation tower for a great view of San Francisco (although, I think the UCSF medical building has a better view) .  I gave it  4 stars out of 5 because of the annoying girl that works there who kept asking to see our museum entrance sticker over and over.
author: Katherine W.

description: Surprisingly, I enjoyed myself strolling through the art collection, surrounded by buff studs in their latest Ted Baker shirts, following their wives through the gift shop, on their way to the stage to listen to some band whose name I didn't catch. The VIP room was swanky, with lots of posers sitting on white faux leather couches waiting to see if they knew someone in the crowd. Heaven forbid your member sticker should fall off your garment as you were walking around, as the diligent volunteers on the prowl would snap that you must put one on. My cherry coke came in a Design-Out-Of-My Reach style glass, and was served by a witty bartender whose feet were hurting and was about to hurl insults at all the rude patrons. So, let it be said this is a fun, loud event, that quite nicely fills an artistic need on a Friday night.
author: David G.

description: I almost gave the De Young five stars because I love the architecture and the material the building is constructed out of.  It is a different color in different lights, giving it many faces and feelings.  Also, the tower has a 360 view of the city and on a clear day is just exquisite.  However, I did have to take one star off because I have never really been that impressed with the actual exhibits.  The last time I went, I spent most of my time in the tower and only wandered through the exhibits for a short time.  Oh, and they kept yelling at me about having a backpack...is that normal for museums?  It was pretty annoying that at first they said it could only be on one shoulder and then i had to carry it below my waist...what??  Anyway, even if you just admire the De Young from the outside, it is worth the trip over there.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Wanting to not waste a perfectly beautiful day outside, I only participated in the view from the top floor and the cafe. that was enough to seal the deal. Herzog and de Meuron (the architects) have shown me that i really should have used my architecture degree and not gone over to the more lucrative forms of design. well maybe for just an afternoon. they've done a fantastic job. and Ruth Asawa, damn girl!! you captured my love of shadow and reflection perfectly. the cafe is splendid, the light fixtures like perfect globes of hard candy or dollops of finger nail polish. we enjoyed watching some kind of big sea bird eat the leftovers off of abandoned plates and laughing at the little boy who explored every nook and cranny of one of the sculptures (that looked oddly like both male and female sexual parts) in the courtyard before being reprimanded by a museum employee. the weeble wobble people or sack people or whatever they're called were adorable, too bad you couldn't push them over.
the view from the tower was exceptional. the roof of the California Sciences Academy across the way hints at yet another masterpiece by our Italian friend, Renzo Piano. can't wait to see that from the inside. although i almost got myself into big trouble with the mother of a young girl who heard me exclaim, "oh look, it's the naked boys!" i was showing my friend the photos i'd taken earlier of the naked protest that we stumbled across earlier. it was just a quintessential SF moment and i couldn't contain myself! and i'm not used to being around children, so i have not learned to temper what i say for the shorter crowd. the girl was very very interested and i did a good job of thoroughly embarassing my friend. we got out of there in a jiffy. (which reminds me, does anyone on this coast know what a jiffy store is? if you do, send me a note!)
author: Brooke W.

description:
I just got back from the Chihuly exihibit with some friends and coworkers, and it was utterly amazing.  The detail, craftsmanship and creativity all just blew my mind.  As what many others have said, as you go from room to room, there seems to be no end to the level of artistry.  There were so many indescribably beautiful and wonderful pieces, some of which seemed so vibrant that they could've been alive.  
Of course, it was easy for the work to be phenomenal, but the museum itself also well run.  The staff weren't too uptight, as in other museums that I've been to, especially in the Chihuly exhibit which most everyone and their mothers seemed to check out today.  Certain places were a bit crowded and traffic jams weren't uncommon, but with an exhibit as brilliant as this one, I suppose it couldn't be helped.  The rest of the museum was straight forward.  There weren't quite as many pieces as I would've thought, but there were quite a few that I enjoyed.  I'd definitely recommend checking out the Chihuly exhibit while it's still in town, but if possible, I'd recommend avoiding the the weekends.  It would've probably been a much more relaxed and comfortable atmosphere on a weekday, but either way, definitely go!
author: Gary L.

description: The de Young, architecturally is a postmodern masterpiece, is pefectly functional, and houses a choice collection.  I have been enjoying the great line up of visiting exhibitions (Ruth Asawa,Chihuly, Yves Saint-Laurent, Andy Warhol, the Quilts, etc.)  Go on a sunny day to best enjoy the view from the Education Tower.  Can't wait for Tut!
author: Castro G.

description: Went the other day to the Birth of Impressionism, and it was great. The paintings where from the Muse D'orsay in France. Simply AMAZING. As for the rest of the museum- Parking was difficult. We decided we would save a little cash and not use the garage, so we just parked on the street. We had to walk a good quarter of a mile, as the museum and tea gardens where fairly busy, but it was not a huge issue. Admission was a little expensive for my taste, but they offered student discounts (with an ID). We had to wait half an hour to get into the next time slot, so we visited the cafe. Over priced, but it's in a museum, what do you expect? We skipped the menu and went with one of their grab and go sandwiches (We had the caprese on the baguette), which was $8, and a $4 dollar cookie, which, to our surprise, had popcorn in it... hmmm... Although the guy at the front checked our bags, we got our bottled water in... Then we got to wait in lines... about an hour all together. Would not recommend for small children, probably ok for 8 and up. Got the head set for the virtual tour- good deal for $6. Don't miss out on the amazing view upstairs!
author: Sydney E.

description: king tut exhibit was missing something... king tut. It was a normal Egypt display but when you got to the end you noticed it was missing the actual mummy. Sure the actual mommy might have been hard to transport but he had like 5 outer coffins they could have brought over at least one of the many outer coffins. The coffin is in Ireland_ this would have been good information to have before laying down 30 dollars for the exhibit.
author: Julie C.

description: KING TUT EXHIBIT:  The curse is alive and well....Just boycot this thing entirely.  No cameras or videos allowed.  A bunch of small artifacts and an overall small exhibit.  You will NOT see the large gold sarcophagus that they show in ALL the posters and advertisements.  No mummified remains of anybody.  When the ads say "King Tut returns to SF" that's a straight up lie.  About the most impressive thing there was a solid gold dagger and sheath and a gold "crown" apparently worn by the boy king.  A big waste of money.  Way too expensive.  Nice how you exit the exhibit directly into a gift shop full of TUT stuff (hang onto your wallet if you go with your kids!).  Speaking of kids, don't bring them.  They will not enjoy any of the statues, and what stuff you can explain to them based on what is written on the walls, will go way over thier heads.  It would have been more interesting if the exhibit was on HOW these things were made and WHY and included a mummy and an exhibit on mummification, or more about how the items were discovered.... (if your kid is an Indiana Jones fan, you will know where I am coming from).  We went midweek at 10am and it was PACKED.  They try to space people out in blocks, but it doesn't work.  TOO MANY PEOPLE.  The exhibit rooms are small, you bump into people, it's dark...you feel like you are an ass if you try and stop to read something or take a closer look at an exhibit.  Then you have to deal with the "Audio tour" people who have to stand around for 5 minutes in front of an item listening to thier little audio tour gadget.  DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY.  We probably spent about 45 minutes in the exhibit and just wanted to get out.  Worth $27 a pop?  Sadly, we would have gotten more out of a HD DVD of the same items.  They could have done more with what items they had if they would have been more creative and added a more well rounded historical type exhibit with other items of the same period?
author: Mr. B.

description: It was enjoyable going to this museum, some museums seem like a burden to study every little thing on display but I didn't feel this way at De Young.  Broswsing the museum was not a burden, it was interesting and didn't really take a long time either.  The museum looks so big on the outside but you can see everything in less than an hour.  I appreciate the design of the building, they really thought through a great construction when they made this place.
author: nathan n.

description: This was a beautiful museum.  I would have liked more information displayed regarding each exhibit, but the art is wonderful.
author: Joanna S.

description: I went here a while ago when they had the flower exhibit featured.  I thought the gumball machine created out of carnations was super cute!!  Anyone else remember that??  Truth be told, nothing else really stood out to me, except for the blown glass art display, that was nice.  I didn't have the opportunity to go through the entire museum, but I might go back to visit one day.
author: Rox M.

description:
Never remember coming here, but the architecture of De Young Part Deus is incredible to look at. 

You can be cheap and have a great time here, pick up some lunch, stroll around the surrounding gardens, take in the art and steal a table at the Museum Cafe. Which for some reason was crazier than the actual museum!?!?! Best of all you can wait in a short line to go up to the tower. Which gives you a fairly expansive view of the city, from the bridge to downtown. Found myself face up to the window gazing at buildings and landmarks for some times.

Or if you feel like springing for museum tickets, take muni which you might already and you get a nice discount. Recommend the Oceania exhibit which has incredible pieces from the face masks to the spirit boards, which I thought were ancient surf boards, just had to read a bit closer. When we went there was a few special exhibits, which usually draw in the crowds. Will go back next time there is something big!
author: David B.

description: What a fantastic way to spend a few hours. Take a friend with you and play!!! I loved the teapot collection, just mind boggling. You can never say there is nothing to do in this area and with the De Young you always have an option. I'm going back asap.
author: M. M.

description: What a great idea this is.  Some of us with 8-5 jobs have problems getting there during regular hours, so staying open Friday nights til 8:45 is convenient.  And what a great party.  I went there Friday 3/21.  Admission was free that night for myself and my companion as there was a special college student/staff exhibit in the lobby.  The music that night was a bit too loud, but it was in the spirit of the strange Gilbert and George installations in the basement.  There were models wearing odd garments in one of the rooms and people were making drawings/portraits of them.  This is the kind of stuff that makes museums and art interactive for the community.  Plus we spent most of the time looking at the permanent collection.
author: Richard W.

description: Maybe it's just me, but this museum is just too mixed up.  I really like the architecture and the fact that the copper building will eventually change colors.  One time I was doing this huge cross-town scavenger hunt and one of the answers was about a statute in the garden on this museum-- so that's a really good memory, but the actual curation, I can't really understand.  I did like the Vivienne Westwood exhibit and I would go back for any other special exhibits or with out of towners or on the free Tuesday every month... I just wouldn't pay again, I guess.
author: Jessica T.

description: Membership at the De Young is practically worthless now. The museum is dedicated almost all its exhibition space to the King Tut show, which runs through March 2010.  Thus, if you purchase a membership now, you will essentially get to see only the special exhibition King Tut during your year of membership.  At the same time, the Museum is also charging Members $22 per person to see the King Tut exhibit, thus making it expensive for members to see the show more than once.  I am not sure why anyone would sign up for this deal.
author: Tom W.

description:
Only three stars because I brought my 4 1/2 year old and 2 year old and I'm reviewing as a family.  We have a membership in order to feel better about short visits with the kiddos.  The building itself is lovely to look at and other Yelpers have written about the basis of the design (trees, light, transformation).  I LOVED the Maya Lin, and felt that this was very accessible to my 4 yo.  There are many groovy pew-like benches placed around the museum, which allowed us to sit and play I Spy with various artworks, as well as look out onto the sculpture garden.

Oh, yeah - the Sculpture Garden.  A giant Claus Oldenberg  safety pin, complete with a perfect little spot for the under 7 set to squeeze through and into.  A dozen foot-tall apples. perfect for little bums to sit on.  A mound of climbable grass around the dome.  Trees every where, all with very low branches - so very climbable.  I could go on.  The thing is, everything is a "do not touch, do not climb" situation.  Whoever designed that sculpture garden just wasn't thinking - this outdoor area is where families *need* to bring their kids to release some energy and escape from the constant chant of "this is a looking place, not a touching place!" - and not only have they made all the art off-limits, but they are TEASING the children with art that is screaming to be handled and loved, trees that are practically BEGGING to be climbed, hills that are meant to be conquered by little feet.  

My husband and I felt bad for the security guards - out there every 5 minutes berating children for doing what comes naturally to them.  I am a big believer that, if you want to teach kids to have an appreciation for art, they need to experience it on terms that open their minds, not close it.  That outdoor area is practically a big F-U to families with little kids - a big tease that makes me think they'd rather we stayed away until they were teenagers... who no longer care about art because all their early experiences with it were negative.

Great building, OK collection, wonderful traveling exhibits, and a LAME outdoor space.
author: Catherine K.

description:
I went to the de Young expecting to really like the architecture, and maybe like its exhibits and permanent collections. Actually, it turned out to be the opposite. I'd seen some gorgeous photos of the building in San Francisco magazine, but I think the weather made all the difference. The photos were taken on a perfectly clear day, but last weekend was cold, overcast and windy. That meant the building was just a dull copper color, whereas in the pictures it seemed to glimmer and reflect the sun and surroundings. 

Nevertheless, it is still an impressive place. I liked the shards of rock and bamboo gardens; you saw them as you made your way around indoors, and it made you feel like you were outdoors at the same time.

And I liked the permanent collections more than I thought. They have some particularly good pieces by Wayne Thiebaud, his vertiginous paintings of San Francisco hills. There's also a piece of the Central Valley, its fields rendered in Technicolor. The permanent collections are more extensive than I thought, too.

The exhibit we saw, the Arts and Crafts movement, was curated well, made up of little areas devoted to the movement in various countries. It was packed. 

My friend Angie suggested becoming a member because it nearly pays for itself in two visits, particularly the student membership. It includes unlimited free admission for two people to the de Young and the Legion of Honor, where I'm headed next weekend to see the Monet in Normandy exhibit with my mom.
author: Deb K.

description: What a great addition to GG Park! The architecture alone is amazing. I love the small alcoves and windows looking out of the museum into various angles, gardens, sculptures. The Polynesian art was the highlight for me, but there is such a wide variety of work, you are bound to stumble upon something that inspires you. The outdoor sculpture garden is beautiful and a great place to relax among the grass, trees and giant ceramic apples.
author: A Y.

description:
The De Young Museum is something new and exciting in an area of Golden Gate Park that was seldom used and even more seldom visited by folks touring our city.  It has now become a world-class museum and houses some of the most rewarding and worth while exhibitions I've seen (though some have been average at best).  Not to mention the fact that it has re-invigorated this section of the park, and pushed out some of the all to common riff raff that one would have to step over in order to retrieve a stray golf disc.  And it was done mostly with private funds raised by local philanthropists.  

The design of the building, both exterior and interior, is a reflection of our city in a minimalist and elegant expression.  It encompasses many influences from the design world that resonate with the history of our area --- most prominently the craftsman movement that had its early roots in this part of the country, and incidentally was one of the first exhibits at the museum.  From the outside I agree that it isn't the most inviting building, but to have an exterior that changes over time --- a living and ever evolving skin, much like that of our city --- is an ingenious representation of what this area is to me --- a reflection of my growth and change as I've lived here and experienced life.  I look forward to watching the green patina develop and blend into the natural surroundings of the park, as I sit in the sculpture garden with a great book or a picnic lunch and gaze at the whimsical lawn art on the grounds.  One of my favorite aspects of the design is the observation tower.  This space lends so much perspective to the area, to the museum, and to me when I stand in it looking out and contemplating my time spent in and memories of San Francisco.  I love this museum.
author: Pedro, aka Burgundy M.

description: The museum itself is great. They have a wonderful permanent collection. The only thing I found wrong about the museum is the Indian girl in the admission desk by the Hiroshi Sigimoto exhibition.  She refuse to give me a student discount because my sticker was expire Spring 2007. Doesn't she know some people do not go to Summer school. This is the first time it has happened to me,  the Lady's at the main entrance admission are much more knowledgeable. If the museum wants people to keep visiting, they need to get rid off people like that Indian lady.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
I concur with the general assessment that the Chihuly exhibit is not to be missed if you're at all interested in glass as an art form.

As for the permanent collection, they have Rookwood and Newcomb pottery, 2-3 John Singer Sargent paintings, some nice furniture, and some excellent California landscape paintings.  The observation tower is, well, an observation tower.  It falls a bit short of the views from elsewhere in San Francisco.  One part of the museum that folks might miss is the garden outside (away from the cafe end of the building).  Its a nice place to wander and rest to round out a day at the DeYoung.
author: Richard A.

description: Must see the Chihuly. Great for kids. Amazing vivid colors. Breath taking. Wonerful.
author: Meredith S.

description:
The Warhol Exhibit is out of this world.  It is totally fantastic.  Go see it!!!

Also the restaurant has a new chef.  The food is quite remarkable!
author: Stephen P.

description:
This review is more directed at the de Young staff than potential visitors, as the Post-Impressionist display from Musee d'Orsay wraps up its visit this week. 
To sum it up, the exhibit felt cramped and unbecoming to such valuable works. Being my first visit to a San Francisco art museum, I was very surprised at how this collection was shoved into modest, dark rooms, and then hoardes of people were pushed through it like so much bologna thru the grinder! Lucky for me, my height enabled me to jockey for a view most of the time. 
The Van Goghs were clearly the top draw -- and unless you played the rude card, or wanted to creep along one body width every 5 minutes, you weren't going to get a front row glimpse. I know, because I abided the line for 10 minutes and hardly moved! So I did the over-the-shoulders look from behind 4 or 5 people. It was OK, but only because I've been to the real museum in Paris, which is much more spacious and appropriate for such great works. 
The gift shop was a little lame too. Surely someone with a little creativity could stock it with more interesting and memorable items than a few books, reprints, espresso cups and a goofy tie?
C'mon de Young, get some elbow room in there. I echo someone else's review that it must've been pretty frustrating for the wheelchair-bound, trying to move around in that mob. I saw very little accommodation being made by visitors, either. Weird.
Sorry, go to Paris and see this stuff in its rightful home. San Francisco continues to disappoint as a cultural center, more interested in you paying for their residents' health care, scolding you for your caloric intake, and of course, no parking but by the hour at usurious rates!
author: Joe I.

description:
Agree with Jamie the architecture & design is awesome esp with the windows bringing the gardens inside etc BUT the collections & layout leave a lot to desired. Nothing seemed to flow from one wing to the other.
However the Chicano exhibit is a MUST!

The cafe is a great spot to enjoy lunch!
author: dawn w.

description: This rating is for the collections only, I was impressed by the variety and selection of artwork. I was also very happy to see 2 Thomas Cole works available. This Hispanic artwork downstairs is also catching. I do agree with some of the layout and routing problems mentioned below.. And some of the exhibits seem really dumbed down. Yet the view from Eisengard tower did offer something you don't see in SF every day.. worth a trip overall if not crowded..
author: Frank B.

description: We have enjoyed the recent special exhibits, but would not go back on a regular basis as the exhibits do not change that often and once you have seen the museum you have seen pretty much all of it.
author: Martha M.

description: If you have not seen the Chihuly exhibit, hurry and go quickly!  It closes at the end of September!  You don't have to be a blown glass guru to appreciate the amazing color pallet and beautiful work of this show.  It's an e-ticket for sure.
author: Angela T.

description: Recently went there for the Van Gogh, Gauguin...exhibit - I come here often to make full use of my membership. I love the park setting, the exhibits, but the staff and security could be a little more polite. The security at the entrance greets you gruffly with an "Open your bag so I can check it"! without so much as a please. And why that tone of voice? People who visit here are paying patrons. We don't need that. And the staff at the counter and the museum shops could use some customer service training. It's OK to be nice and polite to your customers, if you haven't heard.
author: Adam B.

description: I love the De Young so much.  I HATED the building as it was being built but one day I realised it was supposed to oxidise and I fell in love with it.  It's gorgeous.  What was wrong with me?  They have magificent special exhibits, they have magnificent regular exhibits.  They have that Andy Goldsworthy at the entrance.  The Chihuly made me almost cry with joy.  The membership fees are amazingly reasonable.  Thanks De Young, I love you, see you on Sunday.  xx
author: Dee K.

description:
The De Young has a nice collection of art - it takes hours to try and see everything.  However, the experience does have some negatives.  The collection seems to lack focus.  One minute you are looking at French impressionists and suddenly you are looking at tribal masks of Africa.  Because the collection jumps around in terms of location and time, you end up having to read nearly every plaque to get the context of what you are looking at.

The new building is a mixed bag in terms of architecture.  The main building is a big brown irregular polygon with a strange finish.  The irregular shape creates some non-functional "dead areas" cut out from the middle of the building.  The strength of the new building is clearly its asymmetrical tower element  that in addition to making a strong architectural statement has a nifty observation deck to look down on the rest of San Francisco. 

The De Young is a nice art museum but there are better museums to see in SF.
author: Brandon S.

description: Awesome huge museum.  A wealth of a collection of art and history from all ages. I definitely need to go back to culture myself again.
author: Syonora A.

description:
Saw Tut 30 (yikes) years ago and thoroughly enjoyed it. Tons of remarkable jewelry and Tut. Was somewhat disappointed when I realized we were at the end of the tour and very little jewelry and no Tut. It was a real let down.  I had gone to the De Young website prior to my visit to give myself a bit of an education . There were lots of things included on the site I had looked forward to seeing. Unfortunately, they weren't included in the actual exhibit. Even the banners around town had a picture of Tut, but he was a no show.
 I think if they were honest they should have called the exhibit "Tuts Tomb". I still enjoyed myself. It was a beautiful exhibit, just not what I was expecting. Parking is pricey but super easy and the lines into the museum on a Sunday were extremely light. The cafe was a great place to relax after the tour. My major complaint  was the gift shops were stuffed with poorly chosen, uninspired, expensive Tut souvenirs. Do we REALLY need a Tutty-bear ? Tacky. You expect more from The De Young. Bottom line, GO. It's amazing. I wouldn't recommend taking small children, tho. Very boring for them and not fair to others trying to see the exhibit.
author: Janice G.

description:
Just visited it for my second time, the California Landscape show is an excellent show that I was glad to see getting some wall space.  Other than the Oakland Museum, I don't think many major institutions have given 18th, 19th, and early 20th century California art the credit it's due.  For a state as crucial as California with so many varied and stunning landscapes, this stuff should be highly coveted, but I guess critics around those time periods had different ideals, huh.  
I liked the permanent collection as well.  Many works by the mega artists who are near and dear to the bay area, Wayne Thiebaud and Richard Diebenkorn, as well some nice examples by 20th century staples.  I loved the Edward Hopper painting (forgot the title), it really made an impression.  Never cared for Ed Rushca, they have some of his prints up along with Jasper Johns' in a room that seems a little out of place. 
I had trouble following the exhibit on artifacts from the americas.  I'm not sure what the curator was thinking, maybe I was walking the wrong way, but it didn't appear chronological.  Upstairs from that features some older works, including a major painting by Frederic Church and a view of the sculpture garden beyond it.  I spend some good quality time with that painting.
Fun to go to the observation tower, especially with some friends.  If you want a fun joke to play, go up to your friend while s/he is standing at the window and grab them and pretend you are pushing them off the side.  I did this to my friend and he freaked out and I got some good laughs from onlookers.  Then, later, he did it to me and I freaked out EVEN though I was somewhat expecting it. 
The sculpture garden is nice, especially on a sunny day - the claes oldenberg safety pin was my favorite out there.
author: Tim A.

description: The architecture is one of the best reasons to come to the De Young. I like to bring friends from out of town here because of the lovely setting. The collection is a little hit and miss. If you're used to museums like the Met in NYC, then the DeYoung seems a little chaotic and sometimes it's hard to understand what makes their collection "art." The organization of the exhibits also seem a little random. However, they have had some absolutely amazing special exhibits, and I'm a huge fan of their fashion exhibits. I still dream of the Vivienne Westwood show!!! They also have a nice cafe, which is great when you want to make a day of Golden Gate Park. Also, the cafe chefs are willing to accommodate food allergies! Can't beat that in my book!
author: ayi l.

description: The King Tut exhibit at the De Young museum in San Francisco is a rip off. If you go to see it, expect to be there all day. I purchased tickets for 3pm and I will still waiting an hour to go in. My pregnant wife and I walked out of line and did not see the exhibit. Waste of money... the employees were not helpful at all.
author: Steven D.

description: After living in SF for the last 6 years I decided to finally come visit the De Young museum for the Birth of Expressionism exhibit. The museum was having issues with their credit card machines and the lines to enter were super long and slow. Mistakenly, we went on the day that the California Academy of Sciences was free and there was no parking to be seen. We drove around for over an hour looking for parking (even the garages were full) and I was so worried that my online ticket for the 11:30 show wasn't going to be accepted. Luckily, they took it because we were also purchasing another ticket. The exhibit itself was beautiful. Stunning. It left me speechless at times. The crows were not so entertaining and because it's been such a long time since my last museum visit, I didn't prepare myself for the head phone wearing, toe crunching (be sure to wear closed toe shoes!), completely oblivious crowds. It was packed and at times I felt claustrophobic and blazing hot. With a little more planning, I will return. Most likely in the Fall when schools are in session and the tourist season has tapered.
author: Heidi S.

description: This review is for the Tutankhamen and the Golden Age of the Pharaohs exhibit.***I was both thrilled and disappointed. I'd give the exhibit one less star, except that I've waited most of my life to see this. I'm not going to run down everything in the exhibit, the major attractions can all be seen online. I'm going to get my gripe out of the way up front. Akhenaten was Tutankhamen's father. The exhibit is festooned with a flood (comparatively) of chotchki from Tutankhamen's relatives, to Akhenaten's 3 major items. 3. That's it. Wanna know why? Akhenaten liked guys and at one point ruled with a co-regent king named Smenkhare who we'd also have to mention. The curator of the exhibit is very conservative and would prefer not to talk about such things, so Akhenaten, the bisexual, heretic, one of the most noteworthy and influential pharaohs in all of Ancient Egyptian History, is mostly overlooked. And it's not for lack of artifacts, there are a ton. There, I got it out of the way. The rest...there were some precious items. I'm still trying to figure out how to sneak Tutankhamen's jeweled burial dagger out of the museum. Just kidding. One thrill was seeing my first sarcophagus, belonging to one of the aforementioned relatives. The line going in felt like Disneyland and the audio tour was very basic. To fully appreciate this exhibit, I suggest you do some prior reading, unless of course you are an Egyptologist.  I'm taking my nephew back before the run is up. I wanted from the time I was 8 to see this exhibit and came away thrilled, but also with mixed feelings. Oh well, I can't have everything.
author: Jeremy C.

description: i liked this museum a lot. there were a couple of more known artists here, i saw a rothko and a de kooning, and yada yada. i enjoyed the african art exhibit the most, i think. perhaps this was the first time that i really paid attention to the pieces on a conceptual level as opposed to just making a beeline for the flashiest object and then move onward to the next exhibit. it's fascinating.
author: Joanne S.

description: i love the museum, but the staff is horrible.  very rude and arrogant.  i think most of them forget they work for the museum and don't actually own it.
author: Peter Y.

description: I bought two discounted tickets to the Tut Exhibit from Costco, which were still pretty pricey, but I was excited to see what it had in store.  It was my first time at the De Young museum, and I brought my girlfriend along.  The day did not start well as I spent 40 minutes searching for parking.  The lot off Tea Garden drive was closed, so I proceeded to circle the streets in search of a spot. No luck.  Little did I know that the 10th street parking lot entrance was open.  There were no signs to redirect you, so keep this in mind if you're visitng on a weekend.  The exhibit itself was pretty cool, from the dramatic door-opening entrance to the mysterious exhibit halls.  I highly recommend that you get the audio tour (free with Costco tickets) as the tour would have been extremely boring without it.  It does a good job of explaining certain exhibit pieces and it adds a level of interactivity and drama you just don't get from reading the placards.  The time we spent in the tour was pretty short, just under an hour.  We zipped by some of the pieces as I have a short attention span and hadn't eaten lunch yet.  I give it only 3 stars because of the high price-point and the fact that there isn't King Tut's sarcophagus, as misleading as the big billboards are.
author: Alex H.

description:
king tut is dead...and he disappeared too...
who knew that my ex wife would make such a lousy recommendation for a completely disappointing tour of tuts alleged exhibit in san francisco...after flying 2500 miles, across the continent, all we got were a bunch of artifacts, television images, and of course....a discount card for restaurants in the city....but tut is nowhere to be found...on the bright side, the ex is visiting in several weeks with her new beau, and i will recommend same to her.....why not share...for the rest of you...pass on the exhibit, save your pesos and go to egypt...
author: nizam h.

description: Went here mainly for the King Tut exhibit.  While the exhibit, itself, was well executed, the logistics were botched.  We had purchased pre-timed, reserved tickets through American Express and arrived well in advance of our reservation.  While we waited for our time to be posted, we observed the craziness.  Lines for the exhibit formed right in the middle of the main lobby, causing confusion and moderate chaos.  By the time our time had rolled around, the groups were nearly 45 minutes behind schedule.  There were clearly too many people reserved for each 30 minute block.
author: Alex N.

description:
amazing.
saw the Birth of Impressionism there and it was breath-taking. one thing: The cafe is REALLY nice. good food (premade sandwiches, soups, entrees, fresh fruit, cookies, breads, pastries) good drink (wine, izzy sodas, coffee, espresso, tea). a little pricey, but worth it. Its all local and organic.
author: King L.

description: a big chunk of me wants to give de young five stars. after all, i'm a member and want to appear cultured in a self-important city like san francisco. well, i still can't do it. according to my niece, the building looks like a "giant red walmart without the sign." ahhh, nothing like the naked truth from an eleven-year-old... the exhibit and the collections were certainly compelling but they left me wondering- why is it so difficult for san francisco, who often claims cultural superiority, to build a world class museum? just a reminder. i'm no art snob. just a casual museum goer.
author: frisco j.

description: The de young is an awesome museum and the cafe serves better than expected food but I was let down by the King Tut exhibit because it dis not include the famous death mask even though it is all over the advertisements. there are many worthy artifacts in the exhibit; however I had a buildup of expectation to see the death mask at the end in a spectacular arrangement.  Instead there is a blurry projection of the sarcophagus at the end. I later read that the Egyptians won't allow the death mask to leave Egypt anymore because it has become fragile.  Come on, can't someone make a duplicate with a placard explaining the Egyptian's concerns? That lame blurry projection at the end was a bummer.
author: L M.

description: i live near this museum now. so you will probably find me here. and when you do i will tell you that i am planning on writing a review about it when i have more time.
author: coffeecake j.

description: What a horrible museum. From the exterior it looks like something you'd find next to a dumpster. Inside, since the building is all form no function, the displays have to be laid out in a fashion that makes it very hard to navigate. You'll end up going in circles. No  matter what you think about the museum, however, do not make the mistake of becoming a member. I did and getting inside is always a bizarre process. Non-members can quickly navigate a short line but members either have to stand in a very slow-moving line or try to get a persnickety card reader to read your card. It's one of those machines that the wind has to be blowing in just the right direction or it won't read your card. You can entertain yourself watching people get frustrated trying to work it while you  wait in the awful 'members' line. Needless to say, they've gotten the last bit of money they'll ever see from me. San Francisco has so many good museums, there's no need to waste your time with this one.
author: Joe H.

description: I would love to review the place but they would not let me in because I was wearing bicycling shoes. The staff was resistant to any sort of reason, or display showing that the shoes do not scratch the floors,. I've been in the museum before wearing these same shoes, so I was a little irritated having ridden out there only to be turned around.
author: Mike R.

description: King Tut exhibit is good, but a bit disappointing.   The famous death mask is not included in this exhibition despite the fact that the museum's advertising seems to imply it's included. Most of the artifacts are not from Tut's tomb, but from the tombs of his ancestors.  Shame on the De Young for not being honest about this exhibition.  I think If they were honest about it, many people would stay away.   If you saw the exhibition in 1979, you can skip this one - especially at the price of admission.
author: Michael F.

description: Went to the king tut exhibit. The layout was easy and open so it didn't get crowded. Cool opening to the exhibit too. And not too intense for younger kids. Totally recommend going!
author: Lisa B.

description: Still unimpressed.  I visited the De Young again for the YSL exhibit.   Again, I wasn't overly impressed with the special exhibition nor their permanent collection.
author: Khloe M.

description:
TUT Exhibit was worthwhile to see but some major annoyances. The type size on the display descriptions is too small unless you are standing nearly on top of the display case. The lighting is many of the rooms is too dim and not properly directed on to the descriptions. If you are older, have poor vision, or if you are in a wheelchair (as several visitors were when I toured) this is a major disadvantage.  The other issue is packing way too many people into each "wave" of ticket-holders.  Having too many people in a room, plus too-small type, requires that you hang back until everyone else moves on and THEN walk up, nose-to-glass, and read the descriptions.
They also do not enforce the "no strollers" rule. Meaning that little kids who don't understand what's going on are either screaming because they want to get OUT of their stroller, or crying because they want to get out of the dark, scary rooms. Parents, TUT is not a kid-friendly exhibit!  Spoils the experience for everyone else.
author: Carol D.

description:
i can only remark on the King Tut exhitibit...i missed the tour in la a few years back
we got to the museum at 4:15 and just in the nick of time of our tickets.
we also purchased the audio tour, we i highly suggest, it gave extra tidbits that the placard did not give.
I went on thursday, oct. 15, 2009.  it was not at all crowded.  Oh, helpful hint, no backpacks, unless you carry it in your hand at all times.  and no cameras...which sucks, but i understand
it first starts with king tut's grand parents...the only mummy was his grandmother...most do not realize that king tut is not in the exhibit...he is only available in egypt.  i knew that, however my bf and our friends did not know that, they were a bit disappointed.  however, we were all very impressed with the whole exhibit.  
it was well spaced and it took us almost 2 hours to walk through and enjoy the detail of every item.  benches are placed along the walls and were greatly appreciated after the days activities of walking and standing.  Absolutely amazing.  
My only regret is that we did not get to see the rest of the museum, but will definitely come again.
author: Cristy B.

description: friday nights here are happening!!  i came on fri for the chihuly exhibit, and it was PACKED around 7 pm.  i love the live music, which makes the event extra festive!
author: Helen T.

description: What a weird place they've made here. From what I understand, the copperish design is supposed to mimic the appearance of the trees. Blahblahblah. I guess it's what inside that counts, and this place was disappointing. I used to come to the "old" pre-earthquake (damn earthquake..) museum back in the day. Back when they still had that funky pond deal outside and those cute little turtles chilling on the rocks with their cute little heads pointed up at the sky. The museum used to be classy and timeless in its way, pretty awesome really (for San Francisco. I hear New York museums are the best). Anyway, the new place just seemed disjointed. It looked expensive (and I'm sure it was..) and whatnot. For someone like me who doesn't know a lot about art, I don't know, it just didn't make much of an impression. I certainly miss back when the Asian Art Museum and the De Young were both in the same complex. Now it seems both have suffered an identity crisis. Have you been to the Asian recently? Wow, what a confusing and ugly place. Yikes. Hopefully with the Academy of Sciences coming back there will be more foot traffic in Golden Gate Park. I want people to come to Golden Gate Park and enjoy it. I hope the De Young can get its "stuff" together and be a little more coherent to me in my next visit. Maybe their target audience is too narrow or something.
author: Al B.

description: When we got to the Academy of Sciences in the morning I saw that the line for deYoung was as long, if not longer, than the line for the CAS!!  Luckily, I had pre-purchased tickets online through museumtix.com for the Chihuly exhibit for 3PM which gave us 6 hrs to spend at CAS if needed... which we spent 5 of... after walking over we had an hour to spare til it was our turn so we roamed around the museum... This was our first time here and the first time I've been to any kind of art museum with the hubs.  It was a nice experience to discuss the different pieces with him and find out the kind of art he liked.  The museum was easy to walk through and not get lost... We were able to get around and not feel like we had already been here.  The Chihuly exhibit was beautiful... it was breathtaking... the colors, the shapes... after going thru it once... we turned around and decided to do it again since there was no re-entry back into it.  It was the last day of the exhibit and it was quite crowded... people were everywhere.  I just wish I wasn't so tired but I will be back again! maybe to check out the YSL exhibit!
author: Kymberli C.

description: my famsf membership helps me sleep at night.
author: Jamie C.

description: The curator's hand is so evident inside.  Works of art are chosen with obvious care for the "personality" of each of the spaces within.  My first visit was a quick one, but I joined for a year, as it includes admissions to the legion of honor and all "special" exhibits as well.  Really beautiful--I enjoyed it much more than SFMOMA, the Tate, and NY MOMA.  Agree that the selection is eclectic, but enjoyed access to the textiles, a nice touch.
author: Mel B.

description: Even though I'm a museum junkie, I had never gone here until a couple weeks ago.  The parking is always SUPER crazy because of the new & improved Academy of Science (which I have yet to visit!) so be sure you get here early in the morning or take MUNI.  I wish I had come here sooner!  Loved it.  I was lucky & came @ the time they had the YSL & Warhol exhibits.  If you haven't gone to the Warhol exhibit- GO before it's gone!  It's huge & you will not be disappointed.
author: Blushed M.

description: exquisite architecture. this museum is a pure pleasure. it's not my personal favorite kind of art but i sill go and enjoy learning about new stuff. bonus: the de young and the palace of the legion of honor are now linked so if you plan the day accordingly, you can take the free shuttle between the museums and pay only one admission for two museums. pretty sweet!
author: lisa w.

description: love the de young museum. great location (in GG Park) and good exhibits
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Definitely come here on a Friday night.  And if you do go bring someone you can have a lot of fun talking with, who also has an appetite for some dancing and alcohol.  Friday nights are free to get in, but to actually go around the exhibits you need to pay for admission, and drinks aren't the cheapest.  This is definitely a pay for the atmosphere place.  I work on the side with the company that sets up the cash bar there so I got admission and free drinks all night for me and the lady friend I brought along.  There's nothing like walking through the exhibits a bit more then tipsy and really checking out art.  We both loved it but the alcoholic in me always brought me to the bar area again to refill.  Right next to the bar in Wilsey Court is where the live music was playing and that night it was all salsa.  Every week the theme changes but it's always a good time out with someone you can have fun with in any situation.  Go here, and tip big at the bar!  I could use the extra cash.
author: Alex H.

description: i was a little worried about the de young museum-- the legion of honor is kind of a snooze fest.  but the de young is nothing like its sister.  sure, the building and grounds are beautiful, but that is where the similarities end.  the art was interesting (the collection is a bit more contemporary, both the art itself and in its selection)- of course there were pieces that were less than intoxicating, but getting lost in galleries was a really wonderful way to spend an afternoon.  i'm looking forward to going back.
author: Samantha W.

description: NIce!  I'm so happy to have it back and better and bigger than ever before.  It is so beautiful just looking at the building versus the old one!  I'm just a short walk away so having the ability to be so close to a world class museum again is fantastic.
author: Misti L.

description: i'm just a scrub when it comes to art, but i can appreciate some culture from time to time.  i found the de young to be de-lightful, especially the view from the observation deck.  my only gripe, like seong p., is with the abrasive museum staff.  ease up folks..it's art!
author: Niki M.

description: I went to this one recently, (I think it just re-opened?) and it was pretty cool. I guess its a sister museum to the legion of honor which I've been to, but the exhibits seemed really different. You do get free sameday admission to the legion of honor if you go to the deyoung in case you wanted to do both. There were two floors and four wings and one side was this sculptural artwork by a local japanese artwork where she bent copper and galvanized steel wires into baskets and made them into intricate designs (like stars and trees). The other exhibits were african and native american artifacts, then there was california landscapes which we didn't spend too much time on. And the other exhibit were a bunch of random paintings some by diego rivera and picasso. My boyfriend and i had a good time there. Outside they had giant sculptures, like a giant safety pin, some 3 ft apples, and a hollowed out limestone rock or something. I liked the garden and the japanese artists' exhibit the best
author: Thao T.

description: The hanging sculpture constructed from the charred pieces of an African American Southern Baptist Church torched by arsonists as a testament to the power of faith and love in the face of hatred was enough to make me go back again and again. powerful - beautiful, simple- beauty found in tragedy and the poignancy that brings. Add to that the Bouquets to Art exhibit that my friends are ready to "call in sick" to see on the first day next year (and yes, it really was that good, even in its' final hours) and, as we discovered last weekend, the masterpiece that is the cafe's macaroni and cheese (OK- I would add the salad- but macaroni and cheese you will get a second order after you've split one already is worth a mention in any review) - well, you basically have a neat place with fun events and great architecture. Now if someone can explain the upside down apples in the sculpture garden to me (I like it- I just don't think I get it!) - I'll be ready to go.
author: Keri B.

description: The new de Young officially opens this weekend with a 31 hour continuous opening. The building, by the Swiss team of Herzog & de Meuron, authors of the Tate Modern, is surprisingly warm and humane for a contemporary museum built by superstar architects. Just when you thought glass, steel and poured concrete were the only materials deemed worthy for such buildings, along comes wood. Wooden floors and ceilings, the latter aiding with acoustics so that when the person next to you is chatting incessantly, their voice is softened enough you don't want to kill them -- a very nice touch. This is also likely the first museum designed so that collections can intermingle at the edges of their proper galleries, very unusual, in fact, particular attention has been paid to both the collection and the exterior landscape of the park. Frankly, after so many spectacular museum buildings that look ruined by the objects they are meant to hold, this feels like a revolution.  A puckered and perforated copper skin sheaths the building, giving it an odd, almost chameleon-like appearance, almost as though it were hiding within the park. A smart, thoughtful and somewhat plain sculpture garden by local landscape architect Walter Hood extends the experience to the out-of-doors. This enveloping of inside/outside occurs within the building itself, a welcome feature in what could otherwise have been an experience in artificial light (like SFMoMa). Go this weekend, Oct 15-16, in the middle of the night. They'll be open, and the collection is quite nice.
author: Iana S.

description: It's nice and we like going there. I am only giving it 3 because with such a great location and building they could have done so much better! Some interesting stuff but lots of junk. And what's with the big colorful paintings at the entrance? Is it a joke? Does not measure up to my kids drawings.
author: Olivier V.

description: I love the De Young, but I was so disappointed to find that King Tut is no where to be found in the King Tut exhibit.  Not the sarcophagus, not the head mask, not the gold inner coffins. The advertising with his blue/gold image is misleading. They should say "relics from the tomb" of King Tut and lead with a picture of an artifact that is actually in the exhibit.  What's more, when you ask the staff "where is King Tut" some said they didn't know and some said "Cairo Museum."   I've found some posts on the web that say "Valley of the Kings" where his tomb was.
author: CakeMaker S.

description: The YSL retrospective is what drew me here.  It had been a while since I'd visited the museum (Chilhuly exhibit) but each time I've been, I've been impressed.  For some reason I didn't realize there was also a Wharhol exhibit going on at the same time, so that was an added bonus. I'd seen numerous Wharol exhibits before, but this one stood out thanks to the album cover art instillations, music and the movie feeds that were playing.
author: L. B.

description: I finally got around to visiting the DeYoung over the Memorial Day weekend. I was impressed by the variety and scope of the collection. I've always thought the outside of the museum was unbelievably ugly, but when I learned more about how the museum was designed to very eco-friendly and sustaining, I appreciated it a lot more. The view from the tower is quite pretty even on an overcast day, but it's a bummer you can't climb up there. I'd give this four stars were it not for the insane amount of harassment from museum personnel regarding bags. We were told it was fine to bring a bag in, but from one room to the next, we were alternatively told to put both straps of backpack on, only put one strap on, carry bag by top handle and not have any part of it on, etc. It was obvious that someone had knocked something important over with a bag in the recent past, but it was took away from our enjoyment of the museum to constantly being hassled about our bags (and given different information by different people). Had their been a bag check, I would've been happy to leave it behind and avoid the endless museum policing.
author: Megan K.

description: We went today for the free bank of america admission. The people at the front desk were very rude when they learned we were getting in for free. There was some interesting stuff to look at. They don't have anything for kids to do, not even a scavenger hunt, they said they had art but it's only once a day at 10:30 am. My kids are 10 so they were okay just looking around. Of course, the highlight of the museum was going to the ninth floor for a breathtaking view of the city.
author: Tricia B.

description: 4 stars for the chihuly exhibit, truly amazing. The space that it is contained in, a little less than stellar. It was extremely hard to step back in certain spaces and see the pieces as a whole. But this is abou the DeYoung and its amazing grounds and exterior features. I really love the way this space looks, from the bi-directional dimples in the rusted fascade and the rolling landscaping that follows as you decend to the basement. thats where the freshness kind of stops for me. We never ventured into the other galleries and instead attempted to enjoy a trip to the tower. Being a Sunday the museum was extremely crowded and as we waiting in line for the elevator up we shouldve known it wouild be the same on the way down. we didnt, or we wouldve left the line all together but instead we boarded an elevator hoping to see some cool views of the city and the new science center next door. As we disembarked we got directly on the line that wrapped around the tower in order to get back down. they never opened the stairs and instead forced everyone to wait as we shuffled around the entire tower. Overall a really bad idea. that soured my trip here and the wonerful views we were able to see from the line.
author: Kennan S.

description: the architecture is quite unique and it has a very spacious interior.  if you get a chance to get to the top, you can get a gorgeous view of the park.  the collection is quite comprehensive, a bit overly extensive, but there are some highlights.
author: Amy Z.

description: stunning architecture, warm night with full moon, vivienne westwood opening party, aesthetes, dandies, and other well-dressed people with not a burning man themed automaton in site.  they were serving these sabayon fruit things in little espresso cups that were the perfect thing for some reason.    less 1 star for an over-zealous museum goon that tried to warn me about taking pictures until i said what are you talking about this is the party not the art section.   he realized what a dork he was and apologized profusely, but still.
author: X X.

description: Attended the Chihuly exhibit, which as everyone notes, was amazing--a stunning collection of mostly glass art. The creativity expressed here went beyond what I could have imagined with this medium, and the  use of the intense colors was equally compelling. The other exhibits at the DeYoung Museum were worth attending as well, particularly some of the ancient african rooms. The only drawback--a big one--was the poor crowd control and management at the museum. There were hundreds of people pouring in the day (Sat) we attended, and only a few receptionists. No one was directing the crowds, but we somehow learned about more ticket booths down stairs with shorter lines. We headed down, only to find there were only two receptionists, and as we got closer, one got up to leave--apparently it was her break, leaving 40 or so people in line. It took us over 45 min. to get in, and then we had to wait 1.5 hours for the 3:30 show. There were dozens of employees roaming around handing out flyers and watching the crowds, but no one helping usher them through. Admittedly, it was a big crowd (they advertised heavily). But if the museum is to aspire to really be a national class operation, it'll have to manage better than this.
author: mark i.

description: I don't know how I'm *just* getting around to reviewing it after the opening bash was a cataclysmic if not life changing experience (the textiles through history, the wall of tungsten(?), the mayan dancers ready to do a ritual to the sun, the lack of cell service within it's walls) - but let me just say this:  On those days when you're sitting around trying to figure out what you want to do and how to take advantage of this amazing city (i.e. "What do you want to do? I don't know.  What do you wanna do?  I don't know.") GO TO THE DE YOUNG.  You won't regret it.  Even if you don't like art, museums or other people, the De Young will STILL find something for you.
author: Anjali K.

description: the building itself is a piece of art and visually so pleasing on the eyes.  this museum gets amazing exhibits and is a treat here in san francisco.  i saw both the vivienne westwood and the nan kempner exhibits here.  they were each stunning and had a nice variety of pieces in their collections.  there was also a great speaker from new york who gave a very informative and interesting discussion before the kempner exhibit.  the observation tower is also another strong feature in this building, the view alone is inspiring.
author: Steven K.

description: i grew up in Washington DC, so the idea of paying to get into a museum is still strange to me. but honestly, ART is easily worth $10 compared to half the things i could waste my money on. the architecture of this place is exquisite. the way they designed it so every inch of the museum receives natural sunlight is a feat beyond me! the view from the tower is absolutely breathtaking!! and the best part is the copper material used in the entire outer structure will age into a deep green over time to blend with the surrounding park. brilliant!
author: Daniel N.

description: real primal soul searching art upstairs.  this is the crap MOMA is built off of.
author: traffic d.

description: It took me quite a while to decide whether I loved the building or hated it, and the former won out.  At least from the outside, where it looks strange and wonderful and unique.  The Andy Goldsworthy crack is kind of darkly humorous and a bit uncanny if you can't find the plaque with the caption.  The Turrell piece in the garden outside is much better than a description will make it seem.  The inside architecture is less impressive, but whatever.  The collections themselves are not the best I've seen (and I haven't seen all that many, to be honest) but they're decent.  Love the Thiebaud stuff and the SF figurative pieces, the "Saxe" room of contemporary ceramics and sculptures, and F.E. Church's Rainy Season in the Tropics (say what you will, the painting's a crowd-pleaser).  The non-western art was interesting but kind of unfocused and the much-discussed transitions between the Western and non-Western galleries were indeed jarring, but added a kind of (probably unintentional) playfulness similar in attitude to the Goldsworthy piece.  After 4:30 admission is free until it closes at 5, which is great if you happen to be in the park at that time.
author: Alex T.

description: The new De Young building outshines the art inside. I think the MOMA's collection would be better suited to the De Young.
author: Marina D.

description: The collections are okay, but the building is cool, the tower is cooler, and they have a James Turrell skyspace!
author: Amy C.

description:
keep in mind, this is more of a tut review...

since we had to wait four and a half hours to see "tut" we had time to cover the rest of the museum which was pretty cool.  tut, on the other hand, was a nightmare.  so we get there and buy tickets (at 1pm)  only to find out we can't get in to see tut until 5:00.  but what that really means is you have to get in line to at 5:00.  then when you finally make it downstairs, guess what?!  more lines.  then while fighting the crowds you see a bunch of artifacts (interesting, yes) only, you keep wondering, where is king tut?  there were items from his tomb, but i was expecting perhaps his sarcophagus or something of that nature.  in my opinion it was a whole lot of waiting and quite anti-climatic.  and not to mention, if you want to use the restroom during your tour of the exhibit you're screwed.  we were told, "no re-entry."  $63 to wait in line, not see king tut, and try to ignore the fact that you have to use the restroom because you don't want all that waiting around to be for nothing.  no thanks.
author: Sylvia G.

description: i went here on sunday afternoon by myself since i had some time to kill while my husband was writing a paper.  it was absolutely mobbed and i had to wait in line to pay my admission fee.  but once inside, it didn't feel too overly-crowded because it's so huge.  i was actually able to look at pieces without having to wait until someone else moved out of the way or having someone looking over my shoulder (i hate that).  but all in all, while i was very impressed by the architecture of the building itself, i wasn't all that enthralled with the art inside or out.  i have a BFA in photography so i did like the modest but nice photo exhibit, and i did like the textile exhibit with the dresses from 17th century france and christian dior, etc...   but beyond that, i didn't think there were too many other pieces to write home about.  the line to go up in the tower was too long and i didn't feel like paying extra (wtf?) to see the international arts & crafts exhibit, which also looked packed, so i breezed in and out of the whole place in under two and a half hours.  and i, too, was aghast at the type of people who came to this museum or who go to any art-oriented place in the first place?  i saw hoardes of families with little kids who were running around screaming and playing on the sculptures outside, there were strollers galore, and people who looked like they fell off the turnip truck from east bumblefuck, kansas.  i'm not a pretentious art-snob like some others, but i can't imagine people really appreciating art they way they should, especially if they have a toddler and a baby in tow and are still wearing faded denim jeans with keds and a disney sweatshirt.   go visit alcatraz or ride the cable car or something!
author: Cyn B.

description: if you need a place to get out of the rain and you've got $6 and a student id, its a great place to hang out until dinner (its open until 6:15 p.m. on Saturdays)
author: Mary A.
